Yours sincerely, Ian Lloyd Ex-chairman, Parliamentary Office of Science and Technology Dear Sir Ian, No one argues that the stereotypical man in the street should be deciding the contents of the next stereotypical test tube. But he does have a right to "a new democratic input". Expert-led decision-making made strategic failures on nuclear power and intensive agriculture in the 1950s. It is popular dissent that has been the brake on these failures rather than expert examination. This chimes with what social science is now telling us, and what expert-led process has always hated admitting: "ordinary" people are smart. When people reject GM food it is because they understand that science hasn't got everything under control; yet the assertions that GM food is safe come as thick and fast as they did about nuclear technology before Three Mile Island. As the House of Lords science and technology committee acknowledged this week, people's attitudes to new scientific developments are shaped by the values they hold. These values are likely to include improvement in social well-being, fairness, the need to protect nature, and so on. The scientific community needs to take note of those broader values. Science needs to inform societal decisions, but not to take them. This is not a new dilemma. It was Sir Winston Churchill, not a man known for being racked with postmodern angst, who said that science should be "on tap, not on top". Yours sincerely, Doug Parr Chief scientific adviser, Greenpeace UK Dear Dr Parr, I do not disagree with Churchill's comment, which makes my point that policy-makers must reconcile expert and public opinion. This is where the problem arises, for it is easy to appeal to prejudice rather than expert knowledge. When Britain was under threat of missile attack, Churchill did not consult focus groups or hold a referendum. He called in men such as Tizard, Lindeman, Blackett and a "young turk" of science, RV Jones. Churchill's own words still have relevance. "This was a secret war, whose battles were lost unknown to the public. [] The terms in which it could be recorded were unintelligible to ordinary folk." Today's scientific controversies are even less "intelligible to ordinary folk", as any issue of Nature will confirm. How many members of the public understand the terminology involved in gene transfer, such as the difference between eukaryotic and other DNA? The membrane of judgment in advanced societies to which decisions can be referred is very thin. I support its enlargement by policies that increase public understanding - the only defence we have against tabloid judgments proffered by those anxious to obstruct what they do not understand. I deplore those who attack indispensable developments such as nuclear power or GM crops on the basis that occasional misjudgments prejudice the authority of the scientific community. Again, in Churchill's words, "its strange, sinister resources" must be "effectively brought to bear on the struggle for survival". Yours sincerely, Ian Dear Sir Ian, In wartime, society was dedicated to winning the war and everyone was behind that, happy for scientists to beaver away in secret. Now we have been at peace for 50 years, things are different. Science and technology are among the most important forces shaping society. What is so unreasonable about people being given a say? We don't stop people voting because they can't grasp the intricacies of tax policy, but if you argue that people are too ignorant to understand, this is where you end up. It is the broad strategic judgments about future society into which people should have input. The notion that this can only be decided for us by those with expert knowledge is wrong. Scientific endeavour should be taking us where a plurality of society wants us to be, not where a few laboratory experts think we should be. The real range of options gets ignored because experts often see a large role for their specialism: ask a genetic engineer how to feed the world and he'll suggest genetic engineering. Nuclear power and GM crops are cases in point. I see an abundance of evidence that neither of these "indispensable" developments are at all necessary. Yours sincerely, Doug Dear Dr Parr, In the half-century since Churchill's era, Galbraith's "Revolution of rising expectations" depended on two fundamentals - the rule of law, and a massive increase in the world's R&D, which now absorbs billions and employs millions. We are not, therefore, talking about "a few laboratory experts". This transformation was not accompanied by a comparable increase in scientific literacy. Had that happened, the public perception of risks attaching to nuclear power and GM foods would not support your scepticism. On a visit I made to Washington and Three Mile Island, Dr Norman Rasmussen reported that alternative energies in the west would never exceed 10% of requirements. There has been no convincing refutation of that estimate. If foreseeable demand from China and the third world is to be met without massive dependence on fossil fuels, the nuclear component will have to be substantial. A comparable dependence on scientific progress in agriculture is unavoidable if their people are to be even adequately fed. Your comparison with tax policy is interesting, since it points out that our dilemma is government by consent of the governed in an age when problems are far incomparably more complex than those faced by Gladstone. The genius of our democracy lies in its representative character. Most people have a view on taxation, welfare and what they expect from the state. They do not have the competence to decide whether or not we budget for more research on thermal reactors or the application of the human genome but expect their governments to get these matters right. They do not expect to be governed by scientists, but they do expect their leaders to sustain and consult the best science. They are betrayed when judgment is biased by organisations which consider that the adjective "environmental" entitles their members to ignore the rule of law or distort scientific evidence. Yours, Ian Dear Sir Ian, Dr Rasmussen would appear to be a classic nuclear "expert". A study for the European Commission in 1995 showed that, on conservative assumptions, offshore wind power in Europe has the potential to generate more than the entire current European electricity demand. I find your attitude towards voters deeply patronising. If people can have a valid view on taxation and the welfare state, why are they not competent to judge what sort of energy system we should have? Events like "consensus conferences", where lay people are asked to come to conclusions on complex technical matters after consulting a range of experts from different sides, show that people are capable of dealing well with issues that have hitherto been regarded as "too complex" for them. Yet these conferences often come to radically different conclusions from the experts determining policy. Which bring us back to values. Consensus conferences come to different conclusions from the experts because people bring different societal values. Groups like Greenpeace are at their most powerful when our campaigns reflect the values of society at large and contrast with those of the political and scientific elites. This is evidently the case over genetic engineering. Whilst elite opinion continues to regard the whole affair as one of performing better and more refined scientific risk assessments, Greenpeace campaigns remain powerful. Yours sincerely, Doug Useful links National Science Week Greenpeace

fields.headline: Trinity to invest £150m in websites
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
The Mirror Online
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror became the latest "old media" group to embrace the new yesterday when it outlined plans to invest £150m over three years in a network of national and local websites.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror became the latest "old media" group to embrace the new yesterday when it outlined plans to invest £150m over three years in a network of national and local websites.

The company aims to develop the business , using content from its stable of newspapers, on the back of its internet service provider and portal, ic24, which has 215,000 users. Another 16 regional portals will be set up with revenues primarily advertising-driven.

The group has established a new media division headed by David Clarke, formerly managing director of Virgin.Net, and set targets of acquiring 1m access customers by the end of the year. Trinity Mirror is offering unmetered access which it estimates will cost £6m this year.

But, just as publishing group Emap's investment in the web was greeted with a 12% fall in its share price on Thursday, so Trinity Mirror suffered a 29.5p slide to 709p. Analysts said the online market looked increasingly crowded.

The company reported its first set of results since Trinity group bought the Mirror in September last year and turned in a 14% improvement in pre-tax profits during 1999 to £168m. Turnover increased by 4% to just over £1bn and the dividend was lifted 10% to 16p a share.

Mr Graf reiterated the board's support for Mirror editor Piers Morgan whose share dealings sparked controversy last month.

"If you look at the share price then clearly the episode has had no damaging effect on the group," he said. "Would we rather it hadn't happened? Yes, of course."

webTitle: Victory for the talking bank on three fronts

fields.headline: Victory for the talking bank on three fronts
fields.standfirst: First Direct launched a 24-hour banking revolution and people are still signing up in their thousands. What is its secret?
fields.trailText: For a forward-looking organisation regarded as a hi-tech, leading-edge pioneer of remote banking, First Direct - winner of no fewer than three categories: best customer service overall, best current account provider and best savings account provider - has a refreshingly traditional explanation for its success.
fields.body:
For a forward-looking organisation regarded as a hi-tech, leading-edge pioneer of remote banking, First Direct - winner of no fewer than three categories: best customer service overall, best current account provider and best savings account provider - has a refreshingly traditional explanation for its success.

"It's our people," says First Direct chief executive Alan Hughes. "Our customers don't want to buy financial services. They want to feel good. They want reassurance that they are in control, that they are known as an individual. We're happy to show our competitors around our operations. Often we'll come to the end of the tour and they'll shake their heads and say: 'But we still don't understand what it is that you do differently'.

"Our people, we tell them, are the only difference. In the way we recruit and manage our people we encourage them to treat the customers as their friends and to let their personalities shine through." To work at First Direct, conversational skills are of paramount importance. "The ticket to the game might be the banking transaction, but customers don't remember the transaction," says Mr Hughes. "But they do remember the conversation."

First Direct has had the field to itself since it leapfrogged the banking world more than 10 years ago by offering the UK's first 24-hour telephone banking service. It now has almost one million customers and more are joining at the rate of 10,000 each month.

The bank's record on customer service is staggeringly impressive. In a recent NOP survey, 86% of its customers said that they were either "extremely" or "very" satisfied with the service it provides, 80% said banking with First Direct was better than banking with other banks, and 76% had recommended First Direct to friends and colleagues in the last 12 months.

Now 24-hour banking is an industry standard. So how has First Direct maintained its edge? According to Mr Hughes, more bank customers are transferring their accounts to First Direct than to any other bank.

"Customers want to be known as an individual," he explains. "And, when they call us again, they can pick up from where they left off. It's as if the 4,000 of us are one."

First Direct is investing heavily in internet banking. But while other banks may have been faster rolling out their websites, First Direct has been working at its own pace, trying ways of injecting some personality online.

"Banking with a screen enables us to give our customers a greater choice of information. It makes it simple for them to be in control and shifts the balance of power in their favour. We won't be afraid, for example, to give our customers information on what other products and services there are in the marketplace.

"Some might say that giving customers more information is a dangerous strategy. But in our opinion the only dangerous strategy is not giving customers what they want. If customers don't get what they want from us, they go to someone who does."

So how did First Direct come to capture first place in the cheque account category? Most banks find it difficult to get excited about such a bread-and-butter product, but for First Direct cheque accounts are a vital means of establishing a relationship with its customers.

Commercial director Peter Simpson says: "Cheque accounts are at the heart of our business, and we've developed our infrastructure around them. They are a bit like the wiring in your house. You have to have it but it's also got to work effectively and efficiently."

The key factor which differentiates the First Direct cheque account from others, he says, is how staff interact with customers. "We have created a culture which people seem to enjoy and that comes across on the phone - a little sparkle with the customer. We have very little scripting in our call centre, and our representatives can see a total picture of our customers - we call it totally integrated customer services. We also try to respond to the mood of the customer - if they seem to be in a hurry, we won't keep them back."

webTitle: Sky's the limit for cricket TV coverage

fields.headline: Sky's the limit for cricket TV coverage
fields.trailText: In England if you want to watch live cricket from overseas you have to subscribe to Sky Sports. You can do this by having cable installed, putting up a satellite dish or buying a digital box for your television. Any of these three methods guaranteed all the live action until now.
fields.body:
In England if you want to watch live cricket from overseas you have to subscribe to Sky Sports. You can do this by having cable installed, putting up a satellite dish or buying a digital box for your television. Any of these three methods guaranteed all the live action until now.

I had cable installed in November in anticipation of the South Africa-England series. I was aware that I would also be able to watch the West Indies take on Zimbabwe and Pakistan in the Caribbean, two series of particular appeal because both the West Indies and Zimbabwe visit England this summer. The hours of play are very convenient for those of us in the UK with games starting at about 2pm GMT. Previously Sky have shown Australia, New Zealand and India visiting the West Indies.

Of the first two days of the first Test between West Indies and Zimbabwe all that was available live was the post-tea session on the second day, because I do not have a digital box. Instead on Sky's main sports channels we were treated to motocross and repeats of last weekend's football. If Sky do feel the need to show these repeats they should start up a separate channel and not inflict them on people who want to see live action.

When Sky first came to prominence in 1990 with their coverage of the England tour to the Caribbean, they promised that we would not miss a ball, and by and large they have kept to their word. Subscribers have received up to eight hours of coverage a day in the winter with no breaks for local news or imported soap operas.

The arrival of the digital box has meant that Sky have shoved live cricket on to channels only available to those with the right technology - even though many have paid the extra money for sport. When I asked to have my cable link replaced by a box Sky told me that I would have to join a waiting list and my equipment would be with me in four weeks. By that time the Zimbabweans will be in England swapping their swimming trunks for thermals.

Even worse for people with cable is the fact that Sky have all England's home one-day internationals and the Trent Bridge Test. When I phoned them they did not know which channel they were going to broadcast these games on. So it may or may not be worth getting Sky Digital before the summer. Although the service is no different in cost it is inconvenient to get cable switched because many subscribers also have their phone lines going through the cable link-up. Sky should have made their subscribers aware of exactly what they will be able to watch throughout the summer. After all we get enough promotional guff from them every month.

In Australia there are restrictions on television coverage in the state where a game is being played. But that is to encourage people to go to the ground and they have a winning team. I wonder if there is anywhere else where people paying extra for coverage are denied it? Perhaps we have been spoiled for the last ten years or will we just have to rely on wisden.com for up-dates like the rest of the world?

fields.headline: The last word on...   Repentance
fields.standfirst: Our repentance is not so much regret for the evil we have done as fear of what might happen to us because of it. - La Rochefoucauld
fields.trailText: Our repentance is not so much regret for the evil we have done as fear of what might happen to us because of it. - La Rochefoucauld
fields.body:
Last Sunday the Pope publicly repented on behalf of his Church for its errors over the last two millennia, citing "betrayal of the Gospel" and "deviations" from its message. Among other things he had in mind the Crusades, the Inquisition, holy wars, the torture and burning of heretics, ethnic cleansing and genocide, forced conversions of Indians and Africans, discrimination against women including their enslavement by excessive childbirth with resulting poverty and ill-health, and the Church's role in the Holocaust.

Not all of these matters were explicitly mentioned - the Holocaust, for example, was left out - but they were all hinted, and in explanation of why the list was unspecific a Vatican spokesman said, "Given the number of sins committed in the course of 20 centuries, it must necessarily be rather summary."

Repentance means changing one's mind. Students of art history learn how to recognise the "pentamenti" in a painter's work: the alterations, over-paintings, erasures and adjustments detectable most clearly by X-rays, which reveal the painting's evolution and, indirectly therefore, its maker's intentions. One needs to X-ray the papal apology to understand its evolution.

As long ago as 1994 the Pope mooted the idea of purging the Church's conscience, but in its circumspect way the Church required that a report first be prepared, to explore the precedents and consequences of such an action, and to assess how far the apology should go - after all, as the resulting document issued by the international theological commission pointed out, many of the sins were committed "in the service of truth", as for example the massacre of Cathars and the burning of heretics, who were in danger of getting deeper into the sin of heresy if they were not quickly despatched, for their own good, to Purgatory. (Some definitions: heresy = disagreeing with the Pope; truth = agreeing with the Pope.)

The commission's quest for precedents must have been heartening, for the Pope turns out to be in good company: no less a personage than God was given to repenting, as when in Genesis 6:6 he repents that he had made man, and in 1 Samuel 15 that he had made Samuel king, and even - after a lecture from Moses - in Exodus 32:14 that he had been on the point of letting his wrath wax hot against his stiffnecked people. As various humanity-destroying floods, earthquakes and immolations attest, however, he did not repent often; which might explain the Church's 2,000-year delay in its own first effort.

That God repented at all has been a problem for theologians, for there is an embarrassing contradiction between divine perfections and divine repentings. Apologetical writings on the subject accordingly have chapter headings like "God repents, 1 Sam 15:35, but this does not mean he was mistaken or in error, 11 Psalms 110:4". The theological commission ought to have taken this tack in the Papal apology: a form of words which more circumloquaciously said "we were wrong but we weren't wrong" would have done.

"Sinning is the best part of repentance," says an Arab proverb, and one suspects that the Church, in the heyday of its power and influence, would have given not a moment's consideration to the idea of repenting en masse (and in a mass) for its "sins of 20 centuries". In a lecture to Roman Catholics on "teshuva" Rabbi David Blumenthal observed that in addition to acceptance of one's sinfulness and remorse for it, repentance involves restitution.

This opens an interesting possibility: will the Church, which is very rich, compensate its victims or their heirs now that it has acknowledged its sins against them? Restitution is not a canonical part of Catholic doctrine on repentance, but something Melancthon says suggests it could become so: he describes repentance as consisting of "contrition, that is, terrors smiting the conscience through the knowledge of sin... (and) faith... from which good works, which are the fruits of repentance, are bound to follow." This, at least, suggests how to test the sincerity of an apology; we wait with bated breath.

An apology can sometimes help victims, at least in being a recognition of their suffering - and a modest revenge, for "he punishes himself who repents of his deeds" as Publilius Syrus said. But it does not repair the damage or reverse the injustices of history. When apologies are offered too late, or only because they have become unavoidable, they are worth little. How much better it would be if they had not been necessary in the first place.

webTitle: Pope's pilgrimage of a lifetime takes him into minefield

fields.headline: Pope's pilgrimage of a lifetime takes him into minefield
fields.trailText: The last time a pope passed through the Holy Land, he was whisked in and out within 12 hours. The word "Israel" did not pass Paul VI's lips, and he scrupulously avoided calling on government ministers or rabbis. Meeting the president could hardly be avoided, but the encounter was held away from the head of state's office.
fields.body:
The last time a pope passed through the Holy Land, he was whisked in and out within 12 hours. The word "Israel" did not pass Paul VI's lips, and he scrupulously avoided calling on government ministers or rabbis. Meeting the president could hardly be avoided, but the encounter was held away from the head of state's office.

That was 1964, before the Second Vatican Council repudiated the teaching that the "perfidious Jews" bore collective guilt through the ages for the crucifixion of Jesus.

The coming week, when John Paul II begins his tour of the Holy Land, promises to be rather different. Israeli officials have labelled the security arrangements for his six-day stay - including one day in the Palestinian Authority's terrain - Operation Old Friend.

The code name is a wistful reflection of the desire that this visit, coming so soon after an expression of penance from the Vatican, can help erase the stains of grievance and contempt from an often bloody history two millennia old.

Since his reign began in 1978, the Pope has been acutely conscious of the year 2000, and of his role in leading the church into the third millennium of Christianity.

Now 79 years old, and stricken with Parkinson's disease that makes it difficult for him to walk more than a few paces at a time, he is embarking on this arduous journey both as a humble pilgrim following in the footsteps of Jesus, and as the supreme authority of the world's billion Catholics who seeks also to promote dialogue with Muslims and Jews and between Christian denominations.

Of his more than 140 foreign trips, this will be the climax of his papacy. But political rivalries and religious sensitivities are conspiring to ensure that every painful step the Pope treads when he arrives in Israel on Tuesday will be like walking through a minefield.

"If you expect everything to be hunky-dory and no problems on the agenda then that is ridiculous," says Rabbi David Rosen, of the Anti-Defamation League, who has frequently met the Pope, and who is part of a small, but valiant, band of inter-faith activists.

Jewish leaders will be poring over the Pope's message at the Yad Vashem holocaust memorial on Thursday for an explicit apology for the silence of the Catholic church while 6m Jews were annihilated during the Nazi era. Palestinian leaders will seek acknowledgment for the suffering of their people under Israeli occupation when he visits the Deheishe refugee camp near Bethlehem a day earlier. The Muslim clergy is holding out for an apology for the slaughter of the Crusades 900 years ago.

Local Christians, now just 2% of the population - which is why 50,000 pilgrims will be flown in to bolster numbers at a papal mass next Friday near the Mount of Beatitudes overlooking the Sea of Galilee - will seek support in their struggle to withstand both Jewish and Muslim intolerance. In the weeks before the visit, religious zealots in the cloistered community of Mea Shearim, the Jerusalem enclave of ultra-orthodox Jews, spraypainted the walls with anti-Catholic messages.

Chief rabbis have complained that the Pope's tour of northern Galilee at the weekend will force Israeli policemen - 18,000 will be on call for the duration of the visit - to desecrate the Jewish Sabbath, and bridled at the suggestion that the special ambulance accompanying the pope will be shorn of the red Star of David.

He could also risk causing outrage when he goes to the Western Wall on the final day of his visit wearing his crucifix. "The Western Wall is a synagogue and is a place of worship for hundreds and thousands of people around the world," says Rabbi Aharon Feldman of the Be'er Torah yeshiva, Jerusalem.

"If the Pope wants to visit, he should remove his cross because it is a symbol of another religion." And yet, Jews and Christians acknowledge that this Pope has done more than any other to cast aside the doctrine that helped to validate anti-semitism. He was the first to denounce the persecution of Jews as a sin, the first to set foot inside a synagogue, in Rome in 1986. It was also under his stewardship that the Vatican recognised the state of Israel in 1993, which many acknowledge as a milestone in the changing attitude of the church towards the Jewish people.

"He has done more for Catholic-Jewish relations in 20 years than the Catholic church has done in 2,000," says Father Michael McGarry, rector of the Tantur ecumenical institute near Bethlehem.

When he visits Yad Vashem, the Pope from Poland will be reunited with survivors from his home town of Wadowice. There are no Jews left now in the place of his birth; 3m Polish Jews died in the Holocaust. The handful who remain from Wadowice say they remember that Lolek - as Karol Wojtyla was known during his boyhood - stood out for his friendships with Jews.

Roman Krisher, who now lives in a suburb of Tel Aviv, will also be there; he still has the blue skis he used during a 1937 race in which both took part.

"He was very liberal, very religious, and he knew no difference between Christian and Jew even when he was very small," says Mr Krisher, who was in the same class as the Pope at primary school. fields.headline: Passing the point of peace
fields.standfirst: Mordechai Beck
fields.trailText: Pope Paul John II's forthcoming arrival in the holy land on Monday was preceded some weeks ago by a decision to scrap his planned meeting with Israel's two chief rabbis at Jerusalem's western wall.
fields.body:
Pope Paul John II's forthcoming arrival in the holy land on Monday was preceded some weeks ago by a decision to scrap his planned meeting with Israel's two chief rabbis at Jerusalem's western wall. Their office defended the decision vigorously: "If a major foreign dignitary visited London, would he not be received at 10 Downing Street?"

The Talmudic logic of this statement - suggesting somehow that Downing Street is the English equivalent of Jewry's most sacred place - points to the deep ambivalence many Israelis feel towards the visit of the Holy See.

In the official view, it is that of the head of a foreign state; it is therefore only fitting that the Pope should meet the chief rabbis, who are government officials, at their official residence. Some Orthodox rabbis, however, feel that a great opportunity was missed: "Had they taken up the Vatican's offer," said one (who requested anonymity), "it would have been a clear statement of the Pope's recognition of Jewish sovereignty over Jerusalem."

"The real reason for the cancellation," said another rabbinic critic, "was because of intimidation from the extreme Orthodox sector. They threatened to disrupt the visit because they still think of the Pope and the Catholic church as the Jews' enemy No 1."

Rabbi Shimon Naftalis, a longtime resident of Mea Shearim, the stronghold of Jerusalem's ultra-Orthodox community, suggested a more practical reason. "It would be a security nightmare. It is also possible that the Council of Ultra-Orthodox Jews might have suggested the change. Inflammatory posters - calling the Pope an idol worshipper - were displayed in Mea Shearim, urging people not to pay any attention to the visit. But their language suggested they were written by west bank settlers."

"The reason for the ultra-Orthodox reaction," observes Rabbi David Rosen, "is that their frame of reference is medieval. They cannot relate to the Catholic church's radical reappraisal in its view of the Jewish people."

Orthodox Rabbi Rosen, director of the Anti-Defamation League in Israel, and its contact with to the Vatican, is also head of the International Council of Christians and Jews, and a major player in the expanding dialogue in which Jews and Christians have engaged since the second world war. He sees the current visit as the climax of a long process.

"The last pope to visit the holy land, in 1964, was Paul VI. He entered Israel from Jordan, never uttered the word 'Israel', was greeted in Megiddo by the then president of the state, whom he addressed as 'Mr Shazar', and declined to visit any Israeli institution in western Jerusalem, including Yad Vashem."

In retrospect, Rabbi Rosen believes this was a slap in the face for all those who thought the church had begun to make amends for its past, because "of the church's inability to grasp the significance of Israel, not just for Judaism, but for all Jewish people."

More typically, Rabbi Shlomo Riskin, of Efrat, observes that "the Pope could not recognise Israel without negating one of the tenets of the church. But this is irrelevant. History itself has negated church dogma. I am just disappointed that the Vatican has not gone further." Rabbi Rosen disagrees, arguing that the Catholic church is now world Jewry's biggest ally in fighting anti-semitism.

Will any of this make an impact on Israel or the average Israeli? Rabbi Rosen guesses that most "will enjoy the visit as an international media event, although they won't be aware of its historical or theological context. Yet the fact that the Pope will be received by the president in his official residence carries more significance than a meeting with the chief rabbis. It symbolises far more clearly the radical transformation of the Catholic church in its attitude towards the Jewish people."

"Moreover, when the Pope goes to Yad Vashem and speaks there, it is irrelevant that he will say nothing that he hasn't already said or written in countless published documents. What is significant is where he says it.

"Jews and Catholics the world over will be offered a visual demonstration of the church's commitment to reconciliation. The message may have been conveyed before, but the fact that it is coming from the Jewish state, and in particular from Jerusalem, means that it will be heard, and hopefully absorbed, in Israel and in the eyes of the world at large, for the first time."

Mordechai Beck is a Jerusalem-based journalist

webTitle: Top Tories' secret plot to quit EU

fields.headline: Top Tories' secret plot to quit EU
fields.standfirst:
Eurosceptic Conservatives in talks with Americans over trade deal that could replace links to continent

Tories in opposition: special report
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: A secret plot has been hatched by senior Conservatives to prepare the ground for British withdrawal from the European Union, raising new doubts about William Hague's ability to hold his party together over Europe.
fields.body:
A secret plot has been hatched by senior Conservatives to prepare the ground for British withdrawal from the European Union, raising new doubts about William Hague's ability to hold his party together over Europe.

A group of Eurosceptic Tory frontbenchers, who are determined to undermine Britain's place in Europe, have played a leading role in persuading a powerful United States senate committee to investigate the possibility of Britain unilaterally joining the North America free trade area. Such a move would lead to instant expulsion from the EU.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, last night seized on the secret plan to claim that the Conservatives' policy of "withdrawal by stealth" had at last been exposed.

Mr Cook said: "William Hague's cover has been blown. Nobody can now take seriously his protestations that he wants Britain to remain in the EU when he he is secretly working to get Britain to join Nafta."

The foreign secretary hit out when it emerged that the US senate's finance committee launched an investigation into possible British membership of Nafta after intense lobbying from a group of senior Tory Eurosceptics.

These include John Redwood, who said yesterday that he received a "warm reception" in Washington last year while he was a member of the shadow cabinet. The group also included Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, and the rightwing backbencher Eric Forth, who is a close ally of the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo.

Mr Redwood said that a series of trips to Washington by leading Tories had played an important role in persuading the senate committee to commission its investigation into British membership.

"There is growing opposition to a fortress Europe in the United States," Mr Redwood said. "If low tariffs make sense in Europe why can't they make sense across the Atlantic?"

The Conservatives last night angrily rejected Mr Cook's claims that Mr Hague was behind a plot to use Nafta membership to force Britain out of the EU.

A spokesman for Mr Hague said: "We believe that Britain should join Nafta but this should be done through the European Union. To claim that we are pushing for Britain to join Nafta unilaterally is a Millbank lie."

The row between the foreign secretary and the Tories broke out after a team of officials from the US international trade commission, which is carrying out the Nafta investigation on behalf of the senate finance committee, arrived in London this week to launch their investigation. The Americans are meeting Eurosceptic groups such as the anti-single currency group Business for Sterling.

Pro-Europeans believe that the Eurosceptic Tories have succeeded in pushing forward their "withdrawal agenda" by persuading the US senate that Britain could make a unilateral decision to join Nafta.

The US commission's terms of reference talk about British membership of the North American free trade area, without making any reference to the EU. They talk of investigating "the impact on the US economy of including the United Kingdom in a free trade arrangement".

Foreign office officials will tell US commission officials, when they meet next week, that a unilateral move is impossible because Britain can only set up trade deals through the EU.

One source said: "Our officials will stress the constitutional impossibility of Britain joining Nafta without leaving the EU."

This was reinforced by Mr Cook. "The fact is that that the overwhelming majority of our exports [52.7%] go to countries of the EU, while only 17% of our trade is with Nafta," the foreign secretary said. "This shows that William Hague is prepared to jeopardise a very large number of British jobs for the sake of satisfying his party's extreme anti-European prejudices."

Despite the Tories' dismissal of Mr Cook's claims, the disclosure of the role of senior Conservatives in the Nafta investigation will once again focus attention on Mr Hague's commitment to Europe.

At last year's Tory conference, the party leader raised the possibility of a future Conservative government renegotiating Britain's European treaties, which was seen as code for withdrawal.

Mr Hague's lurch towards extreme Euroscepticism was largely put down to pressure from Lady Thatcher, who hijacked the conference when she declared that all Britain's problems had come from the continent.

The former prime minister underlined her contempt for the European Union yesterday by publicly supporting the rightwing peer Lord Pearson of Rannoch when he introduced a bill that would lay the ground for British withdrawal from the EU.

fields.headline: Republicans welcome Britain's queen
fields.standfirst: Australia and the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen of Australia returned to her kingdom yesterday for the first time since a bitter referendum campaign finally rejected republicanism only four months ago. But after a low key welcome in Canberra she was given a friendly reminder that while the republicans are down they are not out.
fields.body:
The Queen of Australia returned to her kingdom yesterday for the first time since a bitter referendum campaign finally rejected republicanism only four months ago. But after a low key welcome in Canberra she was given a friendly reminder that while the republicans are down they are not out.

Her tour - her first in Australia for eight years - began like clockwork when a Royal Australian Air Force VIP jet landed in a warm autumn evening at the Fairbairn base after collecting the monarch and her entourage of 32 from her chartered Qantas 747 in Sydney.

The Queen was met on the tarmac by the governor general, Sir William Deane, the Australian prime minister, John Howard, and their wives. There was no red carpet, no national anthem, no military guard of honour, no 21-gun salute.

While a few royal well-wishers lined the route between the airport and the governor general's official residence of Yarralumla, the local branch of the Australian Republican Movement stole their thunder with a large yellow and gold banner reading "The Republic of the ACT [Australian Capital Territory] welcomes the Queen of England".

An ARM spokesman, Robin Poke, said he wanted to remind the Queen that the struggle for a republic continued.

The singing of God Save the Queen by a handful of royalists outside the gates of Yarralumla sounded a little hollow as the royal Rolls-Royce sped into the vice-regal sanctuary to give the Queen a quiet weekend to get over jet lag.

Prince Philip did not fly in from London with the party but arrived later in Canberra from the United States.

However, there was one bright spot for traditionalists. Janette Howard, wife of the prime minister, an avowed republican, curtseyed to the Queen.

It was a small but significant sign of how things have changed at the top. The last time the Queen arrived in 1992, Annita Keating, wife of the then prime minister, Paul Keating, refused to curtsey in what some tried to make out was a calculated republican snub.

Despite the divisions caused by the republic debate, which was defeated by 45% to 55%, the royal tour does not so far appear to have stirred great passions from either side. While the Queen's every move and word are likely to be scrutinised on the busy itinerary, which does not take in Queensland or South Australia, few pundits are predicting much of a turn out, at least in the cities.

The Queen's first official appointment of her 13th tour of Australia is a meeting with Mr Howard today at Yarralumla while her first public appearance will be at a church service tomorrow.

The initial test of public support for the royal tour will be seen on Monday, when the Queen will receive a 21-gun salute at the official welcoming ceremony at the Sydney opera house. The ceremonies will be complete with a traditional greeting from local aboriginal people.

The Queen will spend another day in Sydney visiting the Olympic site before joining the duke to tour the outback town of Bourke, which in recent years has been stigmatised for its poor relations between blacks and whites and for its law and order problems.

Next week will be rounded off with two days in Melbourne and in rural Ballarat. After another relaxed weekend in Canberra, the final week will include two days in Tasmania and a whistlestop tour through Alice Springs and Perth before returning to Britain.

The Queen's first official appointment of her 13th tour of Australia is a meeting with Mr Howard today at Yarralumla while her first public appearance will be at a church service tomorrow. The initial test of public support for the royal tour will be seen on Monday, when the Queen will receive a 21-gun salute at the official welcoming ceremony at the Sydney opera house. The ceremonies will be complete with a traditional greeting from local aboriginal people. The Queen will spend another day in Sydney visiting the Olympic site before joining the duke to tour the outback town of Bourke, which in recent years has been stigmatised for its poor relations between blacks and whites and for its law and order problems. Next week will be rounded off with two days in Melbourne and in rural Ballarat. After another relaxed weekend in Canberra, the final week will include two days in Tasmania and a whistlestop tour through Alice Springs and Perth before returning to Britain.

webTitle: PE teacher jailed for sex with girl

fields.headline: PE teacher jailed for sex with girl
fields.trailText: A PE teacher was yesterday jailed for 12 months for having sex with a 14-year-old pupil he knew had a crush on him.
fields.body:
A PE teacher was yesterday jailed for 12 months for having sex with a 14-year-old pupil he knew had a crush on him.

Mark Unsworth, 40, from Sutton, Kingston-upon-Hull, was found guilty at Teesside crown court of three specimen charges of having unlawful sexual intercourse with the girl. He had denied the charges.

Unsworth will be registered as sex offender for 10 years, after Judge John Walford told him his behaviour had been an "appalling breach of trust".

The court heard that Unsworth met the girl on a school trip when she was 12. They became friendly and by the time she was 14, she regularly visited his flat. On Valentine's day Unsworth sent her a card and chocolate with a message that it would "whip up her passion".

Unsworth maintained they never had sex and claimed the girl and her family were lying.

webTitle: We are no longer in the driving seat

fields.headline: We are no longer in the driving seat
fields.standfirst:
The Rover fiasco has taught Blair that his influence is limited

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: After the fantasy economics of the last few weeks - with internet billionaires lifted up daily on a web of crossed fingers - financial reality has returned with up to 50,000 Midlanders facing the loss of their jobs after the sale of the Rover plant. And another cruel truth - about the nature of political power - has been brought home to Tony Blair.
fields.body:
After the fantasy economics of the last few weeks - with internet billionaires lifted up daily on a web of crossed fingers - financial reality has returned with up to 50,000 Midlanders facing the loss of their jobs after the sale of the Rover plant. And another cruel truth - about the nature of political power - has been brought home to Tony Blair.

For the story of Rover touches on the three biggest issues in British politics over the past 20 years: the industrial legacy of the 70s, the power of the market and Britain's relationship with the rest of Europe. As a politician, Blair tried to banish the first, celebrate the second and equivocate on the third. After the sale of the Rover plant at Longbridge to a venture capitalist with no experience of cars beyond occasionally driving them, none of these three positions seems entirely tenable. The wheels, as they say in the automobile business, have come off.

Blair sold himself to Labour as the baggage-handler. His mission was to make voters forget the 70s. In broad political terms, this has worked. But the memory of industrial strife survives in the poor reputation of British cars among drivers: the underlying cause of the £700m losses which led BMW to sell.

While the Militant Tendency and the public service strikes affected most voters at an anecdotal level, too many have personal experience of the mechanic's sad head-shake and the lament that you bought what they call a last-thing-Friday car, made when the production line was rushing to the pub. There were times when all British cars seemed to have been made in the final hours of the week. Accordingly, even those Britons prejudiced against Berlin by two wars and various semi-finals hold it as an article of faith that Germany is better for cars and classical music. This anti-British prejudice even in the otherwise patriotic is finally what finished Rover.

Only two parts of Rover fully adapted to the new politics. The Mini has benefited from a general retro chic in British culture while the Land-Rover division (yesterday sold to Ford) flourished by producing the ridiculously inappropriate tank-like carriers in which the neurotic middle classes who voted Blair in to power choose to move their children between house and school.

Apart from the unexpected return of the 70s to haunt him, the other surprise for the prime minister over Rover is that his policy of careful back-seat driving over Europe has proved to be a bad steer. While BMW has specifically blamed the strength of the pound for its losses, membership of the single European currency would only have made a significant difference if Britain had joined long ago at a much lower exchange-rate. Yesterday's recriminations between London and Bonn are more important symbolically: showing the impatience and hostility in the pro-euro countries to those which maintain a tentative or conditional membership of Europe. This developing division clearly threatens the wait-and-see policy of the British parties.

Although one aspect of these matters was theoretically within the power of Blair to change - Britain's relationship with Europe and the euro - he has made no obvious mistake. Returning to huge state subsidy of the car industry would earn him friends only in the one section of the political arena - the old seats on the far left - in which he sees no political advantage. Were Blair to return to serious state intervention in industry, he would fear that his Land-Rover driving voters might next time park at the polling booth and vote for someone else.

The point is not that Blair should have done something else but that there was nothing much he could do. The hardest lesson for the government has been the impotence of politicians. On yesterday morning's news programmes, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, looked as wrecked and helpless as a parent whose child had been kidnapped, admitting that the gang who had swooped had not told him very much and he could only hope they were acting in good faith but he had no power to do anything about them.

Norman Tebbit - the leading Thatcherite promoter of privatisation - once admitted that the sale of the nationalised industries had a practical motivation as well as an ideological one. In theory, there would be fewer matters over which voters could hold their leaders directly to account. Government would become more ceremonial and presidential, while the private sector got the hate-mail. In reality - as the Tories discovered - the public continued to blame the ruling administration for most things. Byers and Blair have this week learned that the market takes the credit while the leaders take the blame.

Blairism held three central promises: that the industrial troubles of the 70s were quite forgotten, that the market was essentially a benevolent mechanism and that Europe and the euro were not a problem in the short term. On these three matters, the prime minister has received an education, education, education. But the toughest instruction has been in the limits of his own influence. The man who pledged to end the days when Labour prime ministers invited trade unionists for beer and sandwiches at Number 10 has just learned what it's like to have them round to share his humble pie.

webTitle: 'We knew right from the beginning that they would eventually close us down'

fields.headline: 'We knew right from the beginning that they would eventually close us down'
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Dam Ji Ladwa applied for redundancy from Rover yesterday. He has worked at Longbridge for 24 years, from the British Leyland era to the sorry BMW phase, but now he has had enough.
fields.body:
Dam Ji Ladwa applied for redundancy from Rover yesterday. He has worked at Longbridge for 24 years, from the British Leyland era to the sorry BMW phase, but now he has had enough.

"I had thought that I would wait till I was 50 and then retire," he said yesterday at his home in Moseley, Birmingham. "But I don't think I will wait till then in case there is no more money in the pot. So I'll finish now and look for another job."

He does not know how much cash will be in his personal pot - the personnel department stopped issuing redundancy payout figures yesterday morning.

Mr Ladwa, 49, first walked into the factory in 1976, having spent two years trying to get a job that he knew would be secure and paid well.

"I submitted several applications and eventually went in as a driver, moving vehicles around the plant," he said. "I started when there was a strike on and I think I was the only person in there at the time."

Unions were mighty then. The legendary convenor Derek Robinson - "Red Robbo" - could halt all production and set up impassable picket lines. The Thatcher government put an end to that, but Mr Ladwa thinks he still might have a job if the unions had taken some old-style tough action last year.

"Everyone seemed to stick together back then. When things started going wrong we should have shown BMW what we could do," he added.

Mr Ladwa has good memories of Rover's link-up with Honda during the days when British Aerospace owned the company. "If we could have stayed with Honda, I think we would have survived. We worked side by side with Japanese managers and workers. The Japanese were happy to put their badges on our cars. But BMW were too frightened to do it - they should have put their badge on the Rover 75. That would have sold it.

"We knew BMW bought the Longbridge plant just to get Land-Rover. We knew right from the beginning that they would eventually close the place down. They made a big mistake when they stopped making Metros - we then didn't have a small-range car.

"The BMW management style was very strict. They worked us harder but did not achieve anything. They were trying to increase productivity all the time. We would work 14, sometimes 16-hour days and had no choice about it."

Mr Ladwa spent his final day at Longbridge feeding the track with the parts that are assembled into finished cars.

"Everyone is multi-functioned now. You didn't have a particular job. They could move you around any time they wanted."

Mr Ladwa has fond memories of his working life in conditions that were always good and he enjoyed the company of his workmates. "But I feel very sad. Everything has gone and I want to get out now. I'm pretty confident that I will get another job.

"BMW have betrayed us, although, looking at it from their side, the company obviously lost a lot of money. I don't think they knew what they were doing. They messed it up at Longbridge right from the beginning."

webTitle: The secret deal that left Rover a museum piece

fields.headline: The secret deal that left Rover a museum piece
fields.standfirst:
BMW power struggle cleared the way for Project Crufts - and the loss of thousands of Longbridge jobs

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: In Germany yesterday a sign said it all. In 11 languages - the BMW Museum. That is where, with some of the most elegant cars of the 20th century, the German car maker this week consigned Rover, one of the most famous names in British motoring.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Mark Milner  in Munich and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
In Germany yesterday a sign said it all. In 11 languages - the BMW Museum. That is where, with some of the most elegant cars of the 20th century, the German car maker this week consigned Rover, one of the most famous names in British motoring.

A power struggle in the BMW boardroom, faced with huge losses at their British subsidiary, had left blood on the carpet there, thousands of people facing unemployment in the West Midlands and an angry government looking powerless in the face of big business.

And so ended, after six years, the Munich-based company's ambition of using Rover to provide the economies of scale that would allow it to compete with the emerging automotive supergroups.

The museum stands alongside the group's landmark headquarters - a building which is a monument to BMW's importance as one of Bavaria's most famous corporate sons.

It is one of only two skyscrapers allowed by the Munich city fathers and it was within that 21-storey tower on Thursday morning that BMW's board made its fateful decision. The English Patient was simply not responding to treatment. Ailing Rover, into which the group had poured billions since it gazumped Honda to buy it from British Aerospace in 1994 would, in large part, have to go.

But the process had taken a long time. It was six months ago that the takeover of the Longbridge car plant by Alchemy Partners was mooted privately during secret talks in Munich behind the backs of the British government and workforce.

It was particularly galling for the government who were pushing Brussels to clear a £152m cash injection it hoped would guarantee Longbridge's future. And all the time BMW was looking to sell.

The plan was codenamed Project Crufts by Jon Moulton and Eric Walters, who run Alchemy and hoped their takeover could be agreed during the dog show. It was not to be made public until it was too late to stop.

The news of the takeover leaked out on Monday night when the presses at the Suddeutsche Zeitung began to roll.

The edition carried a story which sent shockwaves through the motor industry in general and the West Midlands in particular. According to the Suddeutsche Zeitung, the BMW management was recommending the sale of the Longbridge plant in Birmingham, and the Rover name to a buyer which was "not one of the established auto groups".

The impact was immediate. The Suddeutsche Zeitung is regarded in Germany as an influential newspaper with a track record of scoops about BMW.

In the event the car group responded immediately. Though it did not exactly confirm the story, it acknowledged that plans to restructure Rover were being considered and that a sale was an option.

The following day the Suddeutsche Zeitung did it again, lifting the lid on what was going on behind the scenes at BMW.

It reported that following Thursday's meeting of the supervisory board - German companies have two boards, one made up of the operational management and the second supervisory board including representatives from shareholders and the workforce - three top executives would go.

Even before Thursday's meeting of the supervisory board there had been a power struggle within BMW and the hawks - those who wanted to get rid of Rover - had won. However, when he went into the supervisory board meeting the management board chief Joachim Milberg, a tall grey-haired bespectacled man with a sufficiently academic air to make his title of professor more than a courtesy one, already had an exit strategy to put on the table.

But how and when did BMW executives, who had been adamant that Rover would stay within BMW come to such a change of mind.

After all, the issue should have been buried when a previous boardroom bust-up saw the departure of chairman Bernd Pischetsreider and his rival Wolfgang Reitzle.

Immediately after he took over at BMW last February Prof Milberg put in place what Dr Thomas Gauly, the spokesman for the Quandt family which effectively controls BMW through a near 48% shareholding, "a very exact and detailed" analysis of Rover.

Towards the end of last year, according to BMW executives, the German group received a number of approaches - including one from Alchemy - about Rover. It took a while, apparently, to sort the serious from the frivolous.

At the same time it was becoming clear that BMW's strategy of turning Rover round was not going according to plan. Sales of the 75 model and the 25 and 45 were not going according to plan. The company could not shrug off it's old fashioned image. And instead of weakening - as BMW had apparently hoped early in 1998 - the pound strengthened further, making the cars more and more expensive abroad.

By the time of the Geneva motor show it was clear that matters were coming to a crunch. Even then executives were letting it be known that some UK investment decisions were under threat - though the sometimes mixed messages emerging indicated the extent to which management was divided. Even heavier losses than in 1998, the row over state aid for Longbridge and government policy towards the single currency only added to the pressure.

At Geneva Prof Milberg was talking then of restructuring Rover. Quite when restructuring turned to division is not entirely clear though Prof Milberg says, rather enigmatically, that the build-up to the decision "took more than one day".

Some reports suggest that the Quandt family pushed for an end to the Rover affair. They were certainly in a position to do so. Though Johanna Quandt, the third wife of Guenther Quandt, the man credited with building up BMW, plays little active part in running the company her two children Susanne Klatten and Stefan Quandt, both in their 30s, sit on the supervisory board.

Prof Milberg insisted that the plan for Rover came from the managing board and the Quandts responded "positively". According to Dr Gauly: "It was Professor Milberg who prepared the Rover plan, he was the man who pushed it forward." The Quandt's, he insists, do not get involved in operational decisions.

Prof Milberg said he consulted industry secretary Stephen Byers "a couple of days" ahead of the supervisory board meeting to tell him that BMW was "considering various alternatives" and to warn him that the situation was critical.

Prof Milburg insisted that he had held talks with the government several weeks before the supervisory board meeting which approved the Rover break-up in a bid to get across just how serious the situation was.

One of those alternatives was Alchemy which, judging by the reports in the Suddeusche Zeitung had, by Monday at the latest, turned its original approach into a concept which Prof Milberg could push through the management board and then at that fateful meeting on a grey cold blustery Munich day sell to the supervisory board as a face saving - if expensive - exit strategy.

The BMW directors who ditched Rover could yet meet the fate of workers in the West Midlands as speculation grows that the German company has left itself open to takeover.

Volkswagen is tipped as a potential suitor in an industry where big is beautiful as manufacturers pool resources in an industry suffering 25% overcapacity.

Germany's Daimler-Benz and the US producer Chrysler have already teamed up while Renault of France has a large stake in Nissan of Japan.

Sweden's Volvo is now part of Ford while a fortnight ago the US-based General Motors teamed up with the Italian giant Fiat.

Back in London yesterday, Mr Moulton made it clear that Longbridge will soon end its reign as Britain's largest car plant - employing 8,500 staff directly and thousands more in ancillary businesses.

He admitted large job losses are on their way and that output of the Rover 25 and 45 will be slowed and ended with no replacements. The future, he said, would be in aluminium MG sports cars, including a saloon, similar to those made by Lotus, with fewer than 100,000 produced on even the most optimistic forecasts against 180,000 vehicles now.

The political fallout could trigger a political backlash against a humiliated Tony Blair and his party in many marginal seats after the government was left in the dark and then exposed as impotent.

Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, is expected to travel to Germany next week for talks with BMW executives.

The past week proved a nightmare for the once rising star of New Labour as he struggled to find out what was going on and never quite caught up with BMW or Alchemy.

Mr Byers, in the West Midlands yesterday for talks with the Longbridge management and unions, announced a task force to deal with the fallout and help workers made redundant find new jobs.

The decision, whatever the fighting talk about finding another buyer, suggests the government are resigned to Longbridge facing big cuts.

The industrial fallout was witnessed in the BBC's Millbank studios yesterday morning after Mr Moulton and Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, appeared on Radio 4's Today programme.

Astonished BBC staff witnessed Sir Ken, a trade unionist who puts great store on partnership with managers, jabbing his finger at Mr Moulton as he protested: "I'm bloody disgusted at what's happening."

It had not been a good week for a lot of people.

Rover's glorious past

1904 Rover produced its first car, an 8hp model.

1906 The Rover Company Ltd was founded.

1912 Rover offered a bigger selection of vehicles than any other firm, with cars from 100 guineas to £600.

1924 The 14/45 hp model made its debut at the Olympia motor show. It incorporated more up-to-date features than any other car of the time.

During the war More than 21,000 people were employed producing engines for planes and tanks, aircraft wings and other items. The firm's total wartime turnover was more than £20m.

1948 The Land-Rover was launched at the Amsterdam motor show.

1949 The P4 was launched. Commonly known as the Auntie, it was described as a luxury saloon.

1958 Rover launched the P5, a 3 litre, 6 cylinder saloon which became the choice for royals and prime ministers.

1963 The advanced Rover 2000 (P6) won the Car of the Year award.

1967 Rover merged with the Leyland Motor Corporation. The following year the Leyland group merged with British Motor Holdings to form the British Leyland Motor Corporation.

1976 The classic SD arrived, billed as a large, fastbacked car.

1984 The 200 series was launched, introducing the small car range.

1986 The executive 800 series was launched.

1993 the 600 series of upper medium sector cars was introduced.

1999 The Rover 75 was launched, and described as truly contemporary

Sally James

And instead of weakening - as BMW had apparently hoped early in 1998 - the pound strengthened further, making the cars more and more expensive abroad. By the time of the Geneva motor show it was clear that matters were coming to a crunch. Even then executives were letting it be known that some UK investment decisions were under threat - though the sometimes mixed messages emerging indicated the extent to which management was divided. Even heavier losses than in 1998, the row over state aid for Longbridge and government policy towards the single currency only added to the pressure. At Geneva Prof Milberg was talking then of restructuring Rover. Quite when restructuring turned to division is not entirely clear though Prof Milberg says, rather enigmatically, that the build-up to the decision "took more than one day". Some reports suggest that the Quandt family pushed for an end to the Rover affair. They were certainly in a position to do so. Though Johanna Quandt, the third wife of Guenther Quandt, the man credited with building up BMW, plays little active part in running the company her two children Susanne Klatten and Stefan Quandt, both in their 30s, sit on the supervisory board. Prof Milberg insisted that the plan for Rover came from the managing board and the Quandts responded "positively". According to Dr Gauly: "It was Professor Milberg who prepared the Rover plan, he was the man who pushed it forward." The Quandt's, he insists, do not get involved in operational decisions. Prof Milberg said he consulted industry secretary Stephen Byers "a couple of days" ahead of the supervisory board meeting to tell him that BMW was "considering various alternatives" and to warn him that the situation was critical. Prof Milburg insisted that he had held talks with the government several weeks before the supervisory board meeting which approved the Rover break-up in a bid to get across just how serious the situation was. One of those alternatives was Alchemy which, judging by the reports in the Suddeusche Zeitung had, by Monday at the latest, turned its original approach into a concept which Prof Milberg could push through the management board and then at that fateful meeting on a grey cold blustery Munich day sell to the supervisory board as a face saving - if expensive - exit strategy. The BMW directors who ditched Rover could yet meet the fate of workers in the West Midlands as speculation grows that the German company has left itself open to takeover. Volkswagen is tipped as a potential suitor in an industry where big is beautiful as manufacturers pool resources in an industry suffering 25% overcapacity. Germany's Daimler-Benz and the US producer Chrysler have already teamed up while Renault of France has a large stake in Nissan of Japan. Sweden's Volvo is now part of Ford while a fortnight ago the US-based General Motors teamed up with the Italian giant Fiat. Back in London yesterday, Mr Moulton made it clear that Longbridge will soon end its reign as Britain's largest car plant - employing 8,500 staff directly and thousands more in ancillary businesses. He admitted large job losses are on their way and that output of the Rover 25 and 45 will be slowed and ended with no replacements. The future, he said, would be in aluminium MG sports cars, including a saloon, similar to those made by Lotus, with fewer than 100,000 produced on even the most optimistic forecasts against 180,000 vehicles now. The political fallout could trigger a political backlash against a humiliated Tony Blair and his party in many marginal seats after the government was left in the dark and then exposed as impotent. Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, is expected to travel to Germany next week for talks with BMW executives. The past week proved a nightmare for the once rising star of New Labour as he struggled to find out what was going on and never quite caught up with BMW or Alchemy. Mr Byers, in the West Midlands yesterday for talks with the Longbridge management and unions, announced a task force to deal with the fallout and help workers made redundant find new jobs. The decision, whatever the fighting talk about finding another buyer, suggests the government are resigned to Longbridge facing big cuts. The industrial fallout was witnessed in the BBC's Millbank studios yesterday morning after Mr Moulton and Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, appeared on Radio 4's Today programme. Astonished BBC staff witnessed Sir Ken, a trade unionist who puts great store on partnership with managers, jabbing his finger at Mr Moulton as he protested: "I'm bloody disgusted at what's happening." It had not been a good week for a lot of people. Rover's glorious past 1904 Rover produced its first car, an 8hp model. 1906 The Rover Company Ltd was founded. 1912 Rover offered a bigger selection of vehicles than any other firm, with cars from 100 guineas to £600. 1924 The 14/45 hp model made its debut at the Olympia motor show. It incorporated more up-to-date features than any other car of the time. During the war More than 21,000 people were employed producing engines for planes and tanks, aircraft wings and other items. The firm's total wartime turnover was more than £20m. 1948 The Land-Rover was launched at the Amsterdam motor show. 1949 The P4 was launched. Commonly known as the Auntie, it was described as a luxury saloon. 1958 Rover launched the P5, a 3 litre, 6 cylinder saloon which became the choice for royals and prime ministers. 1963 The advanced Rover 2000 (P6) won the Car of the Year award. 1967 Rover merged with the Leyland Motor Corporation. The following year the Leyland group merged with British Motor Holdings to form the British Leyland Motor Corporation. 1976 The classic SD arrived, billed as a large, fastbacked car. 1984 The 200 series was launched, introducing the small car range. 1986 The executive 800 series was launched. 1993 the 600 series of upper medium sector cars was introduced. 1999 The Rover 75 was launched, and described as truly contemporary Sally James

fields.headline: AOL buys out Bertelsmann
fields.standfirst:
US group shoots for the stars in content stake deal

E-finance: special report
AOL
Bertelsmann
fields.trailText: America Online yesterday moved to confirm its position as the pre-eminent global internet company, striking a content deal with Bertelsmann and agreeing to buy out the German media company's stakes in AOL's European and Australian subsidiaries for £5.4bn.
fields.body:
America Online yesterday moved to confirm its position as the pre-eminent global internet company, striking a content deal with Bertelsmann and agreeing to buy out the German media company's stakes in AOL's European and Australian subsidiaries for £5.4bn.

Even in the so-called new economy sector, the swiftness of AOL's deal-making is leaving many industry observers struggling to keep up.

AOL is still completing its £118bn merger with Time Warner, announced in January. Once AOL's merger with Time Warner - a Bertelsmann competitor - was announced, the relationship was expected to come under pressure.

The unbundling of Bertelsmann's investment in AOL was also expected because the German group found the internet service provider busi ness was detracting from its core media activities.

Analysts welcomed the alliance, however. "We regard both announcements as positive for AOL. We believe this will help re-energise the international operations, which in our opinion have been firing on only five [of six] cylinders, in part as a result of the split ownership and responsibility," Merrill Lynch said.

AOL and Bertelsmann have struck a four-year content deal, valued at £163m, in which Bertelsmann will offer media content from its newspaper, music, magazine, book and other entertainment services to AOL's 23m users.

The companies have also agreed for AOL to mop up Bertelsmann's half ownership in AOL Europe and AOL Australia via an option arrangement. AOL will pay £4.4bn to £5.4bn in a number of steps until 2002; alternatively, AOL can pay cash or stock to Bertelsmann after January 31, 2002. Merrill Lynch's valuation of AOL Europe puts the Bertelsmann stake at closer to £13bn. They will cross-promote each other's brands and Bertelsmann will provide broadband distribution for AOL.

Bob Pittman, AOL's chief operating officer, said: "These agreements demonstrate our confidence in both our Bertelsmann partnership and the continued successes of AOL Europe and AOL Australia.

"Our new alliance will deliver Bertelsmann's world-class content and e-commerce properties to the tens of millions of consumers of our multiple brands around the world." Bertelsmann is expected to use the cash to fund further expansion of its e-commerce activities.

Thomas Middelhoff, the Bertelsmann chief executive, said: "By forging this new global strategic alliance Bertelsmann will have the largest world wide distribution of any e-commerce company. "In addition, by restructuring our joint venture relationships with America Online, we will gain substantial new resources to focus on our primary goal - to fully digitise Bertelsmann's media properties and build our position as one of the world's leading internet content and e-com merce companies." Michael Lynton, the president of AOL International, will become acting chief executive officer of AOL Europe, replacing Andreas Schmidt.

There was some speculation of a potential public offering of AOL Europe's shares, which has 3.8m users. Next week American portal Lycos's European arm will make its stock market debut. "We believe AOL management can run this unit more effectively and will be free to pursue an IPO and other strategic arrangements," Merrill Lynch said.

webTitle: Schröder ally drawn into funding scandal funding

fields.headline: Schröder ally drawn into funding scandal funding
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: German state prosecutors yesterday announced that they were investigating a leading figure in the ruling Social Democratic party on suspicion of illegal party financing.
fields.body:
German state prosecutors yesterday announced that they were investigating a leading figure in the ruling Social Democratic party on suspicion of illegal party financing.

Bodo Hombach, who is currently the EU Balkans coordinator, is suspected by the state prosecutor's office in Düsseldorf of illictly channelling £100,000 to an election campaign manager for the Social Democrats (the SPD) between 1994 and 1998.

Mr Hombach is a former close adviser to Gerhard Schröder, who was elected chancellor in October 1998.

Mr Hombach was a key figure in Mr Schröder's campaign and worked as his chief adviser in the chancellery until last year.

A staunch advocate of Blairism, he drafted a joint Social Democrat-Labour policy document with Peter Mandelson last June mapping out the parties' joint commitment to the politics of a "Third Way" alternative to the ideologies of left and right - to the annoyance of the left in the SPD.

"The investigation has only just started," the prosecutor's spokesman, Peter Schwartzwald, said yesterday. "We have reason to suspect that the money came from Mr Hombach's company. He could face a criminal charge for breach of trust."

Mr Schwartzwald said the cash appeared to have been paid by a trading company called Preussag Handel - of which Mr Hombach was director - to an SPD election campaign manager, Harry Walter, in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia.

If convicted Mr Hombach could face a jail term of up to five years. His lawyer, Martina Fromberg, yesterday called the allegations "inaccurate".

The very fact of the charges is an embarrassment to Chancellor Schröder and his government. Corruption was exposed in the SPD-controlled state government of Lower Saxony earlier this year. But Mr Schröder's party has so far avoided any suggestion that illicit party financing involved senior figures.

The SPD's standing has been boosted considerably in recent months because it has appeared untainted on the issue of funding, while the opposition Christian Democrats (CDU) are in crisis because of the scandal over the money-raising activities of their former leader, the ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl.

Before taking on the job last year of running the Balkans stabilisation programme set up after the Kosovo war ended in June, Mr Hombach was already under suspicion: Mr Schröder defended him before a parliamentary inquiry last September over allegations that he had received a discount on the building of an expensive apartment in Düsseldorf in return for official favours. The inquiry was unable to substantiate the charges.

The Hombach investigation doubtless pleased Mr Kohl. The former chancellor made his first appearance in the Berlin Reichstag since November yesterday to attend a 10-year anniversary ceremony marking the first free elections held by the East German parliament. He avoided TV crews by using a back entrance.

Last week he had managed to collect nearly all of the money - equalling £1.84m - to pay the fine imposed on his party for his illegal funding. The cash was provided by celebrities, friends and a second mortgage on Mr Kohl's home.

The CDU scandal is still not laid to rest, however. Yesterday the state prosecutor in Augsburg - whose investigations first exposed the Kohl funding affair - said that unspecified charges were being laid against two of the main protagonists. They are the German-Canadian business middleman, Karlheinz Schreiber, and Mr Kohl's former party treasurer, Walther Leisler Kiep.

Mr Schreiber says he handed 1m deutschmarks (currently worth more than £300,000) to Mr Kiep in a Swiss supermarket car park in 1991.

The prosecutor said two senior mangers of the German arms firm Thyssen had also been charged. One of them, Winfried Haastert, announced his immediate resignation yesterday from the board of Thyssen-Krupp Automotive.
