fields.headline: Internet nerves depress World Online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Flotation of World Online, Europe's largest internet stock offer to date, did little to dispel general nervousness about dot.com valuations yesterday.
fields.body:
Flotation of World Online, Europe's largest internet stock offer to date, did little to dispel general nervousness about dot.com valuations yesterday.

Shares in the heavily hyped company ended their first day of trading only marginally above the offer price.

The stock opened at 50.2 euro (£31), a 16.7% premium to the 43 euro offer price set earlier in the day, but fell back to close at 43.20 euro, valuing the company at 11.8bn euro. On Thursday the grey market was predicting World Online shares would reach 75 euro when trading began on the Amsterdam bourse, having pitched that at 135 euro before this week's technology stocks sell-off.

World Online's usually forthright founder, Nina Brink, yesterday said only: "I'm happy, and that's it."

Analysts in Holland said there was a feeling of anti-climax in the market, even though World Online shares had to be suspended at one stage to cope with the volume of trades. One leading British internet analyst said World Online, as a pan-European internet service provider, suffered from not having a market leading position in any one country.

"They've spread themselves too thin. It's no good being number five in a load of countries, it's better to do a Freeserve and be number one in a key market."

World Online has been buying smaller ISPs, such as Telinco Networks and Bun.com in the UK, and analysts expect the strategy of growth by acquisition to continue. However, fund managers are being advised to save their cash for next month's flotation of Germany's T-Online, an ISP which is being spun out of Deutsche Telekom. "There is a handful of European stars and T-Online is one of them, along with Terra Networks of Spain, Wannadoo of France and Tin.it of Italy," the London analyst said. "Freeserve could join them, but I doubt World Online will."

World Online's largest share holder is the Sandoz family of Switzerland with 43%, followed by Reggebogh Participates with 10% and Intel's 8%.

 Bizzbuild.com, the first pre-IPO placing made through Durlacher's online service nothingventured.com, has closed 11 times oversubscribed.

Huge demand from retail in vestors means 132 shares at 250p apiece will be issued to each valid application, the company said.

Shares in the e-commerce development group are expected to start trading on March 21. Bizzbuild's assets include 54% of online domestic electrical products retailer Value-Direct.

webTitle: Vendors on the net brought to book

fields.headline: Vendors on the net brought to book
fields.standfirst:
Jill Papworth investigates whether the price war raging among online booksellers spells the best deal for the consumer

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: As literary deals are struck at the London International Book Fair, the book world's major trade show which kicks off tomorrow at Kensington Olympia, where can the reading public get the best deal when buying a book?
fields.body:
As literary deals are struck at the London International Book Fair, the book world's major trade show which kicks off tomorrow at Kensington Olympia, where can the reading public get the best deal when buying a book?

The price war raging among internet booksellers as they battle for market share supremacy suggests you are likely to find the best cover price discounts by shopping online.

But as a Jobs & Money snapshot survey reveals, the story is not straightforward. Prices for popular best-selling titles vary enormously from vendor to vendor and while it is usually cheaper to buy from internet bookshops, no one online vendor seems to consistently offer the cheapest deals. What's more, in some instances you can get a better discount from high street retailers.

The conclusion is that, if you know what books you want and you've got the time, it's worth shopping around for the best price on individual titles.

Of course, many book lovers would agree that if your aim is to browse the shelves before choosing a book to buy, there is no online substitute for visiting a real store where you can handle the books, read the blurb and sample the texts. Buying from a real bookshop also gives you the advantage of being able to get the book on the spot rather than having to wait an average two days for delivery from an online vendor.

In this Jobs & Money survey, we compared prices for the top three books from the hardback and paperback fiction and non-fiction bestseller lists compiled by Bookwatch from data supplied by BookTrack's nationwide sample of sales from 4,600 outlets over seven days ending 26 February.

First stop was the internet where a query about how to find the best book prices addressed to the Ask Jeeves site (www.ask.co.uk) linked me to the hugely time-saving and useful Shopgenie site (www.shopgenie.co.uk) which searches online stores for the best prices on various goods.

In its book section, you simply have to type in the author and title of your chosen book and specify whether you want prices for the hardback or paperback edition. One click of the mouse and, within a minute, the screen displays three charges - the price, P&P cost and price including P&P - for your requested book from seven internet booksellers. One more click and it will sort them into best buy order. Shopgenie compares prices for Amazon (www.amazon.co.uk); Alphabetstreet (www.alphabetstreet.infront.co.uk); Bol (www.bol.com); Countrybookstore (www.countrybookstore.co.uk); the Internet Bookshop, part of WH Smith Online (www.bookshop.co.uk); the Book Place (www.thebookplace.com); and Waterstones Online (www.waterstones.co.uk). The results for the 12 bestselling titles varied enough to show that it is impossible to predict which vendor will be offering the best price, including post and packing, on any one title. So, if you want to buy a particular bestseller online, it is worth doing a quick search first to find out where you'll get the best deal.

But if you want to buy several books at a time, it may be cheaper to stick to one supplier because of the minimum delivery charges levied by some online vendors. Free postage and packing is on offer from Alphabetstreet and Countrybookstore.

For book deliveries to UK addresses, Amazon and Waterstones Online charge £1.95 plus 50p per book; Bol charges a flat £2.95 per delivery; the Internet Bookshop charges 15% of the ordered books' full price with a minimum charges of £1.95 and maximum £6; and the Book Place charges £2 for the first book plus £1.75 for each subsequent book.

After obtaining prices from internet vendors, we asked Waterstones and WHSmith for their instore prices for the same list of bestsellers. Neither retailer charges the same for titles in store as via their internet outlets.

One could argue that to be scrupulously fair, when com paring the high street store prices with internet bookseller prices one should add the cost of return travel to the nearest branch.

Taking our sample of 12 bestsellers, Alphabetstreet offered the cheapest price including delivery charges for four titles (including one joint best price with Countrybookstore), the Internet Bookshop for three, Waterstones high street stores for two, Countrybookstore for two (including one joint with Alphabetstreet) and Amazon and Waterstones Online each took credit for one best price.

If you have an independent bookshop nearby, one final tip is to check whether they are willing to match any best price you find elsewhere, including those on offer from online booksellers.

Taking our sample of 12 bestsellers, Alphabetstreet offered the cheapest price including delivery charges for four titles (including one joint best price with Countrybookstore), the Internet Bookshop for three, Waterstones high street stores for two, Countrybookstore for two (including one joint with Alphabetstreet) and Amazon and Waterstones Online each took credit for one best price. If you have an independent bookshop nearby, one final tip is to check whether they are willing to match any best price you find elsewhere, including those on offer from online booksellers.

fields.headline: 'Blunt' analyst breaks golden rule
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Terry Smith, the outspoken City analyst famously sacked in 1992 for publishing unflattering research on big potential clients of the then Union Bank of Switzerland, is reported to have made upwards of £30m profit on his investment in an e-commerce venture 18 months ago.
fields.body:
Terry Smith, the outspoken City analyst famously sacked in 1992 for publishing unflattering research on big potential clients of the then Union Bank of Switzerland, is reported to have made upwards of £30m profit on his investment in an e-commerce venture 18 months ago.

The man whose guide to spotting dodges in company reports was titled Accounting for Growth is now accounting for a spectacular personal gain in his involvement with procurement group Infobank - practically dead in the water at the end of 1998 and now one of the success stories of the net shares boom.

There seems to be just one fly in the ointment for the "analyst without portfolio" at broker Collins Stewart: he is thought to be still holding some of the shares, thus breaking his own golden rule: "Cash is fact - everything else is opinion."

Mr Smith's "staggering personal profit" was disclosed yesterday on the Citywire news service, which reported him as saying that his gain, while "a significant sum", was not as high as the £40m suggested.

Collins Stewart helped put together a rescue of Infobank at the end of 1998 when the shares dropped from 330p to just over 33p.

The online procurement group has since signed deals with, among others, local government and its shares surged at one point to more than £40, although they have since settled at closer to £30.

Mr Smith was not available for comment last night. He is thought to be part of a team trying to buy Collins from its owner, the independent mer chant bank Singer & Friedlander, which has just announced plans to sell off its stockbroking outfits before the share bubble bursts.

It was in 1987, when working for securities group BZW, that Mr Smith's blunt personal style first came to light. He was a banking industry analyst with the temerity to suggest clients sell shares in Barclays, the parent of BZW.

In 1992 he was back in the news when UBS tried to suppress publication of the first edition of Accounting for Growth, in which Mr Smith alleged many of the success stories of the 1980s owed their growth to fancy accounting.

At least one UBS client was offended and Mr Smith was sacked. Unrepentant, he published a second edition in 1996, detailing ways round the "reformed" accounting system.

In 1996 it emerged he had dabbled as a franchisee of the Athena poster chain, and insisted on exercising his option in 1994 to sell the franchises back to parent group Pentos. His timing was impeccable - the month after he received his money, Athena went into receivership.

fields.headline: How lastminute.com clicks with users
fields.standfirst:
Investors flocked to invest in the online travel seller, but how does the service compare with other ways of buying trips?

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: After weeks of hype lastminute.com - the internet site that promises great deals on everything from a weekend in New York to a box of the finest Cuban cigars - went public this week.
fields.body:
After weeks of hype lastminute.com - the internet site that promises great deals on everything from a weekend in New York to a box of the finest Cuban cigars - went public this week.

Despite the company never having shown a profit, more than 200,000 investors rushed to buy in: shares rocketed from the opening price of 380p to 555p on the first morning of trading, sending the stock market value of lastminute.com up from £570m to £832m.

The biggest winners were the company's creators, Oxford graduate Martha Lane-Fox and Old Etonian Brent Hoberman, who have come to epitomise the new generation of internet entrepreneurs.

But not everybody is convinced. Some City analysts have warned against internet investments.

Others have described lastminute.com, which began by selling bargain basement flights but now offers everything from theatre to football tickets, as a triumph of marketing over content.

Defenders of the company argue that it is more than just a bucket travel shop. It is designed for the cash rich twentysomething generation with either not enough time or imagination.

Does lastminute.com live up to the hype? The Guardian road tested some of the deals available to try to find out.

Return flights to Paris

It's spring, so it has to be a weekend in Paris.

By internet:

Logging on to the lastminute.com website we are told they're offering flights from only £87 per person including airport tax.

Seven clicks of the mouse later and we're nearly on the plane, despite the problem of the only flight available on the day we want to travel leaving at 6.45am and the first flight back being at a similarly ungodly hour four days later.

But with the final click of the mouse a worrying development arises. "Sorry. We might not be able to deliver those tickets in time," a warning sign informs us. "For flights leaving before 2pm on the day you have chosen, you generally need to book before 3pm two days in advance."

It would appear lastminute.com isn't quite so last minute after all. We are given a telephone number to call where they would try to arrange delivery.

An electronic switchboard puts us through to an attendant at Apollo Travel, which apparently handles flight inquiries for the company. There is a surcharge of £3.50 to courier the tickets to Heathrow for us to pick up on arrival.

The total price of two tickets would work out at £180.

By phone:

Directory inquiry gives us the number of Thomas Cook Direct, where a woman says we need to call a subsidiary, Flight Direct.

"When were you planning to travel?" Gavin in the call centre asks. Tomorrow is the wrong answer. "I'm sorry, there's no way we would be able to get the tickets to you in time. We're in Peterborough and the courier van leaves for London once a day and it's already gone."

But he helpfully gives the number of British Airways and suggests we try them direct.

We get through to their call centre. Availability is not a problem. We can fly out of Heathrow at 9pm on Friday night returning on a late flight on Sunday in good time for work on Monday morning.

But you have to pay for the choice. Two return tickets plus taxes adds up to £302, more than £120 above lastminute.com's price.

Verdict:

Lastminute.com was quicker and cheaper, but flight availability was too limited.

A sporting event

The England rugby team take on Italy in the Six Nations championship in Rome today.

By Internet:

Lastminute.com is offering a package to the game for £169 per person.

Clicking the more information button we are told the flight would leave at 7am from Stansted, arriving in Rome mid-morning, and that we would be transferred to a location near the ground where we could have a drink and a sandwich before the match. Our tickets would be sent to the airport for collection.

After the final whistle we would be transferred to the city centre, where we would have plenty of time to find somewhere for a drink and a meal before heading back to the airport for a late evening flight to London.

But there is a problem: halfway down the more information page the price of the trip appears to have suddenly doubled to £339 per person. After phoning the hotline we are told it is a glitch in the computer system, but the price is £169. New technology is clearly not infallible after all.

A couple of clicks later and we're on our way to Rome.

By phone:

Trying to get to the match through more conventional routes is not quite so simple. Ticketmaster does not sell tickets, and neither does Keith Prowse. But it gives us the number of a broker who is offering tickets for the match for £95 per person.

This company can also arrange the same package as Lastminute.com, but this time the price is £225. Not such a good deal.

Verdict:

Lastminute.com was quicker and much cheaper.

A weekend away

A sudden need for a change of scene. It doesn't matter where, just as long as it's away.

By internet:

Lastminute.com is offering two nights at the apparently sumptuous Tylney Hall Hotel in Hampshire. An executive double room, including dinner and breakfast, works out at £185. Bed and breakfast rates for the same room work out at £99. Both offers come with a bottle of champagne.

By phone:

The price at the same hotel works out to be almost exactly the same. But it was easier to find on the internet.

Verdict:

Not much in it.

fields.headline: Financial websites fall down
fields.standfirst:
The challenge of the net is not being met, says Jessica McCallin

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Personal finance providers are failing to rise to the internet challenge and the market is suffering. Industry magazine Retail Finance Strategies ranked the websites of the top 100 UK financial services providers in terms of what they provide to customers and found most of them lacking.
fields.body:
Personal finance providers are failing to rise to the internet challenge and the market is suffering. Industry magazine Retail Finance Strategies ranked the websites of the top 100 UK financial services providers in terms of what they provide to customers and found most of them lacking.

"The majority of financial sites have sparse functionality and limited content, while design and branding is either over-ambitious to the detriment of site navigation or so ill-conceived that it damages the image of the company as a whole," says Edward Humphrey, editor of Retail Finance Strategies. "Despite the innovations of a select few, the vast majority show an alarming lack of strategic planning."

Axa, HSBC and Standard Life Bank were among the worst scorers. Out of a possible 100 points, the survey gave them only, respectively, 56 points, 47 and 62.

Retail Finance Strategies pointed to these websites' limited functionality - customers can get online quotes but not buy over the internet - and clumsy and confusing navigation as features which let them down.

Some companies were also accused of playing catch up to keep their investors happy. Mr Humphrey says: "All the internet ventures announced during the AGM season seem to be more about keeping analysts and shareholders happy, not the customers."

Some sites, naturally, fared better than others. Nationwide Building Society topped the list, scoring 91 out of 100.

The ability to buy almost all Nationwide products, including mortgages, loans and credit cards through the internet was praised by the report's authors. High quality content, links to other sites, including its own football site - the building society is a major sponsor of football in the UK - and the fact that Nationwide is an internet service provider all made for extra brownie points.

Citibank, Egg and Natwest came second, third and fourth. All were deemed to have good functionality and an easy navigation system. These results are made more pertinent by the findings of Datamonitor market analysts on what makes people use internet banking.

The analysts conclude that the number of internet bankers will grow by 30% in the next five years, reaching 5.3m, and that the biggest determinant in who these people bank with will be the level of service they get.

The rise of tailor-made products and increasing competition over rates means the only way internet banks can distinguish themselves is in the service they give their customers, it says.

It also found that online users of financial services tend to be young and know what the internet can do and expect their banks and fund managers to know as well.

Additional services such as online finance guides, homepage customisation and the ability to access accounts through internet service providers like Yahoo and AOL are ways of giving a better service through the website, says the report.

Offering competitors' products on your website was also flagged up as good customer service. Datamonitor believes that if customers can access other companies' banking products through one website, they are more likely to use that website for all their internet banking.

Banks were the most consistent performers in the Retail Finance Strategies study, with the top 10 banks all scoring 77 points or more.

The top 10 building societies, on the other hand ranged between 91 points to 58.

The top 10 fund managers received similar rankings to the building societies. In the number one spot was Fidelity Investments with 84 points out of 100. Perpetual, in 10th place, scored 58 points.

The range of points for the top 10 insurers was tighter, with the number one insurer, Legal & General, being awarded 83 points and the number 10 insurer, Skandia Life, getting 66.

fields.headline: A time to be generous
fields.standfirst:
Time too for Mr Brown to tame the pound

The budget: special report
fields.trailText: There ought to be two overriding objectives in next week's budget: the need to find money to finance much higher spending on health and education, and measures to bring down the value of the pound.
fields.body:
There ought to be two overriding objectives in next week's budget: the need to find money to finance much higher spending on health and education, and measures to bring down the value of the pound. There is now strong public support for higher public spending, as reflected in a poll in this week's Economist, showing that Britain is unique among 17 countries surveyed in having a majority of people prepared to pay tax to fund better services. An impressive 91% wanted more spent on health, and 81% more on education.

On the strong pound, the government - after wilfully neglecting the issue - has been shamed into considering it by political repercussions from the breakup of Rover's Longbridge operations. BMW cited the overvaluation of the pound as a major factor in its decision to shed its troublesome subsidiary - a move that seems bound to cost jobs in the area. Here is a brutal reminder to Labour, already reeling from claims that it is neglecting its heartlands, that the 16 seats won from the Conservatives in the West Midlands in 1997 could be vulnerable if it is seen to abandon manufacturing to the vagaries of the markets.

But can anything be done? As he puts the final touches to his speech, Gordon Brown could be forgiven for feeling imprisoned by his own success. A combination of fiscal restraint (or raising taxes as Mr Hague would put it) and stronger than expected economic growth has left him surfing on a tidal wave of a budget surplus - around £10bn - that no previous Labour chancellor would even have dared to dream about. The trouble is he cannot easily spend it for fear that by doing so he might overheat the economy. Raising taxes would be one option - but hardly an easy one when Mr Hague is trying to turn lower taxation into a moral crusade. Nor is it an easy economic one at a time when the treasury fears that the economy is overheating. If the chancellor increases spending to improve education and the health service, unfunded by higher taxes, then the economy may expand so fast that the Bank of England will be forced to put interest rates up yet again. That could force up sterling still higher thereby turning the demise of key parts of manufacturing - and farming - into a rout.

Truth to tell, what is really needed now is not lower but higher taxes so that fiscal policy can assume more of the job of cooling down the overheating economy. That would create the conditions that would enable the Bank of England to lower interest rates, which are now nearly twice as high as those in the rest of Europe. Most of the proceeds of higher taxes should be used to finance the improvements in education and health that the citizens of the UK clearly want. The rest can be used to take money out of the economy so that higher interest rates do not need to be used to do it. This is not an easy thing for any chancellor to do with a general election looming on the horizon next year, but if the result is that this year's expected economic growth of over 3% (way above the 2.5% regarded as sustainable) is reined back to something more realistic, then everyone will gain in the long term.

Mr Brown has a matchless talent for raising taxes by stealth so that hardly anyone notices. He now needs to show a matching skill in precision targeting on the fiscal side, so that his tax increases hit the economy only where it needs to be hit. Far better to increase the higher rates of stamp duty, or even to introduce a modest capital gains tax on house sales - which would dampen the southern housing boom - than to take the blunderbuss of interest rates to spray bullets across the whole economy, manufacturing industry and all.

The chancellor has been extremely astute in redistributing income from the better off to the working poor and in encouraging the unemployed back to work without, at least until recently, unduly upsetting Daily Mail readers. He has plenty of scope to make for further stealthy incursions - making the rich pay their fair share of national insurance contributions, for instance, and, maybe, raising money from increases in the value of land. And wouldn't most people be prepared to see more tax imposed on their estates when they are dead, if that brought the reward of better health facilities now that might prolong their lives?

Budgets need to redesign not just the economy but society too. It is one year ago today that the prime minister committed Labour to eliminating child poverty within the next 20 years. By the end of this parliament, Labour will have lifted almost 1m children above the poverty line (half average income). But that still leaves 3.8m to go. A combination of welfare to work schemes, increases in child benefits and children's allowances for income support claimants, and minimum pay and new childcare allowances have all helped. But now the difficulties begin. There are no more easy redistribution options, like the married couple's allowance, left. Mr Brown has promised an integrated child credit, but so far we have had no firm figures. A special allowance for children under five, the stage in their lives in which parents are normally most stretched, would be one welcome relief. But what is really needed is a coherent strategy plan on how the chancellor aims to accomplish the goal, with an open invitation to the Tories to sign up to it.

Labour's second most ambitious social goal - lifting health spending to the European average over the next six years - is still stuck in a statistical quagmire. There can be no backtracking now. It was Mr Blair who said British health spending was too low at the moment, and his government would bring it up to the European average. That implies annual rises above 5% for each of the next five years. The prime minister will be aware of how much damage the government's squeeze on health in its first two years eroded public confidence. From being Labour's strongest card, health has now slumped, with a startling 41% in a Guardian/ICM poll believing the NHS is getting worse - and only 14% of respondents seeing any improvement.

Labour's first priority - education, education, education - remains desperately short of funds. More has been invested. There is good news in the primary sector, particularly the advance in literacy and numeracy standards. But even after Labour's infamous claim of a £19bn increase, rightly exploded in Nick Davies's Guardian series on schools earlier this month, the government still spends less of national income on education than John Major did in his first year as prime minister. This budget gives Gordon Brown the chance to recapture the loyalty of Labour's heartlands while retaining his reputation as an iron chancellor. He should go for it.

By the end of this parliament, Labour will have lifted almost 1m children above the poverty line (half average income). But that still leaves 3.8m to go. A combination of welfare to work schemes, increases in child benefits and children's allowances for income support claimants, and minimum pay and new childcare allowances have all helped. But now the difficulties begin. There are no more easy redistribution options, like the married couple's allowance, left. Mr Brown has promised an integrated child credit, but so far we have had no firm figures. A special allowance for children under five, the stage in their lives in which parents are normally most stretched, would be one welcome relief. But what is really needed is a coherent strategy plan on how the chancellor aims to accomplish the goal, with an open invitation to the Tories to sign up to it. Labour's second most ambitious social goal - lifting health spending to the European average over the next six years - is still stuck in a statistical quagmire. There can be no backtracking now. It was Mr Blair who said British health spending was too low at the moment, and his government would bring it up to the European average. That implies annual rises above 5% for each of the next five years. The prime minister will be aware of how much damage the government's squeeze on health in its first two years eroded public confidence. From being Labour's strongest card, health has now slumped, with a startling 41% in a Guardian/ICM poll believing the NHS is getting worse - and only 14% of respondents seeing any improvement. Labour's first priority - education, education, education - remains desperately short of funds. More has been invested. There is good news in the primary sector, particularly the advance in literacy and numeracy standards. But even after Labour's infamous claim of a £19bn increase, rightly exploded in Nick Davies's Guardian series on schools earlier this month, the government still spends less of national income on education than John Major did in his first year as prime minister. This budget gives Gordon Brown the chance to recapture the loyalty of Labour's heartlands while retaining his reputation as an iron chancellor. He should go for it.

webTitle: New rules to stop hospital cruelty

fields.headline: New rules to stop hospital cruelty
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers will next week issue strict rules to protect vulnerable adults from abuse, after an inquiry report yesterday exposed "degrading and cruel" treatment of elderly dementia patients at a hospital in Carlisle.
fields.body:
Ministers will next week issue strict rules to protect vulnerable adults from abuse, after an inquiry report yesterday exposed "degrading and cruel" treatment of elderly dementia patients at a hospital in Carlisle.

Alan Milburn, health secretary, dismissed the chairwoman of the NHS trust responsible for the unit, where no disciplinary action was taken when abuse was first uncovered.

Nursing staff were found to have sworn at patients, roughly manhandled them, fed them while they were on the toilet and, in one case, tied a man to a commode.

Some patients were denied ordinary food, being given a "grunge" diet of pureed fruit, bran and yoghurt. Staff who disagreed with this resorted to trying to smuggle solid food into the ward.

On one occasion, the inquiry found, two frail elderly women patients were put out of the ward into a verandah area, without adequate clothing or blankets.

The scandal, at the former Kielder House unit run by the North Lakeland trust, is the latest of a series of cases of abuse of vulnerable adults in hospitals and care homes.

On Monday, the government will unveil new guidance designed to prevent such abuse.

Mr Milburn said the report had revealed disturbing practice and "an unhealthy atmosphere of claim, counter-claim and suspicion" at the trust.

The chairwoman, Mary Styth, has had her contract terminated. The chief executive, Alan Place, has been suspended since last August and now, with other staff, faces possible disciplinary action.

The inquiry was an external review, set up at Mrs Styth's request in April last year after two earlier internal investigations of allegations of abuse - the first as long ago as 1996.

That investigation found much of the malpractice and abuse now confirmed. But no staff were disciplined, and the second investigation, in 1998, centred on some of the same individuals, including a ward manager, and what yesterday's report calls "remarkably similar or identical" allegations.

Disciplinary action in 1998 led to one dismissal and three warnings, with the manager - a senior nurse - resigning ahead of a disciplinary hearing.

The inquiry team, led by Dianne Jeffrey, who chairs a community health trust in north Derbyshire, was initially not told of the 1996 investigation and had to request a copy of the report. The team says it found it "alarming and distressing" reading.

Concluding that an unacceptable culture of care existed at Kielder, which had 30 beds, the team says: "Unprofessional, counter-therapeutic and degrading - even cruel - practices were used by some staff and, at times, condoned by others on the ward."

The trust and the local North Cumbria health authority has apologised unreservedly to Keilder patients and their families.

Keilder closed a year ago.

webTitle: Vote tests Taiwan's nerve against China

fields.headline: Vote tests Taiwan's nerve against China
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: China is about to discover whether its denunciations of the pro-independence candidate in today's Taiwanese presidential election have intimidated the voters or provoked a defiant backlash on the island.
fields.body:
China is about to discover whether its denunciations of the pro-independence candidate in today's Taiwanese presidential election have intimidated the voters or - as in 1996 when Beijing's navy fired missiles offshore before the ballot - have provoked a defiant backlash on the island.

On the eve of today's vote in Taiwan, William Cohen - the US defence secretary who is currently visiting Japan - said that if China ratcheted up the pressure on Taipei to abandon its independence, that would increase demands in the US congress that more arms be supplied to Taiwan.

In Washington, the state department said it was urging "prudence and patience" on Beijing, and reiterated that force was not the way to deal with differences over Taiwan's status.

The vote count in Taiwan starts tonight, with most eyes on the tally for Chen Shui-bian, the man who has Beijing rattled. In a race that looks close, he is the front-running candidate of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive party (DPP).

Despite China's sabre-rattling - which included a threat that force might be used if Taiwan indefinitely avoided unification talks - unofficial soundings still suggested yesterday that Mr Chen was maintaining his narrow lead.

His two main rivals are James Soong, an independent, and Lien Chan, the candidate for the ruling Nationalist (Kuomintang or KMT) party and the man Beijing is believed to prefer.

The KMT's television adverts portray Mr Chen as likely to "lead Taiwan into turmoil" because he is resisting Chinese demands for unification talks. He has retorted by urging the voters to "use your ballots to ward off the KMT's missiles."

For the second day, the government dug into a previously untouched stabilisation fund to shore up Taiwan's stock market, jittery at China's threats and the possibility of a president from outside the ruling party so familiar to investors, the KMT.

At tumultuous evening rallies in the capital last night, Mr Chen's supporters hailed him as a "real Taiwanese" who would lead the island away from the "black gold" corruption of the KMT.

Mr Soong, the independent, was praised by his camp as "a man who gets things done", while Mr Lien's supporters insisted that only he can deal with Beijing.

Mr Chen sought to defuse Beijing's attacks by promising to lead a mixed delegation, including his opponents, to China if he is elected. He also pledged that as president he would "stop taking part" in the activities of the DPP.

The current president, Lee Teng-hui, mocked Mr Chen's recent offer of talks with Beijing. "First Number 5 (Mr Chen's position on the ballot paper) talks of independence", he told supporters, "then when China threatens force he says something else. Going to Beijing would just make Taiwan lose face."

Looking for a way to stop a Chen victory, senior KMT figures have switched to Mr Soong, the independent, in the last two days as Mr Lien appeared to be losing ground. They appealed to the voters to "dump Lien and save Soong".

The Lien campaign's tactics suggested increasing nervousness that the KMT may finally lose the presidency - though it still dominates the island's current legislature.

Beijing kept silent yesterday having last raised the temperature on Wednesday when the Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, warned Taiwanese voters to "make the right choice", saying that otherwise they "might not have the chance to regret it."

One Taiwanese official noted sarcastically that Beijing's denunciation of the DPP opposition gave the appearance of a new "united front" between the Chinese Communists and the KMT - who were allies during two periods before the civil war.

Analysts say that China is deeply frustrated because all three main candidates see Taiwan as effectively a separate state, though only Mr Chen has so far dared to call it "independent".

Mr Lien supports President Lee's current formula of "state-to-state relations" with China which enraged Beijing last year, while Mr Soong says that the relationship is "quasi- international".

The popular mood is in favour of maintaining the status quo without a formal declaration.

fields.headline: Sleeping with the fishes
fields.standfirst: The fish I'm looking after has so far contented itself with occasionally pretending to be dead. Then, at other times, it becomes quite frisky
fields.trailText: The fish I'm looking after has so far contented itself with occasionally pretending to be dead. Then, at other times, it becomes quite frisky
fields.body:
Here in New York, I have been put in charge of a small tropical fish. Its owner has gone to Los Angeles to organise Vanity Fair's annual Oscars party, and won't be back until the end of the month. Her parting instructions were minimal. I was asked just to sprinkle a little fish food on it from time to time. That was all. I wasn't told how much food to give it or how often (if at all) to change its water.

I have never looked after a fish before, and everyone tells me it is a difficult task. For example, fish do not know how to stop eating: if you give them too much food, they burst. And changing a fish's water is a delicate operation: not only is the fish easily lost in the process, but the water has to be the right temperature or it may die. It may well die anyway, of course. Fish usually do.

This fish has so far contented itself with occasionally pretending to be dead. At other times, it is quite frisky. But it has very little space to be frisky in - its home is a square glass jar on top of a desk; so small and square that it cannot even do circles. A visitor to the office the other day said he thought that its owner should be charged with fish abuse. But I don't suppose he knows any more about fish than I do, and the size of the jar is probably just right for a fish of this particular kind.

It is not a colourful fish. In fact, it is completely black. But it is curious to look at, having several seemingly superfluous fins almost as big as its little body. It's a bit like several fishes stuck together. This appearance suggests rarity - and therefore considerable expense if it should die and have to be replaced before its owner returns from Hollywood. Maybe it is a million-dollar fish and we will have to sell the house in London.

When I aired this anxiety to Chris Garrett, the managing editor of Vanity Fair, she told me a cautionary tale about a dog that was flown from Europe to New York to be re-united with its lady owner. It travelled in a crate in the hold, but turned out on arrival to be dead.

The airline staff could not face the idea of presenting the owner with a corpse, so they rang her to say that her dog was now arriving on a later flight and spent the time thus gained searching the pet shops of New York for one that looked the same. Returning triumphant from their mission, they replaced the dead dog in the crate with a living one, and told the owner that her dog was now ready for collection. When she arrived and saw it, she shrieked and then fainted. Her dog had died in Europe, and she had been bringing it home for burial.

There is little relevance in this story to my dilemma, but I was much amused to hear it. I suspect that fish anxiety is widespread. In the 80s, when President Reagan was about to hold his first meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev in Switzerland, he rented a villa from the Aga Khan on the shore of Lake Geneva. One of the Aga Khan's children had left a note in the house asking him to keep an eye on the goldfish. At the appointed time, the President's chief of staff, Donald Regan, came by to pick him up and take him to the historic summit. He found Mr Reagan standing gravely in front of the fish tank. "Don, we've got a problem," he said. One of the goldfish was lying dead on the bottom. So, as the peace of the world hung in the balance, members of the President's staff were urgently dispatched to find a replacement.

If only the fish in my care were a humble goldfish, instead of this strange, multi-finned specimen, I would have rather less to worry about. In case you are wondering how I find myself in this situation, the answer is that I am spending a month in New York working at Vanity Fair, thanks to the kindness of its editor, Graydon Carter. By the time you read this, he and all of his senior staff will have gone to Hollywood for the great Oscars extravaganza. It is the most popular party of the year, and Carter writes in the current issue of his magazine that he has been besieged by people angling for invitations.

I haven't been one of them, though. I am perfectly happy where I am; and anyway, I have an onerous duty to perform here in New York.

fields.headline: Fuzzy Feltz
fields.standfirst: As a celebrity, Vanessa Feltz is about as celebrated as leprosy; as a popular television personality, she is about as popular as piles
fields.trailText: As a celebrity, Vanessa Feltz is about as celebrated as leprosy; as a popular television personality, she is about as popular as piles
fields.body:
Some time ago, in that mythical land of milk and money we call the 80s, I wrote a piece called Apocalypse Now (Please) for the Face magazine, in which I posited the notion that some people, far from finding the thought of imminent disaster distressing, positively relished it with an enjoyment that was well-nigh sexual.

At the time, you could find this idea of sexy disaster in many strands of work: Frankie Goes To Hollywood were everywhere, leering, "We're living in a world where SEX and HORROR are the new gods", while Martin Amis, bless him, had just discovered these really nasty things called nuclear weapons. On the other (right) hand, the newsprint moralists were getting themselves into a similar squirmy state alongside such Amockalypsists (my word: yes, I know it doesn't quite work) as Mrs Victoria Gillick, who chose, somewhat insanely, to view sexual generosity as a sign of the decline of the West. This was when the Daily Mail really stepped up the why-oh-why? editorials, and it hasn't stopped whining yet.

Surveying both contingents in the gleefully despairing galère , I could never help but recall a line from a Sparks song: "My parents think the world is cruel/I think that they prefer it cruel." The fact is that most mildly intelligent people - of which the media, the arts and entertainment are mostly composed - feel too much like peasants if they are optimistic; they want to be the cerebral equivalent of pale and interesting. (Poor Geri Halliwell, with her endless attempts at being "deep", is the most pitiful sufferer from this syndrome.) Therefore, they see demons everywhere, and shout about them ceaselessly; they are the Hoarse Men Of The Amockalypse, who see imminent disaster as little more than aftershave - splash it all over, feel real big.

Since the fall of Communism, penny-a-line alarmists have been looking around for some equally horrid enemy to blame for the ills of the world - and, hopefully, the end of the world, or at least the decline of western civilisation. They periodically try women, gays and immigrants - but that makes them look like big bullies, because women, gays and immigrants are so prone to getting themselves beaten up and killed. In recent months, an enemy has been located who isn't at all weak and vulnerable, but apparently big and strong. The new middlebrow demon is Celebrity, which, like Communism before it, is apparently waiting around every corner to destroy all that is decent and good in our sceptered isle. Celebrity, they say, is the beast that will swallow liberal democracy whole: in a nightmarish Day Of The Locust-type scenario, we all trample each other underfoot trying to get nearer to the healing flame of fame. And this all started in the 80s, apparently!

Myself, I'm not convinced. I believe that people have more contempt and less adoration for the famous now than they have ever had. Think back to the 20s: women killed themselves when Valentino died. Does anyone really believe that Brad Pitt's demise will trigger a rash of suicides? The celebrity stalker was unknown until very recently. In the 50s, Marilyn Monroe's private number was actually in the New York phone book, so trusting was she that no one wanted to harm her. The desire of stars to become literally naked in the eyes of millions of strangers - think of the sublime (J Lopez) and the ridiculous (G Halliwell) in that Versace dress - can only aggravate the contempt that familiarity breeds.

People who rail against celebrity will feel a lot happier if they understand that it's not they who are playing us, but we who are mocking them - as we once toured through Bedlam or baited village idiots - for making such shows of themselves. Sure, they're well paid, but if one's need for attention is so great that one will go out almost naked, money's never going to fill that hole. Contrary to the why-oh-whiners, the cult of celebrity doesn't damage anyone but the celebrities themselves. The rest of us go on with our daily lives and big loves, while they become their masks, often to the destruction of their real lives and loves.

And the more educated you are - the more "equipped" to do something more worthwhile - the worse the effect of celebrity is going to be on you, because you know you're punching below your weight, and you feel worthless. That's why Stephen Fry "suffers" so much from his celebrity, whereas Posh Spice is obviously completely in her element with hers; like Madonna, "famous" was all she wanted to be and all she was fit to be. It's only when you're fit to be something else (Marilyn a great actress, Judy Garland a great singer, moi a great writer) that the trouble starts. Look at Vanessa Feltz - a woman with a first in English literature from Cambridge could have lived a really fulfilling life as a plain academic, single or married to an equally plain, non-flash male academic. But so swept up by the lure of fame was Feltz that, though obviously aware that her raw material is hardly the stuff that dreams are made of, she felt the need to throw her education to the winds and make a living as a sort of ambulatory archive of all that is loud, greedy, neurotic, pushy.

As a celebrity, Feltz is about as celebrated as leprosy; as a popular TV personality, she is about as popular as piles. The things that defined her - her fatness and her happy family life - have now melted into air. Yet she now models the thin, unhappy self as though there is a real demand for it, not realising that a thin Vanessa Feltz has about as much point as a chocolate teapot. Everywhere we turn, we hear her banging on that "telly" is her passion, and now the BBC is going to pour even more good licence payers money after bad in order to further her crazed dreams of populism, when it is obvious to even the blindest soul that the only truly entertaining thing about the poor wretch is not the dismal programmes she propels on to the screen, but the car-crash that is her private life. It is for this service that she is rewarded with millions: for proving, as surely as any medieval mummers play, that pride comes before a fall and that money can't buy you love.

If any celeb-bashing columnist really wants such a job, they can always go and spill their dirtiest, deepest secrets to the Sundays and get one. But I believe they should count their blessings - and not just their wordage - when next tempted to pillory the poor Personality. There, but for a decent agent, go all of us.

And this all started in the 80s, apparently! Myself, I'm not convinced. I believe that people have more contempt and less adoration for the famous now than they have ever had. Think back to the 20s: women killed themselves when Valentino died. Does anyone really believe that Brad Pitt's demise will trigger a rash of suicides? The celebrity stalker was unknown until very recently. In the 50s, Marilyn Monroe's private number was actually in the New York phone book, so trusting was she that no one wanted to harm her. The desire of stars to become literally naked in the eyes of millions of strangers - think of the sublime (J Lopez) and the ridiculous (G Halliwell) in that Versace dress - can only aggravate the contempt that familiarity breeds. People who rail against celebrity will feel a lot happier if they understand that it's not they who are playing us, but we who are mocking them - as we once toured through Bedlam or baited village idiots - for making such shows of themselves. Sure, they're well paid, but if one's need for attention is so great that one will go out almost naked, money's never going to fill that hole. Contrary to the why-oh-whiners, the cult of celebrity doesn't damage anyone but the celebrities themselves. The rest of us go on with our daily lives and big loves, while they become their masks, often to the destruction of their real lives and loves. And the more educated you are - the more "equipped" to do something more worthwhile - the worse the effect of celebrity is going to be on you, because you know you're punching below your weight, and you feel worthless. That's why Stephen Fry "suffers" so much from his celebrity, whereas Posh Spice is obviously completely in her element with hers; like Madonna, "famous" was all she wanted to be and all she was fit to be. It's only when you're fit to be something else (Marilyn a great actress, Judy Garland a great singer, moi a great writer) that the trouble starts. Look at Vanessa Feltz - a woman with a first in English literature from Cambridge could have lived a really fulfilling life as a plain academic, single or married to an equally plain, non-flash male academic. But so swept up by the lure of fame was Feltz that, though obviously aware that her raw material is hardly the stuff that dreams are made of, she felt the need to throw her education to the winds and make a living as a sort of ambulatory archive of all that is loud, greedy, neurotic, pushy. As a celebrity, Feltz is about as celebrated as leprosy; as a popular TV personality, she is about as popular as piles. The things that defined her - her fatness and her happy family life - have now melted into air. Yet she now models the thin, unhappy self as though there is a real demand for it, not realising that a thin Vanessa Feltz has about as much point as a chocolate teapot. Everywhere we turn, we hear her banging on that "telly" is her passion, and now the BBC is going to pour even more good licence payers money after bad in order to further her crazed dreams of populism, when it is obvious to even the blindest soul that the only truly entertaining thing about the poor wretch is not the dismal programmes she propels on to the screen, but the car-crash that is her private life. It is for this service that she is rewarded with millions: for proving, as surely as any medieval mummers play, that pride comes before a fall and that money can't buy you love. If any celeb-bashing columnist really wants such a job, they can always go and spill their dirtiest, deepest secrets to the Sundays and get one. But I believe they should count their blessings - and not just their wordage - when next tempted to pillory the poor Personality. There, but for a decent agent, go all of us.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: My oh my, things have changed round at what some of us still think of as the Daily Worker. Clock the Morningstar.com website and say goodbye to yesteryear's bad-tempered attacks on US foreign policy and demands to "kick the Tories out".
fields.body:
 My oh my, things have changed round at what some of us still think of as the Daily Worker. Clock the Morningstar.com website and say goodbye to yesteryear's bad-tempered attacks on US foreign policy and demands to "kick the Tories out". Instead we have: "Free! Over 300 stock analyses", and: "Are you in a top mutual fund? Find out now". Alas, this is, we learn, one of the top-rated American online investment news services. A little further along the net is to be found our very own Morning Star ("one in every three children lives in poverty [yes, but are they in a top mutual fund?] ... Capitalism doesn't work"). That's more like it. As you were.

 Another puzzler from the world of publishing arrives in the shape of "Issue 01/the pash magazine for stylistic devices". Do what? Glossy pages follow, containing arty pics of young-ish folk in (presumably) trendy gear. The first thing in the way of editorial is an interview with an unnamed "illustrator" who declares, inter enormous alia, "I happen to be pleased with ... many most aesthetically pleasing ... internally meaningful inflections on society". The publisher is in Munich, but the purpose of this jolly periodical is stated nowhere. We won't say "pretentious", but you feel free.

 Disturbing rumours circulate as to the future of the satellite court building at Chichester Rents off Chancery Lane, London. Currently the scene of the Lloyd's civil case hearing, Chichester Rents has lost its status as an Old Bailey offshoot. In 1991, when the first case (Blue Arrow) opened in the Chancery Lane building, the Guardian reminded readers that in days gone by London's "rents", being church land, were havens for suspected persons. True to form, the "hi-tech" fraud trial courtrooms were to provide the scene for notable defeats for the Crown - Blue Arrow, the George Walker trial and Maxwells Kevin and Ian. The lord chancellor's department is aware of the rumours that the rents may be shut down, but "cannot confirm any of it". We fear the worst.

 Elsewhere in the no-future department, the (somewhat premature) obituaries for trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers raise again the "curse of Victoria Street". Should Mr Byers's Rover-and-off problems prove terminal, the DTI's burn-up rate will have increased slightly, from 0.8 secretaries of state per year since 1970 to 0.83. Meanwhile, whereas nasty, Anglo-Saxon, cut-throat, short-termist British Aerospace flogged off Rover after a mere six years, stakeholding caring, sharing long-termist BMW held on to it for, ah, six years.

 Meanwhile, our world-beating spread betting industry has, it seems, shied away from making a price on the survivability of Mr Byers; technically a spread could be created for "Byers Days", said a source at one index betting outfit, pricing his remaining time in office, but "that's so in-your-face ... it's not necessarily a great move for a business". Who says deference is dead? Actually, the bookmakers' reluctance might be down to more than fear of official displeasure. The problem with creating a book on Mr Byers's replacement, said our man, is that you need to price a winner and a runner-up. Surely the pool of cabinet talent hasn't run that dry?

 Not even with the absence of mayoral candidate Frank Dobson, who is allegedly fending off demands from Labour's chief pollster, Phillip Gould, that he shave off his beard. We don't believe a word. Had Mr Gould really discovered evidence that bearded men are thought untrustworthy, he would surely have buried it to spare the feelings of his close friend and Express newspapers chief, the heroically hirsute Lord Hollick?

 On a happier note, those busy-bee savers round at the Nationwide building society have voted the 1929 Wall Street crash "the most momentous monetary moment of the 20th century". But, with a fine grip on bathos, they put British decimalisation a close second and the advent of the cash machine third. Definitions of "momentous", please, on a postcard.

 This week's winner of our super socko competition - in which you nominate names of companies, products or organisations every word of which is inaccurate/misleading/a lie - is Carl Darby of Huntingdon. We pondered this one a bit, given it is somewhat off the Underside's normal ultra-civilian beat, but let it in on the basis of recent reports that espionage outfits are piling into industrial espionage. So, thank you Mr Darby for: "Secret Intelligence Service".

fields.headline: Inadmissible evidence
fields.standfirst:
It is a year since Rosemary Nelson was buried, yet we are no closer to nailing her killers

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: One year ago today, a coffin containing the body of the murdered solicitor, Rosemary Nelson, was carried through the streets of Lurgan, watched or followed by a large part of the town's population
fields.body:
One year ago today, a coffin containing the body of the murdered solicitor, Rosemary Nelson, was carried through the streets of Lurgan, watched or followed by a large part of the town's population. Rosemary was identified with a handful of high-profile cases that made her a hate figure for loyalists and RUC officers, but her day-to-day work involved the rights and needs of many local people, Protestant and Catholic. Her firm dealt with all the mundane things people require from a solicitor. She worked with mixed community groups and with the people who perhaps have the hardest time getting a hearing in Northern Ireland, the travellers.

It is unlikely, however, that this work got her killed. Most of us who knew her, and to whom she spoke about the threats she received, believe that the hands of the British state are not clean in this matter. The British government and the chief constable were well aware of those threats, including a handwritten one, a copy of which was forwarded by the Committee for the Administration of Justice to minister Adam Ingram, who passed it on to the chief constable, Ronnie Flanagan. The government refused to include her in the Key Persons' Protection Scheme.

On Wednesday, the anniversary of her death, a petition bearing 100,000 signatures, calling for an independent inquiry, was delivered to Downing Street. Sadly, the event lost the battle for coverage in the British media. Rosemary did get the odd mention, however, because a man arrested by police investigating her murder was charged with weapons offences and membership of the Loyalist Volunteer Force. This man, who may or may not face charges directly related to Rosemary's murder, was at that time a serving member of the Royal Irish Regiment. The RIR is notorious for overt loyalism and the abuse of the few Catholics in it.

In County Armagh, the RIR work closely with the RUC. On the night when the bomb was attached to Rosemary's car, local people report that there was a remarkable level of activity by the security forces. Efforts by police to explain away helicopter activity as a routine pass over the neighbouring Kilwilkee estate, contrast with residents' reports of helicopters hovering directly over the quiet suburban close where Rosemary lived, for a period of about six hours. People also saw large numbers of soldiers in the surrounding fields, no doubt just having a lie down.

Perhaps this doesn't ring any alarm bells with you, despite the fact that a heightened security presence in the run-up to the state murder of human rights activists is the pattern the world over. You might not even be impressed that Rosemary had received death threats from RUC officers. A young reporter, interviewing me the other day, asked: "The fact that RUC officers threatened her doesn't mean they killed her does it?" Well, perhaps not, but a death threat might be regarded as a lead worth following up. But I suppose it's not much use handing the RUC a suspect on a plate if the suspect is the RUC.

This is why people all over the world, including the UN, Amnesty International and the law societies of England and Wales, Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, call for an international inquiry into this murder. Even if no security service personnel were involved, which I very much doubt, the fact that the investigation is based in Lurgan RUC station makes it more or less pointless. The contempt for Rosemary from many of the officers there, observed by the Independent Commission for Police Complaints, means that the investigation is tainted at best.

Yes, it was taken over by British police officers under Colin Port, but weeks after it had started. First we were told the chief constable of Kent, David Phillips, was running it, excitingly assisted by the FBI. Phillips's mostly-absent involvement was quietly phased out. The Feds hung around for a bit as observers and then said their work was done. The only substantive thing that appeared to happen in those crucial weeks was an advert in the local press calling for witnesses but giving the wrong date and advertising a phone line that was left unmanned. Oh, and officers called at the office of the Committee on the Administration of Justice, to ask if they had an original copy of the hand-written death threat. Somewhat late but at least they took an interest.

Colin Port inherited an investigation designed by Lurgan RUC, including a team of RUC officers, dedicated to investigating collusion. Port has reduced but not ended RUC involvement and is still working out of the same building. With the best will in the world, he hasn't a hope of being able to conduct the investigation in a way that could uncover more than the partial truth.

I'm sure a couple of local loyalist headbangers will go down for this, but the issue will not go away. You will be hearing the name of Rosemary Nelson for many years, which is a good thing, because she deserves that.

webTitle: They were big but they weren't clever

fields.headline: They were big but they weren't clever
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
Deep in the Siberian permafrost, a 47-year-old male mammoth lay entombed. Like many of its brothers and sisters that roamed northern climes during the ice age 20,000 years ago, it had, in life, resembled the elephant. It possessed a trunk, tusks, and a sexy sashay as it went on its way to a career of ball balancing and tutu wearing in prehistoric circuses. Naturally, this was many years before Stalin banned capitalist circuses in Siberia for all mammals, mammoths in particular.

The mammoth was bigger than any elephant. Its tusks were about three metres long. Neanderthal hunters rarely hung mammoth tusks over their mantlepieces for fear that they would ruin the plasterwork. Hence the tradition for fish in display cases in early domestic decoration. The mammoth smelled of urine even when the Siberian air did its best to neutralise such niffs. Unlike the elephant, it was innocent of the pleasure of eating a banana messily.

The mammoth often cut a doleful figure as it lolloped across the tundra in search of nutritious plant life. It was so burly that it knew no enemy but man. Sometimes, the death toll that resulted from climactic changes was so severe that the mammoth suffered from depression. As it migrated and evolved, the mammoth grew thick hair all over its body and its ears shrank from large flaps to little lugs. The mammoth, then, was uncannily like Frank Dobson.

In Raising the Mammoth (Discovery), a team of French, Russian, American and Dutch men with parkas and PhDs decided they would dig the mammoth out of the ground in a cube of permafrost and fly the thing by helicopter to a nearby city. It would then be deposited in a man-made underground cavern.

Cynics might have suggested that to move a 6 tonne block of cold earth and long-dead hairy monster from one Siberian hole to another was the height of futility. But this wasn't a futile excavation. Oh no. Scientists, speaking with the misplaced eagerness of Richard Attenborough in Jurassic Park, believed that if they could isolate a single strand of mammoth DNA, it wouldn't be long before mammoths once more foraged in the tundra. In no time at all, they would be causing gridlock on the North Circular and placing great strain on cafe facilities in Paris. Other scientists waxed snooty about such visions. But everyone with a paleontology qualification in this programme seemed to agree that we could learn a great deal about prehistoric mammalian lifestyles from inspecting the big fellow's internal organs.

It took a long time to dig this mammoth out of the ground. Two hours of air time and many more weeks for the PhDs. There were setbacks involving too much snow, meals involving too much reindeer meat and delightful conversations of mutual incomprehension over little jars of vodka. What precisely is the Dutch, or Russian, for "It may well prove difficult to transport this mammoth across the tundra, paleontological colleague of mine"? Answers on a postcard, please.

But when the first hairs of this long-dead beast emerged from the earth before the cameras, it was a very poignant moment. A Dutch mammoth specialist (or perhaps the Dutch mammoth specialist - surely this isn't a boom trade in the Netherlands) stroked the hair between his fingers like a barber and used a hairdryer to blow debris from these precious strands. He was sitting on the back of this mammoth, and for a moment, became a tender maharajah of the tundra.

Since the start of the 19th century, 12 mammoths have been dug up, two of them by a nonagenarian paleontologist from St Petersburg, whose name is even more difficult to say than the phrase nonagenarian paleontologist. Most of those mammoths have been male.

It's easy to understand why. Imagine that you are a 25-year-old boy mammoth, spending about 20 hours a day foraging. In a lake you see some plants and wade in, not thinking that you will stick in the mud or drown. Males often do stupid things, but most of us only rarely suffer the consequences. This stupid male, poor lump, did suffer for his hormone-fuelled stupidity and died where he was stuck. Female mammoths rarely got into such scrapes, but were instead killed principally by Neanderthal males. Which is sad and ironic, when you think about it.

webTitle: So that was the future, was it?

fields.headline: So that was the future, was it?
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
Digital radio advocates constantly enthuse about the greater number of radio stations and the higher-quality sound to be bestowed by this potential cornucopia, yet on the subject of innovative programming they rarely have much to say. But now, hallelujah, an independent radio company commissioned by BBC Digital Radio has produced a multi- media pilot CD-Rom to demonstrate how digital radio might imaginatively enhance the stuff we hear, and not just produce more of it.

Somethin' Else is a commercial radio company in love with public-service broadcasting. It has been making Jazz on 3, Radio 3's excellent Saturday night contemporary jazz programme, for two years. The CD-Rom features High Tide, a 20-minute recorded improvisation session by the Evan Parker Quartet - in itself delicious enough. But added to this is an animation by web designers Airside, based on digital footage of the quartet playing, shot at the session.

Put it down to OD-ing on Fantasia, but I'm generally pretty resistant to visual artists getting their hands on music - their interpretations tend to battle with my own or with the music, or their approach is too literal. But Airside's animation, into which Parker himself had a major input, has clearly been generated by the music, with players' limbs discernible among the abstract shapes.

Likewise, the text, by avant-garde writer, poet and longtime Parker collaborator Paul Haines, which might otherwise have seemed more than a tad Pseuds Corner, here reads like a piece of music, and works on you in the same way. There are drawings of the musicians, an interview with Parker, and biographies and discographies of the musicians. You don't need a digital radio set to hear it, just a digital card for your PC.

Yes, but is it radio? Somethin' Else argues that it is - new radio, rather than old, but all of it sound-led. And although it is pricier to produce than digital broadcasters can currently afford, Somethin' Else argues that it's a template and subsequent costs would fall. At least someone is finally experimenting with the creative aspects of digital radio. Listeners can judge it for themselves when it's put on the BBC website in a couple of weeks.

There's another first in digital radio with the test transmissions of Oneword, the first commercial station in the world that is entirely devoted to books, plays, and comedy. Or that will be. All you can hear at the moment, if you're one of the 5,000-plus owners of a digital radio set, is Andrew Sachs's dark-brown voice reading Silas Marner, Michael Kitchen's reading of Wuthering Heights and Jenny Agutter doing Emma, all unabridged.

Oneword wants to do for the spoken word what Classic FM has done for music. Among its backers is the Guardian Media Group. Starting in a modest, low-key way, it may have admirable intentions, but it is clearly going to be years before it's in a position to, say, commission an original comedy series rather than readings from works by dead (and out-of-copyright) authors. And won't it be competing with the audio books market? Most crucially, plays and comedy are much more expensive than CD-spinning. So far, no one has worked out a profitable way of doing them.

Although a date has been set for the switch-off of analogue TV, no such date has been set for radio, and in a paper in the next issue of the Journal of Radio Studies, an American publication, British lecturer David Hendy argues cogently that although digital radio will greatly expand the number of radio services, it probably won't increase their range. Despite the ideology of the market, we're likely to have many similar stations serving the same range of advertiser-friendly tastes and demands, each branded as unique.

But why are we talking about digital radio anyway? As I wrote a fortnight ago, in a short while you'll be able to hear radio via the internet on your Wap (wireless application protocol)-enabled mobile phone. The bulky digital set (about 13 times dearer than the average mobile) is already becoming a dinosaur.

fields.headline: Let's tax and spend again
fields.trailText: At last we have the beginnings of a debate on taxation (Labour admits tax rises; Low tax a moral duty, says Hague, March 15). But only the beginnings. Labour now needs to articulate a popular vision for fair taxation and good public spending.
fields.body:
At last we have the beginnings of a debate on taxation (Labour admits tax rises; Low tax a moral duty, says Hague, March 15). But only the beginnings. Labour now needs to articulate a popular vision for fair taxation and good public spending.

First, Labour should emphasise to middle-class voters that, even if they are paying a slightly larger proportion of gross income in tax, buoyant earnings growth means most people still have greater post-tax income than on May 1 1997. So a higher tax burden does not necessarily mean that people are, even privately, "worse off".

Second, many people are not paying more tax: on low-income households and most families with children, the tax burden is falling not rising. (Message to core voters: Labour is redistributing.)

Third, Labour needs to stress that the higher tax burden is funding (along with "modernisation") improved public services which benefit everyone. Hague's claim that lower taxes give more freedom to consume should be challenged: if one's priority for spending is better education and health - as opinion polls show that, for most people, it is - there is more freedom from public spending than from private consumption. Labour must say loud and clear that public spending makes people better off.
Michael Jacobs
General secretary, Fabian Society

 The budget is looming and another research report - this time from the family budget unit at King's College - documents pensioner poverty (Report, March 8). The case for substantially increasing the basic state pension has become unassailable, on grounds of simplicity, small administrative cost, popularity, the fact that there is a huge surplus in the national insurance accounts, and ensuring that trickle-down to all the poor actually happens. The most effective result - by comparison with other action tried by the government - is that nearly a million pensioners in poverty who would otherwise have no benefit would gain.
Prof Peter Townsend
London School of Economics

 If the evidence of the Institute of Fiscal Studies is believed, low taxation does not generate more charitable giving. People of all classes gave more proportionately in the 1970s then they do now. Further, few lottery winners have channelled their new found wealth into charitable trusts, and indeed the rate of creation of new charitable foundations is less today than it was in the 1960s. All the evidence shows that the most heavily taxed, the poor, give most to charity - and that doesn't include their spending on lottery tickets.
Rodney Hedley
London
rodneyhedley@hotmail.com

 By focusing on VAT, Peter Effer (Letters, March 16) moves the debate on. VAT is not only a stealth tax but is highly regressive. New Labour, following the Tories, has increased the regressive while reducing the progressive element of the total tax burden. This, together with neglect of manufacturing industry and the running down of the public services, has greatly contributed to the polarisation of British society by placing the real burden on the poor.
Patrick Brady & Geraldine Thorpe
London Guildhall University

 My wife recently noticed the road hadn't been cleaned for weeks. She phoned a councillor and in two days it had been done and we were back on the schedule. I can't wait for the Hague future when, out of our 40% tax savings, we have to personally pay some bloke to come around and do it, because all our neighbours "prefer to spend it on their priorities".
Joe Phillips
Bingham, Notts

fields.headline: Dog days for Rover
fields.trailText: Contrary to your leader, (March 16), the root causes of the problems with Rover are to be laid squarely at BMW's door. If Rover was in such a bad way when BMW bought it, why was it that Honda had offered a partnership agreement with Rover, but was refused because British Aerospace wanted an outright sale to finance its aerospace business?
fields.body:
Contrary to your leader, (March 16), the root causes of the problems with Rover are to be laid squarely at BMW's door. If Rover was in such a bad way when BMW bought it, why was it that Honda had offered a partnership agreement with Rover, but was refused because British Aerospace wanted an outright sale to finance its aerospace business? BMW took on a viable company, with no image problems. Rover was steadily recovering market share and had had a healthy collaboration with Honda for some years.

BMW stepped in mainly with a view to acquiring Land-Rover. It had spent about £2bn trying, unsuccessfully, to develop its own four-wheel-drive vehicle, and here it was being offered the whole company, including Land-Rover, for £800. Since then it has created the problems that now besets the company. Unfortunately it will be the workers of Rover that pay the price. I only hope that the British car-buying public make the BMW marque pay a very high price indeed.
John Taylor
Norwich

 Something appears to have been overlooked in this amusing saga of modern capitalism: the ancient formula make good car, stay in business; make rubbish car, go bust. Rover have simply and inexplicably had a stay of execution over many decades.
John Adams
East Malling, Kent
bottle@musicinkent.co.uk

 Had the UK adopted the euro 14 months ago, neither Rover nor the rest of our economy would be suffering from a grossly overvalued currency.
Frank Oliver
Exeter
F.R.Oliver@exeter.ac.uk

 Couldn't the prime minister simply take a plane to Munich and return with a piece of paper making everything better again?
Tony Vinicombe
Hove, East Sussex
ViniView@aol.com

fields.headline: Not playing the game
fields.trailText: I find the implication that the former Tory, now Labour MP for Witney, Shaun Woodward, may have had something to do with the complaint against Ken Livingstone outrageous (I didn't shop Ken, March 17).
fields.body:
I find the implication that the former Tory, now Labour MP for Witney, Shaun Woodward, may have had something to do with the complaint against Ken Livingstone outrageous (I didn't shop Ken, March 17). Mr Livingstone is an unprincipled person who left his party purely for political gain. Mr Woodward, on the other hand ...
Cllr Keith Mitchell
Conservative group leader, Oxfordshire County Council

 You were misinformed by your source, a Tory spokes-person (Short faces outcry over low wages abroad, March 13). A party that opposed the minimum wage now demands we pay the UK rate overseas. We fix a good rate for local employers according to local conditions and we have improved the rates. They were of course lower under the Tory government.
Clare Short
Secretary of state for international development

 It's a bit disingenuous to bemoan that my "completion" of Holst's Planets (which is no such thing) has been "propelled on to broadsheet front pages" (Leader, March 17). You phoned me, without any prompting, and it was your decision to put it on the front page, not mine.
Colin Matthews
London

 How many animal organs will a human being be permitted to accommodate (Pigs cloned for organs down at the 'pharm', March 15) before he/she no longer qualifies for human rights?
Claire Bendall
Exmouth, Devon

 I note that the fifth little cloned piggy is called Dotcom. Is that because he goes e-e-e all the way home?
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes, Bucks

 Your report on the Leeds-Slavia Prague tie tells us that Rada was sent off. Playacting?
Justin Horton
Letchworth, Herts
