webTitle: The art of being a mayor

fields.headline: The art of being a mayor
fields.trailText: The debate surrounding public art has been raised again with the unveiling of the latest "Fourth Plinth" installation of a sculpture by Bill Woodrow in Trafalgar Square (Come friendly pigeons, March 16). Antony Gormley (Sculptor pleads for public art, March 15) rightly called for greater vision and generosity on the part of British cities in commissioning public sculpture.
fields.body:
The debate surrounding public art has been raised again with the unveiling of the latest "Fourth Plinth" installation of a sculpture by Bill Woodrow in Trafalgar Square (Come friendly pigeons, March 16). Antony Gormley (Sculptor pleads for public art, March 15) rightly called for greater vision and generosity on the part of British cities in commissioning public sculpture.

While sculpture may be the most overt and tangible form of public art, there are numerous other visionary, poetic and practical ways in which today's artists are contributing to the life, identity and economy of cities and rural areas. Urban squares - designed by Richard Wentworth in Walsall, Tess Jaray in Birmingham and Wakefield, and, imminently, Francoise Schein in Coventry and Tom Heatherwick in Newcastle - are just one area where London has lagged far behind other British cities. Artists also excel at the design of parks, gardens, waterscapes, bridges, street furniture, even waste-to-energy plants and electricity substations. And artists are relighting cities and structures, enabling us to see them with fresh eyes, as is currently happening in Wolverhampton.

How about a scheme of pilot projects in vacant brownfield sites which, like Barcelona's squares, could be the subject of design competitions for artists and other creative professionals, and the resultant environments installed for fixed-term periods? It would be a logical follow-up to the government's Urban Task Force report and a means of creating a visual and cultural identity for the new mayor that would be popular and pragmatic.
Vivien Lovell
Director, Modus Operandi Art Consultants

fields.headline: Seeds of discontent at C4
fields.trailText: Channel 4 and producer Martin Durkin have made clear that next week's Equinox special, The Rise and Fall of GM, would be a critical analysis of the case against GM foods (Getting your science from charlatans, March 16). This was explained to every contributor, including Dr Mae-Wan Ho, a leading scientific authority with critical views on genetic modification. Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth were offered the chance to see the questions in advance, and the final extracts, to ensure their views had not been taken out of context. They declined to take part.
fields.body:
Channel 4 and producer Martin Durkin have made clear that next week's Equinox special, The Rise and Fall of GM, would be a critical analysis of the case against GM foods (Getting your science from charlatans, March 16). This was explained to every contributor, including Dr Mae-Wan Ho, a leading scientific authority with critical views on genetic modification. Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth were offered the chance to see the questions in advance, and the final extracts, to ensure their views had not been taken out of context. They declined to take part.

We have scheduled a studio debate to allow a further airing of both sides of the debate. Channel 4 has given extensive airtime to the anti-GM argument, including editions of Dispatches and The Mark Thomas Product.

George Monbiot's article also made allegations about another edition of Equinox on silicone breast implants, which concluded there was no reliable scientific evidence to support the view that silicone gel implants cause serious disease. Your article accused the programme of "ignoring a powerful body of contradictory evidence". Such evidence has never been brought forward as criticism of the programme and no complaint about the programme to the ITC or the BSC has been taken up or substantiated.

C4 is not censoring coverage of the environment and the developing world. I would point to our recent On The Line season and we have two forthcoming documentary series on the work of humanitarian aid agencies and on the effect of global branding on the third world.

The implication that senior Channel 4 staff are somehow in the pay of the multinationals does not merit a response.
Tim Gardam
Director of programmes, Channel 4

fields.headline: I love science
fields.trailText: The Science Museum benefited from a special £1m grant last year, with an additional £1.4m in this forthcoming financial year, and a further £1.4m for the National Collections Centre at the museum's Wroughton outstation (Scientists angered by 'arts mafia' influence, March 6).
fields.body:
The Science Museum benefited from a special £1m grant last year, with an additional £1.4m in this forthcoming financial year, and a further £1.4m for the National Collections Centre at the museum's Wroughton outstation (Scientists angered by 'arts mafia' influence, March 6). These grants are in addition to the baseline uplift of £1.5m over three years and the special £2.4m to compensate the science museums for the cost of free entry for children and pensioners. The baseline grant-in-aid of the Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester has been increased by over 7% to £2.3m.

"Science chiefs" are not against what you describe as "an arts-loving government minister" because the record shows this minister loves science as well as arts.
Chris Smith
Secretary of state for culture, media and sport

fields.headline: French view
fields.trailText: The French government has consistently made clear its preference for the Rutherford Appleton site for the synchrotron facility (Report, March 14). But when it joined the project, it agreed that the decision on the location was for the British government and the Wellcome Trust to make.
fields.body:
The French government has consistently made clear its preference for the Rutherford Appleton site for the synchrotron facility (Report, March 14). But when it joined the project, it agreed that the decision on the location was for the British government and the Wellcome Trust to make. Moreover, the French government has always regarded it as a tripartite project, and made it clear that its participation was dependent on the Wellcome Trust being involved.
Daniel Bernard
French ambassador

fields.headline: Orbit still in
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements got the plot a bit twisted on whether or not William Orbit should be in the classical chart (What  is classical music, G2, March 14). In fact, the album has not been removed from the chart, even after the classical advisory panel decided it should be.
fields.body:
Andrew Clements got the plot a bit twisted on whether or not William Orbit should be in the classical chart (What is classical music, G2, March 14). In fact, the album has not been removed from the chart, even after the classical advisory panel decided it should be. (Who over-ruled the panel and why?) Retailers make up the biggest grouping on the panel. Their decision was based on the fact that most buyers do not look for the Orbit album in classical departments. The Mediaeval Babes can't sing, but they're in the classical chart because people wanting to buy their album will look for it in the classical section. Any chart is a marketing tool - if anything at all is allowed in it ceases to perform any function. Is that elitist? Imagine how daft the Dance chart would be if it were dominated by Steps and Britney Spears.
David Blake
Select Music Distribution
dblake@selectmusic.co.uk

fields.headline: And the lucky winners are...
fields.standfirst:
The Brits are tipped to do well at next Sunday's Oscars with actors, writers and directors up for awards. And as Britain increases in importance as a centre of production, breaks for hungry young talent abound. Rupert Jones reports

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The cream of the UK film industry will gather in Hollywood next Sunday for the annual pageant of pomp, glamour and backslapping that is the Oscars ceremony. And some are predicting it could be a vintage night for the Brits.
fields.body:
The cream of the UK film industry will gather in Hollywood next Sunday for the annual pageant of pomp, glamour and backslapping that is the Oscars ceremony. And some are predicting it could be a vintage night for the Brits.

Sam Mendes leads the field with eight Oscar nominations for the widely acclaimed American Beauty, while Janet McTeer is seen as being in with a good chance of scooping best actress for her role in the American comedy Tumbleweeds.

Michael Caine and Jude Law are up for best supporting actor, Nottingham-born Samantha Morton is in the running for best supporting actress, while Mike Leigh and Anthony Minghella are among those vying for the best screenplay award for Topsy-Turvy and The Talented Mr Ripley respectively.

Our healthy showing in the nominations reflects the fact that the British film industry is thriving. Recent figures showed that American and other overseas studios spent £404m on shooting film and TV productions in Britain last year, up sharply on the 1998 figure of £250m. In fact, four of the half-dozen or so biggest grossing films in the world in 1999 were made here, including Star Wars Episode One: The Phantom Menace and Notting Hill. The number of films made that meet the definition "British" jumped from 102 in 1998 to 160 last year.

Last month, former Channel 4 head Michael Grade declared that the British film industry was set for a huge expansion as government initiatives such as tax breaks for film-makers and millions in Lottery money takes effect. But not everything in the garden is rosy. Many Lottery-funded Brit flicks of the last year or two have underperformed at the box office; Britain lacks an effective film distribution infrastructure, and investment in movies can be, as the department for culture, media and sport puts it, "very volatile".

However, such concerns have done nothing to dampen the enthusiasm of the thousands of people pouring out of film and media courses, hungry for a slice of movie action. It's a fiercely competitive sector. "The UK media industry employs roughly 60,000 people and there's always another 60,000 people trying to get in," says Skillset, the national training organisation whose website (www.skillset.org) features a wealth of useful information on the various courses and training schemes on offer around the country.

But there are no hard and fast rules for getting into the industry, according to Skillset's online careers guide. "There are people who have successfully completed relevant courses who are still unable to break into a real job. And there are others who by being enthusiastic and in the right place at the right time are given that all-important first job," it adds.

As always, the advice is to get as much experience under your belt as possible. That's what Andrew Mitchell did, and his efforts paid off - a year ago he landed a job as a junior camera assistant with Bristol-based Aardman Animations, the company behind Wallace and Gromit.

Originally from north London, Andrew, 24, studied English literature and creative writing at Bath Spa University College. As part of this, he did a film studies module, which involved students making their own short films. After graduating he applied to several film schools, was shortlisted for a cinematography course at one, but did not get in.

"They did say to reapply. I considered it. Then I decided I wanted more experience in the industry itself." He fired off letters to various production companies and did short stints including a spell on BBC1's Casualty and three weeks' work experience at Aardman. "I broke into the camera department through that. They tried me out for a couple of weeks and thought I was getting along OK, and offered me a job after that."

Andrew is currently working on Aardman's upcoming animated feature Chicken Run and says his advice to those keen to follow in his footsteps is to "get as much experience as possible, even if you are not getting paid straightaway. You are making contacts and it looks very good on your CV."

You would imagine that a company as well-known as Aardman would have no difficulty filling any of the posts it advertises, but it has had no end of problems recruiting animators with expertise in the field of 3D clay animation and has had to bring in people from overseas. "There is a huge shortage at the moment," says Pam Hayes, head of human resources. It has also found there are a dearth of illustrators versed in the art of 2D storyboarding (preparing the storyboard for the animator). In an attempt to raise awareness it is putting together a roadshow which will tour careers events around the country, and is running its own training school for people who have just left college.

Around 90% of those who work in film are freelancers, and don't have access to structured training and development. Yet with new technology revolutionising the way movies are made, it is more important than ever. So the film industry last year set up the Skills Investment Fund, which will help finance new training in areas where there are shortages.

One recent development that has given hope to film students everywhere is the global box office success of the Blair Witch Project. Hoping to ride the renewed wave of interest in horror is Nigel Wingrove, head of London-based Salvation Films. He aims to build Salvation into "the world's largest sex and horror company, far surpassing the past glories of Hammer Films", and the first film is Sacred Flesh, a depiction of suppressed sexuality set in a convent. The £300,000 movie was shot in 10 days at locations including London's Tower Bridge.

Filmed on digital video, Sacred Flesh has secured a two-week run at London's ABC Piccadilly and has been sold to most of Europe, the US and Japan - not bad for a first feature that received no state or Lottery funding.

Mr Wingrove says that more than 60% of UK-made films never get a theatrical release or make back their budget, while Sacred Flesh is on target to go into profit. Making a film is only half the battle - you've then got to get it in front of a paying audience. "I've seen it so many times - someone has made a film and haven't thought about how to market it and get their money back."

Many colleges and universities offer film-related courses. One of the most highly-regarded is the National Film and Television School in Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire (www.nftsfilm-tv.ac.uk), which runs full-time diploma courses in 11 subjects including directing, screenwriting and cinematography. It helps for applicants to have a degree under their belts and/or some experience.There are about 140 students at the school, and the rate of employment in the first six months after graduation is high - about 75%.

Where do I start?

Skillset, the national training organisation for the film industry, publishes "Careers Pack: A Career in Broadcast, Film and Video," which is crammed with information and advice on jobs, training and education. The entire nine-chapter guide is available to read for free on Skillset's website (www.skillset.org). A new updated version is currently being prepared and will be in bookshops this autumn.

Skillset's website also features an online guide aimed at students aged 14-17 who are thinking about a career in television.

The British Film Institute (www.bfi.org.uk) publishes an online database of hundreds of short courses in film, TV, video and radio taking place around the country - everything from an introduction to lighting to digital video editing.

Two useful BFI publications include Media Courses UK 2000 (£12.99, edited by Lavinia Orton), which carries details of courses offered by UK colleges and universities.

webTitle: Albanian lawyer is beaten in Belgrade

fields.headline: Albanian lawyer is beaten in Belgrade
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: An ethnic Albanian lawyer and his wife were brutally beaten in their flat in the Yugoslav capital Belgrade by four masked intruders, a humanitarian worker said yesterday.
fields.body:
An ethnic Albanian lawyer and his wife were brutally beaten in their flat in the Yugoslav capital Belgrade by four masked intruders, a humanitarian worker said yesterday.

Husnija Bitici, who defends Albanians held in Serbian jails, and his wife were attacked at their Belgrade home late on Thursday, said Natasa Kandic, head of the locally-based Humanitarian Law Fund. Mr Bitici's wife let the men in when they said they were neighbours.

Mr Bitici sustained serious head injuries and was operated on overnight, but doctors said his life was not in danger. His wife, with lesser injuries, is in intensive care.

Ms Kandic, who went to the Bitici flat as soon as she heard of the incident, said that there was blood all over the room and even human tissue on the floor.

Mr Bitici defended ethnic Albanians from Kosovo who were detained in Serbia, mostly on charges of terrorism or conspiracy against the state.

Most of them were arrested between March and June 1999, during Nato's air campaign over Yugoslavia's repression of the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo.

Ms Kandic said that Mr Bitici had been threatened by some Serb lawyers from Kosovo in an effort to stop him accusing them of taking huge bribes from the families of ethnic Albanian prisoners to secure their release.

Mr Bitici also defended a prominent Kosovo Albanian poet and humanitarian worker, Flora Brovina, who was sentenced to 12 years in prison last December, and one of five ethnic Albanian students in Belgrade who were charged with terrorism.

Ms Kandic's organisation estimates that 1,400 ethnic Albanians are still being held in Serbian jails.

fields.headline: A pointless pursuit
fields.standfirst:
Why the Guardian will continue to resist

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: There ought, in a free country, to be a presumption that people can contact newspapers without the fear that their communications will be handed over to the police.
fields.body:
For well over three years the former M15 officer, David Shayler, has been spilling secrets in interviews, articles and on his own website (www.shayler.com). Only recently he took part, live from Paris, in a Newsnight programme which also included Tom King, parliamentary overseer of the security services. Last month, miffed by something he read about himself in these pages, he wrote a letter to the Guardian. It broke no new ground and revealed no new secrets. Much of it was a rambling diatribe against politicians, cut for reasons of space.

For reasons which are still not entirely clear, the police applied to a judge to force the Guardian to hand over the full text of the original email sent by Mr Shayler. Pressed to explain how this might help investigations, an officer told the court it might reveal Mr Shayler's email address. Jack Straw might have helped them there: Mr Shayler emails him, too. Though the police could provide no further evidence as to why it was so vital that they have access to Mr Shayler's email, an Old Bailey judge yesterday found against the Guardian (and its sister paper, the Observer).

We will challenge this judgment. There ought, in a free country, to be a presumption that people can contact newspapers without the fear that their communications will be handed over to the police. If the legal authorities do wish to impose this chill on freedom of expression there ought to be a heavy onus on them to prove the exceptional nature of the circumstances. It is our belief that the police came nowhere near proving such circumstances in this case. We recently argued a similar case when the police asked us to provide pictures of the City of London rioters. On that occasion, their application failed. This application also deserves to fail. Meanwhile, the police could do worse than try emailing david@shayler.com.

webTitle: Providers fall at the first fence

fields.headline: Providers fall at the first fence
fields.standfirst: Only seven out of 55 'stakeholder friendly' plans conform to the rules. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: A new pensions survey published today reveals that just one in eight of existing "stakeholder-friendly" pension plans meets all of the criteria for the low-cost retirement policies which start officially in April 2001
fields.body:
A new pensions survey published today reveals that just one in eight of existing "stakeholder-friendly" pension plans meets all of the criteria for the low-cost retirement policies which start officially in April 2001

It says that to call the other plans - 48 out of 55 - "stakeholder friendly" is "clearly misleading". The research, by trade publication Money Marketing, states that just seven plans out of 55 which claim to be "stakeholder friendly" fit with all the eight rules for acceptability (see below).

And that could hit confidence in the new-style schemes before their official take-off date. The government is betting that stakeholder pensions will bring millions more people into the personal pensions net. It hopes success will save the exchequer billions in state pensions and income support.

The new scheme hopes to score with a number of criteria based on two very simple propositions: low cost and flexibility. And as the contrast between the stakeholder recipe and present personal pensions is so wide - old-style products gener ally featured high costs and inflexibility - pensions companies have rushed out "stakeholder friendly" plans.

This is not altruism; without a "bridge" product, life companies would have found it difficult to sell the old, expensive schemes with new products looming on the horizon. But the majority of life companies offering plans which claim "stakeholder-friendliness" fail on one and often several of the rules.

According to Money Marketing's Sandra Grandison, only five schemes open to the general public - Friends Provident, Marks & Spencer, Mattioli Woods, Scottish Mutual and Virgin Direct - fit all the criteria. Two other plans, from Flemings and Liberty, also meet all the conditions but are only available as group schemes.

Norwich Union fails on six of the eight points, including most of those on charges; MGM also has the same low pass rate; and a large number of plans including those from from Allchurches Life, Britannic, Halifax, Lincoln, Pearl, United Friendly and Wesleyan fail on five points.

Financial advisers believe that some of the criteria are more important than others. The nominated default investment option is perhaps the least important. Abbey National's Flexible Pension plan only fails on this point as does the plan from Clerical Medical.

A scheme from James Hay, only sold to companies as group plans, fails on one point - it has more complex charges.

New rules announced last week now allow with-profits plans to be included in stakeholder, a move which has been hailed by life companies as increasing choice to investments offering a "smoothed return". But these policies are seen by some independent financial advisers as "lacking transparency and being incomprehensible to normal humans".

They also say unscrupulous companies could confuse potential purchasers. Critics point to endowment mortgages as an example of how with-profits plans can disappoint - returns are falling despite stockmarket gains. The insurance industry had to lobby long and hard to get its way on this.

Life companies say they are improving their plans - some blame computer problems for their slowness in adopt ing the news standards. But they claim they will have a genuine stakeholder product available for next April.

Stakeholder rules

To be accepted for stakeholder, pension plans need to conform with these eight criteria.

 There must be only one type of charge on the fund - this rules out confusing charging structures where customers pay a percentage of each premium, a monthly fixed fee which hits the least well off the hardest, and annual fund charges.

 The charge must be no higher than 1% a year - some existing schemes charge three times as much. But fees can be lower. Marks & Spencer and some financial advisers have cut costs down to the 0.7% line.

 The minimum contribution must be no higher than £20 - many plans now start at £50 a month or as much as £1,000 for a lump sum.

 No minimum contribution frequency - so that savers are not forced to pay in each month.

 A nominated suitable default investment option - this should guide investors to wards a middle of the road choice such as a tracker or a with-profits fund rather than leave the selection to an adviser who might charge

 No exit charges - some funds levy a fee when the holder wants to retire.

 No transfer penalties - insurers can currently keep customers in poor funds by threatening to make them pay a large fee to take their pension cash elsewhere.

 No high front end charges - some life companies have taken a large part of the first two years' contributions, although the rules do allow for the costs of "advice".

fields.headline: Birchin International
fields.standfirst: Our weekly probe into the companies that are hot gossip on the internet chat rooms
fields.trailText: Birchin International?
fields.body:
Birchin International?

Not the usual company to spark fever-pitch excitement in the internet chat rooms. It's an upmarket training and conference company and owns venues such as Swinton Castle in Harrogate, Chewton Place in Bath and Eynsham Hall in Oxfordshire. Until this week. On Thursday it sold the venues for £17m and says it will reinvent itself as a net-based business-to-business training provider specialising in financial services, plus supplying content to other sites.

Run by kids with daddy's silver cyberspoon?

Unlike most net companies, Birchin has a board with impressive management experience. Chairman and chief executive is Colyn Gardner, who founded banking training specialists DC Gardner. Also on the board is Liz Davies, who with ex-husband George co-founded Next and the George label sold through Asda stores.

But has Birchin ever turned a profit?

It was losing £2m a year until the new management team took the conference venues into the 90s with a redesign, added a range of money-spinning services and took the near-zero weekend occupancy rates to hotel levels. Last year it reported a profit of £750,000.

What's it worth?

Depends on the time of day, with the share price currently yo-yoing madly. In early December the shares were trading on the Aim market for 1.25p, valuing the company at £15m. Then it began to soar, and at its peak it hit 15p, taking its market value to nearly £190m. This week it was fluctuating by 2-4p every day amid widespread panic in the dot.com market.

So the news about the switch to e-business must have leaked out early?

A peculiar sequence of events. In mid-November, Birchin raised £4.5m in finance, and told shareholders it was to buy some conference properties off ICI. It never bought them. Its share price took off in late December, and on January 20 it issued a statement revealing that it may sell its portfolio of properties. Then on February 23 it announced that it was seeking to turn itself into an e-business. At its EGM on Thursday this week it confirmed that it was selling the properties to Hanover International for £17m, and made some more, but not very spe cific, noises about its internet strategy.

So what is it going to do now?

Mr Gardner said at the EGM that it is too early to provide specific details, but that it was looking "very closely at opportunities in which content and product could be delivered by way of the internet, such as distant learning, education, training and financial services products" and that Birchin is considering "entering into alliances or syndications with third parties."The market was not impressed. The shares fell 3p to 11p, knocking more than 20% off the value of the company.

Is this just penny-stock madness?

They love it in the internet chat rooms, where gossip about Birchin almost matches the number of messages about lastminute.com. But remember, these messages can be misleading, deceptive or wrong. Many were expecting the shares to be suspended pending a major announcement, but it didn't happen. Here's a selection:

"Big announcement next week after money has been received in bank. Fill those boots," posted on hemscott by mega1.

"Birchin is a small company which does a little training from a few small buildings. None of this justifies the price rise to 15p. This fall [to 11p] isn't a small correction, it's profit taking from those who have ramped the share price. Time to walk away, folks. Birchin is money down the drain," posted by Tony Wilson at iii.

"You don't need balls for this company, it's sold with a good team, and the all-important .com future, and £17m in the bank," posted by Cassius at hemscott.

webTitle: Finding the breathing space for quality time

fields.headline: Finding the breathing space for quality time
fields.standfirst: As people start to revolt against the domination of work over life employers are recognising the wider damage to society. Caroline Glynn reports
fields.trailText: Far from witnessing the emergence of the family-friendly working environment, most UK employees are struggling to find enough hours in the day to have any quality time with their families. Enabling individuals to balance their working and personal lives is finally being recognised as a critical management issue.
fields.body:
Far from witnessing the emergence of the family-friendly working environment, most UK employees are struggling to find enough hours in the day to have any quality time with their families. Enabling individuals to balance their working and personal lives is finally being recognised as a critical management issue.

The idea has even reached Downing Street; only last week Tony Blair launched a campaign, Employers for Work-Life Balance, to be chaired by Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB and backed by the heads of 22 companies employing about 500,000 people.

The past decade has been characterised by unprecedented numbers of employees experiencing stress as a result of work. Working hours have lengthened and workloads increased as organisations respond to the pressures of globalisation and adjust to the fall-out of earlier downsizing.

This had a negative impact on family and community life. Changes in family structures, the growth of dual-career families and the increasing pressures of caring for elderly relatives have also contributed to the lack of balance being reported.

The answer, of course, is that the issue of work-life balance has grown in scope since it first emerged as a valid topic for debate. Initially, balance was marginalised as women's business which only reared its head when a professional female needed to juggle the demands of family with work.

However, a study by Roffey Park Management Institute, Work-Life Balance, Careers and the Psychological Contract, has conclusively shown that balance is desired by employees regardless of their gender, age or parental status. Work-life balance is a much wider issue than work-family balance. When individuals define what they mean by balance it equates with having a successful career and a fulfilling personal life which encompasses family, friends, and hobbies.

Our research revealed that it is organisational pressures which are driving the current imbalance between work and home. The report concludes that people were unable to redress the balance as the organisational culture conspired against them.

Employees reported that, despite the presence of family-friendly policies, the culture within organisations conspired against fostering true balance. Instead, the unspoken corporate rules judge commitment and performance by the number of hours spent in the office, rather than quality of output.

Employees are left with the choice of taking up the family-friendly policies and foregoing career development or achieving career success by sacrificing their personal life.

But there is mounting evidence that balance is beginning to play a critical role in the recruitment and retention of key employees. In future, organisations which are branded as "employers of choice" will have to offer genuine balance between life at work and off work.

Failure to realise this will mean poor recruitment and retention levels. Employees are reporting a high degree of confidence in their employability and will leave a job in favour of one that meets their needs.

The latest research from Roffey Park emphasises this shift quite dramatically. Following telephone interviews with 50 MBA and MSc students, the research concluded that a key criterion being used to select potential employers was the organisation's values. These were important in terms of the way the organisation values its employees and its vision in relation to the wider society.

This moves the focus towards not just the creation of a supportive culture but an external image which reflects this. It also opens up the debate from one concerning just employees and organisations to one inclusive of the community in which the corporations operate.

New definitions of careers are emerging which do not centre around work but embrace personal life. Failure in career terms is characterised by a lack of time and energy for activities outside work. Employees are less willing to put in long hours at the cost of personal fulfilment.

Organisations are made up of the same people who make up the families in society and constitute our communities. It is important that the issue of work-life balance is considered in a holistic sense and that individuals too, in their capacity as managers, employees, parents or community leaders, take responsibility for bringing about this change.

Work-Life Balance, Careers and the Psychological Contract, £20: Inquiries, tel 01293-851644

webTitle: Market leaves singles out of the picture

fields.headline: Market leaves singles out of the picture
fields.standfirst: John Prescott may advocate the building of smaller units but family houses are still in strong demand, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Government attempts to persuade house builders to switch from building Brookside-style detached and semi-detached homes to apartments for single people will fall on deaf ears unless tougher rules are introduced, say planning experts.
fields.body:
Government attempts to persuade house builders to switch from building Brookside-style detached and semi-detached homes to apartments for single people will fall on deaf ears unless tougher rules are introduced, say planning experts.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott sounded the death knell for the family and executive homes in the countryside last week when he announced plans for 215,000 new homes in the south-east in the next five years and a further 115,000 in greater London.

Single people, including divorcees, the young and the elderly, will account for nearly two-thirds of new households over the next 20 years, according to the government. Developers must stop building detached and semi-detached homes and start building homes to meet the needs of the new singles, he said.

But planning experts say tougher guidelines will be needed if ministers are to persuade house builders to construct the type of homes the government wants. According to figures from the National House Building Council, houses made up 80% of new homes started in the south-east last year.

Mr Prescott said single people will not want or be able to afford executive homes: "Many will need well-designed, well-located homes for rent or to buy which are affordable and which give them a range of choice and a better quality of life."

However, as the number of single person households has increased, the number of one-bedroom new homes has fallen. Figures from the National House Building Council show that during last year 42% of new homes started were detached houses. Terraced houses accounted for 20% of new starts and flats and maisonettes only 19%. The same is true elsewhere in the country. In the east Midlands houses accounted for 97% of new starts.

The House Builders Federation warns against rushing to solve the housing shortage in the south-east with a particular style of housing. The federation points to the mistakes of the 60s when tower blocks were seen as the fastest way to provide homes.

Builders say they build what the public wants to buy. "Competition is so stiff in the sector and land so scarce that no builder will build homes he can't sell," says a Federation spokesman.

All the signs are that with some builders the detached home is as popular as ever. Already this year Wates has announced a development of six five-bedroom detached houses in Yarnells Hill, Oxford, from around £550,000; a £1.5m detached home in Ascot; and six four-bed country houses in Sevenoaks, Kent, from £400,000.

Simon Bennett, group marketing manager of Redrow Homes, says while interest in city centre apartments has increased the demand is for traditional family homes. It's not just families who buy the four/five-bedroom homes, says Mr Bennett. Those without children or whose children have left home also want space for entertaining and for home offices. "We will always have a certain amount of greenfield development. Villages are also growing and people there need homes to enable them to sustain village life. Traditional homes will still be in demand," he says.

The social housing sector, rather than follow the gov ernment's line, is also investing in two/three bedroom houses. As Abena Nsia, head of regeneration and investment at the National Housing Federation, explains: "Housing associations have a remit to provide homes for people in priority need. Usually this means single parents or couples with children. Only those single people classed as vulnerable are considered."

The problem with one-bedroom apartments is their inflexibility, says a spokesman from the Housing Corporation, the agency that funds housing associations. "Only one thing needs to change in someone's life and the accommodation becomes completely unsuitable. There is no room for sons or daughters to return home nor for live-in carers," he said.

Mr Prescott expects local authorities to use the planning system to encourage the development of higher density homes for smaller households. But Brian Raggett, president of the Royal Town Planning Institute, says planners can't dictate what type of homes people should live in. He says developers will be reluctant to construct smaller homes which only appeal to one type of buyer and are hard to resell. "The planning system can only try to increase the proportion of smaller units that are acceptable to buyers and easy to resell or re-let," he said.

The government has promised more guidance to help local authorities take local needs into account when considering planning applications. But ministers have some way to go if they're to convince builders that there really is a demand for smaller homes for the new singles. For now, at least, most of them appear to want as much space as other households.

fields.headline: Strong grounds for the independents
fields.standfirst: Chic coffee bars are springing up everywhere, but as the big chains fight for control there's still room for the passionate individual, says Sandra Deeble
fields.trailText: Coffee bars, like mobile phones, are everywhere. Posturing with your Nokia while trying not to gag on your Mocha Valencia (chocolate syrup, orange syrup, coffee and steamed milk), is a tall order, but if you want to live up to your urban swashbuckler image, it has to be done.
fields.body:
Coffee bars, like mobile phones, are everywhere. Posturing with your Nokia while trying not to gag on your Mocha Valencia (chocolate syrup, orange syrup, coffee and steamed milk), is a tall order, but if you want to live up to your urban swashbuckler image, it has to be done.

The proliferation of branded coffee bars - Starbucks, Coffee Republic, Aroma and Costa - on the streets of London and other major cities has far from reached its zenith. Costa recently declared war on Starbucks: it plans to have 256 outlets by the end of the year - way ahead of Starbucks, which currently has 115 sites.

People might fantasise about running their own cafe but surely the market has become far too daunting for an individual to fulfil caffeine-fuelled dreams. Where exactly would you start? "Location, location, location," says Michael Fairholme, of the Urban Espresso Training School in Maida Vale in London, where would-be cafe owners can learn the ropes. "Finding a site is a full-time job."

Victoria Reid, who founded Urban Espresso after owning and operating cafes in Australia and who now advises people who are setting up businesses, agrees: "It's a long slog: it can be more than 18 months before you make your first cup of coffee".

Jones Lang Lasalle is retained by Starbucks to search for sites around the country. You can appoint an agent to look for you and they will charge you around 10% of the rental as a fee. If they don't find you what you want, you don't pay anything. If you have never traded before, you won't get a prime site as you need a covenant to show the strength of your accounts, which is why, according to Jones Lang Lasalle, "most start-ups are in slightly quirkier positions".

Annual rent can be anything from £50,000 for a site in a fairly busy sidestreet in a commuter town to £200,000 for a site in a prime section of, say, Long Acre in Covent Garden.To help get you started NatWest publishes The Business Start-Up Planner and any bank will have a smallbusiness adviser who will be able to put you in touch with your local BusinessLink. Estate agents will also help you get to grips with the legalities of leases.

When it comes to staff, Michael Fairholme reckons that the minimum is three people: one on the till; one cleaning up and managing stock and, most importantly, the person who could make your business a success: the Barista. The person who operates the coffee machine - be it a model by La Marzocco (approx £3,500) or a Faema (expect to pay around £2,500) - is in a profession, which, in the UK, is about to come of age.

For as the chains scramble to secure the best sites they are creating a market for Baristas with a more professional vision - not for their own branches - but to work in the new, independent coffee shops being opened by maverick entrepreneurs.

At Cuppa-cino, situated between platforms 9/10 and 11/12 at Clapham Junction station, Jorge Fernandez is in his element: "I will always consider myself first and foremost a professional Barista. I love it. I love to go behind the bar and shout and rant and rave and create. It's a real buzz. When it's busy, and it's pumping, it's a little bit special. You get in for six in the morning. You start guzzling your coffee. It does help to be caffeined up"

Created by Andrew Roberts and Amanda Fletcher, Cuppa-cino opened last summer. "It worked pretty much straight away," says Andrew Roberts, who is committed to growing the business without having outside shareholders: "We don't want to lose the fun of it."

"It doesn't have to be about cut-throat competition," adds Amanda Fletcher. "It's about quality of life". With plans to open a maximum of seven or eight stores, Mr Roberts suggests that Cuppa-cinos will tend to be located in "unconventional locations".

Quality of coffee and developing a loyal, professional team are key, believes Mr Roberts, who buys his coffee from specialists the Monmouth Coffee Company and experiments with offering single origin coffee (espresso is made from a blend), often bought direct from estates, which helps to raise awareness. On the recruitment front, he is quick to point out: "I couldn't pay someone £4 per hour. I just couldn't expect them to arrive and do a good job".

Out of London, the entrepreneurial spirits is also flourishing: "Starbucks wants to rule the world like McDon alds so it will do it at all costs", says Steve Sartori, co-owner of the Italian Coffee Company in Worcester. "This leaves opportunities for small individuals. With my hands-on approach I can always do better than them. My service will be 10 times better."

Mr Sartori persuaded a family of Birmingham-based farmers, A E Becketts and Sons, to diversify into coffee bars and hopes to open no more than 10 outlets in the next two years. His staff have been with the business since it opened last July and the second shop opened in Cheltenham on 13 March. Looking at sites in Gloucester, Malvern and Leamington, Mr Sartori is avoiding the big cities: "I looked at a site in Bristol which was four or five doors away from Coffee Republic and across the road from Starbucks.Why do I need to jump into that?"

Mr Sartori and his team all learned to make good coffee at the Urban Espresso Training School where an afternoon's course will set you back £70, during which time Michael Fairholme will endeavour to help you find "that sweet spot".

Infused with passion, Mr Fairholme studied his art with professional Baristas in Italy and is consequently committed to spreading the word about good coffee. "It's a drug," he admits, and after an afternoon learning that you need 7 grammes to make a single espresso and pondering "gramme throw" (the weight dispensed by the grinder) - you have to believe him.

The ultimate, reveals Mr Fairholme, is Jamaica Blue Mountain, sold at approximately £35.00 per kilo, which is "naturally perfectly balanced".

John Kavaliauskas also learned to operate the "Ferrari" of coffee machines - La Marzocco - under the tutelage of Michael Fairholme, and is now ready to set up shop. Together with his partner, Maria Clancy, he is launching a cafe business called Organic Xpress which has backing from the Social Venture Network Europe (SVNE). Starting in London, and then looking towards Liverpool and beyond, with the first London outlet due to open before the summer, Mr Kavaliauskas can only reveal so much about the nature of the Organic Xpress brand.

If it were a car, he says, it would be "something coming out of the RockyMountain Institute: the ultra-light Hypercar, a more enlightened expression of contemporary sustainable living and lifestyles" and adds that while the property search is fraught - he has already been gazumped by a fast food retailer - he remains motivated and enthusiastic.

"The organic movement has evolved mainly from the 70s: maybe it's ready for a fresh outlook that's really vibrant." He admits he would like to do for food "what Malcolm McLaren did to the music industry"

Currently researching fairly traded products, Mr Kavaliauskas is unfazed by the likes of Costa: "Despite the voracity of the big brand chains, it is creating a space for the individual," he says with conviction.

And back at Clapham Junction, where the the Cuppa-cino team know all of their regular customers by name, referring to "Mr Short White Brew" or "Mr Tall Latte and Pain au Chocolat", Jorge Fernandez believes that the Barista as a profession will grow as smaller, more personally-driven businesses are developed.

"A certain percentage of people will appreciate being recognised by staff and will appreciate the fact that a coffee shop has a soul and a heart and isn't driven purely by money."

With plans to open a maximum of seven or eight stores, Mr Roberts suggests that Cuppa-cinos will tend to be located in "unconventional locations". Quality of coffee and developing a loyal, professional team are key, believes Mr Roberts, who buys his coffee from specialists the Monmouth Coffee Company and experiments with offering single origin coffee (espresso is made from a blend), often bought direct from estates, which helps to raise awareness. On the recruitment front, he is quick to point out: "I couldn't pay someone £4 per hour. I just couldn't expect them to arrive and do a good job". Out of London, the entrepreneurial spirits is also flourishing: "Starbucks wants to rule the world like McDon alds so it will do it at all costs", says Steve Sartori, co-owner of the Italian Coffee Company in Worcester. "This leaves opportunities for small individuals. With my hands-on approach I can always do better than them. My service will be 10 times better." Mr Sartori persuaded a family of Birmingham-based farmers, A E Becketts and Sons, to diversify into coffee bars and hopes to open no more than 10 outlets in the next two years. His staff have been with the business since it opened last July and the second shop opened in Cheltenham on 13 March. Looking at sites in Gloucester, Malvern and Leamington, Mr Sartori is avoiding the big cities: "I looked at a site in Bristol which was four or five doors away from Coffee Republic and across the road from Starbucks.Why do I need to jump into that?" Mr Sartori and his team all learned to make good coffee at the Urban Espresso Training School where an afternoon's course will set you back £70, during which time Michael Fairholme will endeavour to help you find "that sweet spot". Infused with passion, Mr Fairholme studied his art with professional Baristas in Italy and is consequently committed to spreading the word about good coffee. "It's a drug," he admits, and after an afternoon learning that you need 7 grammes to make a single espresso and pondering "gramme throw" (the weight dispensed by the grinder) - you have to believe him. The ultimate, reveals Mr Fairholme, is Jamaica Blue Mountain, sold at approximately £35.00 per kilo, which is "naturally perfectly balanced". John Kavaliauskas also learned to operate the "Ferrari" of coffee machines - La Marzocco - under the tutelage of Michael Fairholme, and is now ready to set up shop. Together with his partner, Maria Clancy, he is launching a cafe business called Organic Xpress which has backing from the Social Venture Network Europe (SVNE). Starting in London, and then looking towards Liverpool and beyond, with the first London outlet due to open before the summer, Mr Kavaliauskas can only reveal so much about the nature of the Organic Xpress brand. If it were a car, he says, it would be "something coming out of the RockyMountain Institute: the ultra-light Hypercar, a more enlightened expression of contemporary sustainable living and lifestyles" and adds that while the property search is fraught - he has already been gazumped by a fast food retailer - he remains motivated and enthusiastic. "The organic movement has evolved mainly from the 70s: maybe it's ready for a fresh outlook that's really vibrant." He admits he would like to do for food "what Malcolm McLaren did to the music industry" Currently researching fairly traded products, Mr Kavaliauskas is unfazed by the likes of Costa: "Despite the voracity of the big brand chains, it is creating a space for the individual," he says with conviction. And back at Clapham Junction, where the the Cuppa-cino team know all of their regular customers by name, referring to "Mr Short White Brew" or "Mr Tall Latte and Pain au Chocolat", Jorge Fernandez believes that the Barista as a profession will grow as smaller, more personally-driven businesses are developed. "A certain percentage of people will appreciate being recognised by staff and will appreciate the fact that a coffee shop has a soul and a heart and isn't driven purely by money."

webTitle: How fortunes appear on the landscape

fields.headline: How fortunes appear on the landscape
fields.standfirst: The work of 18th and 19th century British artists - featuring Constable and Turner's vivid rural and maritime images - is considered to be this country's greatest contribution to modern painting. Stewart Dalby looks at the saleroom possibilities
fields.trailText: It has been said that the greatest contribution Britain has made to modern painting is in the realm of landscape. The great period of British landscape painting is considered to be the late 18th and early 19th centuries, the age of Constable and Turner. Many of the best pieces are watercolours or drawings.
fields.body:
It has been said that the greatest contribution Britain has made to modern painting is in the realm of landscape. The great period of British landscape painting is considered to be the late 18th and early 19th centuries, the age of Constable and Turner. Many of the best pieces are watercolours or drawings.

That there should have been a concentration of outstanding landscape painters in Britain around the turn of the 19th century could have a lot to do with the French Revolution and the Napoleonic wars. This made travel on the continent hazardous and difficult. This, in turn, had the effect of making artists look closer to home for their inspiration. East Anglia with its flat landscapes, big skies and special qualities of light coming off the sea became a favourite area.

That many of the fine pieces in this quintessential British art form should have been watercolours as opposed to oils is explained by the easier portability of the materials needed for watercolours. Oil painting, with the greater paraphernalia of preparation, drying and cleaning, made it more suitable for the studio, apart from small canvases. All the watercolourist needs is an easel (and not always that) a small case of paints and brushes and, well, water.

Victorian watercolours used to be unfashionable. They usually fetched lower prices than oil paintings. Possibly this was because they were thought of as less durable and there is a fear of fading. However, according to the experts, provided they are kept away from direct sunlight and strong artificial light, with proper precautions taken they should not fade.

In the past 10 years watercolours have become increasingly popular. They are thought to be more restful and less formidable than oil paintings for the home or office.

Auction houses and galleries have a constant stream of sales and exhibitions. On April 7 Christie's King Street is having a sale of what it describes as the largest private collection of watercolours to come on to the market in 20 years. The collection contains 141 lots including some well-known names such as Brabazon, Turner and Cotman.

Around the corner from Christie's there is an exhibition at the Spink-Leger gallery called Feeling through the Eyewhich began last Tuesday. The gallery says this is a ground-breaking exhibition in that it surveys the work of a generation of young British artists active in the early years of the 19th century, that is, when British landscape painting was supposedly at its zenith.

It has taken Lowell Libson, a leading watercolour expert at Spink-Leger, six years to assemble the 140 lots, all of which are for sale. Although the painters included did not form a movement or school as such, what marks them out, according to Mr Libson, is that they had a new approach to landscape painting.

He says: "Unlike the majority of earlier artists they are not so much concerned with accurately recording a view, as fixing, often for personal interest, an emotive reaction to an effect of nature, a particular landscape or even a component part of it."

In this, he feels they anticipated the Impressionists to some extent. As in the Christie's sale there are some famous landscapists. These include JMW Turner, Thomas Girtin, John Constable, Richard Parkes Bonnington and William Turner of Oxford.

But the core of the exhibition is centred around groups of works by some of the 19th century's lesser-known, and, Mr Libson believes, underrated artists like John Linnell and Cornelius Varley.

Mr Libson says that prices for many of the artists in the show have risen sharply in recent years. But they are still, on the whole, modest by any standards. Having said that, JMW Turner's magnificent alpine view, the Val d'Aosta from Fort Roche, 1809, has a price on application (POA) tag. The gallery is looking for £1.25m, which of course is not modest.

Against that A Tree in Hyde Park, number 76 in the catalogue, is on offer at £450. Admittedly this is a pencil drawing and not a painting, but watercolours by Cornelius Varley and John Linnell typically start around £7,000 to £8,000 and go up to some £45,000.

A Norfolk cottage that is a watercolour over pencil and is 10 inches by 14 inches costs £3,800. The slightly more detailed, A House in Dolgelly, north Wales again a watercolour over pencil, is £8,000. Both are soft brownish impressions of houses rather than bold-in-your face snapshots.

The point about watercolours is that, despite sharp rises in some areas, they are still largely affordable. As Mr Libson likes to say: "You can buy a painting, a work of art, really, of significance and beauty for the price of a second hand car." And a Victorian watercolour will probably increase in value.

For further information telephone Spink-Leger 020-7629-3538, Christie's, King Street 020-7839-9060.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Once again, a cultivated British lady travels to the Middle East, 'discovers' an enchanting city and falls in love with it (Smitten In Futureville, March 11). Like many of her predecessors, Linda Grant returns from Tel Aviv full of myths and anecdotes but few accurate facts. In the Orient, all is as usual: museums are closed, houses are derelict and the natives have no collective memory of their history. Thank goodness we have such ladies to tell us. Pity she missed the fun to be had in today's Tel Aviv, particularly for the young.
Dalia Manor
School of Oriental and African Studies
University of London WC1

Once again, a cultivated British lady travels to the Middle East, 'discovers' an enchanting city and falls in love with it (Smitten In Futureville, March 11). Like many of her predecessors, Linda Grant returns from Tel Aviv full of myths and anecdotes but few accurate facts. In the Orient, all is as usual: museums are closed, houses are derelict and the natives have no collective memory of their history. Thank goodness we have such ladies to tell us. Pity she missed the fun to be had in today's Tel Aviv, particularly for the young.
Dalia Manor
School of Oriental and African Studies
University of London WC1

David Colquhoun asks why people accept 'untested' herbal remedies (Dear Weekend, March 11). While these may not have been subjected to a testing regime similar to that for new drugs, they have been subjected to human exposure for years, in many cases centuries, without ill effect. And they work, often better than pharmaceutical products. Some opposition to GM food may not be rational, but that doesn't mean there is no case to answer. 'Scientific testing' allowed CJD and Thalidomide into the population.
David Beattie
Chester

Julie Burchill's pun 'married in Hastings and repented in Leicester' (March 11) can be found in The Reluctant Vampire, a children's novel by Eric Morecambe.
Dave Gunning
davegunning@hotmail.com

Julie Burchill is right: a fax is much quicker than an email (March 11). But it is also a potent weapon for consumers' rights. Suppose you order furniture, and weeks later the shop has still not given a delivery date. Its phone is constantly engaged. When you do get through, they promise to look into it and phone back, but never do. Sounds familiar? In such a situation, I put my query in writing and fax it every 30 minutes. The amount of annoyance you cause is well worth paying for, and gets results every time.
Claude Shields
Aylesbury, Bucks

The BBC has had to put up with a lot of fury for revealing key moments from new films. Nicholas Blincoe managed it for two films on release all in one article (Front, March 11).
Neil Paknadel
London N17

Nicholas Blincoe must have been asleep during The Talented Mr Ripley to conclude that Ripley could not come to terms with his homosexuality. He kills Peter not because he can't cope with gay love, but because he will otherwise be exposed. As for the comments on American Beauty, he mistakes clichéd writing for homophobia.
Anatol Orient
anatol@emeraldcity.demon.co.uk

It was the 60s. Hampshire, my team, was playing Kent. Dad had died, and Mum was struggling to know what to do with me, a difficult teenager. I was at the ground early. Then, there he was, my best-ever player. 'Mr Underwood, can I have your autograph, please?' (Famous Then, March 11). Five minutes later, all 10 pictures had been signed, and I'd had a chat with my favourite player. My perspective of what I thought a horrible world was changed, just a little. I disagreed with his venture to South Africa, but he did help a young man see that the world was not all bad. By the way, I'm now a secondary school headteacher.
TW Hunt
Bishop's Castle, Shropshire

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: Drama Queen
fields.standfirst: Kathleen Turner's life has been something of a melodrama from the start. On screen, she'd be the perfect film noir vamp if it weren't for her wicked humour. Strange, then, that the woman herself turns out to be quite different
fields.trailText: Kathleen Turner's life has been something of a melodrama from the start. On screen, she'd be the perfect film noir vamp if it weren't for her wicked humour. Strange, then, that the woman herself turns out to be quite different
fields.body:
It was after we had been talking for about half an hour that I began to wonder if Kathleen Turner could be making everything up. It is partly the way that she says things, with the intensity of having just thought of them. But, more than this, her story is so self-consciously theatrical, so laden down with clichés, that it can't easily be believed. There is a bit too much of everything and, to paraphrase Wilde, whereas one cliché may be accounted bad luck, a whole accumulation begins to look like design.

Then again, anyone who knows Ms Turner's work - from her debut film Body Heat in 1981 through to Serial Mom in 1994 - might say that this runs close to a definition. She is pretty over-the-top. A creature of impulse, a creator of impulse.

There's a great line that Ken Russell gives her in his 1984 film, Crimes Of Passion, in which she plays parallel stereotypes, a frigid career woman by day and a hot-as-hell hooker by night: "B-movies have always been my inspiration," declares the hooker, China Blue. Clichés, stereotypes, stock fantasies, of course, are what we reach for when we don't know which way the plot is going and have to resort to something that we know has worked before.

Clichés are a loss of bottle. This is partly what the film is about. The quick fix. The lengths to which we will all go to find the illusion of safety. It's a quintessential Russell film: a black comedy, complete with nuns and masturbation, and Anthony Perkins doing a reprise of Norman Bates, now a deranged preacher at large on the streets of LA. It is also Turner's favourite of all her films. I spent a lot of time wondering why. Why not, say, Body Heat, her spectacular debut that set up her femme fatale image, the idea of woman as enchantress, purveyor of sex as death, the image she has so brilliantly parodied throughout the rest of her career? Or, for that matter, The War Of The Roses, probably her best part?

Crimes Of Passion pushed her, she says, "to my limit". After completion, she was so exhausted that she slept for 22 hours. It is a clever film, a kind of maze, that leads you in all sorts of wrong directions, teases you, before finally succumbing - no, wrong word - celebrating what some may think is the biggest cliché in the book, love.

Not Kathleen Turner, however. The film, you might say, is a kind of thumbnail sketch of Ms Turner's life. Because it turns out that, in real life, the most provocative woman on celluloid, this fascinatingly mysterious nocturnal diabolique, has been happily married to the same man, Jay, for 18 years. Their daughter, Rachel, is 12. And, at the risk of making her sound dull or unadventurous, which she certainly isn't, I can report that she also tells me, "Sexual fidelity is very important to me and to my husband." And: "Sexuality has never been the core of my personality."

First, the clichés and melodramas. They begin with her birth in - where else? - midwest Missouri, home of American corn. Third child of four, the beauty in the family. Four years later, now living in Cuba, where her father is a diplomat, she is evacuated on the eve of the revolution. On one of the last American planes to leave Havana. "They came for us in the middle of the night, just the women and children. We waited for the men in Florida. My father closed the American embassy."

Next stop, Caracas, where her father was consul, and she was the only blonde on the block. Cuba she had loathed, and still does in her memory, but Caracas she loved, and the deep-throat huskiness of her voice can be read as a kind of tribute to the Spanish language that she spoke there as a kid.

No sooner is she back in Washington, aged nine, than Kennedy is killed. "The President has been shot," she recalls someone saying. And, always the school smart-ass, she recounts her reply: "Don't be silly, that was Abraham Lincoln." As a teenager in London in the late 60s, she decides she wants to go on the stage, and when her father tells her to stop her ridiculous fantasies, she's going to university like her brothers and sister, there is a huge row of the "It's my life" variety.

The irrepressible adolescent, just 17, "runs away from home" and fetches up in... Stratford-on-Avon. She is following her passion, the theatre. In Stratford she sees, no doubt, the production of its day, David Warner's Hamlet, casting herself, surely, not as the blighted Ophelia but as the prince, à la Sarah Bernhardt. Drama queen. Turner arrives back in London after a weekend away, without a penny, and telephones home, reversing the charges. She expects one of her parents to come and pick her up, imagining they'd be so relieved to have her home safely that they'd forget to be too cross.

Have you noticed how, when someone is relating something bad that has happened to them, they always have to start at the beginning and follow through to the end. No short cuts, no editing. The story slows right down; it's all or nothing. As if this is the only way that something truly terrible can be grasped.

"I remember my mother's voice at the end of the phone, saying, 'Get a taxi home, darling', and thinking this was odd because we never did that. And when I got there the house was filled with people I didn't know. My father had died one hour before in the backyard, from a coronary thrombosis. He had been interned by the Japanese in Shanghai for four years during the war. His health never recovered. It was a very bad time." With no diplomatic status to remain in Britain, the family was uprooted, lost their home, and returned to smalltown Springfield, Missouri, where the grandparents lived. "I think it has since changed, but in those days a foreign service widow only got half her husband's pension. So we were broke." Missouri was pretty odd. "I'd never lived in anywhere like the midwest. Er, so that was a first."

She loved her father, she says, "very, very much. A very strong man, a good man." Maybe she is like him? "Yes," she says, "I think maybe I am." She must miss him. "Not really. He has been dead a long time, longer than I knew him."

No theatricality here, only restraint. Which is what happens, I guess, when melodrama turns to reality, comedy to tragedy. In her career, of course, she has done both. But it is parody, irony, that is her true form. Maybe this comes from the diplomatic background. If artifice with an ulterior motive could be one definition of parody, it could stand equally well for diplomacy.

She is hugely likeable. And immensely formidable. "I am Kathleen Turner and you are late" are her first words when we meet. Which is frightening and funny - just like her. And she is right. I am precisely a minute-and-a-half late, according to her watch. It's not worth making an excuse. In her book, late is late. Which is another thing about her. There's a surface baroque extravagance, but it's always undercut with a kind of purism. If she were a city, she would be not Rome, where she longs to live, but Barcelona - think Gaudí's Sagrada Familia, all vulgarity and vertigo.

She is no pushover, clearly, and is not easily flattered - a truly uncommon trait in a film star. When people greet her in the street with, "You are Kathleen Turner. I love you", she corrects them roundly. "I hope you mean you like my work, you don't know me." She doesn't let anyone get away with anything. So, when I say that I imagine that she likes the idea of herself as a bold denter of taboos, she replies, "Not really. Not in my life." She smokes, cigarillos. Swears, not like a trooper, but enough - "I love the theatre because, unlike film, they can't fuck with you." Of course, absolutely no one in Hollywood smokes or swears, which may account for why she lives in New York. But this hardly makes for a revolution.

She has a reputation, too, for being difficult. "In my work." All that means, she says, "is that I know what I want. In a man it would be deemed admirable." She gives me this example: "Say a director asks me to do another take because he wants to pan the room, and I say, 'You don't need me for a shot of the room. Get a dummy.' In my work, I am very sure, and if I run up against someone who is less sure they can be defensive. And, unfortunately, I am not the most tactful person." Difficult, in other words.

She has this way, as she speaks, of leaning seductively forward, her upper torso tilted gently towards you, while raising one eyebrow into the shape of an immaculate isosceles triangle. It's hard to do and very alarming. She used it to great effect in John Water's Serial Mom, the eyebrow going up and down like a bouncing ball as she gets madder and madder, until by the end it's almost permanently raised. It's the one thing that she really likes about film, she says. "With the camera and a 70ft wide screen, even a blink is a sentence. That kind of precision I find interesting."

She thinks she'll miss it when she goes on stage in the West End later this month as Mrs Robinson in Terry Johnson's new adaptation of The Graduate. But I doubt that she'll need it. With that dome of heat that hangs over her, she will smoulder as Mrs Robinson. And, assuming Johnson doesn't turn it into some heavy-handed social satire, she definitely has the whiplash sense of humour that Anne Bancroft so conspicuously lacked in the film. Bancroft is married to Mel Brooks, I say. "That's too bad," says Turner, fast as lightning and not looking remotely sad. "Still, maybe he knows how to make her laugh."

Turner is her mother's daughter, no question. She tells a story about her during their time in Cuba: apparently, towards the end, as the revolution loomed, all the telephones carried one of those eternal recordings; so, with every call, prior to connection, would be heard, "Castro is your saviour. Castro is your future." "My earliest memory is of my mum shouting down the phone: 'Castro is an asshole, Castro is a fucker.' " After their father died it was her mother who kept the family together, made sure he got his wish that all of the children went to college. She was scrupulously loyal to him. She's now 76. "She never married again. Never met anyone, I guess." The two of them are close. "She's coming over to stay with me in May."

It wasn't always the way. Her mother was furious when her daughter, aged 20, insisted on moving from Missouri, where she was in a theatre group with John Goodman, to Baltimore to join another group there. There was another big fight. "I am not your daughter any more. I am a woman, and unless you can treat me as one we cannot go on." Turner packed her bags, got in her car and drove off. About 60 miles out of town, she turned around and drove back. She'd learned, not so long before with her father, that you don't part in anger from people you love. A year later, her mother wrote a letter: "She said that she hoped one day I would understand how frightening it is for a parent not to understand their child's wants. That a parent always tries to keep a child on familiar territory, to keep the child safe. It was a lovely letter from a good woman."

After Baltimore, she moved east again, to New York, where she slept on a friend's floor, went to auditions during the day and was a hotel receptionist or sometime waitress in the evenings.
