It was three months later, now in Los Angeles for something else, that another casting director asked her to read for the part of Matty Walker. The next day she was screen-tested with William Hurt, who was to play what can now be said to be his best role as the self-satisfied lawyer, Ned Racine, whom Matty hires to kill her husband. When executive producer George Lucas saw the screen test, he said simply that he didn't want to look at anyone else. "It was Lucas who said I had to have it. So that was it."

It was great, she says. "Being treated like a goddess, it felt right. I'd never had that much attention in my life." The third child, of course. And then filming ended, the attention stopped, and she had to go back to waitressing in New York. "It's a funny thing that. It was nearly a year later that the film came out. And then I was a star again." But maybe in this interim she learned something about the fickle nature of fame. Or maybe it was just her natural perversity. Because, when all the offers started coming in from Hollywood, "for essentially rip-offs of Body Heat - so boring, so stupid", she just said no.

Then Carl Reiner rang and asked, "Do you have a sense of humour?" Which is how, in only her second film role, in The Man With Two Brains, opposite Steve Martin, and featuring also David Warner, her erstwhile Hamlet, she came to be playing a send-up of the part that made her famous - a femme fatale who kills men for money, and ends up weighing a few hundred pounds.

What makes her so compelling to watch is that you can sense she is not frightened - it's what makes her such a convincing, swashbuckling adventurer, more than the equal of Michael Douglas in Jewel Of The Nile and Romancing The Stone. People such as this can make you frightened for them, viz her mother and father, though probably even they underestimated her. Like Bette Davis before her, there's a strong strain of sado-masochism in her work. Imagine Turner in a remake of Whatever Happened To Baby Jane? But, as she says, Hollywood today would never dare as much. "It seems to me that our national taste is determined by adolescents. Our culture is based entirely now on teenagers."

Sure, not everyone is a fan and not every role is a gem, but she makes her mark. It's interesting, looking back, how she never looked young. There has never been anything of the ingénue about her. She was always too old for Hollywood. She carried this weight of experience around, all the frenetic activity of her past, and channelled it into her work with an almost clownish or burlesque quality. She never expected much of the business, she says: "I knew that after 40 I would be less valued. Experience is not something American film values."

She says that she never expected much of her personal life, either. But here she was surprised. "I was ambitious to succeed. I didn't think I'd get married. I know men aren't well trained at having a wife who gets more attention than them. So it never seemed likely that I'd have a stable marriage and home." She wasn't going to settle for less. She was 29 when she met Jay, a property developer. "Up to that point, his idea of family life was picking up the kids every other weekend." After four months, they were "engaged". After eight months, they married. That was in 1983 - either the same year she filmed Crimes Of Passion or soon after. It has been great, she says. "Though, God knows, it hasn't been smooth."

Between Prizzi's Honor in 1985, in which she was a contract killer opposite Jack Nicholson and seemed to have little lust left for anything except killing, and Serial Mom in 1994 - almost a decade, during which time she became a mother - only The War Of The Roses, a satire on marital mores opposite Michael Douglas, stands out. The actress who was upward-bound suddenly dropped from sight. Somehow, the lustre left her. She didn't seem to have the enthusiasm for making movies any more. Serial Mom was different, a return to parodic form: all that blatant, man-eater eye-rolling as she devours her victims. She's a fleshy vamp, the men are puny wimps. It's her circus, a solo performance, and a lot to carry.

It was during Serial Mom that she noticed her feet were swelling. She couldn't get into her shoes. She didn't mention this to anyone. Then her neck locked, and she couldn't turn her head. The joints in her hands swelled so much that it got to the point where she couldn't pick up a glass, the pain was too great. Several medical diagnoses later, she was informed that she had the incurable disease, rheumatoid arthritis - a swelling of the lining of the joints.

Most people, she explains, have a rheumatoid factor of between 40 and 60. "Mine was 1,600." Immuno suppressants (ie, steroids) and anti-inflammatory drugs were the only treatment available. On the steroids, she blew up like a balloon. Because of the pain, she was a virtual cripple. Rheumatoid arthritis is what is known as an auto-immune disease, an illness where the body's immune system reacts inappropriately and actually creates the problem in seeking to cure it. The ultimate ironic illness, you might say.

Of course, the illness fits perfectly the B-movie theory of her life. Beautiful actress succumbs to incurable progressive illness. Except she didn't succumb. So what about: beautiful actress struck down by incurable illness triumphs over adversity? Enough clichés. She didn't have a plot, she didn't have anything to hang on to. She didn't triumph. She just carried on day-to-day as best she could against worn-out medical advice that there was nothing to reverse the illness.

Then the rumours started. "That I was a drunk, that's why I had put on all the weight." There were photos of her in the papers. Unrecognisable. "Hollywood's a strange business. It's happy to hire people who are drunk on set or arrested for drug use, over and over again, but being ill is quite another thing. So my policy was to keep quiet and let them think what they wanted. I decided not to tell anyone in the business that I was ill. Still, I think that I was right about that." In 1997, at the height of the illness, she was giving interviews in which she spoke of it in the past tense. And there was a further imperative: her husband's business was going through a hard time. "I needed to work."

She kept going, she says, through eight years of chronic pain. Angry, though never sure if it was the illness or the drugs that made her lash out. Crying. "Oh yeah. But trying not to cry in front of Jay and Rachel." They were wonderful, she says. Rachel was four when Turner was diagnosed. She was too weak to walk, too weak to pick up her daughter. Far too weak to pretend. Then, 18 months ago, a new drug was administered that reversed most of the effects of the illness. "I remember being met by Rachel and Jay at the airport. When I saw them, I just started to run. Then I heard Rachel saying, 'Mummy, you ran.' She was so aware and so happy for me."

When your children see you more helpless than they are themselves, she says, it changes something in the balance of your relationship. And for the better. "You are no longer the all-powerful parent. You have to cede that position, and it brings you closer. Through pain you learn a lot. It's unfortunate, but it's true. Maybe not. But it's not only through suffering that you learn. It seems she learned a great deal from her parents and from her wise mother in particular. That looks are only a part of a persona, not the core of the self. "Beauty wasn't made much of in my family. I had an older sister who wasn't as pretty as me and I was always told: 'Don't pat yourself on the back for something you didn't earn.'" This stood her in good stead when she began to lose her looks through the illness.

"Of course you feel sexually threatened. You lose confidence. I became a little timid, yes. But my whole sense of self worth wasn't bound up with my looks fortunately. But now, she says, she is once again turning heads on the street and it's wonderful. "Once, it was a burden to me. Now, it's the icing on the cake.

The sexually predatory, cunning older woman. She'll need all the humour and the irony that she can muster if this is not to look like some kind of dinosaur of sexual politics. Whereas in the play, Elaine Robinson "will be a real person."

fields.bodyText: It was after we had been talking for about half an hour that I began to wonder if Kathleen Turner could be making everything up. It is partly the way that she says things, with the intensity of having just thought of them. But, more than this, her story is so self-consciously theatrical, so laden down with clichés, that it can't easily be believed. There is a bit too much of everything and, to paraphrase Wilde, whereas one cliché may be accounted bad luck, a whole accumulation begins to look like design. Then again, anyone who knows Ms Turner's work - from her debut film Body Heat in 1981 through to Serial Mom in 1994 - might say that this runs close to a definition. She is pretty over-the-top. A creature of impulse, a creator of impulse. There's a great line that Ken Russell gives her in his 1984 film, Crimes Of Passion, in which she plays parallel stereotypes, a frigid career woman by day and a hot-as-hell hooker by night: "B-movies have always been my inspiration," declares the hooker, China Blue. Clichés, stereotypes, stock fantasies, of course, are what we reach for when we don't know which way the plot is going and have to resort to something that we know has worked before. Clichés are a loss of bottle. This is partly what the film is about. The quick fix. The lengths to which we will all go to find the illusion of safety. It's a quintessential Russell film: a black comedy, complete with nuns and masturbation, and Anthony Perkins doing a reprise of Norman Bates, now a deranged preacher at large on the streets of LA. It is also Turner's favourite of all her films. I spent a lot of time wondering why. Why not, say, Body Heat, her spectacular debut that set up her femme fatale image, the idea of woman as enchantress, purveyor of sex as death, the image she has so brilliantly parodied throughout the rest of her career? Or, for that matter, The War Of The Roses, probably her best part? Crimes Of Passion pushed her, she says, "to my limit". After completion, she was so exhausted that she slept for 22 hours. It is a clever film, a kind of maze, that leads you in all sorts of wrong directions, teases you, before finally succumbing - no, wrong word - celebrating what some may think is the biggest cliché in the book, love. Not Kathleen Turner, however. The film, you might say, is a kind of thumbnail sketch of Ms Turner's life. Because it turns out that, in real life, the most provocative woman on celluloid, this fascinatingly mysterious nocturnal diabolique, has been happily married to the same man, Jay, for 18 years. Their daughter, Rachel, is 12. And, at the risk of making her sound dull or unadventurous, which she certainly isn't, I can report that she also tells me, "Sexual fidelity is very important to me and to my husband." And: "Sexuality has never been the core of my personality." First, the clichés and melodramas. They begin with her birth in - where else? - midwest Missouri, home of American corn. Third child of four, the beauty in the family. Four years later, now living in Cuba, where her father is a diplomat, she is evacuated on the eve of the revolution. On one of the last American planes to leave Havana. "They came for us in the middle of the night, just the women and children. We waited for the men in Florida. My father closed the American embassy." Next stop, Caracas, where her father was consul, and she was the only blonde on the block. Cuba she had loathed, and still does in her memory, but Caracas she loved, and the deep-throat huskiness of her voice can be read as a kind of tribute to the Spanish language that she spoke there as a kid. No sooner is she back in Washington, aged nine, than Kennedy is killed. "The President has been shot," she recalls someone saying. As a teenager in London in the late 60s, she decides she wants to go on the stage, and when her father tells her to stop her ridiculous fantasies, she's going to university like her brothers and sister, there is a huge row of the "It's my life" variety. The irrepressible adolescent, just 17, "runs away from home" and fetches up in... Stratford-on-Avon. She is following her passion, the theatre. In Stratford she sees, no doubt, the production of its day, David Warner's Hamlet, casting herself, surely, not as the blighted Ophelia but as the prince, à la Sarah Bernhardt. Drama queen. Turner arrives back in London after a weekend away, without a penny, and telephones home, reversing the charges. She expects one of her parents to come and pick her up, imagining they'd be so relieved to have her home safely that they'd forget to be too cross. Have you noticed how, when someone is relating something bad that has happened to them, they always have to start at the beginning and follow through to the end. No short cuts, no editing. The story slows right down; it's all or nothing. As if this is the only way that something truly terrible can be grasped. "I remember my mother's voice at the end of the phone, saying, 'Get a taxi home, darling', and thinking this was odd because we never did that. And when I got there the house was filled with people I didn't know. My father had died one hour before in the backyard, from a coronary thrombosis. He had been interned by the Japanese in Shanghai for four years during the war. His health never recovered. It was a very bad time." With no diplomatic status to remain in Britain, the family was uprooted, lost their home, and returned to smalltown Springfield, Missouri, where the grandparents lived. "I think it has since changed, but in those days a foreign service widow only got half her husband's pension. So we were broke." Missouri was pretty odd. "I'd never lived in anywhere like the midwest. Er, so that was a first." She loved her father, she says, "very, very much. A very strong man, a good man." Maybe she is like him? "Yes," she says, "I think maybe I am." She must miss him. "Not really. He has been dead a long time, longer than I knew him." No theatricality here, only restraint. Which is what happens, I guess, when melodrama turns to reality, comedy to tragedy. In her career, of course, she has done both. But it is parody, irony, that is her true form. Maybe this comes from the diplomatic background. If artifice with an ulterior motive could be one definition of parody, it could stand equally well for diplomacy. She is hugely likeable. I am precisely a minute-and-a-half late, according to her watch. It's not worth making an excuse. In her book, late is late. Which is another thing about her. There's a surface baroque extravagance, but it's always undercut with a kind of purism. If she were a city, she would be not Rome, where she longs to live, but Barcelona - think Gaudí's Sagrada Familia, all vulgarity and vertigo. fields.trailText: First of all, there are the facts. Sylvia Plath, the American poet, committed suicide in 1963 at the age of 30, gassing herself in her London flat after leaving out bread and milk for her two children, a daughter of nearly three and a son of 13 months, who were sleeping in an upstairs bedroom.
fields.body:
First of all, there are the facts. Sylvia Plath, the American poet, committed suicide in 1963 at the age of 30, gassing herself in her London flat after leaving out bread and milk for her two children, a daughter of nearly three and a son of 13 months, who were sleeping in an upstairs bedroom. Her husband, Ted Hughes, who subsequently became poet laureate, had recently left her. The woman with whom he was having an affair, Assia Wevill, also killed herself six years later. Plath's father had died when she was eight; she suffered depression all her life, and attempted suicide, almost succeeding, at 20.

There are her poems, some of the most brilliant of the 20th century, the finest of which - Daddy, Lady Lazarus, Edge - she wrote when in the most pain, in the last few months of her life: confessional, brutal, not-nice assessments of the viciousness of the world, her relationships with her father, mother and husband, and her belief that "Dying is an art . . . I do it exceptionally well."

There is her novel, The Bell Jar, largely autobiographical, about her breakdown, psychiatric treatment and electro-convulsive therapy.

There are her husband's poems, also some of the most brilliant of the modern age. Birthday Letters, a book about his relationship with Plath that was published only months before his death in 1998, revealed at last Hughes's torment about his first wife's untimely death.

There are her letters to her mother: cheery, happy-go-lucky, all-American confidence that the world was a much, much jollier place than it ever seemed in her poetry.

And there are the attempts to claim her life story after her death, to assert a real "truth" - five biographies, each causing a major controversy (either they were too anti-Hughes, in which case Hughes and his sister Olwyn refused to allow the writer to quote Plath's poems in full, or they were too pro-Hughes, which Plath-lovers thought betrayed her memory), and countless memoirs: from a neighbour she knew in her village, from a woman she met at college, from the man in the downstairs flat. In fact, the most insightful book written about the Plath phenomenon is not a biography at all, but an analysis of the analyses, an interpretation of the interpretations - Janet Malcolm's electric 1994 The Silent Woman, which looked at the Plath/Hughes industry, rather than at Plath and Hughes themselves.

In all of this, Plath has remained, in Malcolm's words, the silent woman. A few recordings exist of her poetry readings - her voice is throaty, powerful, unforgettable - but we have never heard from Sylvia Plath, in her own words, the words she wrote in private, for herself, to try to make sense of the inner life that was ultimately to destroy her. Until now, her journals have never been published in full, anywhere. A much-truncated version, about a third of the total length, was published in the US in 1982; it was co-edited by Hughes, and his omissions are illuminating about the former poet laureate. But only in Britain are we now able to read all of her words - or all that survive - in the original.

The journals reveal, more than anything, a woman in conflict. In an early entry, she writes, "God, is this all it is, the ricocheting down the corridor of laughter and tears? Of self-worship and self-loathing? Of glory and disgust?" But they also expose a multi- layered identity, many elements of which were ahead of her time. Sometimes, she's the 50s housewife ("I married a real poet, and my life is redeemed: to love, serve and create"); sometimes, she's the sexually-liberated 60s child ("We had a very good f'ing. Enormously good, perhaps the best yet"); sometimes, the 70s feminist ("I must move myself first, before I move others - a woman famous among women"); sometimes, the 90s Bridget Jones ("Don't drink much. Be friendly & more subdued. Work on inner life - to enrich.") If we add these elements to the fact that Plath is forever stuck in the role of victim - always the young mother abandoned with two children, always the brilliant woman destroyed by her husband's faithlessness - it becomes clear why she has been, in many ways, an icon for women.

It is here in her diaries that Plath reveals what she really thinks - about her depression, about her sexuality and about Hughes. Hughes burned the journal from the last few months before her death ("I destroyed it because I did not want her children to have to read it," he said. "In those days, I regarded forgetfulness as an essential part of survival."), and the last diary before that disappeared (there is a belief that a female friend of Hughes's took it while on a visit to his house after Plath's death, and that it might still turn up). But the picture Plath paints of early married life with her "demigod", the "big, blasting dangerous love", is often passionate, sexy and loving - more real than any attempts to describe it by others.

An icon who died young, Plath has come to be defined by her death, as if her life was worth nothing except as a preamble to the big event. Perhaps, in some ways, that's as she saw it herself. Certainly the poems obsessed with death fascinate us more because we know what happened to her; just as the journal entries in which she ponders what her life may be at 40 - when we know that she died at 30 - or complains about a wonky car exhaust slowly gassing her - when we know that she gassed herself to death - are almost unbearably poignant.

The journals remind us that there was a time when Sylvia Plath was alive and living - angry, happy, distressed, bitchy, silly, right, wrong. In her own words, without the filter of biography or poetry, here, the silent woman speaks for herself.

fields.headline: Best of both worlds
fields.standfirst: Architect Ushida Findlay's creations aren't like other buildings. But then, their inspiration does come from the opposite ends of the earth. By Dominic Murphy
fields.trailText: Architect Ushida Findlay's creations aren't like other buildings. But then, their inspiration does come from the opposite ends of the earth
fields.body:
A building can be big, small, imposing, even beautiful - it can also, if you're architects Ushida Findlay, be soft and hairy, too. In 1992, the Anglo-Japanese partnership was high on the success of its first project, the Echo Chamber, when a young couple phoned with an unusual request. They had seen the Echo Chamber in the Tokyo suburbs and had loved the way the house seemed to wrap itself around its courtyard, creating both privacy and a sense of space. They had also read Dalí's prediction that architecture would one day be soft and hairy, and wanted a part of this future for themselves. Would Eisaku Ushida and Kathryn Findlay oblige?

Would they indeed. The house was built in Tsukuba New Science City, a relatively green area on the edge of the Tokyo commuter belt. As well as the soft and hairy part, says Findlay, the clients "wanted to have some kind of message for the neighbours - not to destroy the environment". So, the turf roof has been allowed to grow wild, as a reminder of the unkempt, scrubby wilderness that was there before. As for the building, like the Echo Chamber, it too wraps itself around a central courtyard, the outside walls gently curving to accentuate its flowing form. And, in one corner - a nod, no doubt, to the surrealist inspiration for the whole place - there is a blue, egg-shaped pod with a bathroom inside.

Inside, the walls are hung with canvas, a door is covered in fake fur, and plants are draped from their pots. "The form is soft, like the lining of someone's lungs," says Findlay. And the hairiness? "Obvious - hairiness implies something a bit out of control. The thing is that everything in Japan is under control and it's a way of saying everything doesn't have to be like that."

Findlay and Ushida met in Japan in the early 80s. Britain at the time was depressed: economically, emotionally and, at least in terms of what was being built, creatively. Architecture that got made tended towards the historical pastiche, and Prince Charles was blathering on about carbuncles.

"When I first moved to Japan," says Findlay, "the UK architecture scene was very dull. Everything seemed to be about renovation. I was very interested in the energy that Japan had. To get started and to do interesting things is much easier in Japan." Those "interesting things" include the Truss Wall House, a dwelling that is voluptuous with humps and curves: a seemingly continuous piece of moulded concrete that is as far as you can get from the image of straight lines and cold, unforgiving surfaces. The building technique is also highly innovative, its flowing form created by a frame of bent steel reinforcing bars, overlaid with wire mesh, on to which concrete was poured. In a similar vein is Polyphony, a house that seems to spiral from a central cylinder and that has a grand piano at its core. "It was for a couple who loved music. We designed all the rooms so you could play and hear music. There was a parallel between the structure of the building and the repetitive acoustic cycles in music, so I suppose the house is a metaphor for cyclical music."

Findlay spends most of her time in Japan, where she is associate professor of architecture at Tokyo University. That a woman holds such a senior position at the country's most prestigious academic institution is impressive enough. That she is also not Japanese is unprecedented.

Still, it was not until the completion of Polyphony in 1997 that Ushida and Findlay were confident enough to expand to London. The move has brought huge dividends, with the five-member UK practice now bigger than the Japanese arm. The firm recently completed its largest project to date: a lozenge-shaped apartment building in Glasgow, characteristically organic in form, rounded at the front and with a series of cascading terraces.

While much of Ushida Findlay's work appears to be state of the art, the architects themselves are not easily categorised. Not for them the po-faced rigours of minimalism, or the olde-worlde with mod cons of the Prince Charles set. Their buildings look space-age, but in a retro kind of way, and they aren't frightened to exploit traditional crafts, where appropriate. A pool that they are building in the Sussex countryside, for example, has a hi-tech glass surround, but is topped by a thatched roof - not only does this blend in with the farmhouse it sits behind, but it means that, should the roof ever need fixing, expert local labour should be relatively easy to come by.

In another current project, just south of London's Blackfriars Bridge, they have created a Japanese interior inside three loft-style flats that have been knocked into one - walk through the front door, and you're greeted by a Japanese-style platform of tatami mats concealed behind shoji screens, its aspect facing windows overlooking the Thames.

There is, says Findlay, a "continuity" running through their work, however. "I'm really interested in sustainability. When you first become interested, you're confronted with this forest of information, and it's difficult as an architect to deal with it all - how to insulate walls properly, control airflow." The solution, then, is "to develop a design attitude which can embody sustainability but in a language which is more fluid. Sometimes, it can be almost not there, sometimes just part of the ground. So it's less fairly obvious."

For example, Findlay (this time as the Kathryn Findlay Laboratory, with Tomoko Taguchi) has designed buildings that not only takes account of the elements, but whose form is dictated by them. At the almost finished Kasahara community meeting hall in Gifu, Japan, the eaves are designed to be low enough to protect visitors from strong sun in summer and high enough to let in light in winter. And, in a competition project for an art gallery in Aormori, the building is sloped so that drifting snow will catch on the roof, insulating the inside. "If you have a rigorous system with no tolerance, that doesn't give you the most sustainable options," says Findlay of the notion of "schools" of architecture. Design, she adds, "shouldn't just appeal to the intellect, but to the senses, too." It is synaethesia in design. "The sound of a bell, say, makes you feel cool. A bell rings because wind passes through it, so if you hear a bell you think of wind, which makes you feel cool."

It is this latter attitude that prevails in Japan, while, says Findlay, sustainability is explored more in British design. Ushida Findlay, with a finger in both pies, can take the best from the two countries, yet, culturally and intellectually, belongs to neither. All the better, says Findlay: "You can stand on the edge of Japan and see how they do things, but you're not absorbed by it. It's the same in Britain. There is always this stateless thing that allows you to be more fluid." Or, in the case of one house in Tsukuba New Science City, soft and hairy.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort gets a lot more than he bargained for out of a dinner in Liverpool
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort gets a lot more than he bargained for out of a dinner in Liverpool
fields.body:
It was 11pm, and I was sitting in the car waiting for Arbuthnot to come out of the restaurant on the other side of the road. I was passing the time admiring the handsome, Victorian, neo-classical buildings opposite, and the peacock-tail fanlight window above the door of 60 Hope Street in particular. I was slightly startled when the passenger door opened. Funny, I thought, I hadn't seen Arbuthnot coming across the road.

I was rather more startled when a completely strange young woman slid into the front seat trailing clouds of Joie de Nuit.

"I'm terribly sorry," I said. "I'm not a mini-cab driver. I'm waiting for a friend to come out of the restaurant."

"Oh," she said, "I thought you wanted the business."

"The business?" I said.

"You know, the business," she said, and gestured unmistakably.

"Oh, gosh," I said. "Well, that's very thoughtful of you, but . . ."

"Sorry," she said, and was gone.

I had never been to Liverpool before. A shameful confession, I know, but there it is. It was, however, rather reassuring to have its reputation as a fast-moving, cosmopolitan place so unexpectedly confirmed. Yet while no one can deny the city's cultural colour, hitherto it has not had what you might call an outstanding reputation as a gastronomic centre. Now, perhaps following in the footsteps of Manchester, Birmingham and Leeds, things are beginning to look up. For evidence, look no further than 60 Hope Street.

It's new - well, 10 months old, anyway, which is long enough to get any starting glitches ironed out, but not long enough to have lost the freshness and enthusiasm of the neophyte enterprise; nor for the cream walls to be blotted with fingerprints or the big blocks of tasteful primary colours to become chipped and scuffed.

I have remarked already on the classical nature of the outside of the building. The inside bears no relation to it whatsoever, beyond preserving the handsome scale of the rooms. The dining room is thoroughly modern, but it's a tasteful modernity, rather than an in-your-face modernity, with lots of natural wood, glass and chrome to offset the bold colouring. It may not be original, but it is very pleasant.

The menu is pleasant, too, and something more than simply a clone of what passes for "Modern British" cooking these days. Why, there was Bayonne ham with potatoes, egg and Pommery mustard, and smoked salmon with Scotch pancake and crème frache, and roast saddle of rabbit with black pudding and parsnip and grilled calves' liver with potato, ham and sage ballotine, to name but a few of the less standard dishes.

For Arbuthnot, there was seared scallops and creamed celeriac followed by Goosnargh duck breast with Thai red risotto followed by deep-fried jam sandwich with Carnation milk ice cream. For a man suffering from a savage cold and who had eaten eight courses at lunch, this was little short of heroic. I was rather more modest, deciding to stake a good deal on the tuna stack, then venison with red cabbage and a plate of cheeses to finish up.

I think that cheese can often be a good marker for a restaurant, and at 60 Hope Street they were exceptional, English - Appleby's Cheshire, Keen's (I think) Cheddar and Duckett's aged Caerphilly - beautifully kept and in the full flower of their flavour. But, in truth, 60 Hope Street was something of a curate's egg in the delivery department. Arbuthnot's seared scallops with creamed celeriac was an outstanding dish - the scallops just cooked through and singing with that delicate sweetness, the creamed celeriac melding in with its own slightly fruitier sweetness. My venison with red cabbage was not quite in that inspired class, but it was pretty damned fine nevertheless, a classic routine carried through with an Astaire/ Rogers flair. The cabbage was crispish, but unassertive. The meat was fine-grained, nicely hung, but not rank, all sauced with a particularly well-judged gravy.

But against those triumphs I would have to set my tuna stack, which was a kind of dinner-party dish - poppadum-like wafers separated by first the fish and then a cloud of green salad. It was difficult to see the point of it all, and the poppadum things tasted as if they had been fried in stale oil, a feature that became more noticeable with Arbuthnot's ingenious-sounding deep-fried jam sandwich. This might have been a pre-eminently pleasure-giving pudding had it not been for the overwhelming taste of less-than-fresh oil that penetrated even Arbuthnot's clogged sinuses.

Finally, I am not convinced that risotto is best served as a garnish to a hunk of duck. I have never had a version in which the textures did not clash violently, as they did here. It was a pity, because the two principal elements of the dish were, individually, well prepared. They just didn't get along together.

The bill came out to £73.10, that is £50.60 for the food and £22.50 for the wine and other matters. It strikes me that this is what you might expect to pay in London for a very similar experience, albeit with less originality in the cooking, less pleasant service and less strenuous efforts to please. And in London I have yet to be diverted with such a charming post-prandial offer.

Arbuthnot's seared scallops with creamed celeriac was an outstanding dish - the scallops just cooked through and singing with that delicate sweetness, the creamed celeriac melding in with its own slightly fruitier sweetness. My venison with red cabbage was not quite in that inspired class, but it was pretty damned fine nevertheless, a classic routine carried through with an Astaire/ Rogers flair. The cabbage was crispish, but unassertive. The meat was fine-grained, nicely hung, but not rank, all sauced with a particularly well-judged gravy. But against those triumphs I would have to set my tuna stack, which was a kind of dinner-party dish - poppadum-like wafers separated by first the fish and then a cloud of green salad. It was difficult to see the point of it all, and the poppadum things tasted as if they had been fried in stale oil, a feature that became more noticeable with Arbuthnot's ingenious-sounding deep-fried jam sandwich. This might have been a pre-eminently pleasure-giving pudding had it not been for the overwhelming taste of less-than-fresh oil that penetrated even Arbuthnot's clogged sinuses. Finally, I am not convinced that risotto is best served as a garnish to a hunk of duck. I have never had a version in which the textures did not clash violently, as they did here. It was a pity, because the two principal elements of the dish were, individually, well prepared. They just didn't get along together. The bill came out to £73.10, that is £50.60 for the food and £22.50 for the wine and other matters. It strikes me that this is what you might expect to pay in London for a very similar experience, albeit with less originality in the cooking, less pleasant service and less strenuous efforts to please. And in London I have yet to be diverted with such a charming post-prandial offer.

fields.headline: Sharp practice
fields.standfirst: Vinegar
fields.trailText: The Knowledge
fields.body:
The subject

Fermented fluid with added bacteria and a smidgen of wood extract (yum!). Ancient preservative. Essential salad ingredient.

The basics

Any weakish alcoholic beverage is a sitting duck for airborne bacteria - acetobacter aceti - if stored without a tight seal. The bacteria oxidise the alcohol, turning it into acetic acid. In the old days, this happened to a lot of wine. Drinkers gagged. Cooks cheered. The 'sour wine' was vin aigre , which pitched up in English as vinegar. But not as balsamic vinegar, which is a different keg of bugs. Or malt vinegar, which is made from hopless beer.

The details

Making vinegar calls for patience and good ingredients. That's why high-volume, industrial producers need a short cut - namely, put retching-grade vino in big containers with wood shavings and acetobacters, and speed up acetification at the expense of flavour and aroma. What they're scared of is the Orléans process: wood barrels filled with good wine and good vinegar (to start things rolling), plus a bacteria-rich slime called mother of vinegar . Orléans takes longer and costs more, but boy oh boy do you taste the result. Proper vinegar based on Burgundy, Bordeaux, sherry et al retains the wine's character; use in smaller quantities than industrial-grade.

Where to buy

Go hunting: killer vinegar is produced in small quantities and will be found, usually by accident, in specialist shops. If you don't mind paying a small fortune for mind- blowing quality, ring the Oil Merchant (020-8740 1335) for its trio of Piedmontese varietal vinegars, peaking at £11.95/25cl for the exquisite Barolo. Supermarkets can't often oblige, though Sainsbury's Special Selection Vin Santo Vinegar (£3.49/200ml) is delicious, and the widely available Aspall organic vinegars are pretty good, too. Good news: if you need large quantities for cooking, industrial stuff will serve with gallantry, if not distinction.

The easy way out

Acetic acid and red food colouring - just kidding!

fields.headline: Kids' stuff
fields.standfirst: Shortcake
fields.trailText: Shortcake
fields.body:
Simple, fun and, above all, delicious. Serves eight.

75g sugar

150g unsalted butter, at room temperature

250g flour

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/ gas mark 4. Rub all the ingredients together in a bowl, until it turns a breadcrumby texture.

Set aside two tablespoons of the mix, and press the rest into the base of a 20cm round tin lined with silicone paper, or cut into shapes and place on a baking tray. Sprinkle the reserved mix over the top, and bake for around 25 minutes, until the shortcake is golden and firm to the touch. Leave to cool before turning out of the tin.

To serve, sprinkle over a little caster sugar (if cooked in the tin, cut into eight pieces).

 Kids' Stuff recipes devised and cooked at Petit Cordon Bleu. Call 020-7935 3503 for details of children's classes.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck tries to get his tongue around Ktima Voyatsi
fields.body:
Try getting your tongue around Ktima Voyatsi. Not a smooth ride is it? Greek wine rarely is, and Ktima Voyatsi 1997 is Greek, extremely red, but very far from rough (though it's good and ready). And very proud of it, it is, too. Oddbins stocks the wine, of course (but at its Fine Wine stores only, alas, for even Oddbins couldn't get hold of enough to stretch to every branch), as it's the only place that's bonkers enough to stock it. The wine costs £7.99, my life! Who in her, or even his, right mind lays out £7.99 on a Greek red? Outside a restaurant, that is.

And this is, I fancy, where Ktima Voyatsi 1997 scores (16 points, out of 20, as it happens), for what better wine than this one to go with one of those Greek lamb dishes that slow-roast for a fortnight with a thousand cloves of garlic? You just have to find a taverna that permits BYO custom. The wine has astonishingly savoury tannins and a delightfully chewy texture, and exhibits deep, black fruit of style and savour. It is an exceedingly bravura wine. It tastes as if it has been hewn out of mountains strewn with herbs, bracken and glacial boulders.

Sainsbury's Mont Gras Carmenere Reserva 1998 is a different side of a different mountainside altogether (smooth rather than rocky, Andean rather than Olympian). Being Chilean, it is ineffably sveltely textured though, being carmenere, it has a hint of louche mystery about it, too. For years, Chileans grew carmenere - a somewhat discredited old Bordeaux variety, now vanished from there - but thought it was merlot, and were much aggrieved when a wandering ampelographer (a vine boffin, to you and me) popped up and told them what it was. We will, I suspect, be seeing it more and more as a vinified individual variety, as its delicious combination of rich tannicity and jammy fruitiness gains favour. This example rates 16 points, costs £5.99, and merlot it ain't.

Diemersdal Merlot 1998, however, very definitely is merlot, though I'm grateful that the label informed me of the fact because this Cape wine's presence on the palate offers no huge clues. It is rich, ripe, rivetingly well-packed with lush, fruity flavours, and it goes all squashy and meaty on the finish. It rates 15.5 points and costs £5.69 at Tesco. Bela Fonte Baga 1998, from Portugal, is spikier; a vigorously fresh-edged and keenly tannic specimen, it has food-friendly cherry/plum fruit, and is textured and taut. It rates 15.5 points and costs £4.79 at Tesco. Also at Tesco is Domaine du Soleil Syrah/Malbec Vin de Pays d'Oc, a non-vintage wine rating 14.5 points and costing £3.99. It is delicious and, though something of a rustic country bumpkin, comes across daintily on the finish.

Tesco also has some interesting special offers, ending on March 28, on four worthy reds. Trulli Primitivo del Salento 1998, from Italy (14 points, price down to £3.79), is juicy yet very dry to finish. The own-label Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon (14 points, reduced to £3.49) has a warm, brisk edge of no-nonsense fruitiness, is sympathetic to the tastebuds, bold to the throat, and most agreeable with roast meat and grilled, cheesy vegetables. The own-label French Grenache Prestige (14.5 points, reduced to £2.99) smells a mite vegetal, but gets into terrific fruity gear on the tastebuds and is also an excellent food wine. As is African Legend Pinotage 1998, from the Cape. This 14-point wine, with the typical, burned aroma and rampantly soft fruit of this native grape, is also a specimen of the hearty quaffing variety and as such may perform best consumed from a Viking horn. Certainly, fancy glassware is inappropriate, not because the wine's price has been lopped down to £3.99 but because it is so unpretentiously drinkable and lush.

As if the scantiness of these prices were not enough, I am informed that all Tesco wines, including the ones above, will be subject to further price cuts from tomorrow until close of business on the 25th - that is, if you buy six bottles of any wine, or six of mixed wines, you get a 20% discount as well. Doesn't that send a frisson of pleasure up your spine?

 Superplonk 2000 and Streetplonk 2000 are both published by Hodder at £5.99 each. To order copies at the special price of £4.99 per book (plus 99p UK p&p), freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText: Bamboo | Home sow | Hedgehog trimmings
fields.body:
Plant of the week

Bamboo is good for a wet part of the garden or for screening a grisly view (or neighbour): a real and unusual beauty is Phyllostachys nigra , with its fresh-green foliage and ebony black canes. Unlike some other bamboo species, which can be invasive, this one is relatively well-behaved, growing in clumps around 3m high (with a 1m spread). To buy a plant, contact Burncoose Nurseries, Gwennap, Redruth, Cornwall TR16 6BJ, 01209 860316. Prices start at £22.50.

Home sow

From home to homegrown, it's not that far. Tiny tins of oriental mustard, snowpea, pak choi and Japanese radish seeds, £1 each, from Habitat; 0845 6010740 for nearest store (www.habitat.net).

Time to...

Search for that faded label on any clematis plants in the garden. Many that flower later in the year on this spring's growth will benefit from being pruned hard now - these are generally plants in the late large-flowered; viticella; texensis; late species; and herbaceous groups. If the names and groups are complicated, at least the pruning is simple: it involves finding the first strong pair of outward-pointing buds above ground level and cutting just above them.

Hedgehog trimmings

Hedgehogs emerging early from hibernation need to build up their fat reserves (many had litters late last autumn) but the slugs and other pests they feed on are currently in short supply, says Anne Jenkins of the British Hedgehog Preservation Society. Leaving food out will help: apparently, if there are no slugs around, hedgehogs will make do with fresh water, cereal and dried fruit.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'Those men are going to try on dresses!' hisses Harriet. 'But I don't care. It's cool.'
fields.trailText: 'Those men are going to try on dresses!' hisses Harriet. 'But I don't care. It's cool.'
fields.body:
'Mum? I wish Henry hadn't finished with Holly. She was really, like, cool." Harriet admired Holly's Gothic style, the black buckles, the cobweb sleeves, the spiky dog-collar. My idea of Gothic is more Salisbury Cathedral. But though Henry and Holly are apart, the air sizzles with recrimination. She rings up several times a day and just breathes moodily. I know it's her. I can hear her nose-rings rattling.

Gabrielle, my new pupil, is a little more whole-some, visually. She wears trainers, jeans and loose tunics. She sinks down into her loose tunic while I am coaching her, and pulls down the sleeves to protect her fingernails from my horrible breath. I am acid rain personified. I could probably destroy Salisbury Cathedral in a weekend just by exhaling in an ecstasy of contemplation. "The end of an essay is very important, Gabrielle," I urge, malodorously. "Try and finish off with a quotation, it gives it panache." Gabrielle frowns, too polite to ask what panache is. "Panache," I continue, "bazazz - you know, sparkle, fizz." Trust none of the aforementioned are street slang for drugs.

Nearly half-past. Get up, accept Gabrielle's envelope, smile encouragingly. "You're doing brilliantly!" I assure her, then trip over her bag in my urgent desire to get her out of the house. She slithers sideways along the hall wall. She wants to escape, too. We both want exactly the same out of this relationship: for it to end. With or without panache.

Find Henry slumped in a chair, the phone in his ear, watching MTV and occasionally muttering "yeah" or "nah". Harriet hovers, eavesdropping. "Holly's trying to get him back!" she whispers. "Mum, can you take me to Camden Market for my birthday?" Sudden rogue impulse tempts me to agree. Perhaps also theatre matinee? Educational.

On Saturday, therefore, we push through heaving crowds towards The Black Rose, Gothic emporium. Try to ignore skulls and T-shirts bearing blasphemies for which one would have been roasted alive in the 17th century. Harriet rattles rapturously through the corsets. "This one's quite nice," I suggest. "Velvet, look. Soft, too - reminds me of Romeo and Juliet."

"Thanks Mum," retorts Harriet, caressing patent leather, "but I'd prefer a nice stiff one."

Very ordinary-looking men, who might be librarians or plumbers, queue with us for the changing rooms, presided over by a girl of luminous Satanic beauty. "Those men are going to, like, try on dresses!" hisses Harriet. "But I don't care. Why shouldn't they? It's cool." Eventually, we are entombed in the purple velvet-lined changing womb, wrestling like twins as Harriet goes 10 rounds with the corset and emerges victorious and enchanted. This is what women spent the whole of the last century trying to escape.

Still, I seem to remember wearing even less patent leather in the early 70s, and more provocatively tooled. We make some purchases and run off to a nearby brasserie, where I restore a sense of the wholesome by ordering chicken with "mashed sweat and red cabbage" - a side dish that seems to capture the essence of what shopping feels like these days.

Too tired for theatre, so abandon all aspirations to education and return to the provinces. Spend the evening trying to convince Aunt Elspeth that Harriet's Gothic look is something to do with the school play.

Awoken at 3am by the sound of scratching at the front door, and furtive whispering voices. Know that, for once, we are all tucked up in bed. Peer out of bedroom window and identify Holly, accompanied by two she-devils, fiddling with our lock. Henry did give her a key once - this is a learning curve for him. "Can I help you?" I enquire. Holly looks up. "Oh shit, sorry!" she hisses, "I wanted to collect my Slipknot CD. But it's quite late, yeah?" She then skitters away in the moonlight, followed by her familiars.

Return to bed, but sleep is fled. Soothe myself by working out that, in order to pay for my share of Harriet's birthday clothes, I shall have to teach Gabrielle how to write essays for 11 hours. At this thought, I fall asleep, and dream that one of those building-wrap artists dressed up Salisbury Cathedral in a long black coat and spiky dog-collar. Could be just what the Church of England needs.

fields.headline: Season to be cheerful
fields.standfirst: Flowering perennials are a cheering sign of the spring awakening. Christopher Lloyd can't wait
fields.trailText: Flowering perennials are a cheering sign of the spring awakening. Christopher Lloyd can't wait
fields.body:
As we emerge from winter, spring-flowering perennials give a great boost to the spirits. Most of them are shade-tolerant. In nature, they grow beneath deciduous trees, which are still admitting plenty of light to the woodland floor at a time when these plants are able to take advantage of the situation, flowering and leafing before the heavy shades of summer close in on them. So, "leafy soil in damp shade" is a generalised prescription for making the majority of them happy.

Some will cope with drought in summer quite simply, by going into a state of aestivation. Many cyclamen, for instance, retreat into their tubers, all their leaves dying off. They do their growing in winter and flower, either at the start of their growing season, in autumn, or at its end in spring.

Because they vanish completely from sight in summer, they are endangered in an active gardener's garden, their presence being easily forgotten. That is probably the reason for my never having made a success of Cyclamen coum , an easy and very jolly magenta-flowered species. Coum, incidentally, means from the island of Cos (Kos), so it should be said with two syllables.

The advantage for doronicums of being grown in shade is that their bright-yellow daisies don't bleach, as they do in sun. Almost any of those on offer is a good garden plant. Doronicum orientale 'Magnificum' is effective for bedding out with tulips of your own colour choice.

Pachyphragma macrophyllum makes lovely carpeting patches of white flowers in broad spikes at the end of this month, its large leaves following soon after. You would fall in love with it if you visited Beth Chatto's Essex garden at the turn of this month and next.

She also has a wonderful range of bergenias, which are evergreen and, though shade-tolerant, develop their best bronzed or reddish winter leaf colouring in a fairly exposed site. If an evergreen still looks smart at the end of winter (and a great many don't), it is a good plant. Bergenia 'Abendglocken' is one such, with neat, bronze leaves and carmine flowers. I am fond of the tiny-leaved B. stracheyi , which always flowers abundantly in March-April and is a bright, mauvy-pink.

Several members of the poppy family make a fresh contribution to the spring scene, notably Canadian blood-root, Sanguinaria canadensis , which is a quite tiny, clump-forming deciduous plant coming to life very soon with pure white flowers, one to each stem. Each flower is sheathed by a juicy, deckle-edged leaf, which develops soon after flowering. The double-flowered 'Flore Pleno' is possibly even more arresting. Again, these are woodland plants. So is Hylomecon japonicum , which has yellow poppy flowers, each of them with the gift of looking rather special. Stylophorum diphyllum is similar, though a little less special.

Lysichiton americanus , often called skunk cabbage although its smell is inoffensive, belongs to the arum family and has large, upright, bright-yellow spathes, rising directly from the ground. It grows in very boggy places, often in woodland. If there is flowing water nearby, its seeds will be carried to new sites in that. It can make huge colonies, and the leaves that follow the flowers, are large and glossy. The white Japanese L. camtschatcensis is far less coarse. These two species, planted near to one another, readily hybridise.

Another spring-flowering aroid, this time definitely for immersion in shallow pond water, is the golden club, Orontium aquaticum . It dispenses with the usual arum spathe and just has a white, yellow-tipped club, snakily curved, rising a little from the water's surface and then subsiding back on to it. A lot of them together make a good design.

Lady's smock, Cardamine pratensis , colonises wet ditches and marshy areas, often on clay soils. It is mauve and is one of the food plants of the Orange Tip butterfly, which will be on the wing from mid-April. There is a neatly doubled version, 'Flore Pleno', which well deserves cherishing as a garden plant.

Cardamine quinquefolia is an excellent shady-border perennial, making a colony and carrying heads of deep mauve blossom from mid-February for a couple of months. C. raphanifolia grows like watercress and will colonise around a grassy ditch. Its pinkish-mauve flowers are larger than lady's smocks and a little later.

Darmera peltata, the water saxifrage, really only asks for reasonably damp soil, which it will colonise with a dense tangle of its surface rhizomes. Its umbrella leaves, to 1m, usefully exclude most competitors, but they develop after it has borne, in April-May, its domed heads of charming pink flowers, worn like an Easter bonnet. They are carried on a thick, fleshy stalk, clothed in bristles. That looks better than it reads.

fields.headline: How to... be a swot
fields.trailText: Everyone is familiar with the school swot, but you should remember that, after school, these swots are released into the community. Swots kill anecdotes with irrelevant factual corrections; swots spend more time filing their CDs than playing them.
fields.body:
Everyone is familiar with the school swot, but you should remember that, after school, these swots are released into the community. Swots kill anecdotes with irrelevant factual corrections; swots spend more time filing their CDs than playing them; swots draw graphs of their annual gas usage; swots think a moustache is an act of rebellion.

Don't confuse swots with nerds: swots are obsessive about everything and dress neatly; nerds are obsessed with one thing and dress like a laundry basket. Swots aren't necessarily weedy - they can play sport, but they're more interested in the precise application of the rules than possession of the ball.

Swots love rules almost as much as they love their mothers. That's why breaking a swot's shatter-proof plastic ruler at school leaves a lasting feeling of emasculation. At school, the swot's best friend is his or her pencil case. This is always a sensible leatherette pencil case, and it doesn't have hearts drawn over it in Biro. Instead, it has a selection of sharpened pencils, felt-tips and plastic set squares. A grown-up swot will also have a briefcase, neatly packed with useful bits and pieces. (If you ever want to annoy a big swot in a meeting, just pick up their briefcase and give it a good shake.) Happily, there are vast areas of life where the pencil case is king and swots can swot up everything to their heart's content.

Accountants are swots with big calculators, bureaucrats are swots with big pens, and lawyers are swots with big rubbers. Swots love tests. They like to revise for them, do them quickly and come top of the class. No surprise, then, that swots have rubbish love lives. No amount of swotting up will help you in the terrifying test that is the blind date. True, there will be multiple-choice questions, but sadly there won't be any right answers - not for them, anyway.

At school, swots suck up to their teachers. When they leave, they need another authority figure to suck up to, and that's generally the government: swots never break the speed limit; swots do their tax returns the same day they receive them; swots apply for planning permission for rabbit hutches.

Swots like to be in control. This can lead either to an obsession with trains or to an obsession with ridding the world of impurities. Peek at a swot's notebook: if it's full of numbers, you're okay; if it's full of names, worry.

fields.headline: Patched up
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32 and three quarters. By Sue Townsend
fields.trailText: Adrian Mole, aged 32 and three quarters. By Sue Townsend
fields.body:
Sunday, March, 5, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

I spent the day debating with myself - should I continue to fight the tracksuit-trousers ban on Glenn's behalf or should I give in, thus subjecting the lad to mental torture during cross-country runs and possible trauma in later life? I rang around and sought the opinion of others. My father reminded me that he had "gone out on a limb" to support me when I stood up against the tyrannical headmaster, pop-eyed Scruton, by wearing red socks to school, thereby defying the black-socks-only rule. My mother said, "Give in, Aidy - you can't beat Jack Straw's authoritarian regime."

I rang my MP, Pandora Braithwaite, who had joined me in my red-socks rebellion 20 years ago. She said, "Can't talk now, darling, I've got Ken and Frank round for dinner, and I'm about to serve the pig's brains in goat's cheese." So, it is as I suspected all along! Ken Livingstone and Frank Dobson are hand-in-glove with each other. Their true enemy is Tony Blair. They have conspired to make Mr Blair look as though he can't control his party.

After Glenn had gone to bed, I wrote to his headmaster, Roger Patience:

Dear Mr Patience,

My son, Glenn Bott, has abnormally thin legs, of which he is very self-conscious. In the circumstances, would you please make an exception to your PE-shorts-only rule and allow him to wear tracksuit trousers during cross-country runs.

Yours, A A Mole

Tuesday, March 7, Shrove Tuesday

Peggy Ludlow came round at tea-time to borrow flour, a lemon, eggs, milk, a frying pan and oil. I said, sarcastically, "Wouldn't it be simpler if I made your pancakes in my kitchen?" She agreed, and the whole Ludlow family trooped round and sat in my living room watching Jerry Springer while I tossed in the kitchen until my wrist was aching.

Vince Ludlow doesn't seem to do any work, though his family are always well rigged-out in designer clothes. Peggy continues to invade my thoughts. Today she was wearing a snakeskin sleeveless shift dress. It was the first time I'd seen her upper arms. She has several tattoos, the most recent being a depiction of Jeremy Paxman's head. When I said that I, too, was a fan of Newsnight, she said that she had asked for Jeremy Clarkson and was suing the tattooist.

Wednesday, March 8, Ash Wednesday

My mother invited me and the boys to a No Smoking Day party to celebrate her proposed new status as a non-smoker. We arrived slightly late, at 7.30. She answered the door looking irritable: "You've missed the ashtray-smashing ceremony." At 7.45, she smoked her last cigarette in the garden, surrounded by family and friends. Tears ran down her tobacco-ravaged face. Ivan then ceremoniously applied a nicotine patch to her upper-arm. When I strolled back into the house, it didn't seem the same without its perpetual pall of smoke. No reply yet from Patience regarding the tracksuit trousers.

Thursday, March 9

A telephone call from the school secretary to tell me that Roger Patience can now be reached only on the following e-mail address: patience.com@sailschool

Friday, March 10

I called on my mother unexpectedly this afternoon: she was smoking a cigarette and both wearing nicotine and chewing it. She begged me not to tell Ivan.

Saturday, March 11

I went to see Pandora at the ceremony to close down the community centre on this estate. She told me that her dinner guests were Ken Dodd and Frank Skinner - a grim night, then.

fields.headline: Old soldier who forgives Japanese
fields.standfirst: John Nunneley: Burma veteran at odds with ex-PoWs who 'insulted the emperor'
fields.trailText: John Nunneley has obviously been a soldier: he is fierce, forceful, wide-shouldered. His clothes are dapper and slightly flash and some of his stories are perfectly horrifying. "I had to murder a wounded Japanese soldier when I was 20 or 21. It's bound to have a lasting effect. You ask yourself, why did he look at me as he died? What was he thinking as he died? Was there an alternative?"
fields.body:
John Nunneley has obviously been a soldier: he is fierce, forceful, wide-shouldered. His clothes are dapper and slightly flash and some of his stories are perfectly horrifying. "I had to murder a wounded Japanese soldier when I was 20 or 21. It's bound to have a lasting effect. You ask yourself, why did he look at me as he died? What was he thinking as he died? Was there an alternative?"

There probably wasn't, as he tells the story in a small book of memoirs just published, Tales from the King's African Rifles. In the Burma campaign of 1944 he was leading a patrol which found the wounded man behind enemy lines. They could not take him with them, nor leave him alive to raise the alarm. So they bayoneted him.

There must be many people with stories like that to tell, though few who could write them so well. What makes Nunneley remarkable is that he has come to believe in and to work for reconciliation between the men who fought in that terrible campaign. "In Burma we did unspeakable things to one another." We are eating lunch in a quiet club, a world away from what he talks about. "It was the norm, for God's sake. My friends had their heads cut off; that's one thing, an aspect of war, but neither side took prisoners."

This is one perhaps rather horrible reason why the Burma Campaign Reconciliation Fellowship finds it easier than other ex-service organisations to forgive the Japanese. The survivors did not suffer much at the hands of their enemies because both sides routinely killed those who surrendered.

"We sympathise with those who were prisoners of war, as everyone must, but when they go over the top, you must say so. We hate being dragged into the PoW problems because they were a different theatre of war.

"The Japanese in Burma did their duty as they saw it. The British did their duty as they saw it . We say that the Japanese are not all bad."

Actually, his opinion of them is much higher than that. He takes from his lapel a small enamelled badge in black and gold, worn by members of the elite Japanese division he was fighting. "It's a cherry leaf and a Burmese pagoda. The cherry leaf symbolises the brief life of a soldier. It was presented to me by the Japanese All Burma Veterans Association: one had an enormous sense of gratitude and pride. Isn't the workmanship marvellous?

"They're very nice people these Japanese, you know. Very generous."

This kind of view has caused his fellowship huge difficulties from the more mainstream ex-servicemen's associations. To understand this you have only to compare his book with something like George MacDonald Fraser's memoir of the Burma campaign, Quartered Safe, which is rank with loathing of the Japanese and probably reflects more accurately the view of most of the soldiery. "Because we believe that sufficient apologies have been made by successive prime ministers we are told that we are disloyal and all manner of things.

"We stood up and said that those demonstrations in the Mall when the emperor came were disgraceful and an insult to queen and emperor. But you cannot harbour hatred and bitterness for 55 years. There must be something going further, mustn't there?

"I don't think I can bear hatred. That is frightfully important. I think one has an instinctive compassion for one's fellow beings. In war one does one's duty and kills as many as possible, but I don't feel at all proud of myself. And I believe there is a spring of compassion which never leaves you."

He had been so keen to join the war that he tried to sign up to fight for the Finns against Russia in 1939, but was too young.

He ended up in the King's African Rifles, officered, in Burma, by whites who fought in black make-up to prevent the Japanese from picking them out as targets. He bought with him from a posting in Kenya a servant, Tomaso, who had volunteered to follow him abroad.

That story is, so far as he is concerned, the spine of the book. He was himself badly wounded in the skirmish that lead to Tomaso's death. "I was not even apprehensive before going into action. I certainly wasn't in the least worried when I was fighting. But the reaction afterwards was overwhelming. You really want to be alone, because the shock to your system is such that you really might break down for two or three minutes.

"What I didn't put in was the frequency with which just after dawn in Burma there would be the sharp crack of a rifle and blokes were shooting off their big toe. It takes an enormous amount of courage to do that. Those without imagination just do their duty. Those with imagination go through torture."

But I don't see that anyone without imagination would so thoroughly have embraced the necessity of reconciliation.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Work so-so this week. Floated three new sites, but none went for more than £200 million. I'd carried out the usual checks in accordance with City rules for flotations (both www.tarot-rita.com and www.tarotscope.com showed good omens), and we have very strict in-house rules, too, so I had to consult www.dragon-gate.com for a separate feng shui assessment - our bank is owned by a Macao-based company, also positive. But the problem was that all the sites were profitable, so there was little interest from investors.
fields.body:
Work so-so this week. Floated three new sites, but none went for more than £200 million. I'd carried out the usual checks in accordance with City rules for flotations (both www.tarot-rita.com and www.tarotscope.com showed good omens), and we have very strict in-house rules, too, so I had to consult www.dragon-gate.com for a separate feng shui assessment - our bank is owned by a Macao-based company, also positive. But the problem was that all the sites were profitable, so there was little interest from investors.

Still, I was so busy that I had to miss my hair appointment with Patrick. Luckily, I found www.hqhair.co.uk, a virtual hair salon, where I was told how to tweak my hair with gel to achieve a cutting-edge effect.

Someone called to ask if I wanted to join Raine Spencer, Jerry Hall and Victoria Beckham on the committee of the Save Ken Livingstone Ball (as in party). I was flattered, and I liked Ken's manifesto at www.briefing.org.uk, but then I remembered Tony. I felt so guilty I looked him up. Under the umbrella of www.britain-info.org/blair are Tony's views on the economy, Northern Ireland, and more. Alas, when I tried the site, invariably I was told I was not authorised to view this page. Using the internet to keep people out must be the Third Way.

The good news was that, after many emails, Migraine Alan from the hypochondria noticeboard agreed to meet on Monday. He's gorgeous. Not to waste time, I asked him to dinner at my loft that Friday (I went to the trouble of buying the Migraine Association of Canada Cookbook from www.migraine.ca Everything ready, I was lighting the candles when the phone rang. You won't believe this: he had a headache.

webTitle: Germany lifts import ban on British beef

fields.headline: Germany lifts import ban on British beef
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Germany yesterday agreed to lift its ban on British beef, leaving France isolated as the only European Union country with an import ban still in force.
fields.body:
Germany yesterday agreed to lift its ban on British beef, leaving France isolated as the only European Union country with an import ban still in force.

The government and farmers welcomed a narrow decision by the German parliament's upper house, the Bundesrat, which means the long-running beef saga is now entering its final stage - and pressure is increased on the French to follow suit.

"All credit to the federal government of Germany," said the agriculture minister, Nick Brown. "I really do hope it has a knock-on effect."

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers Union, said: "This was the right decision and leaves France conspicuously out on a limb in Europe over its illegal ban."

The German move will help undermine a key eurosceptic argument - that Britain obeys EU rules only to see them flouted by others.

"This vindicates our position of being fully engaged in Europe and playing by the rules in Europe," said the foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

The vote in Berlin came after the European commission had begun legal action against Germany in the European court of justice in Luxembourg. Moves against France continue.

The Bundesrat, representing the country's 16 regions, cast 39 votes in favour of the government's proposal, just four more than the required majority out of a total 69 votes.

The bans date to the EU decision in March 1996 prohibiting the export of all British beef after the announcement of a possible link between mad cow disease or BSE and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans.

The bans led to a period of confrontation between Britain and its EU partners, the slaughter of millions of cattle, curbs on the use of animal feed, and a comprehensive cattle tracing system.

Last August the commission allowed British beef exports to resume provided the meat was from cattle born in the preceding three years. But France and Germany continued to balk.

Germany is a small market for British beef, importing only 100 tonnes a year, but exporters had expressed concern that a continued ban there would undermine consumer confidence elsewhere.

France is still insisting that priority must be given to its own food safety agency report that there is still a health risk from British beef.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: No action over layby boy
fields.body:
No action over layby boy

No criminal action is to be taken against a social worker and a teacher who left a nine-year-old boy with learning difficulties in a lay-by last month, the crown office in Scotland confirmed yesterday.

Maureen Law, a social worker with East Ayrshire council, was sacked two weeks ago and Michael Roos, a teacher, has been recommended for dismissal.

Dando 'killed by hitman'

Nigel Dando, 47, the brother of the murdered TV presenter Jill Dando, yesterday said he thought she was shot by a professional hitman. Detectives disagree. In an interview in the Guardian the man leading the inquiry, Det Chief Insp Hamish Campbell, said his "gut feeling" was she was killed by a loner.

Parking fiddle ends in jail

A former police inspector who swapped residential parking permits for £600 in backhanders from businessmen was jailed for six months at Southwark crown court yesterday.

Peter Tadman, 62, who insisted he was simply a Good Samaritan saving people from exorbitant car park charges in London's West End, was a fraud enforcement officer in charge of checking applications.

DNA clue to crash victims

DNA testing kits are being sent to relatives of Britons who died in a mysterious plane crash in the Andes in 1947, the foreign office said yesterday.

Officials have traced 13 family members of the eight British passengers and crew on the converted Lancaster bomber, whose remains were found 18,200ft up Mount Tupungato.

Spilt milk protest

Dairy farmers from Kent and Sussex yesterday poured 4,000 litres of milk over a field in Sevenoaks, Kent, to protest against the increasing difference in the price they get and the price milk is sold for in shops.

They say they will go out of business it they are not given a fairer deal.

fields.headline: Far from the madding crowd
fields.standfirst: Matthew Parris sets out for a distant and lonely island
fields.trailText: Matthew Parris will set off tomorrow to spend five months in a hut on Kerguelen Island, 2,000 miles from Australia and South Africa, and 4,000 miles south of India. It must qualify as the coldest and most desolate desert island in the world.
fields.body:
Matthew Parris will set off tomorrow to spend five months in a hut on Kerguelen Island, 2,000 miles from Australia and South Africa, and 4,000 miles south of India. It must qualify as the coldest and most desolate desert island in the world.

The wind gusts at nearly 200mph: the French explorer after whom the islands are named never got through the storms to land and the native insect species have all lost their wings because attempting to fly carries too great a risk of being blown into the Southern Ocean.

About 50 French scientists live on a base there. All other attempts at settling on the island have failed. Though the wind and almost equally incessant rain or sleet keep parts of the island ice-free, it suits seals and seabirds rather better than human beings and once the seals had been virtually exterminated in the 19th century there was no real use for it.

"I believe it's going to be very beautiful. Many have found the island ugly because the conditions are so dreadful; but I have an idea of a place of silvery grey light and black rocks."

There are other people who share his delight. He is flying as far as Mauritius with a British Airways pilot, David Johnson, who responded to a newspaper article he wrote about his dream. From there, they must take a boat to the islands; no plane can land on them in that wind. It wasn't originally the plan to spend five months there. He had been going to spend a week or so and make a television programme.

"But at the last minute, three weeks ago, the French said the ship would only be there for five days; and there would be French tourists in our party. I was faced with the choice of either cancelling the programme or essentially faking it and trying to keep the tourists out of shot; or I could suggest to the French that the ship sail away with the TV crew and leave me behind with my own little camera. I'm taking a case full of books, CDs, and my laptop. I think I might start writing an autobiography. Of course I won't miss company. I'm perfectly sociable. I love my friends, but I enjoy my own company."

This, perhaps, is part of the secret of his unfeignable niceness. Years ago I had tea with him every afternoon for 10 months as a rivalrous colleague when we were both doing parliamentary sketches and it was always the high point of the day. Plenty of people are talented and plenty are charming; what distinguishes him from almost everyone else who is talented and charming is that he is so comfortable with his ambition.

It is in many ways a drive more embarrassing than sex. We don't know how to gratify our ambitions enough without making them insatiable. "It is my ambition to be a rich old man," he said at one of our teas, and I think he will probably make it, but it was clear that he didn't want the money for its own sake. He has a knack for both getting what he wants and enjoying it afterwards. He would, I think, have failed as a politician. He certainly failed in his first shot as a television presenter!

Talking about an acquaintance, he said: "The only thing I don't like about her is her social climbing - that's not the word - her concern about social position. She should not care about that sort of thing. People should not." Part of his objection is that you can never have enough social position. No matter how much you have, someone else will always have more. To worry about the fact is to condemn yourself to endless fretting.

This astringent to his character may be the last key to his departure to Kerguelen. "All beauty is harsh; and the whole of England is tame. I love desolate places and deserts. I absolutely won't get bored out there."

There is only one thing that worries him, a little, as he prepares for the Antarctic winter: "I absolutely hate the cold. It is the only thing that ever saps my morale."
