fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Alder Hey report for minister
fields.body:
Alder Hey report for minister

Lord Hunt, the health minister, is considering a report from Alder Hey hospital, Liverpool, about its treatment of the family of a baby whose internal organs were removed and then accidentally disposed of.

The hospital had been given 24 hours to prepare the report into the case of 10-day-old Stephen White, who died in 1992.

His parents were preparing to bury their baby's heart, brain and lungs in a second funeral yesterday, but on Wednesday were told by hospital staff that the organs could not be found.

On Thursday, Lord Hunt sacked the hospital trust's chairman, Frank Taylor. He said he would not tolerate "this kind of poor management in any NHS hospital".

The hospital removed the organs of 893 dead children without their parents' consent.

Ian Cohen, a solicitor representing the families of 200 children whose organs were retained, said he believed the Stephen White case was just one example of a culture of poor management at the hospital.

"But the Stephen White case is probably the most severe example," he said.

A support group representing the families is demanding that criminal charges be brought against hospital staff. The Pity II group has written to the chief constable of Merseyside, Norman Bettison, to ask him to take action. Joan Wheeler, the group's chairwoman, said: "Our children's organs have been robbed, they have been stolen and we want to bring about formal charges against the hospital."

Superintendent John Gilvary, of Merseyside police, said: "We have to look at it totally objectively and have to respond carefully and professionally within the correct legislation provided."

Arson at flat killed 19 parrots

A woman was jailed for two years yesterday for setting light to her boyfriend's flat and killing 19 of his parrots.

Anna Seeley, 32, was told by the judge, Oliver Sells QC, at the Old Bailey, that the public had to be protected from her repeating such a dangerous act.

Doctors told the court that Seeley was suffering from post-natal depression when she started fires in two wardrobes and a sofa at Douglas Anderson's flat in Croydon, south London, in September last year.

Mr Anderson, 47, kept 24 parrots, valued at £2,600. Nineteen died from smoke inhalation.

Seeley, of South Norwood, south London, pleaded guilty to arson which was reckless to whether lives were endangered, and to causing unnecessary suffering to the parrots.

Seeley had arranged a loan through a friend to allow Mr Anderson to buy and breed the birds so he could contribute to the upkeep of her children, two of whom were his.

Seeley was jailed for two years for arson and six months concurrently for causing suffering to the parrots. Helen Carter

MS sufferer cleared of drug charge

Home office ministers were yesterday urged to change the law on cannabis after a jury cleared a disabled man, who used the drug to ease his pain, of committing a crime.

Campaigners said it was the latest in a series of cases where jurors had refused to convict sick people who used cannabis for medicinal reasons.

Thomas Yates, who has multiple sclerosis, was accused of producing a controlled drug after police found 40 cannabis plants growing at his home in Lowestoft, Suffolk.

Mr Yates, 51, a former deep sea diver, said cannabis was the only drug that eased his pain without unpleasant side effects.

He said he was trying to grow a 10-year supply because his wife, Andrea, 41, was dying of lung cancer and increasingly needed his time and support.

A jury at Ipswich crown court accepted his argument that he needed cannabis to ease his pain.

After the hearing Mr Yates, a father of two, said: "All this has been a waste of time and money.

"The law needs to be changed so that people can use cannabis for medicinal purposes."

Police found the cannabis, plus cultivating equipment, in three upstairs rooms while looking for a fugitive who had been an acquaintance of Mr Yates. The wanted man was not found at Mr Yates's home.

Mr Yates had told police that the upstairs rooms were empty - although when questioned he made no secret of the fact that he was growing cannabis.

Mr Yates, who now uses morphine - which leaves him feeling sick - to ease his pain, will be entitled to have his cultivating equipment back, but the cannabis will be destroyed.

"I know quite a few other MS sufferers who use cannabis. It really works and has no side effects."

Bev Clydesdale, welfare officer with the south Suffolk branch of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, said: "The law needs to be changed. There's no doubt that it does ease pain."

PE teacher jailed for sex with girl

A PE teacher was yesterday jailed for 12 months for having sex with a 14-year-old pupil he knew had a crush on him.

Mark Unsworth, 40, from Sutton, Kingston-upon-Hull, was found guilty at Teesside crown court of three specimen charges of having unlawful sexual intercourse with the girl. He had denied the charges.

Unsworth will be registered as sex offender for 10 years, after Judge John Walford told him his behaviour had been an "appalling breach of trust".

The court heard that Unsworth met the girl on a school trip when she was 12. They became friendly and by the time she was 14, she regularly visited his flat. On Valentine's day Unsworth sent her a card and chocolate with a message that it would "whip up her passion".

Unsworth maintained they never had sex and claimed the girl and her family were lying.

Student on top of the world

Most students sitting their exams might be happy to come near the top of the class, but one trainee accountant, Susan Drury, has come top in the world. Her score of 92% in a tax planning exam beat 11,500 others who sat the same test in December in 140 countries.

It is also the highest achieved since the paper was set 10 years ago by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants.

Ms Drury, 29, of Worksop, Nottinghamshire, now taking a well-earned break from a firm of accountants in the town, said: "It wasn't easy at the time. I thought I had done OK, but I never thought I'd got that much. I couldn't believe it when they said it was the top mark in the world."

She has passed all 11 papers she has sat and has another three to pass to fully qualify.

Vicar abused bell-ringer

A vicar who molested a 13-year-old bell-ringer 25 years ago was jailed yesterday for six months.

The Rev Anthony Clayton, 63, a former personal chaplain to the Duke and Duchess of Rutland, abused the boy at his vicarage in Lockington, Derbyshire.

He then bought the youth's silence with promises of a job with the church when he left school, London's Middlesex Guildhall crown court was told.

Passing sentence, Judge Fabyan Evans said the youth had been no stranger to homosexual activities, but "your behaviour contributed and certainly did not halt his corruption".

Clayton, from Nottingham, was convicted of one count of indecent assault, but was cleared of other offences against the boy, now 38 and living in Lancashire.

The jury heard character references from both the Duchess of Rutland and the former bishop of Leicester, Richard Rutt.

fields.headline: US trips for GCSE under-achievers
fields.trailText: Under-achieving pupils with poor GCSE results are to be sent on £1,000 study visits to the United States to stimulate their interest in education, under an experiment by education chiefs.
fields.body:
Under-achieving pupils with poor GCSE results are to be sent on £1,000 study visits to the United States to stimulate their interest in education, under an experiment by education chiefs.

Roland Absalom, director of the education action zone in Leigh, near Wigan, said the scheme was devised by US psychologists to give young people heading for delinquency and unemployment an incentive to succeed.

Six 16-year-olds from two secondaries, Bedford and Westleigh high schools, will be selected to spend the autumn term at Ciyuga high school in leafy upstate New York. They will undertake job-related studies that could dovetail with vocational courses available on their return to Britain.

"These may be pupils who have played truant or been excluded from school, or who have under-performed because of peer pressures or problems they have at home," Mr Absalom said.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said the scheme might work for carefully selected youngsters. But there was a risk that it could become a reward for bad pupils.

"If it is used too widely, children soon catch on. If they know they can exploit a situation like this, they will. It would take considerable understanding amongst the majority of the pupils at a school not to feel some resentment at the worst pupils apparently being rewarded," he said.

Meanwhile, one of the headteachers who saved the Ridings school in Halifax from collapse four years ago has been enlisted to tackle the problems at a "fresh start" school in Brighton after the resignation of its £70,000 superhead.

Peter Clark was called in by the education authority to analyse management and leadership at East Brighton college of media arts, one of three schools in the government's fresh start programme to lose its head during the past week.

Mr Clark came to national attention when he was seconded to restore order at the Ridings, where teachers were threatening to strike to secure the expulsion of unruly pupils.

Brighton and Hove council called him in after Tony Garwood said he would leave the east Brighton college to make way for someone with the right skills to steer its recovery. Mr Garwood was the third fresh start superhead to resign in a week. Torsten Friedag quit Islington arts and media college in north London last Friday and Carole McAlpine announced her resignation from Firfield school in Newcastle upon Tyne on Monday.

Six 16-year-olds from two secondaries, Bedford and Westleigh high schools, will be selected to spend the autumn term at Ciyuga high school in leafy upstate New York. They will undertake job-related studies that could dovetail with vocational courses available on their return to Britain. "These may be pupils who have played truant or been excluded from school, or who have under-performed because of peer pressures or problems they have at home," Mr Absalom said. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said the scheme might work for carefully selected youngsters. But there was a risk that it could become a reward for bad pupils. "If it is used too widely, children soon catch on. If they know they can exploit a situation like this, they will. It would take considerable understanding amongst the majority of the pupils at a school not to feel some resentment at the worst pupils apparently being rewarded," he said. Meanwhile, one of the headteachers who saved the Ridings school in Halifax from collapse four years ago has been enlisted to tackle the problems at a "fresh start" school in Brighton after the resignation of its £70,000 superhead. Peter Clark was called in by the education authority to analyse management and leadership at East Brighton college of media arts, one of three schools in the government's fresh start programme to lose its head during the past week. Mr Clark came to national attention when he was seconded to restore order at the Ridings, where teachers were threatening to strike to secure the expulsion of unruly pupils. Brighton and Hove council called him in after Tony Garwood said he would leave the east Brighton college to make way for someone with the right skills to steer its recovery. Mr Garwood was the third fresh start superhead to resign in a week. Torsten Friedag quit Islington arts and media college in north London last Friday and Carole McAlpine announced her resignation from Firfield school in Newcastle upon Tyne on Monday.

webTitle: Mr Benn dresses for his biggest adventure

fields.headline: Mr Benn dresses for his biggest adventure
fields.standfirst: Seventies cartoon favourite to be updated and turned into a film for adults starring John Hannah as the eponymous hero
fields.trailText: The 70s children's television character Mr Benn is set for his biggest adventure yet - making it on to the cinema screen.
fields.body:
The 70s children's television character Mr Benn is set for his biggest adventure yet - making it on to the cinema screen.

British film makers are poised to start shooting the cult cartoon series and update the bowler hatted adventurer to appeal to a modern adult audience.

The £4m project will be a live action feature film and big name actors are already being lined up to play the main parts.

John Hannah from Sliding Doors and Four Weddings and a Funeral will play Mr Benn, while Oscar winner Ben Kingsley, best known for his leading role in Gandhi, has signed up to play the shopkeeper.

Movie makers have updated Mr Benn's lifestyle. He will have a girlfriend, played by Absolutely Fabulous star Jane Horrocks; a job in a museum; and he will speak (the cartoons were narrated by the actor Ray Brooks). Unlike the crudely animated cartoon, Mr Benn's knees will move.

Some saw the cartoon's plots as drawing inspiration from hippy culture.

In Mr Benn, the suited cartoon character left 52 Festive Road and wandered into a costume shop - he never went to work.

The shopkeeper would invite him to try on an outfit he had never tried before, and after stepping through "the other door" into the supposed changing room, Mr Benn would escape the mundanity of everyday life and have an adventure.

After learning a moral lesson, the shopkeeper would bring the adventure to an end and Mr Benn would return to reality.

Only 13 episodes of Mr Benn were made for the BBC. The series was first broadcast in 1971, though its popularity was such it was repeated for years afterwards.

The film's director, Jevon O'Neill, said: "The plot is about a man looking for a purpose in his life. He has a series of adventures and ends up realising he's able to seize more opportunities in life than he has so far. It has a life affirming quality, looking at one man's journey to fulfil his potential."

In the film, he will set off on his travels in pursuit of his tragic lost love, Monica McBride.

The makers of Mr Benn say it will be an unusual British movie, breaking out of the usual costume and gritty urban drama.

Mr O'Neill's Erinfilm company bought the movie rights from the TV series' creator David McKee. Mr O'Neill added: "We've been working closely with the original TV show's creators and rights owners, and they are happy with the script.

"At the moment, we are in the process of finalising funding for the project, but in an ideal world we could start pre-production in a couple of months' time.

"The film will be set in England, and it will have a very quirky British feel to it, but until all the funding is in place we will not know exactly where it is going to be filmed."

From small to big screen

The Magic Roundabout

Much-loved psychedelic 60s show spawned the equally trippy Dougal and the Blue Cat.

The Muppets

Inspired a series of films about Kermit and Miss Piggy and even saw Michael Caine taking a leading role in their most recent big screen adventure.

The Flintstones

Stone-age cartoon took a disastrous turn when John Goodman took the lead in a live-action feature.

The Rugrats

Highly successful transfer to the silver screen for this US cartoon.

South Park

Controversial US cartoon, featuring foul-mouthed teenagers, was also made into a movie.

webTitle: Met accused of Tibet protest whitewash

fields.headline: Met accused of Tibet protest whitewash
fields.trailText: An internal police review published yesterday into last year's controversial state visit by the Chinese president was condemned as a "whitewash" by Free Tibet campaigners after it concluded that "no improper influence" was exerted on police by the foreign office.
fields.body:
An internal police review published yesterday into last year's controversial state visit by the Chinese president was condemned as a "whitewash" by Free Tibet campaigners after it concluded that "no improper influence" was exerted on police by the foreign office.

Scotland Yard took the unusual step of releasing the routine internal review following widespread public disquiet about the heavy-handed policing of President Jiang Zemin's four-day visit last October.

It revealed that the British and Chinese governments had expressed concerns to the police about demonstrations ahead of the visit, although it denied that the foreign and commonwealth office had put pressure on the police to crack down on demonstrators to prevent embarrassment to the Chinese authorities.

The assistant police commissioner Ian Johnston admitted there were "inevitably lessons to be learned" but said there was no conspiracy to suppress lawful demonstration and many noisy demonstrations by campaigners opposed to China's occupation of Tibet had been allowed to take place.

He accepted that mistakes had been made but insisted: "By and large I think we did a pretty good job in difficult circumstances." The report made six recommendations, including calling for minutes to be taken at all future planning meetings for state visits between police and foreign office officials, and for formalised codes of practice be introduced for ceremonial events.

The review found that flags and banners were taken from pro-Tibet demonstrators at Horse Guards Parade because of the "threat to public order and the dignity of Jiang Zemin" and that vans were used to reinforce police lines when tensions increased, but that some were "parked unwittingly" in front of protesters. But Mr Johnston highlighted one incident when a group of officers arrested a cyclist, admitting: "Five people on one chap on a bike can look heavy-handed."

He said there was a "fine balance"between the right to free protest and the rights of visiting dignitories under the Vienna convention to have their "dignity preserved". A foreign office spokesman said the report showed there was "not a shred of evidence" to substantiate claims of pressure on the Met.

Among the documents revealed in the report were notes of a briefing by the head of the police operation, Commander Mike Messinger, in which he told officers: "This is a very politically sensitive visit. Both the Chinese and the British governments have expressed concern with regards to demonstrators who may wish to disrupt this visit.

"The tactics of isolate and contain will be utilised to deal with any demonstration." The visit to Britain followed similar criticisms of heavy-handed policing during trips by the Chinese president to Australia, New Zealand and France, but the report criticised the British media for focusing on "selected examples of apparently heavy-handed police behaviour".

The internal review was condemned by the Free Tibet Campaign, which was at the forefront of the anti-Chinese protests.

Director Alison Reynolds said: "The report's attempt to justify the police's actions are deeply flawed. Freedom of expression must be upheld in the face of leaders like Jiang Zemin if they are not to go home with the belief that their methods of dealing with dissent are correct."

The campaign has lodged an application for a judicial review of the policing of the visit, claiming it was in breach of the European convention on human rights.

webTitle: Book names MI6 officers in alleged plot to kill Milosevic

fields.headline: Book names MI6 officers in alleged plot to kill Milosevic
fields.trailText: Secret intelligence service officers have been named in a new book on MI6 in relation to an alleged plot to assassinate the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Secret intelligence service officers have been named in a new book on MI6 in relation to an alleged plot to assassinate the Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic.

Six officers - previously named on the internet but never in print - are identified in MI6, Fifty Years of Special Operations, to be published by Fourth Estate later this month.

The author, Stephen Dorril, says MI6 drew up plans to kill Mr Milosevic in 1992 after evidence emerged he was supplying arms to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.

Plans included training a Serbian opposition group to carry out the assassination, training an SAS cell to do it, or killing the president in a staged road crash during one of his visits to an international conference in Geneva on the future of Yugoslavia, the book alleges.

The book also identifies an MI6 officer who wrote articles for the Spectator magazine criticising journalists covering the Bosnian civil war as well as the UN's role there.

Mr Dorril describes the activities of an MI6 section called I/Ops, for Information Operations, whose job is to plant favourable stories in newspapers.

Mr Dorril said: "Though it's not a 'naming names' book it gives the opportunity for the British public to see material about MI6 available throughout the rest of the world."

webTitle: Trimble relaxes terms on IRA arms

fields.headline: Trimble relaxes terms on IRA arms
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, provided a rare glimmer of hope for the peace process in Northern Ireland when he unexpectedly said he would be prepared to re-enter government with Sinn Fein without prior IRA arms decommissioning.
fields.body:
David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, provided a rare glimmer of hope for the peace process in Northern Ireland when he unexpectedly said he would be prepared to re-enter government with Sinn Fein without prior IRA arms decommissioning.

His comments, made on St Patrick's Day in Washington, threw Unionists into turmoil, and suggested Mr Trimble would face a rough ride ahead of next Saturday's annual meeting of his 860-strong ruling council. Several of his MPs expressed amazement.

Mr Trimble said he would consider taking a government before guns plan to his party again only if he were convinced that the IRA's war was over. He would require guarantees of decommissioning to follow, rather than the vague aspirations which accompanied his decision to go into the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein last November.

Mr Trimble, addressing the National Press Club, said: "The critical thing is that if we are going to have a sequence in the future: is it going to work? We can't move unless it is quite clear it is going to work.

"I have made it clear that we are prepared to be involved in a fresh sequence which probably will not involve arms up front but it has to involve the issue being dealt with and the matter working. The only people who can answer that is the republican movement."

Washington sources were playing down hopes of a breakthrough, but the development was in stark contrast to the gloomy atmosphere which has marked St Patrick's Day at the White House this year. President Clinton was meeting the parties last night.

Mr Trimble's pronouncement surprised his MPs, in cluding Jeffrey Donaldson, a member of the party's steering group set up to oversee the talks. He predicted Mr Trimble would fail to persuade his party to back him again.

Mr Donaldson, an opponent of the Good Friday agreement, was angry at not being consulted. He said: "Having seen the institutions suspended because there was no decommissioning, people would find it difficult to understand why we would set them up again without decommissioning."

Mr Trimble's comments came shortly after Jonathan Bell, the Craigavon councillor who had threatened to run as a stalking horse challenger to his leadership next week, said he was quitting the party because he believed Mr Trimble was preparing to return to government without decommissioning.

The Democratic Unionist deputy leader, Peter Robinson, and the UK Unionist party chief, Robert McCartney, were scathing about Mr Trimble.

Mr Robinson said he was earning the name Putty Man, "easily shaped by presidents, prime ministers and provos".

He added: "As someone who has been made to look a fool on many occasions, you might have expected more caution from someone like him."

The Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, accused Mr Trimble of spinning the media.

Mr Trimble's approach reflects growing doubts that decommissioning was the correct issue on which to gauge republican intentions. Both the army and the RUC believe it has no security value.

The Real IRA explosives found in Hillborough, Co Down, on Wednesday were home made, with the usual ingredients including fertiliser, sugar and diesel. Security forces say it is impossible to decommission the engineering knowledge used to mix them.

fields.headline: n = p1 + p2 ( = $1m )
fields.standfirst: Publisher's cash offer to solve 18th century maths riddle
fields.trailText: Equations do not come much simpler: n = p1 + p2. But knock off a quick proof of this one's eternal truth and you could become a dollar millionaire and earn yourself a place in number history.
fields.body:
Equations do not come much simpler: n = p1 + p2. But knock off a quick proof of this one's eternal truth and you could become a dollar millionaire and earn yourself a place in number history.

All you have to prove is that any even number (n) greater than two is the sum of two prime numbers (p1 and p2).

It is easy to show that it works with lots of numbers (6 = 3 + 3; 20 = 3 + 17; 52 = 5 + 47) and someone last year worked out with a large computer that the equation is valid up to 400,000,000,000,000.

But Faber, the publisher, wants definitive proof that the conjecture, dreamed up in 1742 by a Prussian who taught sums to the children of the czar, is valid to infinity: no one has managed that in 250 years.

This brain teaser was the work of Christian Goldbach (1690-1764) who outlined it in a letter to the great Swiss mathematician Leonard Euler. Learned heads have been kept scratching ever since and it has become even more of an irritant now that Fermat's last theorem has finally been cracked.

Now Faber has launched its million dollar challenge to coincide with a new book to be published on Monday. All solutions have to be submitted to an international team of scrutineers by March 15, 2002.

The book, titled Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture, a novel by the Greek writer Apostolos Doxiadis, tells of an ageing Athenian recluse who staked everything on solving the problem.

"Petros's struggle is as lonely as it is single-minded and by the end it has apparently destroyed his life," said Mr Doxiadis on his website. "Until, that is, a final encounter with his nephew opens up to Petros once more the deep mysterious beauty of mathematics."

Asked whether the deep beauty of Goldbach's conjecture kept him awake at night, Jeff Hooper, lecturer in mathematics at the university of Durham, said: "It's not something that people like me would worry about. It's more of a niggling thing in the sense that one would like, when a problem is very easily stated, that one could just solve it.

"It's very annoying when things are easy to state but seemingly impossible to solve. And prime numbers are not well understood. They behave essentially randomly and there's no nice way to get your hands on them."

Then he was told about the publisher's challenge. "It will be tempting to think about this a little ... But I don't think lots of mathematicians will drop everything and go for it."

fields.headline: Guardian sponsors Tate Modern launch
fields.trailText: The Guardian and Observer are to sponsor the launch of the new Tate Gallery development, Tate Modern, at Bankside power station in south London.
fields.body:
The Guardian and Observer are to sponsor the launch of the new Tate Gallery development, Tate Modern, at Bankside power station in south London.

The two newspapers are also backing the redevelopment of the Tate at Millbank, which is to be renamed Tate Britain.

The existing gallery alongside Vauxhall Bridge will reopen on March 24 and will house an exclusively British collection dating from the 16th century to the present. The Bankside gallery will open in May and show the Tate's international collection from 1900 to the present.

Damien Whitmore, communications director at the Tate, said: "This is a particularly special collaboration for the Tate Gallery.

"The Guardian and the Observer have long supported our work, and we are especially pleased to be working with them on the launch of Tate Britain and Tate Modern.

"This exciting partnership will enable the Tate to reach wide audiences, and help us celebrate this unique period in our history."

The opening of Tate Modern, in Sir Giles Gilbert Scott's power station redeveloped by the acclaimed Swiss practice Herzon & de Meuron, promises to be the cultural event of the year.

The Tate also has galleries of modern art in Liverpool and St Ives in Cornwall.

webTitle: Knifeman hunt as three are killed

fields.headline: Knifeman hunt as three are killed
fields.trailText: A manhunt was under way last night after police replying to a terrified child's 999 call found a mother and two children stabbed to death in their Berkshire home.
fields.body:
A manhunt was under way last night after police replying to a terrified child's 999 call found a mother and two children stabbed to death in their Berkshire home.

A police helicopter with heat-seeking equipment and teams of officers on foot were drafted in to help search for the killer.

Officers went to a house on the Great Hollands estate, in Bracknell, after receiving a call for a child, who said: "Daddy's stabbing mummy - my dad's gone mad."

The call was cut short when the line suddenly went dead. The killer is thought to have torn the wires from the wall.

An ambulance crew, which reached the house minutes later, found the woman and the two children, aged seven and 10, lying dead after what appeared to have been a frenzied attack.

The elder brother of the two murdered children, who arrived home from Bracknell college while police officers where still examining the bodies, almost stumbled onto the grim scene unaware that his family had been killed. Two officers grabbed the 16-year-old and ushered him away to a squad car.

Moments later, bystanders described how he burst into tears as officers told him that almost his entire family had been killed.

It is understood that the woman was a single parent and that the children's father did not live with them.

Sergeant Peter Gotch, of Thames Valley Police, said: "It seems likely that we will release information about the father if that will help the investigation. We are interviewing everyone we can." The manhunt was being led by Detective Superintendent Trevor Davies.

Crowds of residents stood in disbelief in the street after they learned of the murders at their neighbour's grey-brick terraced house.

A police helicopter with heat-seeking equipment and teams of officers on foot were drafted in to help search for the killer. webTitle: Concern in the heart of the Cotswolds

fields.headline: Concern in the heart of the Cotswolds
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: It is hard not to agree with the historian who described Chipping Camden as "the most beautiful village street left in this island."
fields.body:
It is hard not to agree with the historian who described Chipping Camden as "the most beautiful village street left in this island."

The long sweep of honey-coloured stone buildings at the heart of this Cotswold town is a magnet for tourists and day trippers and for what local estate agents like to refer to as the "affluent early retired".

But behind the chocolate- box facade of a street lined with a dizzying choice of pubs is a working Cotswold community. Agriculture remains an important part of the local economy. So it was with some concern that Camden learned yesterday that it had been chosen as the location for one of the farm-scale trials of GM oilseed rape.

"Oh no, it hasn't, has it?" was the spontaneous, disappointed reaction of many local people when news of the government decision was broken to them.

Richard Gill, 62, a construction management expert who has lived in the area for 18 years, was worried about the environmental impact.

"This is a big jump and I am not convinced they have done enough to to consider the risks of spreading the pollen over a wider area. We are going to finish up with pollen from GM crops affecting other crops."

Carole Webb, a smallholder who raises her free- range pigs, sheep and chickens on GM-free feed from a local supplier, said she was shocked by a decision that will result in a GM crop being planted almost on her doorstep.

"Most of the people who buy meat off us are dead against it," she said. "I do worry about what it may do to the environment because they don't know enough about it. Once it's done they can't just put it back in the bottle again."

Camden may not be the sort of place where people don white boiler suits to trample through the GM fields but, with at least two organic farms less than six miles away, the GM issue seems certain to raise tempers should planting go ahead as planned.

"I don't know anything about it. Go and get stuffed," one farmer told the Guardian by phone when it was suggested that his farm was to be used for the oilseed rape trial.

The Soil Association pledged to do all it could to help local organic producers after receiving a stream of phone calls from worried farmers. Their spokesman, Harry Hadaway, criticised the government for using the environment as an open air laboratory.

"We are really shocked that the government have gone ahead without taking into account the independent research indicating how far pollen will travel."

webTitle: Unveiled: the GM crop trial farms

fields.headline: Unveiled: the GM crop trial farms
fields.standfirst:
Government plans for at least 66 full-scale farm trials dismay environmentalists

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The slow march of genetically modified crops across the countryside gathered pace yesterday as the government promised that there would be at least 66 full-scale farm trials this year.
fields.body:
The slow march of genetically modified crops across the countryside gathered pace yesterday as the government promised that there would be at least 66 full-scale farm trials this year.

The sites of 30 farms in England and one in Scotland were announced, with others expected soon. There may be as many as 80 this year with more next year and in 2002.

But Wales will in effect be a GM-free zone for at least three years. No trials are expected on GM maize, beet or oilseed rape because their traditional equivalents are not widely cultivated there.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, condemned people who were tempted to destroy the crops - the exact locations of which will be freely available - for taking a Luddite view.

The government would not be blocked from completing its test programme, he added. Anyone who tried to prevent the trials by destroying crops or declaring GM-free zones would be "shooting themselves in the foot".

Mr Meacher said 114 farmers had volunteered to take part, despite earlier signs that the government was having difficulties finding enough. He confirmed that livestock fed on GM forage maize used in the trials might be slaughtered and processed into food, clearly labelled, before the results of the trials had been fully evaluated in 2003, despite assurances that other crops would not be used commercially. "Anyone who does not want to eat the food need not do so," Mr Meacher said.

His officials said animal feed containing the GM maize grown elsewhere was already widely used in Britain. It would not be possible to prevent the use of the British trial crop if the company responsible obtained all the proper permissions for its use.

Although at least 150 sites have been licensed for small-scale GM trials in recent years, the size of the new operation marks a significant change of pace in the GM story. Lord Melchett, Greenpeace's executive director, said: "This is potential tragedy for the environment. Britain will be bombarded with GM pollen with no regard to wildlife, the public or GM-free farmers. The whole process has been nothing short of genetic tyranny with an almost complete absence of consultation." The organisation is to launch a campaign to try to enforce local GM-free zones.

The government ran nine preliminary large farm trials last year, some of which were disrupted by protesters attacking GM plants. It intends running far wider trials over three years. This year it hopes for 25 fields for maize and oilseed rape and 30 for either sugar or fodder beet. GM crops, treated with new strong weedkillers to which they are resistant, will be planted in one part, up to 25 acres, and the rest will be planted with equivalent non-GM crops. Planting is expected to start in the next fortnight although some crops need not be in the ground until May.

Researchers for the government will study the effects on weeds, butterflies, bees and other insects, and check for cross-pollination.

Mr Meacher said his advisers were satisfied that the farms provided a wide enough range of location and farming methods to provide robust scientific results, though he was disappointed that no organic farms were taking part.

Grid references

Six-figure grid references of all the sites will be placed on the environment department's website, and a series of public meetings near the main trials will be held. The towns where the meetings are planned include York, Lincoln, Norwich, Ipswich, Cambridge, Luton, Leicester, and Worcester.

The government had taken full account of the concerns. "I do not accept that we can be blocked by what I would regard as a Luddite view towards the science," he said. "There is this idea we can say no to planting and no to imports and we can have a GM-free area in the UK.

"The government cannot prevent the import of GM products under both European Union and World Trade Organisation rules unless it can show risk to human health and/or damage to the environment. The only way to secure that evidence, if that is what people want, is through farm-scale evaluations."

He expected police to provide "extra assistance" to protect field sites where there may be disorder or illegal activity, but there was no nationally negotiated agreement.

The Scottish executive, which has so far only announced that a farm near Inverurie, Aberdeenshire, will be involved in a trial for oilseed rape, said it was likely to be the first of a number of sites. Ross Finnie, its minister for rural affairs, said: "We are neither pro- nor anti-GM crops. Our priorities are consumers and the environment but GM crops have great potential."

Roger Turner, chairman of the cross-in dustry biotech group Scimac, said: "Now we can get on with the job of answering the specific questions raised about GM crops on the basis of sound scientific evidence, not scaremongering and hysteria."

webTitle: Love, loathing and life with Ted Hughes

fields.headline: Love, loathing and life with Ted Hughes
fields.standfirst: New revelations show Sylvia Plath's view of the stormy relationship which ricocheted between love and hate
fields.trailText: Sylvia Plath predicted on the day after she met Ted Hughes that their relationship would lead to her death, according to extracts from her diaries, which appear exclusively in the Guardian today and next week.
fields.body:
Sylvia Plath predicted on the day after she met Ted Hughes that their relationship would lead to her death, according to extracts from her diaries, which appear exclusively in the Guardian today and next week.

Plath, one of the 20th century's outstanding poets, committed suicide in 1963, aged 30, having separated from her husband and fellow poet Hughes only months before.

For the first time, the diaries reveal Plath's version of the explosive relationship that has fascinated the literary world for 40 years. They also contain a string of intimate disclosures that shed new light on the complexity of Plath's sexuality, her depression and her hatred of her mother.

After her first meeting with Hughes, at a Cambridge party, she wrote "a full-page poem about the dark forces of lust: Pursuit. It is not bad. It is dedicated to Ted Hughes."

Pursuit begins with the following lines: "There is a panther stalks me down:/One day I'll have my death of him."

Her diaries also reveal that, on the morning of their meeting, Plath had been to see a new psychiatrist. And straight after the party, despite their powerful mutual attraction - she bit Hughes's cheek until it bled - Plath had a sexual encounter with another man, a Canadian student, in his college rooms.

"I was just so damn grateful for his weight on me and his mouth which was nice, and begged that he scold me, and he just said I wasn't a whore or a slut like I said but only a very silly girl and he kind of liked me," she wrote.

Plath dropped the Canadian when Hughes started turning up outside her room in the middle of the night. The diaries show how Hughes would shout her name and throw stones at what he thought was her window - although he got the wrong one.

Hughes heavily censored the diaries 20 years ago, cutting out two-thirds of her words - much of them about himself. Only now are his omissions reinstated and the journals published in full.

He excised Plath's comment that he was "the biggest seducer in Cambridge", and suggestions that he was vain. For instance he removed: "Ted looked slovenly: his suit jacket wrinkled as if being pulled from behind, his pants hanging, unbelted, in great folds, his hair black and greasy in the light." Similarly cut was: "Who knows who Ted's next book will be dedicated to? His navel. His penis."

She went on to say, "This is the vain, selfish face and voice I first saw and the Yorkshire beacon boy, a sweet and daily companion, is gone ... the dirt is too deep for Halo shampoo and Lux soap, the raggedness too far frayed for the neat nip of the trimming shears."

In addition, Hughes had cut out references that Plath made to his depression, and some mentions of their sex life.

But the diaries also show that their complicated seven-year relationship was frequently happy. She wrote often about her joy in finding "the big, blasting, dangerous love".

That love began at that very first meeting. Plath described Hughes as "that big, dark, hunky boy, the only one there huge enough for me". He kissed her "bang smash on the mouth" and ripped off her headband and earrings - "hah, I shall keep, he barked" - before she bit him on the cheek. "Such violence, and I can see how women lie down for artists," she wrote.

Elsewhere she wrote: "Good lovemaking today, morning and afternoon, all hot and hard and lovely."

She confessed: "All day I have to run about, a hundred times, to kiss him in his niche or in his bath, to sniff his smell of bread and grapes and kiss his delectable places".

Plath was determined to make her living as a writer, and worried about her dependence on Hughes. But, in entries that cast her more as a 1950s homemaker than the feminist icon she became, she wrote: "Make him happy: cook, play, read ... never accuse or nag - let him run, reap, rip - and glory in the temporary sun of his ruthless force." She added: "My God, I'd love to cook and make a house and surge force into a man's dreams."

Plath had a tendency to very serious depression, and all her life she "ricocheted" between manic all-American smilingness and self-hating rage.

The last journal before her suicide, when she gassed herself in her London flat while her two toddlers slept upstairs, was destroyed by Hughes, whose next partner, Assia Wevill, also killed herself.

Another Plath diary disappeared several years after her death, assumed stolen. But the journal from 1953, leading up to Plath's first suicide attempt at the age of 20, provides shocking insight into the mind of a woman already spiralling out of control. She took an overdose of sleeping pills, was missing for two days and survived only because she took too many tablets and vomited.

In entries that were censored in the US by Plath's mother, Aurelia, Sylvia wrote brutally about her hatred for her mother, to whom she felt inescapably attached but whom she blamed for the death of her father when she was eight. She wrote: "I hate her hate her hate her ... I hate her because he [her father] wasn't loved by her. He was an ogre. But I miss him. He was old, but she married an old man to be my father. It was her fault. Damn her eyes."

This contrasts sharply with the cheery letters home that Plath was writing to her mother at the time. Plath also wrote about the occult experimentation that was a feature of her life with Hughes; her jealousy about her husband's female friends and her suspicions that he was having an affair; and the homophobia that Hughes, among others, expressed on meeting the gay American writer Truman Capote.

fields.headline: Labour inquest into poll defeat
fields.standfirst:
Tories jubilant at Ayr byelection win as SNP vote increases by 9%

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: There is a plaque on the wall of Ayr council chambers that spells out the motto of the town in gothic gold script. "Ne'er forget the people of Ayr," it says.
fields.body:
There is a plaque on the wall of Ayr council chambers that spells out the motto of the town in gothic gold script. "Ne'er forget the people of Ayr," it says.

But many here believe Labour has wilfully ignored that message - and they have told them so in no uncertain terms, voting them into a humiliating third place in the Scottish parliament's historic first byelection, behind a victorious Conservative party and a resurgent Scottish National party.

This weekend, as the Tories celebrate their first directly elected seat in the Scottish parliament and their first by-election win in Scotland for more than 30 years, the post-mortem for Labour begins in earnest.

Coming second in a marginal seat could have been spun. Coming third and losing 16% of their vote is harder to explain, although the first minister, Donald Dewar, did try yesterday, blaming mid-term blues and distractions such as the row over section 28 for the failure of their candidate, Rita Miller.

He said: "Clearly it was from our point of view a disappointing result. No one likes being in third place. There have been distractions and it has been difficult to get through the basic issues because of these distractions. I think section 28 was certainly a factor. It was obviously difficult when all their campaign was directed against the Labour party."

"I am disappointed. I am going to look, listen and analyse and try to build on this, but there is no way I regard this as some sort of cataclysmic event."

By his side, the Scottish secretary, John Reid, was characteristically blunt and less inclined to blame external forces. "It is a poor result for us. There are no medals for losers. We will look, listen and learn from the result. There are occasions when the electorate blows a raspberry at all of us."

But there are some who say the result is cataclysmic for the party, even on a UK level, and that it will raise fresh questions about Mr Dewar's leadership, the performance of the Labour-Lib Dem ruling coalition at Holyrood, and the general direction of New Labour under Tony Blair.

John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde university, said: "The message is that Tony Blair does not walk on air. It is all of a piece with the evidence of recent British polls, which is that Labour still has a stupendous lead, but it is narrowing. We shouldn't assume that this simply applies in Scotland."

Labour's own grim assessment of its performance made clear that the lessons of a string of recent byelections have finally hit home. For all Downing Street's talk that the party's traditional supporters are delighted with Mr Blair, Labour is suffering a traditional mid-term slump in which core voters either stay at home or flock to other parties.

Privately, senior Blairites are deeply concerned that Labour's voters are so uninspired that they may simply not bother turning out in next year's general election. Labour's strategists believe this is deeply unfair because the government has addressed the interests of core supporters across the board, from the minimum wage to the working families tax credit which tops up the pay of the less well off.

However, traditionally-minded ministers, led by John Prescott, have admitted that there is a perception that the government is not addressing the concerns of its heartlands.

Whatever the national picture, many in Ayr believe that one of Labour's biggest problems is that they didn't think locally.

The successful Conservative candidate, John Scott, a well-known local farmer, has refused to treat Ayr as a proving ground for national issues like section 28. He concentrated instead on local concerns like the impending closure by the Labour-run local council of a well used and much loved day centre for the elderly. In a community with the highest proportion of over-55s in Scotland, the fate of Carrick Halls has become a defining issue of the byelection.

Yesterday, as they enjoyed a St Patrick's day lunch, many of the centre's regular users said they had been lifelong Labour voters but had deserted the party willingly.

"It's a lifeline," said Mary Brown, 71. "I was getting dressed this morning to come here and wondered, how much longer am I going to do this? It keeps people going. I used to vote Labour, but not this time, not after what they've done to us all. I'm pleased Mr Scott got in."

So is the Tory hierarchy in Scotland. Both Labour and the SNP have tried to play down the significance of the Tory win in a seat which has been a Conservative stronghold for decades, before Labour took it in 1997. What's a 3,000 majority when your share of the vote has only risen by 1%, they say.

Raymond Robertson, the party's Scottish chairman, said: "It's a bloody good win for us." The party's Scottish leader, David McLetchie, said: "It is a great day to be a Tory in Scotland and the UK. We have to look at the psychological boost this will give the Conservative party in Scotland as a whole. The people of Scotland woke up this morning to see the Scottish Tories back in business."

Analysts, meanwhile, say the Tories have the SNP to thank for their victory. The nationalists ran a slick campaign and saw their vote increase by more than 9% as disaffected Labour supporters swelled their ranks.

One Carrick Halls regular, Alex Kelly, 75, said: "There are a lot of disillusioned Labour voters in Ayr and for this election they decided to withhold their vote or go to another party. Labour have forgotten the people of Ayr and now they are living with the consequences."

The count

John Scott Conservative 12,580

Jim Mather Scottish Nationalist 9,236

Rita Miller Labour 7,054

James Stewart Scottish Socialist 1,345

Stuart Ritchie Liberal Democrat 800

fields.bodyText: There is a plaque on the wall of Ayr council chambers that spells out the motto of the town in gothic gold script. "Ne'er forget the people of Ayr," it says. But many here believe Labour has wilfully ignored that message - and they have told them so in no uncertain terms, voting them into a humiliating third place in the Scottish parliament's historic first byelection, behind a victorious Conservative party and a resurgent Scottish National party. This weekend, as the Tories celebrate their first directly elected seat in the Scottish parliament and their first by-election win in Scotland for more than 30 years, the post-mortem for Labour begins in earnest. Coming second in a marginal seat could have been spun. Coming third and losing 16% of their vote is harder to explain, although the first minister, Donald Dewar, did try yesterday, blaming mid-term blues and distractions such as the row over section 28 for the failure of their candidate, Rita Miller. He said: "Clearly it was from our point of view a disappointing result. No one likes being in third place. There have been distractions and it has been difficult to get through the basic issues because of these distractions. I think section 28 was certainly a factor. It was obviously difficult when all their campaign was directed against the Labour party." "I am disappointed. I am going to look, listen and analyse and try to build on this, but there is no way I regard this as some sort of cataclysmic event." By his side, the Scottish secretary, John Reid, was characteristically blunt and less inclined to blame external forces. "It is a poor result for us. There are no medals for losers. We will look, listen and learn from the result. There are occasions when the electorate blows a raspberry at all of us." But there are some who say the result is cataclysmic for the party, even on a UK level, and that it will raise fresh questions about Mr Dewar's leadership, the performance of the Labour-Lib Dem ruling coalition at Holyrood, and the general direction of New Labour under Tony Blair. John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde university, said: "The message is that Tony Blair does not walk on air. It is all of a piece with the evidence of recent British polls, which is that Labour still has a stupendous lead, but it is narrowing. We shouldn't assume that this simply applies in Scotland." Labour's own grim assessment of its performance made clear that the lessons of a string of recent byelections have finally hit home. For all Downing Street's talk that the party's traditional supporters are delighted with Mr Blair, Labour is suffering a traditional mid-term slump in which core voters either stay at home or flock to other parties. Privately, senior Blairites are deeply concerned that Labour's voters are so uninspired that they may simply not bother turning out in next year's general election. Labour's strategists believe this is deeply unfair because the government has addressed the interests of core supporters across the board, from the minimum wage to the working families tax credit which tops up the pay of the less well off. However, traditionally-minded ministers, led by John Prescott, have admitted that there is a perception that the government is not addressing the concerns of its heartlands. Whatever the national picture, many in Ayr believe that one of Labour's biggest problems is that they didn't think locally. The successful Conservative candidate, John Scott, a well-known local farmer, has refused to treat Ayr as a proving ground for national issues like section 28. He concentrated instead on local concerns like the impending closure by the Labour-run local council of a well used and much loved day centre for the elderly. In a community with the highest proportion of over-55s in Scotland, the fate of Carrick Halls has become a defining issue of the byelection. Yesterday, as they enjoyed a St Patrick's day lunch, many of the centre's regular users said they had been lifelong Labour voters but had deserted the party willingly. "It's a lifeline," said Mary Brown, 71. "I was getting dressed this morning to come here and wondered, how much longer am I going to do this? It keeps people going. I used to vote Labour, but not this time, not after what they've done to us all. I'm pleased Mr Scott got in." So is the Tory hierarchy in Scotland. Both Labour and the SNP have tried to play down the significance of the Tory win in a seat which has been a Conservative stronghold for decades, before Labour took it in 1997. What's a 3,000 majority when your share of the vote has only risen by 1%, they say. Raymond Robertson, the party's Scottish chairman, said: "It's a bloody good win for us." The party's Scottish leader, David McLetchie, said: "It is a great day to be a Tory in Scotland and the UK. We have to look at the psychological boost this will give the Conservative party in Scotland as a whole. The people of Scotland woke up this morning to see the Scottish Tories back in business." Analysts, meanwhile, say the Tories have the SNP to thank for their victory. The nationalists ran a slick campaign and saw their vote increase by more than 9% as disaffected Labour supporters swelled their ranks. One Carrick Halls regular, Alex Kelly, 75, said: "There are a lot of disillusioned Labour voters in Ayr and for this election they decided to withhold their vote or go to another party. Labour have forgotten the people of Ayr and now they are living with the consequences." webTitle: Newspapers challenge order to hand over MI5 case documents

fields.headline: Newspapers challenge order to hand over MI5 case documents
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: An Old Bailey judge yesterday ordered the Guardian and Observer to hand over any documents and emails relating to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
An Old Bailey judge yesterday ordered the Guardian and Observer to hand over any documents and emails relating to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.

In a case that has serious implications for press freedom, Judge Martin Stephens argued that any material the newspapers may possess could help police in their attempts to prosecute Mr Shayler under the official secrets act.

The judge claimed that any email address or other material relating to a letter from Mr Shayler published in the Guardian last month would be "essential evidence" in police inquiries. This was despite the judge's admission that the letter merely repeated allegations Mr Shayler had made about MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

Mr Shayler - in exile in Paris - wrote the letter to complain about a Guardian article suggesting that he was exaggerating the role of MI6.

The judge also argued that a front-page report in the Observer last month stating Mr Shayler had named two MI6 officers involved in the plot was "highly relevant" to the police investigation, even though the newspaper did not identify them.

The fact that Mr Shayler had already passed the information to the home secretary was not relevant, the judge ruled.

Both newspapers immediately announced that they would challenge the judge's order, and would take it to the European court of human rights if necessary.

Alan Rusbridger, the editor of the Guardian, said last night: "These police powers should only be used in exceptional circumstances against newspapers as they represent an interference with freedom of expression. Sources would be unwilling to contact journalists if they feared that their communications were likely to be handed over to the police.

"This is the second time in a year that the Guardian has had to fight for the right for journalists' material to be kept confidential. This case is similar to the one we fought in the case of the City of London rioters because there was no evidence before the court that the newspaper had anything of value to the investigation, or that any steps had been taken to get the information from other sources.

"Indeed, the judge in this case accepted that the information sent to the Guardian by David Shayler contained nothing new. In this case the police even claimed not to know David Shayler's email address - something Jack Straw could have told them. An application against a newspaper should be absolutely the last resort."

Mr Shayler said last night: "Once again it appears that the right of a free press exposing the activities of government are being trampled on."

fields.headline: Actor's mission on Mir cancelled
fields.trailText: Actor Vladimir Steklov was supposed to blast off to the Mir next month to play a renegade cosmonaut who won't leave the space station, but Russia won't let him leave Earth, a space official said Thursday.
fields.body:
Actor Vladimir Steklov was supposed to blast off to the Mir next month to play a renegade cosmonaut who won't leave the space station, but Russia won't let him leave Earth, a space official said Thursday.

The movie in which he was to star was one of a series of unorthodox proposals for resuscitating the dormant space station with private money.

But Konstantin Kreidenko, a spokesman for the Russian Aerospace Agency, said that "actor Vladimir Steklov will not go to Mir as earlier planned because of the failure to meet the terms of the contract." He declined to give details.

Cosmonauts Sergei Zalyotin and Alexander Kaleri are tentatively set to blast off to Mir on April 4, he said. The station has been unmanned since August. Zalyotin and Kaleri are expected to spend 45 days on board Mir. They will take a movie camera with them and possibly shoot some footage for the movie, Kreidenko said.

The movie, tentatively called The Last Journey, was to have told the story of a renegade cosmonaut who refuses to leave Mir, insisting he'll orbit the Earth for the rest of his days. Ground controllers decide to send up a woman to lure him back.

British producer John Daly and Russian director Yuri Kara said they hoped to involve big box-office names like Robert De Niro, Gary Oldman, Sean Penn and Catherine Zeta-Jones.

Although the filmmakers claimed that they made an initial payment to get the project underway, Russian space officials complained they haven't even been paid for Steklov's training, let alone the multi-million dollar bill for the flight.

Steklov meanwhile complained that his investment of time for training came to nothing.

"Now I am a jobless actor, a hobo," he said, according to the Interfax news agency. "Deep disappointment and bitterness that I could not get what was within reach is too mild a description."

The state-controlled RKK Energia company that built and owns the 14-year Mir has made frantic efforts to keep it aloft by raising private funds.

The cash-strapped government had said it would abandon the station this month unless private investors came up with funds, but then changed its mind and kept Mir in orbit after the Amsterdam-based MirCorp agreed to pay $10-20 million to lease commercial rights on the station. Ownership of the station remains with the Russian government.

MirCorp hopes to make money by offering rides to space tourists, satellite repair and production of materials in weightlessness. Details of the deal are sketchy and Energia has refused to say precisely how much money they received.

Russian space officials and cosmonauts are sceptical of the deal, and say privately their only hope is for the government to resume funding of Mir.

Acting President Vladimir Putin, considered a shoo-in in the March 26 presidential election, has already pledged to keep Mir alive.

The government has ruled that Energia can use booster rockets and cargo ships for the Mir that had originally been earmarked for the International Space Station project. The reapportioning has angered the US space agency Nasa; the ISS already is far behind schedule because of Russia's failure to provide a key module.

Russian officials, meanwhile, are angered over a law signed by President Bill Clinton this week that would cut US payments to Russia for the ISS project if Russian companies are found to have helped Iran develop nuclear arms.

Russia has actively assisted Iran in its nuclear power program, which the United States fears is being used to cover up secret efforts to build nuclear weapons.

The Russian Foreign Ministry on Wednesday called the new US measure "yet another attempt to give internal US legislation an extraterritorial nature, which goes completely against international law."

fields.headline: Alaska meteorite a 'cosmic bonanza'
fields.trailText: A meteorite that dazzled viewers when it exploded in the atmosphere over the wilderness of the Canada-Alaska border may soon provide scientists with a glimpse into life before the Earth was created.
fields.body:
A meteorite that dazzled viewers when it exploded in the atmosphere over the wilderness of the Canada-Alaska border may soon provide scientists with a glimpse into life before the Earth was created.

Charcoal-like fragments of the meteorite indicate it is about 4.5 billion years old - possibly predating the birth of the solar system - and make the discovery a "cosmic bonanza," Canadian and US scientists said on Thursday.

"It tells us what the initial materials were like that which went into making up the Earth, the moon and the sun," Dr. Michael Zolensky, a cosmic mineralogist at Nasa's Johnson Space Centre, said in a written statement.

The meteorite exploded over the mountains between Carcross, Yukon and Skagway, Alaska on the morning of January 18, shaking houses and providing residents of the remote region with a dramatic light show.

The location of the explosion turned out to be ideal for scientists, because the frozen conditions helped preserve organic materials in the fragments that fell to the ground and were discovered by a resident hiking in the wilderness.

The meteorite is a carbonaceous chondrite, a rare type of meteorite that contains many forms of carbon and organic materials, basic building blocks of life, but is difficult to recover because it usually breaks down on entry, scientists said.

"This is probably the only time in my career this will happen," Zolensky said.

The fragments - lumps of crumbly rock with scorched and pitted surfaces - resemble partly used charcoal briquettes and still smell of sulphur, said Dr. Richard Herd, Curator of National Collections for the Geological Survey of Canada.

About 2 pounds (1kg) of meteorite fragments have been recovered so far. The finder, who has asked the scientist not to identify him, has loaned the fragments to the Geological Survey and the University of Calgary.

Scientists have begun to conduct a series of tests on the fragments and say some the value of the preserved condition of the material is that it allows them to store some of it for future study.

"You can tuck samples away for the future when new questions come along that people can't even think up now," Zolensky said.

fields.headline: Smoke signals and wrong tracks
fields.standfirst: Ever since its birth jazz has, unfairly or otherwise, been strongly associated with narcotics abuse. Researching a new series for Radio 3,  Brian Morton  uncovered a far more complex relationship
fields.trailText: Ever since its birth jazz has, unfairly or otherwise, been strongly associated with narcotics abuse. Researching a new series for Radio 3, Brian Morton uncovered a far more complex relationship
fields.body:
How cool would it still seem if it turned out that Charlie Parker had been killed not by heroin but by fried chicken? It's useful to remember that he was called Bird not for his dizzying flights on alto saxophone, or even for his long-standing determination to get and stay high - Parker started using the drug at the age of 15 - but for his prodigious appetite for "yardbirds", to say nothing of burgers, ice cream, doughnuts, Hershey bars and beer. Given the iconic status of the jazz junkie, haunted, hunted, driven by deep need, his death, in an armchair in the apartment of his patroness Nica de Koenigswater, is almost abjectly comfy.

When producer Dave Batchelor and I set out to create the montage of reefer songs, coke highs and low-down, drag-out heroin nightmares that became BBC Radio 3's The Chant of the Weed, our aim was to be no more than cautiously debunking. In the 1990s, the prevailing archetype of the jazz musician is no longer Nelson Algren's needful junkie with a "golden arm" - the figure of Frankie Machine brought to chilling life on screen by Frank Sinatra - but a college-educated boy in a sweater and Timberlands. The female equivalent has also changed: from a sleepy, spangly broad with dead eyes sharing a needle with the guys at the back of the bus (or sneaking off to a truckstop john to inject into her groin so that track marks wouldn't force her to wear long gloves, like Billie Holiday), to a smart, sussed career woman with a cellphone and a gym card.

So unfashionable has the association between drugs and jazz become, so casual the assumption that it amounts to a vast racist slur, that one leading jazz journalist, Mike Zwerin of the International Herald Tribune, actually refused to speak to us on the subject; or rather, he agreed to speak in order to say that there was nothing to talk about.

To a degree, Zwerin, who played trombone and bass trumpet in the 50s with the likes of Miles Davis (a sometime user) and Eric Dolphy (almost puritanically clean), has a valid point. Seeing drugs - to stick for the moment to that awkwardly dismissive shorthand - as the underlying explanation for all jazz biography is nonsense. He points to the case of saxophonist Wardell Gray, murdered in what has always been assumed to be a drug-related incident, but which now seems to have been otherwise motivated.

However, even once corrections of that sort have been registered, there is still a story to tell, and it is one that somewhat surprised us. Easy to assume that, in keeping with the public assumption, a few giggly puffs of a Thai stick at the start of the story gives way to cramped and aching horror at the end, as dope runs out on the street. Easy also to think that for most musicians use of both hallucinogens and narcotics was done - Aldous Huxley-fashion - as a way of opening up doors of expression that might otherwise have remained shut. Easy, too, to blame poor Charlie Parker for turning a whole generation on to the mantra: high is cool, straight is square.

The bulk of our story was inevitably focused on America, but it was a British - indeed Scottish - musician who brought into focus some of the more pointed realities of narcotics use within jazz. Saxophonist Bobby Wellins used to do a tongue-in-cheek guided tour of Brighton which he called "Bobby's Bogs", a round-up of the public conveniences where he used to shoot up, relatively secure from prosecution in the knowledge that if not he, then his friend and drummer Phil Seamen, was a registered addict.

In 1965, Wellins performed one of the most achingly beautiful solos ever executed on a tenor saxophone, Starless and Bible Black on Stan Tracey's Under Milk Wood suite. Full of air and light, it was played, as he now admits, under the influence of "all sorts of narcotics", and yet, for Wellins, there was no intrinsic connection between drug-taking and what or how he played. Diamorphine was a response not to creative agonies, but to the straitened tedium of eking out a living as a jazz player, and to the recognition that he was never going to be a world-ranking player, like Parker or Coltrane.

Wellins was also warned off drugs by the older players, much as Charlie Parker, long assumed to be the tubby poster- boy of heroin chic, had reacted furiously when younger players like Jackie McLean and Frank Morgan had copied not just his bebop chops but also his habit.

Jazz historian Dan Morgenstern was adamant that Parker could not be held responsible and that the saxophonist's famous collapse during the recording of Lover Man, a moment almost voyeuristically lingered over in Clint Eastwood's biopic Bird, had nothing to do with heroin; Parker had demonstrated an unflagging ability to play at the highest level while high.

The facts about heroin use (which inevitably seems the test case in this story) are still muddied. Though there was no register of addicts in America, heroin was not illegal till 1937 and was, routinely, cheaper than brandy and often more readily available. The ironic impact of prohibition - America drank more and turned to drugs - was compounded in the war years when opiates became a basic component of field-dressing packs. When freely and safely available, heroin use seemed surprisingly non-problematic. Vibraphonist Gary Burton, not a user himself, told us that he had worked with many and that the majority managed their habits very well indeed.

Burton also hinted at something that is perhaps even more central to the story. The real motor of drug use in jazz isn't availability or economic location. From the earliest times, drug use was a mark of separateness, a refusal to conform to white middle-class norms. Don Redman's The Chant of the Weed could be adopted by mainstream conductor Andre Kostelanetz in the unquestioning belief that it referred unproblematically to tobacco. And how the boys in the back of the bus must have laughed at the straights who thought that Mary Jane, just in from the country, was a kissing cousin.

Louis Armstrong, who seemed to come closer to Uncle Tomming than any other great figure of the music, used "muggles" and "tea" and references to both as a way of showing his fellow-musicians that he hadn't been bought out by Whitey; Pops's entourage even included a guy whose sole duty was to find the local supplier.

The white clarinettist Mezz Mezzrow, the nearest thing ever to Norman Mailer's "White Negro", inveigled his way on to the stand with infinitely better players simply because he was always holding the best dope. Later on, in the bebop era, heroin was part of the freemasonry of musical separatism; almost nobody would speak of it as an aid to expression; it was a social and then a political act.

Making the programmes was a valuable exercise in scepticism as well as a warning against overhasty moralising. After Charlie Parker, there were to be new poster boys, most convincingly Chet Baker. Chet could have modelled for Saks or taken over from James Dean had he not played the trumpet, which he continued to do long after a gang of dealers kicked his teeth out for non-payment. He carried on, in fact, right up to the moment when he fell to his death from an Amsterdam hotel. In later years, Chet played almost every night all over Europe for one reason and one reason only: to score a fix. And yet the music he made, often with bands that scarcely passed muster, was consistently exquisite, documented on almost 175 LPs, tapes and bootlegs from the last eight years.

And then at the opposite end of the story, there was John Coltrane, famously supposed to have taken heroin to control agonising dental pain but who then went the now-sanctioned route, got clean and got religion. Looking deeper, it's clear that Trane was subject to the same peer pressures as everyone else but that, far from throwing over drugs entirely, he continued to dabble, and, unusually for a jazz musician, experimented with LSD - an episode that says a lot about the "spiritual" foundation of his famous long-form improvisations.

The story Dave and I uncovered was at worst tragicomic and often joyous. Looking in from the outside, it's easy to overemphasise the casualty figures and the exploitative dimensions of the story. Looking somewhat from within - and we spent many hours reading and re-reading the unghosted testimony of musicians themselves - it becomes clear that drugs and jazz are intertwined, but that the nature of the connection is as complex as the pharmocology. The "chant of the weed" is full of dissonances and codes, but it's also a celebration, of music and of life.

 The Chant of the Weed continues on BBC Radio 3 today at 6pm, and concludes on Saturday March 25.
