Easy to assume that, in keeping with the public assumption, a few giggly puffs of a Thai stick at the start of the story gives way to cramped and aching horror at the end, as dope runs out on the street. Easy also to think that for most musicians use of both hallucinogens and narcotics was done - Aldous Huxley-fashion - as a way of opening up doors of expression that might otherwise have remained shut. Easy, too, to blame poor Charlie Parker for turning a whole generation on to the mantra: high is cool, straight is square. The bulk of our story was inevitably focused on America, but it was a British - indeed Scottish - musician who brought into focus some of the more pointed realities of narcotics use within jazz. Saxophonist Bobby Wellins used to do a tongue-in-cheek guided tour of Brighton which he called "Bobby's Bogs", a round-up of the public conveniences where he used to shoot up, relatively secure from prosecution in the knowledge that if not he, then his friend and drummer Phil Seamen, was a registered addict. In 1965, Wellins performed one of the most achingly beautiful solos ever executed on a tenor saxophone, Starless and Bible Black on Stan Tracey's Under Milk Wood suite. Full of air and light, it was played, as he now admits, under the influence of "all sorts of narcotics", and yet, for Wellins, there was no intrinsic connection between drug-taking and what or how he played. Diamorphine was a response not to creative agonies, but to the straitened tedium of eking out a living as a jazz player, and to the recognition that he was never going to be a world-ranking player, like Parker or Coltrane. Wellins was also warned off drugs by the older players, much as Charlie Parker, long assumed to be the tubby poster- boy of heroin chic, had reacted furiously when younger players like Jackie McLean and Frank Morgan had copied not just his bebop chops but also his habit. Jazz historian Dan Morgenstern was adamant that Parker could not be held responsible and that the saxophonist's famous collapse during the recording of Lover Man, a moment almost voyeuristically lingered over in Clint Eastwood's biopic Bird, had nothing to do with heroin; Parker had demonstrated an unflagging ability to play at the highest level while high. The facts about heroin use (which inevitably seems the test case in this story) are still muddied. Though there was no register of addicts in America, heroin was not illegal till 1937 and was, routinely, cheaper than brandy and often more readily available. The ironic impact of prohibition - America drank more and turned to drugs - was compounded in the war years when opiates became a basic component of field-dressing packs. When freely and safely available, heroin use seemed surprisingly non-problematic. Vibraphonist Gary Burton, not a user himself, told us that he had worked with many and that the majority managed their habits very well indeed. Burton also hinted at something that is perhaps even more central to the story. The real motor of drug use in jazz isn't availability or economic location. From the earliest times, drug use was a mark of separateness, a refusal to conform to white middle-class norms. Don Redman's The Chant of the Weed could be adopted by mainstream conductor Andre Kostelanetz in the unquestioning belief that it referred unproblematically to tobacco. And how the boys in the back of the bus must have laughed at the straights who thought that Mary Jane, just in from the country, was a kissing cousin. Louis Armstrong, who seemed to come closer to Uncle Tomming than any other great figure of the music, used "muggles" and "tea" and references to both as a way of showing his fellow-musicians that he hadn't been bought out by Whitey; Pops's entourage even included a guy whose sole duty was to find the local supplier. The white clarinettist Mezz Mezzrow, the nearest thing ever to Norman Mailer's "White Negro", inveigled his way on to the stand with infinitely better players simply because he was always holding the best dope. Later on, in the bebop era, heroin was part of the freemasonry of musical separatism; almost nobody would speak of it as an aid to expression; it was a social and then a political act. Making the programmes was a valuable exercise in scepticism as well as a warning against overhasty moralising. After Charlie Parker, there were to be new poster boys, most convincingly Chet Baker. Chet could have modelled for Saks or taken over from James Dean had he not played the trumpet, which he continued to do long after a gang of dealers kicked his teeth out for non-payment. He carried on, in fact, right up to the moment when he fell to his death from an Amsterdam hotel. In later years, Chet played almost every night all over Europe for one reason and one reason only: to score a fix. And yet the music he made, often with bands that scarcely passed muster, was consistently exquisite, documented on almost 175 LPs, tapes and bootlegs from the last eight years. And then at the opposite end of the story, there was John Coltrane, famously supposed to have taken heroin to control agonising dental pain but who then went the now-sanctioned route, got clean and got religion. Looking deeper, it's clear that Trane was subject to the same peer pressures as everyone else but that, far from throwing over drugs entirely, he continued to dabble, and, unusually for a jazz musician, experimented with LSD - an episode that says a lot about the "spiritual" foundation of his famous long-form improvisations. The story Dave and I uncovered was at worst tragicomic and often joyous. Looking in from the outside, it's easy to overemphasise the casualty figures and the exploitative dimensions of the story. Looking somewhat from within - and we spent many hours reading and re-reading the unghosted testimony of musicians themselves - it becomes clear that drugs and jazz are intertwined, but that the nature of the connection is as complex as the pharmocology. The "chant of the weed" is full of dissonances and codes, but it's also a celebration, of music and of life.  The Chant of the Weed continues on BBC Radio 3 today at 6pm, and concludes on Saturday March 25.

webTitle: Coming soon: The Divorce of Figaro

fields.headline: Coming soon: The Divorce of Figaro
fields.standfirst: So Holst's Planets has finally been completed.  Andrew Clements can think of a few other works that could do with proper endings
fields.trailText: So Holst's Planets has finally been completed. Andrew Clements can think of a few other works that could do with proper endings
fields.body:
For 80 years Gustav Holst's most popular work has been one planet short of a solar system. When he completed The Planets in 1917 the existence of the ninth planet, Pluto, hadn't been confirmed (it was eventually proved in 1930, four years before Holst's death) and so his orchestral suite consists of seven movements; he omitted Earth because it didn't fit into his astrological view of things. But on Thursday the news was announced that Pluto is going to be put into orbit. The conductor Kent Nagano and the Hallé Orchestra have persuaded Colin Matthews to write a movement that boldly goes where no composer has gone before; his music, Pluto the Renewer, will be premiered after a performance of Holst's score is performed in Manchester in May. Apparently Nagano originally wanted Matthews to write an Earth movement too, but the composer refused, on the grounds that it wasn't a "planet" in the Holstian sense of the word.

Matthews hasn't written pastiche, but a piece in his own style (very fast apparently, taking solar winds as its starting point). What he has done, then, is not a straight completion of the kind that litters musical history from Mozart's Requiem (completed by Süssmayer) through Puccini's Turandot (with its closing scene by Alfano), Mahler's 10th Symphony (fleshed out by Deryck Cooke, assisted by Colin Matthews and his brother David) and Berg's Lulu (the third act orchestrated by Friedrich Cerha) right up to the present day and Anthony Payne's deservedly acclaimed "elaboration" (his word) of the sketches that Elgar left for his Third Symphony, which was first performed two years ago. This Pluto is closer to the work that Busoni based upon Bach's Art of Fugue, the massive Fantasia Contrapuntistica for two pianos, which carries on from where Bach left off in the middle of the culminating fugue, or to Alexander Goehr's opera Arianna, which recycles the libretto for Monteverdi's lost opera of the same name.

But the possibilities for other composers are endless. No doubt John Tavener would be only too pleased to add a Resurrection to Richard Strauss's symphonic poem Death and Transfiguration, James MacMillan could add a Second Coming to Mahler's Second Symphony, and Frederick Stocken could write Mendelssohn's Sixth Symphony and we'd never know the difference, while opera houses would no doubt fall over each other to commission John Adams to provide his own Nixon in China with a Watergate sequel.

It is opera that provides the most fertile ground for that kind of fantasy. We know what happened to Cherubino after the events of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro because Massenet tells us in Chérubin, just as Rossini's Barber of Seville reveals how Rosina had got to marry Count Almaviva in the first place. But there are all sorts of loose ends in Cosi Fan Tutte which need to be neatly tied together - did those two nice girls really end up with those ghastly laddish men, and did Don Alfonso finally get off with Despina? (I doubt that somehow.) And wouldn't it be nice to know if Parsifal lived happily ever after as king of the grail knights, and whether Rudolfo found another girl of his dreams after Mimi's death in La Bohème? (Probably the next day, I should think.)

The idea that works of art are fixed in their own, self-contained worlds is obviously in need of a thorough, postmodern overhaul. Pierre Boulez may have spent his career as a composer repeatedly recomposing what he has written before, but little did he realise that he could turn someone else's music into a "work in progress" rather than confining himself to his own pieces. Matthews's extension to The Planets, may be a one off - he is too discriminating and self-aware a composer to treat this commission as anything other than a challenge on strictly musical grounds - but for less scrupulous composers and concert promoters short of a novelty it could be the way to gain themselves a few extra column inches.

fields.headline: The taming of 'beshrew'
fields.standfirst: Beshronk the rain, beshronk the joanna, and beshronk Ystrad Mynach FC
fields.trailText: Beshronk the rain, beshronk the joanna, and beshronk Ystrad Mynach FC
fields.body:
Beshrew me if the price of pumpkins has not risen yet again!" The speaker was a tall, gaunt figure clad in the robes of a senior prelate. His aquiline nose betrayed a certain fastidiousness which his sexual proclivities...

A doctor writes : I deprecate these observations. Over the past few months, my surgery has been inundated with patients asking to be beshrewed. I blame the media, for its ceaseless harping on the topic of dysmorphophobia. Yet medical textbooks give no hint as to how this operation can be conducted. Tales about pumpkins are hardly a practical substitute.

Smallweed accommodatingly responds : I am only too happy to help. Whatever your patients think, the word beshrewed has nothing to do with turning into a shrew, or even into a termagant (the sense in which shrew is used in that somewhat unfortunate play by Shakespeare). Its primary meaning is to make wicked, evil or depraved, though that is not what Chaucer's summoner means when he declares: "I beshrew me but if I tell tales two or three of friars." Beshrew in this context means curse. The summoner is saying: may I be cursed if I fail to fulfil my promise. Likewise the line in Othello: "Beshrew me if I would do such a wrong for the whole world."

A philologist writes : The answer to all these problems is to abandon the word beshrew, which is causing all these appalling problems, and readopt its ancient alternative - beshronk.

Very well: let us start again. "Beshronk me if the price of pumpkins has not risen yet again!". The speaker was a tall, gaunt figure, clad in the robes of a senior prelate. His aquiline nose...

A Seeker for Truth (Crewkerne) writes : Was the prelate perchance wearing a chasuble?

Smallweed guardedly replies: Perhaps. You remind me, however, that, in the matter of chasubles, Martin Loft of Totley passes on a tale of John Buchan's about a candidate for a staunchly protestant constituency who addressed an election rally with the words: "Men of Kilklavers, will you endure to see a chasuble erected in your market place? Will you see your daughters sold into simony? Will you see celibacy openly practised in your streets?" To which the audience replied with a thunderous: "Never!"

 I went this week to see the film version of Graham Greene's The End of the Affair, in which Ralph Fiennes and Julianne Moore are mercilessly pursued by God, heavy rain, and the music of Michael Nyman through 1940s London. I found the rain excessive. London is rainy from time to time, to be sure, but it's hardly Bengal in monsoon. One feels one is being exploited. On this charge, however, the writer-director, Neil Jordan, can claim some mandate from Greene. The opening scene in which Fiennes bumps into the husband whom he has cuckolded is specifically set on a black, wet January night in 1946.

Bad weather also accompanies other encounters. "It was very hot today and it dripped with rain" Greene's heroine records in her diary for October 2, 1945. "I couldn't stand the house tonight, so I walked in the rain," says her very next entry. "It was a worse night than the one when I met Henry a month before," the hero assures us a few pages later. "This time it was sleet instead of rain: it was halfway to snow and the edged drops seemed to slash their way in through the buttonholes of one's raincoat." In the matter of Nyman's music, however, Jordan has no defence. It's full of the sort of background bullying which orders you to Feel Moved. As to The Piano: the pianist heroine there, for reasons never fully explained, is mute. For myself, I put it down to her having to spend so many hours playing the music of Michael Nyman.

 The first instalment of Jonathan Aitken's memoirs, which the Sunday Times is serialising, was full of poignancies. Unlike some of his unlovely defenders, the odious Tacky for instance, Aitken accepts that he did wrong and deserved the heavy penalty visited on him. He also describes how he came close to suicide, asking his son whether the boy thought his own life and future career might have rather better prospects if he were not encumbered with the burden of a disgraced father hovering in the background. The boy told him not to be such a chump, and Jonathan, accepting that verdict, decided to stay alive. There is only one thing wrong with this story. How could it ever be right to involve a 14-year-old boy in such a decision?

 The general verdict is that the 20-year-old Somerset driver Jenson Button did pretty well on his first formula one appearance last weekend. This is bad news, since it means we must expect another avalanche of headlines like these:

All eyes on the starter Button - The Times, Saturday; Button ready to push for recognition - Telegraph, Saturday; Now doubters will have to Button up - Express, Monday; Jenson bright as a Button until late engine failure - Mirror, Monday; Jenson was just 37 miles from glory - the Sun, Monday.

A pedant writes : Jenson was just 37 miles from glory? Where is the pun in that?

Smallweed defiantly ripostes : Can't see it myself, but it must be there somewhere. The Sun is never knowingly out-punned.

 And finally, the latest results from the South Wales senior league, division 2:

AFC Whitchurch 1, Ystrad Mynach S & S 1; Cefn Cribwr BC 1, Stanleytown 6; Cogan Coronation 1, Penrhiwceiber Cons 2; Llwynypia WMC 2, Penrhys Utd 1; Ystradmynach 1, Arjo Wigginstrelai 1; Penrhiwfer 4, Glyn Wallen 2.

webTitle: And the little one said, roll over

fields.headline: And the little one said, roll over
fields.standfirst: A comedy about anal sex under a parachute? No wonder no one has dared stage it. Until now. In extracts from his production diary,  Peter Hall describes the problems of presenting Giuseppe Manfridi's Cuckoos
fields.trailText: A comedy about anal sex under a parachute? No wonder no one has dared stage it. Until now. In extracts from his production diary, Peter Hall describes the problems of presenting Giuseppe Manfridi's Cuckoos
fields.body:
January 6, 2000
I always knew that Cuckoos would be different; just how different was demonstrated by a phone call I had from the well-known agent of a well-known actress. "My client has read your play and is passing." (Agents love the power words of Hollywood.) "I am sorry to hear that," I replied. "And what's more, there is a message for you," continued the disapproving voice. "She doesn't wish to talk about it." I understood.

January 15
Cuckoos is very funny, but also, I hope, curiously shocking. Actresses obviously require strong nerves even to read it. Frankly, I don't know a play of such outrageous delicacy. Although it questions the barriers of taste (as theatre always must, if it is to stay alive) it remains amazingly elegant. That is what intrigued me some three years ago when I first read the play. Colin Teevan, the young dramatist, gave it to me then, and if I could have stayed at the Old Vic, I would have done it on one of the new play Sunday nights.

The play is in a vigorous tradition. From the Greeks on, theatre has always flirted with the shocking, the fantastic, the politically inadmissible or even the plain horrible. Sex and violence are not modern inventions and the censor has always watched them with his gimlet eyes. Theatre audiences - rather like tabloid newspaper readers - have always loved to be outraged. To balance dangerously on the edge of rejection excites an audience.

January 17
So is Cuckoos censorable? It certainly would have been 40 years ago. Our censor, the lord chamberlain, employed a staff of retired army and naval officers to read plays. Their chief attribute was that they had extraordinarily dirty minds: they were indeed adept at finding filth where none was intended. Well, it is intended here. They must be spinning in their graves.

I hated the lord chamberlain during my early years. Where was the land of free speech? Not Britain, certainly. I did the first British production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof and Tennessee Williams's poetic anguish was banned because he was bold enough to say that homosexuality might possibly exist. In my RSC days, Samuel Beckett's line "God, the bastard - he doesn't exist" was removed because the lord chamberlain decreed that the theatre was not permitted to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the Almighty. It is therefore with a feeling of great pleasure that I direct a highly original play that starts as a comedy about anal sex under a parachute.

February 3
As I sat in the tiny auditorium of the Gate this morning I was thinking that it is a miracle such a place exists. Stephen Daldry is the most prominent character, but many other great talents have flowered there and then moved on. I also like the thought that Cuckoos has to my certain knowledge been turned down by every new-play producing stage in London. It is not that they don't like it; they daren't do it. The Gate and its director, Mick Gordon, have dared.

Cuckoos is part of a collaboration between the Gate and the National Theatre Studio. So the actors get paid a pittance for rehearsal and nothing whatsoever for performances. This is typically British. The Gate, one of our most cutting-edge theatres, pays no wages because it hasn't any money. Indeed, people are always telling me that its lack of money gives it freedom. Rubbish. I am sure that our narrow-minded masters of culture are delighted at the existence of the Gate because the British still believe it is terribly good for artists to suffer. It isn't. Actors, alone among highly skilled professionals, are content to work for nothing if they believe in the work.

February 15
After a big search and many refusals, I am thrilled to have landed Kelly Hunter to play the woman. She has developed amazingly and is able to touch comedy and tragedy with equal facility. More to the point, when she came to see me about Cuckoos, she spent 20 minutes enthusing about the play and analysing its precision. She never once asked about how we were to effect the actions under the parachute, or how "real" the events were going to be. She just accepted what the play required. The two men in the play have been much easier to cast. My old colleague David Yelland and the young actor Paul Ready were my first choices and accepted very quickly.

February 18
Giuseppe Manfridi was born in Rome in 1956. His work has been constantly produced on the Italian stage for 15 years. Cuckoos is the first of his plays to be presented in Britain. He is an original, but very much part of the ancient commedia tradition, with De Filippo and Dario Fo as his forebears.

Manfridi calls his theatre - with tongue in cheek - the theatre of excess. Thus the theatre of cruelty and the theatre of the absurd are sent packing. His work pushes our suspension of disbelief to the limit. There is a plain ordinariness about his incredible stories that allows the audience still to believe. One of the most tawdry phrases in the theatre is "We can get away with it", when applied to an inadequate piece of business, or a creaky turn of plot. Manfridi never gets away with it; he confronts it. And out of this is born riotous excess.

Teevan translates Manfridi into English, and Manfridi translates Teevan into Italian. Both dramatists have a love of letting extreme events loose in bourgeois drawing-rooms. It is as if we set up a perfectly ordinary room so that within it Titus Andronicus can cut his hand off, Gloucester can have his eyes pressed into a vile jelly and Howard Brenton's Romans can bugger the British. Who says metaphorical images in the theatre are dead?

February 21
First day's rehearsal. This is always the worst day in a director's life. It is the day when you know your cast is right or wrong; even worse, it is the day when you know if you have misjudged the play and it is no bloody good. You then face six or seven weeks of rising above it, of looking cheerful and trying to help a group of people who know only too well that disaster is slowly approaching them.

Nothing like that today, thank heavens. The play comes up off the page with clarity and wit. And as I suspected, it is remarkably timed and structured. The story is played out with the expertise of a thriller writer.

Manfridi told me that in the early stages of the play, the Italian audience were so amazed by the premise that they sat there with their mouths hanging open and hardly made a sound. Within 15 minutes, they had forgotten the extraordinariness of what they were watching and laughed. Audiences will believe anything providing it is credible. And they will forget anything, providing their attention is frankly engaged. I once saw a production of Don Giovanni in Paris that for some reason had two white horses tethered at the back of the stage, their bottoms towards us. They chewed hay and stamped, as horses do, and did the other necessary things that horses do. After each of these interruptions, the audience quickly forgot about them and went back to Mozart and Da Ponte. I never did discover the point of the horses. They were never referred to or touched by anybody.

February 28
I had been worried about all the technical problems. Since the two actors are under the parachute for almost the entire play, how would they be visible, how would they mask their nakedness, and indeed how would they be able to move at all? Lucy Hall, my designer, bought a real parachute from an army surplus store for £35. We spread it in the rehearsal room and it all worked like a dream. It is strange and beautiful - and also functional. Theatre is exactly like life in that it is always the things you worry about most that end up hurting you least.

March 13
First full run-through. I did something unusual and dangerous - I asked a score of assorted friends to experience our first attempt. They were as surprised as the actors. The play requires techniques akin to acting Pinter. The actors have to control the audience, and allow them to laugh at certain points so that they can hit them with something painful at others. The learning process of provoking then denying laughter takes time. And it is time we don't possess, because there are only three previews. Hence the presence of the audience.

They laughed immediately and well. For 20 minutes the play fizzed along. Then it died and the laughter died with it. Why? The actors relaxed a little after their first tension, and although the playing was still confident, it appeared to grow introverted and serious, and so no longer con trolled the audience. That extra 10% of energy was missing. Consequently, the audience obliged by stopping their laughter. They thought we wanted the fun to be over. In truth, the characters of this play must remain volatile - I mean Latin - and the situation is ridiculously intense, right up to the horror of the last 10 minutes. We can only go serious once. I have a week to completely refocus the play. I knew there was something wrong. I even knew what it was. But I needed it to be confirmed. Only an audience could do that.

'Have you ever - you know...' a scene from Cuckoos

Beatrice: You know, I would have thought that if you had even the slightest inkling that this might happen you could have informed me.

Tito: Firstly, I did not think there was even the tiniest possibility of this happening. And secondly, it was you gave me the green light.

Beatrice: Amber at the most.

Tito: It certainly wasn't red.

Beatrice: Remind me never to catch a ride with you. Again.

Tito: From behind, you said. Not much ambiguity in that. It was almost an order.

Beatrice: That has many interpretations.

Tito: Like what, for instance?

Beatrice: This is neither the time nor the place.

Tito: Means only one thing in my book.

Beatrice: You should read more widely.

He shudders and wipes the sweat from his brow.

You're shaking. Why are you shaking? You're at it again. Stop it. Stop it, I said!

Tito: Ahh!

Beatrice: You've got unlimited resources.

Tito: He might, but I don't.

Beatrice: I suppose, in a certain light, it could be seen as flattering.
Tito: You know, it's my first time, like this, I mean. (Pause.) Have you ever - you know - before?

Beatrice: (Reluctantly.) Only the once.

Tito: Once now or once before?

Beatrice: Once before! Once before!

Tito: Then you should know what to do.

Beatrice: It was a long time ago.

Tito: How long?

Beatrice: When I was young.

Tito: You're still young.

Beatrice: Forget it, sonny.

Tito: Honest. (Pause.) So how was it for you? Then, I mean.

Beatrice: It was beautiful.

Tito: How did it end?

Beatrice: It ended, at least. We emerged, looking at the stars and went our separate ways.

 Cuckoos opens on Friday at the Gate Theatre, London W11 (0171-229 5387). Cuckoos by Giuseppe Manfridi, English version by Colin Teevan, is published on Friday by Oberon Books at £6.99.
fields.bodyText: January 6, 2000 I always knew that Cuckoos would be different; just how different was demonstrated by a phone call I had from the well-known agent of a well-known actress. "My client has read your play and is passing." (Agents love the power words of Hollywood.) "I am sorry to hear that," I replied. "And what's more, there is a message for you," continued the disapproving voice. "She doesn't wish to talk about it." I understood. January 15 Cuckoos is very funny, but also, I hope, curiously shocking. Actresses obviously require strong nerves even to read it. Frankly, I don't know a play of such outrageous delicacy. Although it questions the barriers of taste (as theatre always must, if it is to stay alive) it remains amazingly elegant. That is what intrigued me some three years ago when I first read the play. Colin Teevan, the young dramatist, gave it to me then, and if I could have stayed at the Old Vic, I would have done it on one of the new play Sunday nights. The play is in a vigorous tradition. From the Greeks on, theatre has always flirted with the shocking, the fantastic, the politically inadmissible or even the plain horrible. Sex and violence are not modern inventions and the censor has always watched them with his gimlet eyes. Theatre audiences - rather like tabloid newspaper readers - have always loved to be outraged. To balance dangerously on the edge of rejection excites an audience. January 17 So is Cuckoos censorable? It certainly would have been 40 years ago. Our censor, the lord chamberlain, employed a staff of retired army and naval officers to read plays. Their chief attribute was that they had extraordinarily dirty minds: they were indeed adept at finding filth where none was intended. Well, it is intended here. They must be spinning in their graves. I hated the lord chamberlain during my early years. Where was the land of free speech? Not Britain, certainly. I did the first British production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof and Tennessee Williams's poetic anguish was banned because he was bold enough to say that homosexuality might possibly exist. In my RSC days, Samuel Beckett's line "God, the bastard - he doesn't exist" was removed because the lord chamberlain decreed that the theatre was not permitted to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the Almighty. It is therefore with a feeling of great pleasure that I direct a highly original play that starts as a comedy about anal sex under a parachute. February 3 As I sat in the tiny auditorium of the Gate this morning I was thinking that it is a miracle such a place exists. Stephen Daldry is the most prominent character, but many other great talents have flowered there and then moved on. I also like the thought that Cuckoos has to my certain knowledge been turned down by every new-play producing stage in London. It is not that they don't like it; they daren't do it. The Gate and its director, Mick Gordon, have dared. Cuckoos is part of a collaboration between the Gate and the National Theatre Studio. So the actors get paid a pittance for rehearsal and nothing whatsoever for performances. This is typically British. The Gate, one of our most cutting-edge theatres, pays no wages because it hasn't any money. Indeed, people are always telling me that its lack of money gives it freedom. Rubbish. I am sure that our narrow-minded masters of culture are delighted at the existence of the Gate because the British still believe it is terribly good for artists to suffer. It isn't. Actors, alone among highly skilled professionals, are content to work for nothing if they believe in the work. February 15 After a big search and many refusals, I am thrilled to have landed Kelly Hunter to play the woman. She has developed amazingly and is able to touch comedy and tragedy with equal facility. More to the point, when she came to see me about Cuckoos, she spent 20 minutes enthusing about the play and analysing its precision. She never once asked about how we were to effect the actions under the parachute, or how "real" the events were going to be. She just accepted what the play required. The two men in the play have been much easier to cast. My old colleague David Yelland and the young actor Paul Ready were my first choices and accepted very quickly. February 18 Giuseppe Manfridi was born in Rome in 1956. His work has been constantly produced on the Italian stage for 15 years. Cuckoos is the first of his plays to be presented in Britain. He is an original, but very much part of the ancient commedia tradition, with De Filippo and Dario Fo as his forebears. Manfridi calls his theatre - with tongue in cheek - the theatre of excess. Thus the theatre of cruelty and the theatre of the absurd are sent packing. His work pushes our suspension of disbelief to the limit. There is a plain ordinariness about his incredible stories that allows the audience still to believe. It is as if we set up a perfectly ordinary room so that within it Titus Andronicus can cut his hand off, Gloucester can have his eyes pressed into a vile jelly and Howard Brenton's Romans can bugger the British. It is the day when you know your cast is right or wrong; even worse, it is the day when you know if you have misjudged the play and it is no bloody good. And they will forget anything, providing their attention is frankly engaged. webTitle: The stargazer who came down to earth

fields.headline: The stargazer who came down to earth
fields.trailText: Lastorders.com? | More truths about Archer
fields.body:
A candid confession from Britain's most successful astrologer, Jonathan Cainer. Writing in the increasingly eccentric Daily Express, he said this week: "Wherever possible, astrologers avoid making specific predictions about particular events. We find it a lot safer to be vague. This allows us to claim credit when it suits us - and it gets us off the hook if we have misread a horoscope... Out of respect to tradition, I always make a point of speaking in riddles or of burying my very best prophecies in a set of casual, seemingly off-hand remarks."

In other words, he hasn't a clue what's going to happen, and even if he did get it right, you wouldn't understand it. For instance, his advice to me and my fellow Geminis this week included: "Time is an end in itself. Or rather, experience is." Amazing what the stars foretell, isn't it? Actually, I find Mr Cainer's honesty refreshing. He reminds me of the Punch cartoon captioned: "In a major breakthrough for the science of astrology, all people born under the sign of Scorpio were yesterday run over by egg lorries."

The clue to Mr Cainer's success comes below his quote: "Calls to Jonathan's Zodiac line cost 60p a minute... for a full personal horoscope, send £21.99." Apparently this is a huge business, earning money that would make Ken Livingstone blush. I shall make a fortune with my own personal Destiny Line at £1.20 a minute. Callers will hear a recorded message saying: "The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves. Now, get a bleeding life."

 My other money-spinner comes from an idea by my friend Dr Mark Garnett. It's for non-computer nerds, and it's called: toolate.com. Log on and it will be explained to you how you now have no chance of making a penny on the internet, and will also have to go on paying full price for airline tickets, hotel rooms, books and DVDs. This is such a useful service it should hit the stock market valued at least £10m, for a week at least, before it collapses to 37p.

 I spent many happy hours of my youth on Stalybridge station, and this handsome postcard of the buffet, sent in by David Hoult, brings back memories. I don't know which is more appealing: the town crier announcing last orders as the Stockport Flier thunders through, or that tasty-looking pork pie. Several readers have written about the curious culinary practices of the north-west. Apparently my flippant tone about the closure of Poole's Pies in Wigan was resented: "You can have no idea how delicious they were.

The drivers of Glasgow trains would hold them in Wigan station while the guard nipped out for a stack of pies," one ex-Wiganite tells me. Following my item about the chip pie, Dean Hawkes, now of Cambridge but raised in Rochdale, says that during the war he had a neighbour called Rosie who once told him that for her tea she'd had a cream cracker sandwich. "I made the obvious assumption that this would be two cream crackers with something between them, but she explained that it was two slices of bread with the cream cracker as filling. 'Grand,' she said. Wigan can't be allowed to have all the glory."

 Last week I mentioned Jeffrey Archer's remarkable diary in the Spectator. Something niggled me about it, then I woke up in the middle of the night and remembered what it was. The diary continued right up to Thursday March 9, even though the Spectator's deadline is Tuesday and the last minute anything can be squeezed in is 3pm on Wednesday afternoon. Yet we find Archer discussing the US primary results on Wednesday morning (inaccurately, as it turns out), describing how he wrote 2,000 words in the course of the day, and "in the evening [ie hours after the Spectator was printed] we join the Thatchers for dinner at the Ritz. I have no intention of repeating anything that was said on this occasion, but I suspect you can guess Denis Thatcher's views on Steve Norris's policy for gays."

If you read that very carefully, you'll see that nothing in it is an outright lie. The two halves of the last sentence could be taken separately and would both be accurate. Bearded this week by a colleague, Archer admitted that he had indeed written up this event before it took place. "But I steered the conversation round to Steve Norris and gays so as to make it true," he claimed. What a bizarre notion of truth he has, to be sure! But I suspect the whole thing was really there to show that the Thatchers still break bread with him, so yah-boo to the rest of us.

 Still on Lady Thatcher, there is sad news from the University of Buckingham, the freelance college which is her favourite seat of learning. For months they have planned a massive conference entitled "The Thatcher Years". Any anxieties about whether the participants would come down in favour of those years can be laid to rest by the subtitle: "The Rebirth of Liberty".

Speakers listed include John Redwood, Bernard Ingham, Baroness Young and visitors from various rightwing planets, such as Patrick Minford and Lord Harris of High Cross, who looks like a less rational version of Professor Branestawm. Plus a few less enthusiastic fans, such as Lord Howe and our own Hugo Young.

At a fee of £460 per head, plus VAT, plus accommodation, for the two-day conference, tickets should be a snip for all those people made rich and prosperous by Lady Thatcher's enlightened policies. But, sadly, not enough of them, for the conference has had to be cancelled due to lack of interest.

 More rightwingers of varying degrees of looniness, including Mr Redwood, the Hamiltons, and the ineffable Sir Alfred Sherman, attended the launch at Politico's bookshop this week of Blowing The Whistle, the book about corruption in the EU by the Dutch civil servant Paul van Buitenen. I always feel uneasy rubbing shoulders with such people, and the book itself is rather curiously written. There's a little more than is strictly necessary about the way his travails led the author to his Christian faith.

That said, if just a quarter of what he describes is true, then the EU is wasting our money at an unimaginable rate. The cronyism, the blackmail, the sweetheart contracts, the manner in which several commissioners ran their departments as gravy trains for their friends and compatriots. People who complained that the rules were being broken were threatened with the sack. The main investigatory body was hamstrung by the fact that before it began an inquiry, it had to have not a suspicion, but proof that misconduct had occurred. And we needn't get too complacent about crooked foreigners, either; one of van Buitenen's main villains is a middle-ranking British official whose friends were for a while very fortunate indeed.

Some years ago I was visiting the European parliament, and a group of Labour MEPs asked me to join them for dinner. We swept up to one of the finest restaurants in Strasbourg and tucked into a superlative meal, spoiled for me only by the fear that the paper would be unwilling to pay my share of such a monstrous bill. When it arrived, I pulled out my credit card, and can still remember the look of sheer, HM Bateman, "the man who"-style incredulity that greeted my gesture. "My dear fellow, you are the guest of the socialist group!" said one of the MEPs, as you might explain the use of an escargot fork to an Amazon Indian.

 Alastair Campbell has been complaining this week about the press giving a negative image of politicians by their constant carping. It's a good point. I remember clearly how Alastair, anxious to support democracy, always wanted to put everything in the best possible light before the 1997 election. "Look," he'd say, "be fair. Crime may have doubled over the past 18 years, but it's showing a marked decrease this year, and we have to give the Tories credit for that." Or when we prepared another "Tories split on Europe" article, he'd be the first to say, "There really are two sides to this story, and it says a lot for the Conservatives that they're prepared to give everyone a shout." How different from the cold, cynical, aggressive reportage we see today.

webTitle: Man behind Livingstone complaint linked to Dobson mayoral campaign

fields.headline: Man behind Livingstone complaint linked to Dobson mayoral campaign
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The man behind the complaint that led to Ken Livingstone being censured over his financial disclosures to parliament was revealed yesterday as Robert Smeath, a former treasurer for the short-lived mayoral campaign of Frank Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips.
fields.byline: David Hencke, Seumas Milne  and Will Woodward
fields.body:
The man behind the complaint that led to Ken Livingstone being censured over his financial disclosures to parliament was revealed yesterday as Robert Smeath, a former treasurer for the short-lived mayoral campaign of Frank Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips.

Mr Smeath, a close associate of Jeremy Fraser, Mr Dobson's campaign manager, admitted that he had persuaded the postgraduate student John Jones, "albeit reluctantly", to sign and send the complaint to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, in December.

Mr Smeath's admission came less than 24 hours after Mr Jones had issued a statement through Loughborough University, claiming: "None of this is anything to do with me."

Mr Smeath, a lawyer, is a campaign organiser for the Labour party in Southwark, south London, and has been arranging canvassing for the mayoral elections to win support for Mr Dobson and Labour candidates for the Greater London authority.

Last night Mr Dobson's campaign officials were trying to limit the damage caused by the underhand way the complaint had been handled, insisting that neither Mr Dobson nor Mr Phillips had known about what Mr Smeath had done.

Mr Dobson's spokeswoman conceded that Mr Smeath's decision to ask someone else to sign his complaint was "maybe a silly thing to do" in the light of his links with Mr Fraser and the Labour party. But she added: "It was not dirty tricks, it was a legitimate complaint."

Mr Fraser, who employed Mr Smeath as his parliamentary agent for his failed attempt to capture North Southwark and Bermondsey for Labour from the Liberal Democrats in the 1997 general election, insisted yesterday that Mr Smeath had not told him about the ruse to damage Mr Livingstone.

But Piers Corbyn, Mr Fraser's campaign organiser in 1997 and a Livingstone supporter, said yesterday that Mr Fraser and Mr Smeath were "hand in glove".

He added: "The suggestion that Rogert Smeath would do this without speaking to Jeremy Fraser I find impossible to believe. Politicians should do their own dirty work, not use third or fourth parties." Mr Smeath said yesterday that he had arranged for the complaint because "I wanted to get the issue of MPs not declaring earnings discussed. I was so incensed."

fields.headline: Sidney Heaven
fields.trailText: During lectures to adult educationists, one warm-up technique used by Sidney Heaven, who has died aged 83, was to stand on his head in silence, then comment that "the first lesson of education is never to ask your group to do something you can't do yourself."
fields.body:
During lectures to adult educationists, one warm-up technique used by Sidney Heaven, who has died aged 83, was to stand on his head in silence, then comment that "the first lesson of education is never to ask your group to do something you can't do yourself."

Heaven had a major influence on the teaching of English as a foreign language, and was from 1963-82 inspector for further and higher education for the Inner London Education Authority. Later a specialist adviser to the Commons education committee, he was well known for his work on education in prisons.

Tackling literacy skills and the poor English of many immigrants were priorities at Ilea; there were no teaching qualifications in these specialisations, yet the demand for teachers was growing steadily, and there was increasing concern about illiteracy among school-leavers and adults. With the Royal Society of Arts (RSA), Heaven developed diplomas in the teaching of literacy skills and of English as a second language to adults.

He was also chairman of the RSA committee for English as a foreign language for 20 years, which gave him a worldwide influence on the standards of teaching English. He took pride in the wide range of Ilea evening courses and got enormous pleasure from inspecting classes in subjects such as pigeon fancying and "sea cookery".

Heaven went everywhere in London on his hand-built racing cycle, usually chaining it up in the principal's car park space of the college he was visiting. Equally distinctive was his habit of hanging wet swimming trunks in his County Hall office.

He was a charismatic teacher, who made full use of his striking appearance and athletic prowess. He had lost an eye playing water polo for King's College, London, where he also won the Jelf medal in 1938 as the most distinguished arts graduate of his year. He taught at three grammar schools until just after the end of the second world war, ending up as senior English master at St Olaves, near Tower Bridge.

In 1946, when he became an English lecturer at the College of St Mark and St John, Chelsea, he sported a maroon-coloured corduroy jacket, bow tie and monocle. His dog, Ahab, a boxer with something of the same cast of features, preceded him into college every day, and sat in on his tutorials.

Heaven became the first director of studies for London university's diploma in the teaching of English, and in this period also researched and edited a series of early plays, including The Puritaine (1607), at one time falsely attributed to Shakespeare, and Sir Richard Steele's comedy The Funeral (1701).

During his time at County Hall, he had been responsible for restructuring and revitalising the education departments in the five London prisons. He wrote a series of papers and ran conferences to include judges and politicians, as well as prison education staff and voluntary agencies. He had much to say about the worth of individual prison officers and governors, and no time for the union and institutional rigidities which, as he saw it, stood between prisoners and the educational opportunities.

He married the actress and model Myra Tilson in 1974. There were no children.

John Turtle

Sidney Charles Heaven, educationist, born August 24 1916; died February 27 2000

fields.headline: Ivan Hirst
fields.standfirst: Englishman who made Volkswagen part of the German economic miracle
fields.trailText: It is ironic that the death of Ivan Hirst, at the age of 84, should coincide with another episode in the BMW-Rover crisis. For it was the Yorkshire-born Hirst who, between 1945-49, saved the Volkswagen car business and, as much as anybody else, laid the foundations for the successful postwar German motor industry.
fields.body:
It is ironic that the death of Ivan Hirst, at the age of 84, should coincide with another episode in the BMW-Rover crisis. For it was the Yorkshire-born Hirst who, between 1945-49, saved the Volkswagen car business and, as much as anybody else, laid the foundations for the successful postwar German motor industry.

Hirst arrived in Germany when the British army took over control of the Volkswagen factory at Wolfsburg from the Americans in the summer of 1945. As a major in the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (Reme), his brief was to run a workshop for British army vehicles in the partly-ruined plant. The original intention was to dismantle the entire production line and ship out the machinery and tooling as reparations. Hirst's superior, Colonel Charles Radclyffe, who was in charge of car manufacture in the British zone, was responsible for carrying out this plan.

However, when the Volkswagen equipment was offered to Britain's motor manufacturers, including Rootes and Morris, they turned it down. An official British report famously found that "the vehicle does not meet the fundamental technical requirement of a motor-car ... it is quite unattractive to the average buyer ... To build the car commercially would be a completely uneconomic enterprise."

The British army thought differently and, after one of the few surviving wartime Volkswagen cars had been demonstrated to the British Rhine army group headquarters, the military ordered a batch of 20,000 similar vehicles. By the end of 1945, the factory had somehow managed to put together 2,490 cars. Many of them were then bartered for materials to make further cars, or for provisions to feed the 6,000 workers and other citizens of Wolfsburg, the company town built before the war as Volkswagen's headquarters.

Ivan Hirst was the man who got production going. He organised the clearance of bomb damage and had the buildings repaired; he re-commissioned machine tools, body presses and assembly jigs; he concerned himself with improving the quality of the car, with setting up a sales and service network and with starting exports - the first went to Holland in 1947.

He became a great enthusiast for the Volkswagen, which he was always ready to defend, even against the interference of the British authorities. His view was that the factory belonged to the German people, and it was his task to see that they got it.

In 1947, Colonel Radclyffe decided that a suitable German must be found to take over the company. Following a tip-off from an army colleague, Hirst found the former Opel production manager, Heinrich Nordhoff, running a small workshop in Hamburg, and was instrumental in getting him appointed as managing director in January 1949. Nordfhoff served with Volkswagen for 20 years until his death in 1968, building up the plant into one of the world's leading car manufacturers.

Hirst finally left Wolfsburg in August 1949 and, the following month, Radclyffe, on behalf of the Allied Control Commission for Germany, handed over the Volkswagen company to a trust run by the new West German federal government and the state of Lower Saxony. Hirst had carried out his task.

Born in Saddleworth, on the eastern side of the Pennines, he came from a manufacturing background - his family owned a clock factory. He was educated at the local grammar school and the faculty of technology at Manchester university. He was a keen member of the Territorial Army, training at the drill hall in Huddersfield, and by 1939 had reached the rank of captain.

Hirst was promoted to major while serving with the British Expeditionary Force in 1940, was evacuated at the fall of France and, in 1942, transferred to the Reme. After D-Day, he managed a tank repair workshop in Brussels, and was then sent to the control commission to take charge of the Volkswagen project.

After it was over, Hirst worked for the Allied Military Security Board in Germany and became a regional industry director. He later joined the industry staff of the German section of the foreign office, where he stayed until 1955 before joining the international secretariat of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in Paris. On retirement in 1975, he returned to England and settled in Marsden, in the Colne valley. There, he became a well-known local figure, stopping to inspect vehicles carrying the VW logo and frequently welcoming historians, writers and television documentary-makers to his home.

When Hirst left Wolfsburg, his friends at Volkswagen wanted to present him with one of their cars as a token of their friendship and respect. He refused to accept this. Instead, he was given an 18in scale model, which might have cost more than the real thing. The Volkswagen company and the people of Wolfsburg remembered him with fondness and gratitude. Yet he himself always disclaimed any special role in the salvation of the motor business, ascribing it instead to successful teamwork between the Germans and the British.

Only two years ago, Hirst drove through Marsden in the first of the new VW "Bugs", whose right-hand drive version was finally - and much to his approval - launched in Britain last year.

His wife predeceased him.

Anders Ditlev Clausager

Ivan Hirst, engineer, born March 1 1916; died March 10 2000

webTitle: Why queue for loo stymied the king of kitsch

fields.headline: Why queue for loo stymied the king of kitsch
fields.trailText: Zurab Tsereteli is Moscow's king of kitsch. The Georgian painter and sculptor has left his monstrous mark on the Moscow of the 1990s as indelibly, if not as tyranically, as his compatriot Stalin did in the 1950s.
fields.body:
Zurab Tsereteli is Moscow's king of kitsch. The Georgian painter and sculptor has left his monstrous mark on the Moscow of the 1990s as indelibly, if not as tyranically, as his compatriot Stalin did in the 1950s.

Stalin's seven famous skyscrapers - his answer to the Manhattan skyline - may still dominate the city, but Tsereteli has managed to give the late despot a run for his money through his sentimental confections which any visitor to Moscow simply cannot miss.

There's the no-expense-spared shopping mall at Manezh Square by the Kremlin which purports to offer a simulated tour of Russia through the centuries. The luxurious centre is all set in marble, chrome, brass and glass. Outside, the painter-architect-sculptor has arranged a series of fountains decorated with bronzes of animals drawn from Russian fairy tales.

On the Moscow river, not far from the shopping mall, Tsereteli's Peter the Great walks on water and soars almost 100 metres into the air. The artwork manages to ruin views of the Kremlin, but it makes a mighty statement about how the city mayor, Yuri Luzhkov - for whom Tsereteli is a favoured court jester - sees Moscow.

Mr Luzhkov's political clout and his patronage mean that the Georgian artist can do no wrong. Hundreds of millions of pounds have been spent on his public projects over the past decade.

There's the Moscow zoo which includes Tsereteli's anthropomorphic statues alongside live animals. There's the bronze pillar celebrating "200 years of friendship between the Russian and Georgian peoples". There's the 80 metre-high victory monument dedicated to the second world war featuring Greek goddesses and Christian angels on the end of a giant dagger.

The style is eclectic, post-modern _ and profoundly reactionary, harking back to a cartoon version of heroic Russian history - all tsars, princesses, peasants and cuddly animals. There are no communists in Tsereteli's theme park.

Not content with having already supplied the foremost images of post-communist Moscow, Tsereteli has acquired a city centre palace and is about to open a museum of modern art. His ambition knows no bounds.

Confronted by all this megalomania, the long-suffering Muscovite public reaches for the only potent weapon available - humour.

"Laughter," the Soviet vaudeville artist Alexander Raykin quipped during the Great Terror, "is a very serious business."

That was certainly the case when Stalin was rearranging the city to accommodate his deranged skyscrapers. But these days Muscovites revel in poking fun at the high and mighty and Tsereteli's grandiose follies are a perfect target for the local wits.

Tsereteli's ensemble of bunnies, bears, and squirrels frolicking in flood-lit fountains outside the Kremlin is dubbed "the jacuzzi". The soaring victory monument which features the Greek Goddess Nike airborne at the end of a long dagger has become the "spider on a pin". The pillar of friendship between Russia and Georgia has become generally known as "the kebab".

In a park on the south side of the river by the Tretyakov art gallery, the fallen heroes of a bygone age have been laid to rest. The statues of communist and Soviet luminaries that used to dot every public space have been taken down and piled into what is officially the Park of Art, but which is better known as the politicians' graveyard.

Perhaps Tsereteli's frogs, princes and peasants will ultimately join the Lenins, Stalins, and other discredited heroes reposing there.

In the meantime if they can't stop Tsereteli, Muscovites can at least mock him. And sometimes poking fun yields dividends.

The Georgian had planned to erect a monumental commemoration of the Holocaust. The sculpture featured a long line of victims in various stages of collapse and distress entitled The Tragedy of the Peoples. Public opinion was aghast. But that has never stopped Mr Luzhkov or Tsereteli.

Then someone dubbed the proposed sculpture '"the queue for the loo". The plans were quietly shelved.

webTitle: Leading writer to challenge Indonesian ban

fields.headline: Leading writer to challenge Indonesian ban
fields.standfirst:
Major works will be reprinted in native tongue

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesia's greatest living author is preparing to challenge a decades-old ban on his works appearing in his native tongue, a move seen as the latest test of President Abdurrahman Wahid's vow to break with the country's authoritarian past.
fields.body:
Indonesia's greatest living author is preparing to challenge a decades-old ban on his works appearing in his native tongue, a move seen as the latest test of President Abdurrahman Wahid's vow to break with the country's authoritarian past.

Pramoedya Ananta Toer, 75, who was imprisoned by three successive regimes for his politically-charged writing, has just secured funding from American arts foundations to reprint his 40-odd major works in Indonesian.

"English translations are now available in Jakarta but the Indonesian versions are still officially banned," explained Joesoef Isak, Mr Pramoedya's editor and publisher. "Ever since [General] Suharto fell in 1998 we have wanted to test the ban, and we are now able to do so."

Government sources say there is no sign of the ban being lifted, but add that there is little likelihood of Mr Pramoedya, being prosecuted. "The ban is now just an out-of-date technicality," said an official in President Wahid's office.

Mr Pramoedya, known as Pram to his friends and often compared to Alexander Solzhenitsyn and the Argentinian writer Jacobo Timerman, says the ban has prevented most of Indonesia's 210m people from reading his novels, memoirs, short stories and essays.

"While they remain banned, I regard it as a prized reward on my chest," he said in a living room whose walls were bedecked with literary prizes from around the world. "It's resistance, it's my resistance against injustice."

Among the first works likely to be reprinted are The Buru Quartet, four historical novels Mr Pramoedya wrote mostly in his head while incarcerated on the island of Buru, in eastern Indonesia, for 14 years from 1965. They are regarded as among his finest writings.

Shortly after Suharto seized power, Mr Pramoedya was accused of being a communist and, without being tried, was transported to the remote penal colony of Buru. "I never adhered to any 'ism', except Pramism," Mr Pramoedya said.

Official statistics say that more than 1.3m people were detained in the wake of Suharto seizing power. Thousands of political prisoners were condemned to a life of misery in the Buru Island Humanitarian Project, a classic case of real-life Orwellian double speak.

Amid lowland swamps and jungle-covered mountains, the political prisoners were forced to cultivate crops and open migration sites for settlers.

In The Mute's Soliloquy, a loose collection of letters, essays and reminiscences, Mr Pramoedya graphically described the detainees' ordeal.

One typical act of brutality occurred after two prisoners turned up late for a roll call.

"The soldiers turned the two men into punching bags," he wrote. "Even after the two had fallen to the ground, the beating didn't stop. The soldiers whacked them with bamboo poles until the poles were broken and the men motionless. They were unconscious, and were to remain so for several more days.

"Neither could move of his own accord for several months thereafter."

Mr Pramoedya endured such punishment for 14 years. During that time he was intermittently granted permission to write, but, as he described in The Mute's Soliloquy, he took nothing for granted.

"The basic fact is that for the person without civil rights, death is always present in the background, forever during each second of the day, before his eyes. Look on death if you will, but only silently. There's no need to beckon; the darkness that is death will soon come to you uninvited."

After being released in December 1979, Mr Pramoedya remained under various forms of house arrest until 1992. He was only allowed to travel overseas after Suharto fell.

The one major recognition Mr Pramoedya has yet to receive is the Nobel prize for literature. "He has been nominated on numerous occasions", Mr Isak said, "but every year from August to October, the Indonesian ambassadors in Europe lobbied hard to ensure Pram did not win. Articles also appeared in the Indonesian press discrediting him."

webTitle: Greens turn on each other as fortunes flag

fields.headline: Greens turn on each other as fortunes flag
fields.trailText: Nuclear power, arms exports and party reform will dominate a key conference of Germany's beleaguered Greens today when the party will try to stop the popularity slide that threatens to wreck its long term chances of survival.
fields.body:
Nuclear power, arms exports and party reform will dominate a key conference of Germany's beleaguered Greens today when the party will try to stop the popularity slide that threatens to wreck its long term chances of survival.

At their meeting in Karlsruhe, members are expected to decide on measures that will oblige the government to set a 30-year deadline for an end to nuclear power in Germany, a move certain to prompt a showdown with the country's powerful atomic energy industry.

The conference is taking place in the shadow of an arms export question which threatens to provoke a serious conflict between the Greens and their Social Democrat coalition partners.

There have been leaks in the media about a request from the Turkish government to buy more than 1,000 Leopard tanks from Germany, and about discussions in Berlin over the possible sale of 40 Fuchs armoured cars to the United Arab Emirates.

"Moral values and the standards of democracy and human rights are being cast to the wind," Winfried Hermann, a Green MP, warned yesterday. "The Greens will do everything to stop this."

The party's "realist" wing will try to ditch some of the ideological baggage inherited from the Greens' early years as an "alternative" political movement, including a ban on Green party leaders becoming members of parliament or holding other senior political positions.

But the reform of this rule is hotly opposed by the grassroots "fundamentalist" wing of the party which fears that it could expose the Greens to charges that is open to corruption, following the scandal involving Christian Democrats and their former leader, ex-chancellor Helmut Kohl.

The party's preoccupation with internal Green politics, at the expense of national issues, is seen as one of the main reasons for the popularity crisis.

"The issues that will win us back voters are on the street, they are unemployment, the environment and globalisation," said Germany's Green environment minister, Jürgen Trittin. "But the Greens only seem to be interested in themselves," he added.

The party's bungled attempts to bring about a swift end to nuclear power, its failure to take the lead over immigration and new technology and its reputation as the instigator of a punitive ecological fuel tax are the main causes of the party's unpopularity.

On most issues the Greens have been trumped by their Social Democrat bedfellows. Losses in 10 consecutive regional and local elections cloud the party's political record of the past year.

According to an opinion poll published this week, 67% of the electorate regard the Greens as a "superfluous organisation."

Particularly galling is the decline in young voters who once made up the party's bedrock of support. "The Greens are the people who get up at five in the morning to grind up their breakfast muesli," was one of the responses given to the party's chief spokesman, Antje Radke, by a German high school student this week.

With as many as 40% of young Green voters estimated to have defected to other parties, the Green foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said to be the country's most popular politician, has admitted that the Greens may not survive as a political force in the long term.

"In the end we may come to be regarded as a one-generation project," he said.

webTitle: Man who dropped first atomic bomb dies

fields.headline: Man who dropped first atomic bomb dies
fields.standfirst: Hiroshima bombardier regretted great loss of life, but felt no guilt
fields.trailText: The man who dreamed of becoming a baseball player but instead changed history by dropping the atomic bomb on Hiroshima without realising what he was doing, has died at the age of 81.
fields.body:
The man who dreamed of becoming a baseball player but instead changed history by dropping the atomic bomb on Hiroshima without realising what he was doing, has died at the age of 81.

Thomas Ferebee, the bombardier in the crew of the Enola Gay, was asleep for most of the 13-hour flight to Japan and did not hear the pilot's briefing on the nature of their mission on August 6 1945.

Mr Ferebee, then a 26-year-old veteran of 64 second world war raids, was not aware that the world would never be the same again until 43 seconds after the bomb was released.

"At first I saw this boiling on the ground and the stem of the mushroom cloud was going up and you could see buildings going up in the stem," he said years later.

The bomb killed 70,000 people immediately and tens of thousands later through burns and radiation poisoning. Mr Ferebee, one of only two people to drop a nuclear bomb during wartime, and the B-29's pilot Paul Tibbets, were blinded temporarily because they had not worn their dark glasses.

Three days later a second bomb was dropped on Nagasaki, and Japan surrendered five days after, on August 14. Mr Ferebee, who was a major at the time, said he felt no guilt, but regretted the loss of life.

"I'm sorry an awful lot of people died from that bomb, and I hate to think that something like that had to happen to end the war," he said on the 50th anniversary of the bombing. "People have to go back and study the history of the war and the attitude of people at that time. Everybody wanted the war to end. That's what I wanted; I wanted the bomb to work and end the war."

Mr Ferebee, a career air force officer who retired as a colonel 30 years ago, played a part in a number of landmark bombing sorties during the war, in north Africa, Europe and finally the Pacific.

He was there for the first United States assault on Nazi-occupied France in 1942 and was lead bombardier on the Allies' first 100-aircraft daylight raid in Europe.

Brigadier General Tibbets, who is one of four surviving members of the Enola Gay's crew, had hand-picked Major Ferebee for the Hiroshima job. "He was the best bombardier who ever looked through the eyepiece of a Norden bomb sight," Mr Tibbets said.

Mr Ferebee spent his youth in Mocksville, North Carolina, harbouring an aspiration to become a professional sportsman but joined the army in 1940 instead. After the war he served as a deputy commander for maintenance of B-47 Stratojet bombers, flew on missions during the cold war, and acted as an observer during the Vietnam war. He was awarded the Silver Star, the Legion of Merit, two Distinguished Flying Crosses and the Bronze Star.

The other surviving members of the crew of the Enola Gay are the navigator, Ted Van Kirk, the weapons officer, Morris Jeppson, and the radio operator, Richard Nelson.

The man who dropped the bomb on Nagasaki, Kermit Beahan, died in 1989.

webTitle: Arsenal at house of gun youth

fields.headline: Arsenal at house of gun youth
fields.trailText: Police in Germany yesterday found a huge cache of weapons at the home of a schoolboy who shot his teacher before turning the gun on himself in the stairwell of a Bavarian boarding school.
fields.body:
Police in Germany yesterday found a huge cache of weapons at the home of a schoolboy who shot his teacher before turning the gun on himself in the stairwell of a Bavarian boarding school.

The 16-year-old boy and the 57-year-old teacher suffered serious head wounds and were still in a critical condition in hospital after the shooting on Thursday in Brannenburg, in rural Bavaria.

Police said they found an "arsenal of weapons" when they searched the cellar of the boy's home, including 43 rifles, two machine guns, an assault rifle, 6,500 rounds of ammunition and an assortment of knives and axes.

The boy's father, 43, was detained on charges of illegal possession of firearms and police said they were investigating possible charges of complicity in the shooting.

The local public prosecutor said the boy, who had a history of disruptive behaviour, had faced expulsion after a test by the school confirmed suspicions that he was using cannabis.

"It appears the prospect of expulsion from the school sent him into a rage," she said.

Germany has suffered a wave of school violence after the US massacre at Columbine High School near Denver, Colorado, last year, in which two youths killed 12 schoolmates and a teacher before committing suicide.

webTitle: Mbeki raises doubts on HIV link to Aids

fields.headline: Mbeki raises doubts on HIV link to Aids
fields.trailText: Leading scientists have condemned a plan by Thabo Mbeki to convene an international panel to examine claims that Aids is not caused by the HIV virus, and to scrutinise whether the drug AZT does more harm than good.
fields.body:
Leading scientists have condemned a plan by Thabo Mbeki to convene an international panel to examine claims that Aids is not caused by the HIV virus, and to scrutinise whether the drug AZT does more harm than good.

The South African president ordered his health ministry to assemble the experts after consulting American scientists who assert that Aids is the result of social factors such as poverty and drug abuse, rather than a virus.

Other specialists have loudly condemned the plan as giving credence to "voodoo medicine" which detracts from caring for the 6m South Africans - one in eight of the population - who are HIV-positive.

Mr Mbeki's spokesman, Parks Mankahlana, said: "The president has doubts about the whole issue of Aids; the fact that there's no cure, that some people have contracted HIV but not Aids after more than 15 or 20 years. There are lots of things that are unknown and unclear that need to be investigated."

The president's action comes just as other African leaders are finally focusing attention on how to combat the disease. Zambia this week admitted that more than a quarter of its urban population was HIV-positive, and that the average life expectancy had fallen from 60 years to 37.

Sub-saharan Africa is home to two thirds of the world's 36m people with HIV. Within five years there are expected to be 5m Aids orphans on the continent.

Activists say that Mr Mbeki is sowing confusion which undermines the government's Aids education programme. Earlier this year he contacted a San Francisco-based Aids dissident, David Rasnick, for advice on how to investigate whether there was a link between HIV and Aids.

Mr Rasnick is a controversial biochemist at the University of California who argues that the virus is harmless, and that the disease is caused by other factors, particularly recreational drugs in the west and malnutrition in Africa.

As a result of Mr Rasnick's advice, Mr Mbeki ordered the health ministry to convene the panel of experts to "look at local evidence regarding the causes and diagnosis of Aids". But South Africa's most prominent scientists say they have not been contacted.

Professor Malegapuru Makgoba, head of the medical research council, has warned that South Africa is becoming "fertile ground for pseudo-science". Other doctors say that the panel will set back efforts to combat Aids.

"Those working in the field are dumbfounded, angry and depressed by these potentially retrograde steps," said the chairman of the national Aids convention, Dr Ashraf Grimwood.

In December, Mr Mbeki justified his government's refusal to prescribe AZT for poor HIV-positive pregnant women. The medicines control council said the drug could sharply cut the 50,000 babies born each year with the HIV virus. Mr Mbeki replied that AZT was toxic and that the risks outweighed the benefits.

The government has long said it cannot afford anti-Aids drugs. Some activists say that the real motive behind the panel is as "a justification for the immoral, unscientific and unlawful decision to withhold AZT from pregnant women."

fields.headline: Lady in waiting
fields.standfirst: TV sexologist poised to shake up Sao Paulo as favourite for mayor
fields.trailText: Marta Suplicy made her name discussing sexual dysfunctions on daytime television, wears designer trainers and two of her sons are well-known pop stars.
fields.body:
Marta Suplicy made her name discussing sexual dysfunctions on daytime television, wears designer trainers and two of her sons are well-known pop stars.

Now she stands on the verge of becoming one of the most influential leftwing political figures in South America as run-away leader in the polls for mayor of Sao Paulo, the continent's largest city and Brazil's economic powerhouse.

Ms Suplicy, a member of the Workers' party (PT), stands out in this conservative, Catholic country with a history of campaigning on controversial issues such as gay marriage and legalising abortion.

She has succeeded in keeping traditional working class support as well as reaching out to new voters.

Blonde, combative and articulate from her days as a TV sexologist, Ms Suplicy is a challenge to the old political order.

"She represents a new phase for the Workers' party," said David Fleischer, professor of politics at Brasilia university. "The PT is moving from being hardline and radical to a very, very light socialism, bordering on social democracy. This is definitely the future of the party."

If Ms Suplicy, 55, wins the mayoral elections in October she will be in charge of the third largest budget in Brazil. This will propel her nationally into the political elite and and has the potential to make her the most likely leftwing candidate for president in 2006.

In the latest polls, Ms Suplicy leads the rightwing opposition - which is facing corruption scandals - by 17 percentage points.

Ms Suplicy - who is married to a PT senator - believes that her gender has a lot to do with her success.

"I am a woman and people are very disillusioned with men. I am known for being frank and honest. Our research is saying that the men have had their turn, let's see what the women can do."

But she admits she is taken aback by her success. "I thought that I would only be a [mayoral] candidate in 10 years time, because I thought people would have to get used to the issues that I was campaigning for.

"But these issues gave me a great visibility. They gave me an image of someone who would fight for rights."

fields.headline: Man held in cockpit struggle
fields.trailText: A man broke into the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines jet and grappled with the co-pilot in an attempt to get to the throttle and fuel controls, San Francisco police said.
fields.body:
A man broke into the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines jet and grappled with the co-pilot in an attempt to get to the throttle and fuel controls, San Francisco police said.

The man was subdued by crew members and passengers until the plane landed on Thursday night, an airline spokesman, Jack Evans, said.

"Fortunately all the guys moved quick and we're not dead," said a passenger.

A suspect, Peter Bradley, 40, of Blue Springs, Missouri, was arrested, said a policeman, Joe Reilly. The FBI and the federal aviation administration were investigating.

"What really scared me was when he tried to open up an exit," said Chris Honochick, 37, of Salem, Oregon, who helped to tackle the man.

Flight 259, from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, was carrying 43 passengers and five crew.

Earlier in the flight, Mr Bradley, over 6ft tall and almost 18st, had taken off his shirt and socks and repeatedly disobeyed the cabin crew by switching seats. He ended up in first class, where he allegedly told passengers he was "going to kill all of you", Mr Reilly said.

The man then broke into the cockpit. "He was going for the throttle and fuel controls," Mr Reilly said.

It was an Alaska Airlines flight from Puerto Vallarta to San Francisco which crashed in January, killing all 88 aboard.
