webTitle: Ex-Panther on the run after shooting

fields.headline: Ex-Panther on the run after shooting
fields.standfirst: Black-power activist settled down as a Muslim grocer. Then the police paid a call
fields.trailText: Black Panther, writer, community activist, jailbird, religious leader and greengrocer: to all these sobriquets, that of fugitive was added yesterday to the name of 60s radical H Rap Brown - now known as 21st-century enigma Imam Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin.
fields.body:
Black Panther, writer, community activist, jailbird, religious leader and greengrocer: to all these sobriquets, that of fugitive was added yesterday to the name of 60s radical H Rap Brown - now known as 21st-century enigma Imam Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin.

Mr Al-Amin, on the run after two policemen were shot on Thursday in Atlanta, Georgia, is also a considerable wordsmith, responsible for the phrase: "Violence is as American as cherry pie." Two sheriff's deputies were wounded - one critically, the other seriously - during an exchange of gunfire outside Mr Al-Amin's grocery store after they came to serve a warrant alleging assault, theft, impersonating an officer, receiving stolen property and lacking proof of insurance.

Police said they were uncertain who had fired the shots, apparently from an M-16 assault rifle, but issued a description matching that of Mr Al-Amin, 56. One of the deputies was said to have identified him as the gunman.

"We don't know if he's the shooter or not. We had him cornered in an empty house but he got away," said a spokesman for the sheriff's office, Captain David Chadd. "There's blood on the front porch of the house. He's been hit but we don't know how bad his injuries are."

Mr Al-Amin moved to Atlanta, the capital of the South, 24 years ago after converting to Islam while serving five years in prison for his part in a shootout in a bar in Harlem, New York. Until yesterday that seemed to be the culmination of a transformation that took him from revolutionary to revered, though unrepentant, holy man.

He was one of the leaders of SNCC - the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, famed in its day - and later "minister of justice" for the Black Panthers. Despite the SNCC's name, Mr Al-Amin was charged in 1967 with inciting a riot in Cambridge, Maryland.

Addressing a crowd of about 400 black people from the bonnet of a car, he said: "It's time for Cambridge to explode, baby. Black folks built America and if America don't come around we're going to burn America down." While that did not quite happen, shots were exchanged later between blacks and whites: a pellet hit Mr Al-Amin's forehead; a white policeman was shot in the neck, face and hand.

Next day a fire burned a school and two blocks of the city. Governor Spiro Agnew sent in 600 National Guardsmen with fixed bayonets, and ammunition clips attached to their combat jackets.

"I went there. I spoke there. I got shot. I left," said Mr Al-Amin, claiming he was ambushed by two black policemen. He went into hiding and was placed on the FBI's most wanted list until he was arrested near the scene of the Harlem shoot-out. The Maryland charges were reduced to misdemeanours and he did not face trial there.

"I preach a response to violence," Mr Al-Amin wrote in his 1969 autobiography Die Nigger Die! - published when he was 26. "Meet violence with violence. It's your responsibility to jump back." His book polarised opinion along predictable lines: Newsweek accused him of hate-mongering; Black World described him as a young man of deep sensibilities.

By this time he had studied sociology in his home town of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, but was displeased with the college's record on race. He worked in a government anti-poverty programme in Washington but concluded that it did nothing about the causes of poverty.

The Atlanta years were more placid though not exactly incident-free. Mr Al-Amin, a Sunni Muslim, made the pilgrimage to Mecca three times and became chairman of Atlanta's Council of Imams. His National Community claims to have up to 40 affiliated mosques and 30,000 followers across the US. He found time for another publication, Revolution by the Book, in 1993 and was credited with being a stabilising influence in his Atlanta neighbourhood, working to remove drug-dealing and prostitution.

Five years ago he was accused of assault, carrying a concealed weapon and having an unlicensed pistol, but then the man Mr Al-Amin was supposed to have shot said the police had put him up to making the claims. Mr Al-Amin said he had been targeted because of his beliefs and his past.

"They wanted me to come out of prison broken," he said. "Oh yeah, they wanted me to be broken. Prison is supposed to break you. My feeling concerning myself is that the federal government has never been comfortable with the fact that I just did five years and after coming out I really never did apologise.

"They've made fundamentalism synonymous with with terrorism, the same thing they did with 'black.' They made it synonymous with militancy and radicalism in the 60s. The message is the same."

So, too, is the message of Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin: "There's no change. It's still America."

webTitle: US lifts sanctions on Iran's caviar and rugs

fields.headline: US lifts sanctions on Iran's caviar and rugs
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: The United States yesterday lifted some key sanctions against Iran in a gesture aimed at encouraging the country's new reformist government. The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said the moment had come to end the "cold winter of our discontent".
fields.body:
The United States yesterday lifted some key sanctions against Iran in a gesture aimed at encouraging the country's new reformist government. The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said the moment had come to end the "cold winter of our discontent".

The partial lifting of sanctions means that luxury and food items from Iran, including carpets, caviar, fruit, grain and pistachio nuts, can be imported into the US. But the two main Iranian exports - oil and gas - remain banned.

Ms Albright said efforts would also be made to increase contacts between scholars, artists, professionals and athletes in the two countries and that the US was prepared to put a dispute between the two countries on assets before an adjudicator. Iran claims that $12bn (£7.3bn) worth of Iranian assets have been illegally frozen in US banks.

Sanctions against Iran have been in force since 1980, following the 1979 takeover and hostage-taking at the US embassy in Tehran, and Iran remains on the US list of countries classified as a terrorist threat.

Iran's foreign ministry welcomed yesterday's announcement, made at a meeting of the American-Iranian Council. "Iran thinks it is positive and welcomes it," Hamid Reza Asefi, the Iranian foreign ministry spokesman was quoted on Iranian television as saying. "And within the framework of Iranian laws, the United States can export grain and medicine to Iran."

"Now is the time to plant the seeds of a new relationship," said Ms Albright. She said that the time had come to try to move on. She said the new government elected last month in Iran was moving in a direction which favoured "reform, freedom and openness".

"We cannot build a true relationship on carpets and grain alone," Ms Albright said. "Surely the time has come for America and Iran to enter a new season in which mutual trust may grow and the quality of warmth supplant the long cold winter of our discontent."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Oxfam warns of Ethiopian crisis
fields.body:
Oxfam warns of Ethiopian crisis

The lives of more than 2m people in south-eastern Ethiopia may be at risk because of lack of water, healthcare and food, Oxfam warned yesterday.

The charity has mounted an emergency response to the crisis in the Somali and Borena regions, where no rain has fallen for three years. An assessment found that children and old people are already dying and more than 7m people nationwide could be at risk if rains fail. - Foreign staff

Le Pen tries to defy court ban

Security guards stopped French far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen yesterday as he tried to take up a council seat despite a conviction which makes him ineligible for public office.

Mr Le Pen was told last month he had lost his seat on the council of the southern Provence-Alpes-Cte d'Azur region after he had been given a suspended sentence and one-year ineligibility for public office for assaulting a woman running for election against his daughter. - Reuters, Paris

Radioactivity in Stasi's arsenal

Secret police in the Former East Germany used radioactive material to track their opponents' activities, the office in charge of Stasi files said yesterday.

The Stasi contaminated pins, which were slipped into opponents' clothing, as well as papers and money. But the office said there was no indication that radioactivity was used against political prisoners. - AP, Berlin

Ignore Mugabe, police told

A judge yesterday ordered squatters to end their occupation of more than 500 white-owned farms and told police to ignore any counter-orders by President Robert Mugabe.

The judge said it was the police's duty to remove the squatters. President Mugabe last week said that they could remain in place until the government allocated them plots. - AP, Harare

Fisherman finds son's body

A fisherman yesterday found the body of his son when he hauled up his nets off the coast of a Greek island, the merchant marine ministry said.

Rescuers had been unable to find Panagiotis Vettas, 22, who fell overboard on January 26 during a fishing trip with his father off Kimolos. - AP, Athens

webTitle: Red Army members expelled by Lebanon

fields.headline: Red Army members expelled by Lebanon
fields.trailText: The Lebanese yesterday deported four Japanese Red Army members to Jordan which, according to diplomats in Amman, sent them on their way to Japan where they face terrorism charges.
fields.body:
The Lebanese yesterday deported four Japanese Red Army members to Jordan which, according to diplomats in Amman, sent them on their way to Japan where they face terrorism charges.

A fifth member of the group, Kozo Okamoto, who is accused of participating in the 1972 killing of 24 people at the main airport in Tel Aviv, was granted asylum in Lebanon.

An official statement said he was being allowed to stay for health reasons, but it appeared more likely he was being allowed to stay because he has hero's status among some in the Arab world for his role in the airport massacre.

The others - three men and a woman - were put on a flight to Amman where they were handed over to Japanese diplomats at the airport and flown home.

Last week, all five finished three-year prison terms for illegally entering Lebanon, but they had remained in custody until the Beirut government figured out what to do with them.

Kozo Okamoto, 51, had been freed by Israel in a 1985 prisoner swap with Palestinian rebels.

The Red Army was a shadowy ultra-leftist group that operating in the 1970s. The Japanese government wants all five to stand trial charged with staging attacks around the world.

Lebanon had for some time refused Japan's extradition demands, blaming the lack of an extradition treaty between the countries and claiming Tokyo lacked evidence against the five. Most of those killed in the airport slaughter were Christian pilgrims.

Yesterday's deportees were Masao Adachi, 59, Kazuo Tohira, 46, Haruo Wako, 50, and Mariko Yamamoto, 58.

fields.trailText: In our note about the appointment of the first blind judge to preside over jury trials, page 6, March 16, we also mentioned that "the first blind magistrate was appointed in 1998", overlooking John Fielding (1721-1780). Fielding, the half brother of the novelist, Henry Fielding, lost his sight in an accident at the age of 19. After his appointment as a magistrate, he became known as the "Blind Beak" and was reputed to be able to recognise 3,000 thieves by their voices. - britannica.com

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: South Yorkshire
fields.body:
South Yorkshire

It is hard to avoid cliches about spring. Step outside and there is birdsong, buds bursting and flowers blooming all over the place. Yet while most of the natural world is girding its loins for a period of intense activity, one group is preparing to lay down tools and take a rest. I refer to those selfless individuals who give freely of their time to do voluntary maintenance and management work on thousands of nature reserves and similar sites.

A few days ago I was on the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust's Potteric Carr nature reserve, just outside Doncaster. Without volunteers the cost of keeping this 350-acre site in good order would be prohibitive. Twice weekly work parties ensure that the grass- lands remain wildlife rich, the wetland doesn't turn into woodland and the woodlands don't choke themselves. One group was busy clearing willow and hawthorn scrub from an embankment. The results of their earlier work is evident, as primroses and violets push through into the sunlight.

This was the last major workday before the nesting, flowering and the general reproductive season gets under way. Even as Gary Scarfe cut through a dead silver birch that was threatening to fall across a footpath, the first chiff-chaff called from neighbouring trees. For me, chiff-chaffs are the real harbingers of spring. Unlike our resident birds, which can be persuaded to launch into territorial songs by a mild weather spell, chiff-chaffs make a conscious decision to fly here from their wintering grounds in order to breed in the UK. This one was probably just passing through, moving north, to be followed by willow warblers, black caps and white throats. Then the woods really will fill up with bird song.

Gary put the chain saw blade back in its protective sheath, removed helmet, ear-protectors and gloves. In every open glade huge queen bumblebees searched tirelessly for suitable nest sites, checking every potential hole or grass tussock. Nature can get on with its own business while Gary enjoys the wildlife he spends so much of his spare time working for.

fields.headline: Bank deals claim two scalps
fields.trailText: Two of the City's best known bankers quit yesterday - the casualties of the recent round of consolidation in the banking sector.
fields.body:
Two of the City's best known bankers quit yesterday - the casualties of the recent round of consolidation in the banking sector.

Richard Delbridge, the highly respected finance director at NatWest, and Michael Dobson, a main board director of Deutsche Bank and head of its asset management business, will be leaving their jobs in the coming weeks.

The departure of Mr Delbridge, who joined NatWest as finance director five years ago, was the first big announcement by the Royal Bank of Scotland since it won control of NatWest last month. His departure came as a surprise to some City bank watchers.

Royal Bank had been expected to attempt to keep Mr Delbridge to ease the amalgamation of the two banks.

He is to be replaced by current RBS Finance and Risk Director, 49-year-old Grahame Whitehead.

At Deutsche Bank there was no official explanation for the departure of Michael Dobson, but it is understood he had opposed the bank's decision last week to merge with rival Dresdner Bank.

Mr Dobson, who was educated at Eton, was previously chief executive of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, as the bank's investment banking unit was known, having been with Morgan Grenfell since before Deutsche bought the British merchant bank in 1989.

He will be replaced by Sir Robert Smith, currently vice-chairman of the asset management business, who will not be on the main bank board.

fields.headline: Beeson brokers share millions
fields.trailText: Staff at small company stock- broker Beeson Gregory are to share in the riches they have helped dozens of hi-tech and biotech entrepreneurs earn over the past decade.
fields.body:
Staff at small company stock- broker Beeson Gregory are to share in the riches they have helped dozens of hi-tech and biotech entrepreneurs earn over the past decade.

As many as 20 staff will become paper millionaires after the firm announced plans to place 18m shares at between 250p and 300p, valuing the group at up to £180m. Last night Financial Spreads predicted the shares could end their first day at 470-480p, which would give Beeson a value of up to £285m.

Beeson acts as the broker to clients including Bloomsbury Publishing, Oxford BioMedica, MediaKey and Memory Corporation.

webTitle: Soothing noises as O'Reilly wins in Belfast

fields.headline: Soothing noises as O'Reilly wins in Belfast
fields.trailText: Tony O'Reilly's Independent News and Media Group yesterday attempted to soothe Unionist fears of changes in editorial policy at the Belfast Telegraph after it won the battle for control of the 130-year-old evening newspaper.
fields.body:
Tony O'Reilly's Independent News and Media Group yesterday attempted to soothe Unionist fears of changes in editorial policy at the Belfast Telegraph after it won the battle for control of the 130-year-old evening newspaper.

Mr O'Reilly's group, which includes the Independent newspaper in London and the Irish Independent, agreed to pay Trinity Mirror £300m for the Telegraph - topping the expected price of around £270m.

The auction attracted initial interest from around 12 potential buyers - but only the venture capital group 3i, advised by former Mirror Group chief David Montgomery, and Gannett, publisher of USA Today, were still in at the final bidding.

Sources say that the Competition Commission inquiry into the deal will last at least four months.

The Telegraph, which this month underwent a redesign, makes about £20 million a year, including some lucrative printing contracts for outside customers. Edmund Curran, its editor, is understood to have failed in a management buy-out bid.

Philip Graf, Trinity Mirror chief executive, said he was confident the deal would not be derailed by political concerns. "Obviously it would be surprising if there weren't concerns. The important thing was that the paper should go into someone's hands that would respect the paper's integrity, develop it over the long term and invest in it. This was the best offer financially and for the future of the paper. This is a competition issue as far as we are concerned."

Brendan Hopkins, chief executive of Independent News and Media, said there would be no editorial or management changes and promised no job losses. The company would instead be seeking to expand operations in Belfast.

Mr Curran also moved to assuage Unionist fears and said he envisaged no change in editorial policy: "The Telegraph is one of the great cross-community institutions of Ulster.

" We are proud that it is accepted in unionist and nationalist homes alike and read by many more people across the province than any other newspaper. That strength is recognised by Independent News and Media and I look forward to a future with that distinctive editorial integrity and objectivity intact."

webTitle: Alcohol detector lifts spirits at Axis-Shield

fields.headline: Alcohol detector lifts spirits at Axis-Shield
fields.standfirst: Axis-Shield
fields.trailText: Diagnostics company Axis-Shield sounded an upbeat note about a test to determine alcoholism, after disclosing a 40% increase in its pre-tax losses to £9.87m.
fields.body:
Diagnostics company Axis-Shield sounded an upbeat note about a test to determine alcoholism, after disclosing a 40% increase in its pre-tax losses to £9.87m.

The test determines whether people are heavy drinkers by checking their blood for a substance called carbohydrate deficient transferrin.

Dundee-based Axis-Shield says the product's advantage is that it is difficult to fool - because alcoholics have a high level of CDT even if they have not had a drink for several weeks.

The test is already available in Europe and Axis- Shield expects to launch it in the US this year. Doctors are to be the main customers although the chief executive, Svein Lien, also expects interest from employers suspicious about drinking among their staff.

"It will be ideal for people like airline pilots," he said.

Axis-Shield's losses were increased by costs resulting from last year's merger which brought together Scottish firm Shield Diagnostics and Norway's Axis.

Sales of the group's biggest-earning tests - which predict heart disease - jumped 90% to £3m.

Axis-Shield's shares rose 10p to £10.07.

webTitle: Americans run Bhs stores in secret deal

fields.headline: Americans run Bhs stores in secret deal
fields.trailText: Ailing retailer Storehouse, which operates the Bhs and Mothercare store chains, has sold the stock in nine of its Bhs outlets to a US discount retailer and handed the day-to-day management of the stores to the American Gordons group.
fields.body:
Ailing retailer Storehouse, which operates the Bhs and Mothercare store chains, has sold the stock in nine of its Bhs outlets to a US discount retailer and handed the day-to-day management of the stores to the American Gordons group.

The complex and unusual deal, which it is understood was struck last November but not disclosed, covers six stores and three Bhs For Less factory outlets in locations from London to Lancashire.

A company official said the deal had been done after Bhs announced it was to put food halls into its stores - which will be operated by Iceland - and reduce its clothing ranges. It also announced it would close 60 Bhs outlets.

Gordons has bought the excess stock and is selling it at reduced prices through the nine outlets. It is also managing the stores, which will eventually be closed - but in the meantime they are still operating under the Bhs fascia.

The deal will have raised cash for Storehouse, but Gordons is understood to have purchased the stock at a huge discount. The Bhs official said that under stock exchange rules the deal did not have to be disclosed because "it was a revenue transaction".

News of the deal came as a surprise to retail sector analysts. One said: "It either means they are trying to clear the decks ahead of the sale of Bhs or they realise they can't sell Bhs and they are having to slowly liquidate it."

Storehouse announced at the end of last month that it was in talks with several parties which could lead to an offer for the group or either of its businesses, Bhs and Mothercare.

On March 3, Iceland confirmed it was among those interested in buying the Bhs division but it is understood the supermarket group did not submit a bid by the March 7 deadline.

Discount retailer Brown & Jackson, is also said to be interested.

Yesterday Storehouse shares finished unchanged at 45p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Orange takes centre stage
fields.body:
Orange takes centre stage

Bidding for the five next-generation mobile phone licences became more frenzied yesterday with the offers pushing the total money on the auction table up to £2.17bn.

The 13 contenders, in their second week of the auction process and round 41, watched as Orange held court as the highest bidder at £728.3m. Orange's offer was for licence B where it is bidding against its parent, Vodafone.

Licence A, which has been reserved for a new mobile phone carrier, drew a bid of £537.6m from the Virgin-led consortium SpectrumCo.

Global Crossing's vehicle Crescent tied with the Australian venture One.Tel to offer £294.4m for licence C, while Worldcom bid £300m for D and the Eircom subsidiary 3GUK offered £310m for E.

Internet firms join forces

Lastminute.com and 365 Corporation yesterday signed content deals with cable group NTL and search engine Yahoo that will significantly boost their customer reach.

The alliances give Lastminute.com and 365 Corporation important distribution agreements, while NTL and Yahoo benefit from the expansion of their content offerings.

NTL will provide Lastminute.com with about 1.8m pay-TV customers who have internet access, while 365 Corporation will supply Yahoo with a varied offering of football, rugby, cricket, motor sport and horseracing. The rugby and football will be offered in English, French and Spanish.

Qualcomm settles lawsuit

Qualcomm said yesterday it had reached agreement to resolve the class-action litigation filed by former employees of the company arising from the sale of assets of its infrastructure division to Ericsson.

Under the terms of the settlement, $8.9m (£5.6m) will be distributed to more than 1,000 former employees covered by the lawsuit.

Qualcomm, while agreeing to resolve the lawsuit, paid nothing toward the settlement, with all payments to be made by third parties. The affected employees have until April 17 to opt out of the settlement and Qualcomm has the option to cancel the settlement if more than a designated number of affected employees opt out.

A final settlement approval hearing has been scheduled for April 28.

Scoot boss raises stake Scoot.com, the online directory, said its chief executive, Robert Bonnier, bought 400,000 shares in the company at 268p each. The purchase increases Mr Bonnier's holding in Scoot to 46.5m shares - 8.32% of the total.

webTitle: Deutsche may break up the Kleinwort 'jewel'

fields.headline: Deutsche may break up the Kleinwort 'jewel'
fields.standfirst:
Deutsche Bank
Dresdner Kleinwort Benson
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank is considering selling or splitting up Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the London-based business it will acquire as a result of its £50bn merger with Dresdner Bank.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank is considering selling or splitting up Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the London-based business it will acquire as a result of its £50bn merger with Dresdner Bank.

Sources close to the deal said that Deutsche is most likely to retain DKB's corporate advisory business, regarded as the firm's crown jewel, and sell the rest.

They also said the bank was considering a bid for one of the top three US brokers - Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs and Morgan - once the Dresdner deal is completed. PaineWebber is also in the frame but might be too small for the German bank's US aspirations.

A Dresdner Bank director would not comment on the details but confirmed that Deutsche Bank was "fundamentally interested" in masking a move in the US.

Fox Pitt analyst Adrian Pilz said that Deutsche Bank has the financial resources to acquire a bank such as Goldman Sachs but added that Goldman's staff would leave en masse if such a move were made.

He said Merrill Lynch was a more likely candidate, but did not rate Deutsche's chances highly, pointing out that Chase Manhattan was unsuccessful when it attempted to make a similar acquisition some time ago.

However, Mr Pilz said he expected further developments on the mergers and acquisitions front.

When the merger between the two German banks was announced last week, Deutsche chairman Rolf Breuer described DKB as "a jewel" and denied reports that it would be closed or sold. But yesterday the position had shifted, with the bank saying it was considering options including sale, partial integration or total integration.

Industry sources said that there would be a consider- able overlap on the trading side in London if DKB were to be wholly integrated with Deutsche's operations.

They said Deutsche would be reluctant to restructure the equity and debt trading business it has built up since its $10bn takeover of Bankers Trust.

About 3,500 of DKB's 7,500 employees work in London. The business was best known as the London merchant bank Kleinwort Benson before being bought by Dresdner for £1bn in June 1995.

Banking sources said DKB staff would prefer an outright sale to another financial institution or a partial sale. They believe too many jobs would go if DKB were merged with Deutsche's existing operations.

webTitle: How to source the best pork

fields.headline: How to source the best pork
fields.standfirst: A decently reared pig makes all the difference to the taste of the meat on your plate, says Matthew Fort. And that's not porkies
fields.trailText: A decently reared pig makes all the difference to the taste of the meat on your plate, says Matthew Fort. And that's not porkies
fields.body:
I had made the acquaintance of Richard Vaughan's Middle White pigs without knowing it. I have eaten them at the Lindsay House cooked by Richard Corrigan, at the Blue Print Cafe cooked by Jeremy Lee, at St John's cooked by Fergus Henderson, at Moro cooked by Sam and Sam Clark, and at The Orrery cooked by Chris Galvin, to name but a few of London's most discerning chefs in porcine matters.

There was a time when Britain was awash with pig varieties (Berkshire, Cumberland, Gloucester Old Spot, Large White, Middle White, Small White, Lincolnshire Curly Coat, Tamworth, English Lop, etc), for each of which there was a specialist purpose. The Lincolnshire Curly Coat, say, gave Lincolnshire sausages their distinctive flavour as, once, the Cumberland did to the Cumberland sausage. Gloucester Old Spot, "the pig with the built-in apple sauce", was a 19th-century favourite, for roasting, naturally. The Berkshire/Tamworth cross was the bacon pig of the 1800s.

But that was all in the high days of British farmers. Today, most of British farming is in a pretty parlous state, and pig farming is in a more parlous state than the rest. Global competition, an insistence on price over quality, and higher standards of animal husbandry have spelled disaster for our pig farmers.

All of which makes Vaughan's project to rescue the Middle White all the more interesting. Vaughans have been farming their particular patch of the sylvan Wye valley, Huntsham Court Farm, for more than 600 years. Until 15 years ago, Richard was one of our largest suppliers of beef for the supermarket trade, buying, fattening and sending calves off for slaughter, as many and as cheaply and as quickly as possible. Then the bottom fell out of the market, so, encouraged by his now ex-wife, he switched to rare breeds and, for a while, opened the farm to the public. Today, Vaughan focuses on just three traditional breeds: Long Horn cattle, a magnificent tawny animal with shy black eyes and sweeping horns the length of a sabre; Ryeland sheep, "the sweet meat of Herefordshire"; and the Middle White pig, with its distinctive snub nose and short, chubby body.

Middle Whites may have originated from a cross between the now extinct Small White and an imported Chinese pig, which would explain the retroussé nose. It was a hugely popular porker until the last war, since when commercial tastes and the absurd demand for lean meat - absurd because 65% of flavour is carried through the intramuscular fat in meat, so no fat equals no flavour - resulted in its slide from grace. Now, there are only about 250 breeding sows in the country, and Vaughan has 40 of them.

And very happy they look, too, snuggling and snuffling around in the clean straw in their pens, segregated by age and sex. Not being hardy creatures, they stay indoors until the weather perks up, when they are released into the fields and woods behind the farm to scavenge for natural supplements to their diet. They live this agreeable, unstressed life, growing at their natural rate on their natural food, for 18 weeks, when they are ready for the chop. The chop takes place at a small, family-run abattoir five miles away, so that they have minimum travel and minimum stress. The carcasses are returned to the farm for hanging in a chiller cabin for 10 days, and then handed over to a local butcher, who divvies them up into the neat joints demanded by chefs and the 400-plus private clients who order Vaughan's superlative pork (Pedigree Meats of Hereford at Huntsham Court Farm, 01600 890296).

Of course, there is a trade-off on price - there always is if you demand quality. Buy half a pig from Vaughan (he deals only in halves, ready butchered into shoulders, legs, fillet chops and sausages), and it'll cost you £80 plus £17 delivery. As half a pig weighs in at 16-18kg (don't worry, it freezes well, and you can always share the load with a group of friends), that works out to £5.40-£6.10 per kilo, which is an absurdly small premium for such sweetness of flavour, such supreme succulence, such pluperfect crackling.

fields.headline: Five perfect pork recipes
fields.standfirst: Leg of pork with artichokes and onions, rillettes, crackling, sausages and twice-cooked pork. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Leg of pork with artichokes and onions, rillettes, crackling, sausages and twice-cooked pork. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Leg of pork with artichokes and onions

This feeds more than six, but the leftovers are fantastic.

8-10 small to medium-sized onions

4 bayleaves

1 small sprig thyme

1 leg of top-quality pork (this will weigh, and cost, a lot, so go for leg, if need be, changing cooking times accordingly)

1 small sprig rosemary

Olive oil

Sea salt and black peppercorns

10-20 baby artichokes

Juice of 1 lemon

Pre-heat the oven to 230C/450F/gas mark 8. Peel the onions, taking care to leave the base root intact (cut away any threads still attached to it), then cut them into four or six pieces right through the core. Lay the onions in a roasting tray that is big enough to accommodate them all, crammed with olive oil. Bury three of the bayleaves within the onions, and lay the thyme on top. Lay on the joint, rub it with a little olive oil and sprinkle with sea salt. Do not score the skin. Place in the oven, cook for 10 minutes, then reduce the temperature to 160C/325F/gas mark 3, and cook for 25 minutes per 500g of meat. Once the cooking time has elapsed, switch off the oven, and leave the meat to rest for at least 45 minutes.

While the pork is cooking, squeeze the lemon juice into a wide bowl and add a teaspoon of sea salt. Trim the artichokes of their outer leaves, and cut them back until the greater part of the fibrous outer parts has been removed, revealing the tender stalk and head. One by one, toss each prepared artichoke briefly in lemon juice (too much lemon kills their subtle flavour), then place in a pot. Add to the pot a few tablespoons of olive oil, a bayleaf, a couple of black peppercorns and enough water to cover. If the artichokes bob to the surface, place a plate on top, to act as a weight. Place the pot over a high heat, bring to the boil, then simmer until tender.

Fifteen minutes before serv ing, take the pork out of the pan and place on a board. Strain the artichokes, cut each in half lengthways and add to the pan. Pick the leaves from the rosemary, toss in sea salt and pepper, and scatter over the top of the vegetables in the pan. Remove as much fat from the pan as is possible without breaking up the onions, and return to the oven until the artichokes and onions have browned at the edges.

Rillettes

This is Jane Grigson's recipe for Rillettes de Paris, from her book on the glory of the pig, Charcuterie And French Pork Cookery. The point is the prolonged, gentle cooking, so that the meat is in the most melting condition possible.

500g pork belly

30g good lard

12g sea salt

Black pepper

1 bayleaf

Cut the meat into 2.5cm-long pieces. In a heavy pan and over a very, very low flame, fry the pork in the lard, stirring repeatedly, until the meat is pale gold all over. Pour off the fat, add the bayleaf, and cook, uncovered, for five hours on the lowest possible heat (Grigson recommends care and attention: 'Too high a flame will fry the pieces of meat and harden them', so do as she says). From time to time, pour in a little water to prevent the meat sticking. Switch off the heat, and leave the pot to cook completely.

Next, either finely chop the meat in a blender, or chop and pound it by hand, until you have a smooth, unctuous pté. Season with salt and pepper, and add as much of the drained fat as you want - it all depends on personal taste, but I use quite a lot of it.

Crackling

The first point must obviously be the quality of the pork: at the very least, only free-range should be considered. There is a very old and very good tradition of soaking the joint first in a brine containing vinegar, sugar and spices, but modern problems of storage and time come into play, so I don't expect many would want even to try it. Anyway, a good butcher will be more than happy to brine the meat for you. On no account score the skin. For the best crackling, rub the joint all over with olive oil and sea salt, followed by a slow roast - long cooking renders all the excess fat, and delivers up a deeply bronzed and crisp crackling. The timing and temperature given in the recipe for leg of pork apply to all joints of pork.

Sausages

The British banger is a true duffer when put beside those of Italy, France or Spain, but there is no reason why our standards should not rival them.

750g lean pork

250g pork fat (back fat or flair)

1 tsp black peppercorns, cracked in a mill or mortar and pestle

Sea salt

1 pinch freshly-grated nutmeg

50g sausage casings, 2.2m in total length (from good butcher shops)

Work the lean and the fat meat together through the coarse blade of a mincer (ask the butcher to do this for you), then add the pepper, salt and nutmeg, along with any other spices or seasonings that take your fancy (don't go overboard the first time). Work the mix to ensure an even blend, then leave covered in the fridge for 24 to 36 hours to mature.

When ready to make the sausages, rinse the skins well - leave for at least a couple of hours under running cold water. The traditional method of filling the skins - that is, putting a wide nozzle on a piping bag and then pushing the casing up over the nozzle - is very slow, as the air has to be pushed out of the sausage as you go along. However, unless you have a sausage stuffer handy, or your butcher is of the obliging variety, then very slow it is going to have to be. At least it's easy work. Twist the ends to seal, then tie each sausage, until you have a string of sausages. Refrigerate for at least three hours before cooking, preferably overnight - they will dry slightly and so cook better.

Twice-cooked pork

Christine Yau, the proprietor of Ming, in Soho, gave me the method for this most pleasing dish.

1 pork belly weighing 1.5kg

2 stems dry and pickled vegetables (try a Chinese supermarket) or two big pieces fresh ginger and 1 bunch spring onions, roughly chopped

2 tbsp dark soy sauce

2 tbsp oyster sauce

Fill a pot with enough water later to cover the meat and bring to a rolling boil. Plunge the pork into the water, return to the boil and leave for a minute or two, to remove any impurities. Place the pot in a sink, and run cold water into it until the water inside runs clear.

Remove the meat, clean the pot, then return the pork to it, along with the vegetables, sauces and a litre of cold water. Simmer, covered, for an hour-and-a-half, every now and then lifting up the meat to stop it sticking to the base, then turn the pork over and cook slowly for another hour or so. Remove from the pot and leave to rest for 15 minutes. Remove the bones: first, loosen them with the point of a knife, then pull free. Slice the meat very thinly, place on a serving dish, and ladle over the sauce

 Jeremy Lee is the chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1

webTitle: Blow to Celltech as US restricts cancer drug

fields.headline: Blow to Celltech as US restricts cancer drug
fields.standfirst: Celltech
fields.trailText: Drugs group Celltech suffered a blow last night when US regulators recommended only restricted use of its pioneering new treatment for leukaemia.
fields.body:
Drugs group Celltech suffered a blow last night when US regulators recommended only restricted use of its pioneering new treatment for leukaemia.

After an all-day meeting, an advisory committee at the food and drugs authority concluded that the drug, Mylotarg, should be made available only to patients aged over 60.

Analysts described the news as a severe setback because the product was considered a test of the group's crucial antibody technology.

However, chief executive Peter Fellner put a brave face on the matter, saying: "We're actually quite pleased - I think the impact this will have on the drug's eventual commercial development will be quite limited."

The decision was announced after the close of the London stock exchange but caused confusion on Wall Street. An initial report from Reuters suggested the drug had been blocked entirely, prompting a 20% slump in the company's shares. The New York stock exchange stepped in to order a suspension of trading.

Mylotarg was expected to produce peak annual sales of around £120m by 2003 - only moderately significant in financial terms for Celltech, which this week joined the FTSE 100 index.

However, the product is considered very important as a test of Celltech's research in turning human antibodies into drugs. Its last such product, for toxic shock syndrome, failed three years ago.

Nick Woolf at ABN Amro said: "In terms of sentiment, it's a massive blow. This restricted approval greatly limits the commercial potential and it's their second antibody to disappoint." He predicted that Celltech's shares would fall "dramatically" on Monday. They rose 72p to £13.07 yesterday.

Regulators said clinical trials were too small to prove efficacy; statistical experts criticised the way extra patients were added to some studies without explanation.

The committee voted 10-2 against recommending general approval and 7-4 in favour of its use among the elderly.

Mylotarg is aimed at those with acute myeloid leukaemia which has already gone into remission once. Mr Fellner said that more than 50% of the drug's target patients were over 60 anyway.

webTitle: Toy Story 3 as Oscars stage a Great Escape

fields.headline: Toy Story 3 as Oscars stage a Great Escape
fields.trailText: It has all the ingredients of a great movie - the sort that even picks up Oscars. There's a coveted icon dipped in gold, a heist, a mystery, a police sleuthing operation and a stack of potential supects.
fields.body:
It has all the ingredients of a great movie - the sort that even picks up Oscars. There's a coveted icon dipped in gold, a heist, a mystery, a police sleuthing operation and a stack of potential supects.

But the apparent theft of 55 Oscar statuettes barely a week before the Academy Awards ceremony here is not a treatment for a script but an embarrassingly true story.

A crate of the Oscar statuettes was on its way from the maker in Chicago to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences this week when the whole lot went missing, believed stolen. The statuettes, which each weigh 8lbs and are dipped in 24-carat gold, were due to be handed out at the awards on March 26.

The director of the academy, Bruce Davis, was playing the script as more comedy than drama at a press conference in Beverly Hills yesterday. His message to the thieves was simple: "They can simplify their lives a great deal if they get these back to us."

Mr Davis said the statuettes had disappeared in a mysterious way but predicted that the thieves would find them "a bit difficult to fence". The hijacking unit of the Los Angeles police is on the case and is presumably checking out the Usual Suspects (which in 1995 won a best supporting actor's Oscar for this year's best actor nominee, Kevin Spacey).

The possibility that this year's winners will have to go home empty-handed or carrying a cardboard cut-out was ruled out. New Oscars are being minted and will be shipped to Los Angeles in time for the big night.

Mr Davis used the incident to try to boost the audience of one of the world's most avidly watched TV shows by saying people should tune in to see if there were indeed enough Oscars to go round.

The academy has a jealously protective attitude towards the statuettes. Winners are required to sign an agreement saying that if they decide to dispose of their prize they will sell it back to the organisation for $1.

The disappearance, apparently from a transport company's shipping depot in Bell, California, comes shortly after it emerged that 4,200 Oscar ballots went missing in the post. Duplicate copies have been sent out.

Lobbying in advance of next Tuesday's deadline for voting in the Academy Awards has been intense.

Every day studios are spending tens of thousands of dollars in trade advertising in a final bid to influence academy members who may still not have made up their minds. American Beauty is still seen as the favourite to pick up most awards.

fields.headline: Hague's head girl
fields.standfirst: She's the most powerful right-wing woman in parliament. To her enemies, on both sides of the house, she is known as Doris Karloff. But  Sally Weale finds a softer side to the hard-line politician - and novice novelist
fields.trailText: She's the most powerful right-wing woman in parliament. To her enemies, on both sides of the house, she is known as Doris Karloff. But Sally Weale finds a softer side to the hard-line politician - and novice novelist
fields.body:
It is Saturday afternoon, a slow day in Ann Widdecombe's constituency surgery. There's a child support case; someone with a gripe against taxes on caravans; somebody else wants to talk about asylum-seekers. The Tory MP for Maidstone and the Weald listens, head cocked slightly, like a curious budgerigar. There are custard creams on the table. After each constituent leaves she picks up her Dictaphone and composes an instant letter, thanking them for coming to see her and outlining her response to their predicament.

She looks almost petite in a short-sleeved, navy blue woollen dress which smooths her bulky contours, exposing arms that are surprisingly elegant. Her outfits are rarely so flattering. William Hague smiles down from the wall in a pre make-over photograph like a fond godson.

Ann Widdecombe, 52, has a reputation built on extremes. To some she is Doris Karloff, possibly the most unpopular woman in Britain after being wrongly associated with shackling women prisoners in labour or childbirth when she was prisons minister in 1996; to others she is a national heroine after singlehandedly terminating Michael Howard's political career in a sublime moment of oratorical brilliance.

Since the Tories' crushing 1997 defeat, she has become the most prominent politician on the shadow front bench. A staunch right-winger, Widdecombe has powerful popular appeal and talks to people in a way they understand (pandering, some say, to their baser instincts with her outbursts on asylum seekers, for example). She's unreconstructed, someone who won't give herself up to the image consultants and spindoctors; we may not like all her views, but at least she's got some. But others regard her as a weird anachronism, someone out of step with the spirit of the age; whose unshakeable faith, moralistic views and narrow perspective on life belong to a different era; a politician who shines when compared to her opposition colleagues.

Today she's not shining. In fact, she looks a little jaded. After surgery she takes the Guardian shopping at a little country boutique called Lady Mop to choose a blouse for her mother. Then back home in her bungalow in the Kent village of Sutton Valence (her main home is now in London) she puts in a wash, takes a seat on the granny-style settee and tucks her tiny feet under her. A fire is laid in the grate, an empty scotch bottle is in the kitchen.

She is unfailingly polite and helpful. She rarely shies away from publicity - "a bit too showbizzy" one colleague says. The only media show she refuses to take part in is Have I Got News For You. ("I've never yet seen a politician beat the regulars. They always come off worst. My wit's not fast enough.") But after years of personal and vicious attacks she is keen to get over her human side and doesn't think there's anything wrong with that.

A few weeks ago in Good Housekeeping magazine she talked about giving up her career to look after her mother if the need arose. She even shared her "beauty routine" with readers: she washes her hair with Vosene every other day and likes to be "dressed with perfume", preferably Miss Dior or Chanel No 5. Then there's the cats' diary she's writing for the Daily Mail, looking at the daily lives of her two cats, Carruthers and Pugwash, and her bookings for Call My Bluff. All this against the backdrop of continuing murmurings about the future leadership of the Tories.

Widdecombe dismisses any suggestion that she might one day lead the party. "Oh yeah, I mean - come on!" she says, mock-irritated. "There's this myth that we always solve our problems by changing our leader. We don't. I do get rather tired of the speculation about who the next leader is going to be. For all I know it may not be for another couple of decades and I shall have long gone to prune my roses on Dartmoor."

Michael Portillo's early return following his confessions about his gay past will inevitably steal some of her limelight. She is, she insists loyally, delighted he's back as shadow chancellor to add weight to the team. Many however are convinced she would - and should - throw her hat into the ring, were there a leadership contest. "She's obviously after being leader," says Labour maverick Frank Field, who got to know her on the social security select committee. "Many people think she's a conviction politician who sees everything in black and white. If you listen to her carefully she doesn't, and that's her cleverness. She's much more subtle than most people think."

Peter Luff, her former private parliamentary secretary, now opposition whip for home affairs, agrees: "She's represented as a right-wing harridan, but her views are a lot more sophisticated than that. Her speech to the party conference last year sounded very rightwing, but when you look at what she said about prison policy, she's very liberal."

Perhaps that subtlety, which has largely escaped public notice, will become more apparent with the publication next month of her first novel, The Clematis Tree, for which she was paid £100,000 as part of a two-book deal. It is an ethical tale which explores euthanasia, right-to-life, and our attitudes to the disabled. No surprises there, from a woman whose pro-life, anti-abortion stance is as much part of her identity as her pudding-basin haircut and her headmistressy tones.

What is more striking perhaps is the joylessness of this book. In the space of fewer than 300 pages, a four-year-old boy is paralysed and severely brain-damaged after being hit by a speeding sportscar; four children are killed in a coach crash; we hear of another car crash which kills three (a child who survives dies of cancer two years later); someone has a heart attack, then a stroke, then dies; and the same brain-damaged boy dies in dubious circumstances after the brake on his wheelchair fails and he falls headlong into a stream. And there's more. "Mother thought it was quite miserable," Widdecombe admits.

Mother is right. Widdecombe's vision of life in this book is cruel and unforgiving. "None of it is autobiographical," she insists. "Everybody will be trying to analyse it in great depth and detail, but it's not a tract for my views. It's a genuine attempt at a novel. I've always wanted to write a novel. I've got about seven or eight ideas in my head. This was the one I pulled out first."

The Clematis Tree may not be straightforwardly autobiographical, but it focuses on issues which are at the core of Widdecombe's beliefs. One senior editor allegedly turned it down because, though reasonably well written, she found it preachy and propagandist. It is heavy on duty, responsibility and endurance, the central tenets of Widdecombe's personal philosophy. Her next subject sounds lighthearted by comparison - set in second world war France, it's about a naïve young convent girl who falls in love with a married German officer.

Ann Noreen Widdecombe was born in 1947 in Bath where her father, Murray, a Cornishman, worked in what was then called the admiralty, and his wife Rita was a full-time mother. Anne's brother, Malcolm, was older by 10 years (they were pre-war, post-war babies) and they lived with their grandmother, who had been bombed out of her home in Plymouth. When Widdecombe was five, her father was posted to Singapore. Her brother and grandmother had to be left behind: the first so as not to disrupt school, the second because the doctor ruled her unfit for the three-week crossing.

In Singapore her parents lived in a social whirl while their daughter attended the royal navy school, became very good at swimming and played with her nanny's daughter, Moi, in a garden full of banana trees and bamboos. (It was in Moi's house that she did much of the work on her novel in the summer of 1998).

Three years later they returned to England, and lived in a succession of homes in Bath and the south-east, moving each time her father had a new posting. He became director general of naval supplies and transport. Her mother moved 24 times in her 62-year marriage. Her most recent move has been into her daughter's new London home following the death of her husband last year.

She is, says her daughter, unfailingly soft and gentle. "She's still sorry for absolutely everybody," says Widdecombe. "Anybody!" she adds incredulously. "She'll say things like 'poor Mr Blair' if he's had a rough time. I say, 'Nonsense, it's not poor Mr Blair at all'." Journalists rarely meet her. She doesn't like all the hurtful things that have been written about her daughter. When the Guardian photographer arrived at Widdecombe's London home, her mother was seen disappearing into the upstairs gloom on the recently installed Stannah lift, Widdecombe Jr shouting instructions after her.

Malcolm Widdecombe believes his sister is more like their father than their mother. "Dad was irascible. He was absolutely fair, straight and honest, and totally committed to his job. Ann is totally committed to what she does. My dad was always a just person, but he was tough. I don't think he was warm. He was not an emotional type."

Writer Lucy Gannon was a contemporary at La Sainte Union, the Bath convent where Widdecombe went as a day-girl when she was 11 and later as a boarder. She was one of a minority of protestants in a Catholic school, which taught her to stand up for herself very early. "She has turned out just as I would have imagined," says Gannon. "She was very earnest and had a very clear idea of right and wrong which coincided with the nuns' views. I don't think she ever had a moment's self doubt. But I had a friend who was a boarder and whenever my friend was unhappy, the one person who would be unfailingly kind and considerate was Ann."

She was house captain, senior prefect, she debated for the school and founded the classical society. She tried to get into Oxford to do law, but was turned down after interview and went instead to Birmingham, where she studied Latin (after early ambitions to be a missionary, she wanted to become a Latin teacher). She joined the university's Christian Union and became interested in the evangelist Billy Graham, whose preaching was a key influence on Widdecombe's own distinctive style of speaking.

It was at Birmingham that her ambition to become an MP crystallised. She enjoyed debating, winning arguments - all part of the politicians' armour - and is by instinct combative, adversarial, a bare-knuckle fighter with tiny doll hands, and pearly polished nails. She lavishes an extraordinary amount of attention on her nails - they're always painted, apart from a four-week break she gives them during the summer to recover.

Her passion for politics comes from a sense of duty, public service and concern for society, but there's an egotism about it too. She likes the sheer challenge of the thing. "If you ask me what is most fascinating about politics," she says, "it is trying to solve insoluble problems."

So, while her peers at Birmingham were planning careers as social workers, teachers and probation staff, Widdecombe decided, with her 2:1 and her parents' financial support, to go to Oxford to study politics, philosophy and economics. She got a third - among her greatest achievements she claims, because she did so little work. More importantly, she threw her energies into the Oxford Union, the debating society, where she became secretary and treasurer. "She was quite frightening even then," remembers the writer Libby Purves. "She didn't have the attractive personality that gets made president of the union. She was a pretty, petite little thing but always rather dour. Even then she wasn't somebody you had a giggle with in the bar. There was that feeling even then that she knew she was right."

At Oxford she found romantic love for the first and last time with Colin Maltby, now a banker. They are pictured together in one memorable snap - him in a dinner suit, her somehow shockingly glamorous with dark, tumbling hair, a hint of cleavage, and sexy, wide black choker - more Nigella Lawson than Doris Karloff.

"When I was younger of course I liked to look glamorous," she says. "I wasn't a slave to it, but I certainly did follow fashion at Oxford. I loved my long hair - I had hair half way down my back. When you're young you have these wonderful fantasies about looking marvellous, spending fortunes on lipsticks and other such frippery and then I think you settle down to looking presentable."

The love affair ended after three years. It just fizzled out, she says. Widdecombe left Oxford and embarked on an unhappy career marketing Persil and Comfort for Unilever. At some point she cut her long hair and politics began to take over. There was, some say, a new ferocity about her. Edwina Currie, a near contemporary at Oxford, is quoted saying: "Something min eral entered her bloodstream and something animal left it. Some steel came over her. One doesn't know if there was one specific disastrous incident - something that put her off sex - or whether it's just a general distaste that grew."

Widdecombe is contemptuous. Edwina couldn't possibly know, they weren't even at Oxford at the same time! She does not share the general amusement at the glorious symmetry of these two women: both office holders in the Oxford Union, both senior Tory MPs, both novelists - one writing about sex, the other about euthanasia. (There is, for the record, one very chaste sexual encounter between a married couple in Widdecombe's novel.)

After Unilever, she spent 12 years working in finance at London University, devoting every second of her spare time to furthering her political career. In 1977 she was selected as the Tory candidate for Burnley, and in the 1979 general election halved the Labour majority. In 1983 she lost Devonport to David Owen and in 1985 was selected for Maidstone and the Weald, finally being elected to parliament two years later.

She had achieved her goal through bloody-minded determination. (Widdecombe astonished local party workers in Burnley by travelling up to Lancashire every weekend for two years, charging fearlessly into working men's clubs and demanding their vote.) "I don't think she's brilliant," says one Oxford contemporary. "She's always been a bloody hard worker. It's the beta-plus slog. She's never had that little spark of brilliance that makes everybody in the room smile."

In parliament it was her passionately held views on abortion which first put her in the public eye - in 1987 she joined supporters of David Alton's abortion bill - and it is probably the one issue which defines and upsets her more than any other. All visitors to her cramped, uncomfortable Westminster office are confronted with three fading, but still vividly bloody anti abortion posters. She can't pinpoint exactly where and how her views were shaped - she remembers being horrified by the 1967 act and debated against it at Birmingham and lost. Three years later she debated against it again at Oxford and won. She denies being out of step with general opinion. "Every time we do an opinion poll on abortion, you actually get a consensus in favour of tightening the law."

But Widdecombe's faith and moral convictions do seem to belong to a different era. She's a Joan of Arc figure - battle imagery litters her language - who stands in opposition to the modern tendency to define ourselves by our faults and uncertainties. "I think a lot of people these days suspect certainty, are slightly nervous in the presence of strong conviction. Whereas a few centuries ago, the opposite would have been true," she says. She did briefly lose her faith once - "the slow erosion of belief". Otherwise she seems utterly unshakeable.

She believes in capital punishment as a deterrent; opposes any reduction in the age of homosexual consent; believes in marriage as the foundation of society; thinks divorce is too easy and believes mothers should stay at home and raise their children. Particularly for modern women it's a frightening, immoveable agenda. But somehow, maybe because of her oddity and the fascination with her appearance, her personal moral and religious views are not given a great deal of serious consideration. Widdecombe herself puts them to one side saying they are the subject of free votes only. But it's interesting to consider what a world run along Widdecombe lines might be like. It's not exactly the Taliban, but it would certainly turn the clock back a few decades.

She is a conundrum for feminists. As a strong, independent, successful woman she deserves admiration, but so much of what she represents seems to be anti-woman. She admits she prefers the company of men: women are too emotionally demanding.

Her views have not held her back in her career. In John Major's government, she was appointed parliamentary under secretary of state in the social security department with special responsibility for pensions; she was moved to employment in 1993 where she worked with Portillo; and from there went to the home office where she was responsible for immigration and prisons. (She made a point of visiting all 131 prisons in England and Wales in her own time at weekends, sometimes four a day.)

Her media profile was raised even further by her very public conversion from the Church of England to Catholicism over the issue of women priests. Dressed in her pious Sunday best, she was on the front of almost every newspaper the day she was accepted into the Catholic church. Some grumbled it was tacky making public what should have been a private matter of personal faith. She says she never expected such a media circus: "But I had a statement to make. I would not have done it in a broom cupboard."

There was evidently little love lost between her and Michael Howard, then home secretary and her boss. The common perception was that he allowed her to take a lot of the flak. Frank Field again: "She was used as a fall guy." Then, in 1997, her fortunes changed with that single phrase describing Howard: "something of the night about him". His career was over, Widdecombe's had been resurrected. Howard last week said of Widdecombe: "She was effective, she was competent, she did the right things. She obviously disagreed with me about my decision to dismiss Derek Lewis [director general of the prison service - sacked over a breakout from Parkhurst Prison]. I still think that decision was right. I did not expect her to react in the way she did."

For a time Widdecombe thought her political career was over. She prepared herself for a quiet time on the backbenches and began to write her book. But a year later Hague asked her to become shadow health secretary. She brought the 1998 Tory party conference to its feet with a rousing speech in classic Widdecombe style - some jokes, no notes, and a touch of pantomime. Last year he moved her to her first love, home affairs, as shadow home secretary and she is clearly relishing being boss of her own team.

"She's in the top echelon of the party," says close friend and ally David Amess MP. "She had huge influence on our common sense policies and much of what she believes in is now bearing fruit. The party is being drawn towards her. She's one of the four or five people who have got a big influence over the way we are developing policy. She has accepted being in opposition much more adeptly than many other conservative politicians. Do I think she's going to become leader of the conservative party? There's no vacancy. Do I think she has the qualities of a leader? Most definitely, yes."

Others disagree - vehemently. "She won't ever be leader. There's something missing in her," one says. "I don't think a zealous Catholic virgin is what the party or the country want. If you look at the wider picture of where the Tories are, someone holding Widdecombe's views is part of the problem, not part of the answer."

She is however extraordinarily popular with the Tory rank and file and spends her time dashing to speaking engagements around the country, rousing the troops and raising her own profile. She's famously kind-hearted: there are stories about her quietly buying cups of tea and sandwiches for the homeless away from the media spotlight; she adores babies and very young children and is a popular godmother.

Peter Luff says she is much more sensitive than people realise. "She's also quite vulnerable to criticism. There's a softer side to her. She appreciates reassurance. She likes to be told she's done well." She can also be funny and is good at telling stories at her own expense. (even if she does sometimes tell the same gags again and again).

Gyles Brandreth, writing in Breaking The Code, an account of his time as an MP, recalls her telling his constituents about her first election campaign, in the run-up to which she had published a pamphlet called Christian Principles. She looks ahead to a retirement in the West Country, with animals, and gusty walks across bleak wide open spaces. And of course, there's always the novel writing to fall back on.

fields.bodyText: It is Saturday afternoon, a slow day in Ann Widdecombe's constituency surgery. There's a child support case; someone with a gripe against taxes on caravans; somebody else wants to talk about asylum-seekers. The Tory MP for Maidstone and the Weald listens, head cocked slightly, like a curious budgerigar. There are custard creams on the table. After each constituent leaves she picks up her Dictaphone and composes an instant letter, thanking them for coming to see her and outlining her response to their predicament. She looks almost petite in a short-sleeved, navy blue woollen dress which smooths her bulky contours, exposing arms that are surprisingly elegant. Her outfits are rarely so flattering. William Hague smiles down from the wall in a pre make-over photograph like a fond godson. Ann Widdecombe, 52, has a reputation built on extremes. To some she is Doris Karloff, possibly the most unpopular woman in Britain after being wrongly associated with shackling women prisoners in labour or childbirth when she was prisons minister in 1996; to others she is a national heroine after singlehandedly terminating Michael Howard's political career in a sublime moment of oratorical brilliance. Since the Tories' crushing 1997 defeat, she has become the most prominent politician on the shadow front bench. A staunch right-winger, Widdecombe has powerful popular appeal and talks to people in a way they understand (pandering, some say, to their baser instincts with her outbursts on asylum seekers, for example). She's unreconstructed, someone who won't give herself up to the image consultants and spindoctors; we may not like all her views, but at least she's got some. But others regard her as a weird anachronism, someone out of step with the spirit of the age; whose unshakeable faith, moralistic views and narrow perspective on life belong to a different era; a politician who shines when compared to her opposition colleagues. Today she's not shining. In fact, she looks a little jaded. After surgery she takes the Guardian shopping at a little country boutique called Lady Mop to choose a blouse for her mother. Then back home in her bungalow in the Kent village of Sutton Valence (her main home is now in London) she puts in a wash, takes a seat on the granny-style settee and tucks her tiny feet under her. A fire is laid in the grate, an empty scotch bottle is in the kitchen. She is unfailingly polite and helpful. She rarely shies away from publicity - "a bit too showbizzy" one colleague says. The only media show she refuses to take part in is Have I Got News For You. ("I've never yet seen a politician beat the regulars. They always come off worst. My wit's not fast enough.") But after years of personal and vicious attacks she is keen to get over her human side and doesn't think there's anything wrong with that. A few weeks ago in Good Housekeeping magazine she talked about giving up her career to look after her mother if the need arose. She even shared her "beauty routine" with readers: she washes her hair with Vosene every other day and likes to be "dressed with perfume", preferably Miss Dior or Chanel No 5. Then there's the cats' diary she's writing for the Daily Mail, looking at the daily lives of her two cats, Carruthers and Pugwash, and her bookings for Call My Bluff. All this against the backdrop of continuing murmurings about the future leadership of the Tories. Widdecombe dismisses any suggestion that she might one day lead the party. "Oh yeah, I mean - come on!" she says, mock-irritated. "There's this myth that we always solve our problems by changing our leader. We don't. I do get rather tired of the speculation about who the next leader is going to be. For all I know it may not be for another couple of decades and I shall have long gone to prune my roses on Dartmoor." Michael Portillo's early return following his confessions about his gay past will inevitably steal some of her limelight. She is, she insists loyally, delighted he's back as shadow chancellor to add weight to the team. Many however are convinced she would - and should - throw her hat into the ring, were there a leadership contest. "She's obviously after being leader," says Labour maverick Frank Field, who got to know her on the social security select committee. "Many people think she's a conviction politician who sees everything in black and white. If you listen to her carefully she doesn't, and that's her cleverness. She's much more subtle than most people think." Peter Luff, her former private parliamentary secretary, now opposition whip for home affairs, agrees: "She's represented as a right-wing harridan, but her views are a lot more sophisticated than that. Her speech to the party conference last year sounded very rightwing, but when you look at what she said about prison policy, she's very liberal." Perhaps that subtlety, which has largely escaped public notice, will become more apparent with the publication next month of her first novel, The Clematis Tree, for which she was paid £100,000 as part of a two-book deal. It is an ethical tale which explores euthanasia, right-to-life, and our attitudes to the disabled. No surprises there, from a woman whose pro-life, anti-abortion stance is as much part of her identity as her pudding-basin haircut and her headmistressy tones. What is more striking perhaps is the joylessness of this book. In the space of fewer than 300 pages, a four-year-old boy is paralysed and severely brain-damaged after being hit by a speeding sportscar; four children are killed in a coach crash; we hear of another car crash which kills three (a child who survives dies of cancer two years later); someone has a heart attack, then a stroke, then dies; and the same brain-damaged boy dies in dubious circumstances after the brake on his wheelchair fails and he falls headlong into a stream. And there's more. "Mother thought it was quite miserable," Widdecombe admits. Mother is right. Widdecombe's vision of life in this book is cruel and unforgiving. "None of it is autobiographical," she insists. "Everybody will be trying to analyse it in great depth and detail, but it's not a tract for my views. It's a genuine attempt at a novel. I've always wanted to write a novel. I've got about seven or eight ideas in my head. This was the one I pulled out first." The Clematis Tree may not be straightforwardly autobiographical, but it focuses on issues which are at the core of Widdecombe's beliefs. One senior editor allegedly turned it down because, though reasonably well written, she found it preachy and propagandist. It is heavy on duty, responsibility and endurance, the central tenets of Widdecombe's personal philosophy. Her next subject sounds lighthearted by comparison - set in second world war France, it's about a naïve young convent girl who falls in love with a married German officer. Ann Noreen Widdecombe was born in 1947 in Bath where her father, Murray, a Cornishman, worked in what was then called the admiralty, and his wife Rita was a full-time mother. Anne's brother, Malcolm, was older by 10 years (they were pre-war, post-war babies) and they lived with their grandmother, who had been bombed out of her home in Plymouth. When Widdecombe was five, her father was posted to Singapore. Her brother and grandmother had to be left behind: the first so as not to disrupt school, the second because the doctor ruled her unfit for the three-week crossing. (It was in Moi's house that she did much of the work on her novel in the summer of 1998). fields.headline: Wolfensohn has failed Stern test
fields.standfirst: Rules that must not be bent
fields.trailText: The staff association at the World Bank should be congratulated for blowing the whistle on president Jim Wolfensohn's handling of the appointment of Nick Stern as his new chief economist.
fields.body:
The staff association at the World Bank should be congratulated for blowing the whistle on president Jim Wolfensohn's handling of the appointment of Nick Stern as his new chief economist.

The charges of nepotism and corruption may be a bit harsh but it certainly smacks of arrogance.

No one disputes Professor Stern's qualifications for the job. He is a distinguished development economist who probably deserves such an important role on merit. But if there are rules pre venting the Bank employing more than one family member - Prof Stern's brother Richard is vice-president of human resources - they should not be bent by anyone, least of all those at the top of the Washington-based organisation.

True, in this case following the rules will deprive the Bank of a talented man who has the potential to do a lot of good for the world. But there are two reasons for giving the job to someone else.

First, Prof Stern's appointment sets a bad example to the Bank's employees, who probably have had equally well-qualified relatives excluded from less senior positions than Prof Stern's because of the Bank's employment rules. Indeed, the staff association says that some employees have been sacked once it was discovered that they had family members on the Bank's payroll. Who is to say they are less worthy of special treatment than Prof Stern?

Second, it is the Bank's duty to the present the squeakiest of squeaky clean images to the developing world. Mr Wolfensohn had made admirable efforts to clamp down on graft in his client countries but his blundering over Prof Stern's appointment undermines the integrity of his employees on the ground.

The Bank goes round the world advising on civil service reform and corruption prevention but, after this episode, runs the risk of being perceived as not having its own house in order.

More pickily, as with the fiasco over appointment of the IMF managing director, what are the criteria for the chief economist's slot? Although Prof Stern has the right background, the Bank has not laid down publicly the criteria for his job. He has not been through an open and transparent selection process. If he had, the staff association might not now be in the position of having to raise objections. They could have been made well before Mr Stern's appointment and the whole row avoided.

Unless the staff association backs down and endorses Prof Stern's appointment, the only viable alternative to ditching him would be for Mr Wolfensohn to change the Bank's rules allowing all staff to have their relatives considered for jobs. Otherwise, the staff will be able to accuse him of having one rule for the little people and one for those in positions of power.

Car pound

BMW boss Joachim Milberg's criticisms of the government's policy towards the euro must be treated with some caution. His group has just ditched - at considerable expense - a project which has been a central plank of its strategy for more than five years. It has lost face, too. In the circumstances it would be surprising if BMW executives were not looking for someone to share the blame.

But just because Professor Milberg has a special case to plead does not mean his arguments can be dismissed out of hand. British manufacturing industry is suffering from the strength of the pound against the euro. Look at the data earlier this week showing input prices soaring on the back of higher energy prices while output prices can barely muster of a flicker of life, up just 0.1%. Manufacturers are taking it on the margins and suffering as a result.

Some can shrug it off. As Prof Milberg noted amid his strictures on the single currency, BMW has no plans to build Rolls-Royces outside the UK when it takes over the brand. Put part of that is down to the car's appeal to tradition; the rest to the fact that Rolls-Royce cars are not price-sensitive.

For most, however, the exchange rate counts, a point acknowledged yesterday by monetary policy committee member Sushil Wadhwani, who said intervention to bring sterling down is a possibility.

For manufacturers struggling for survival, it does not matter whether the pound is strong against the euro or the euro weak against the pound or whether sterling is simply bobbing up and down in the turbulence caused by the single currency's slump against the dollar. What does matter is that they are going to continue suffering unless and until the euro rallies. The outlook for the European economies suggest that should happen soon. But on that score it should have happened already.

In the meantime the government's prevarications over the euro will continue to take a toll. That does not mean Gordon Brown should suddenly abandon his economic tests which must be met for membership. But neither should anyone run away with the idea that staying out is entirely risk-free.

He is a distinguished development economist who probably deserves such an important role on merit.
