webTitle: £1.5m too little for ousted A&L chief

fields.headline: £1.5m too little for ousted A&L chief
fields.standfirst: Alliance and Leicester
fields.trailText: Peter White, who was dismissed last October as chief executive of the Alliance & Leicester mortgage bank, has been handed £1.5m in compensation - and he is still claiming more.
fields.body:
Peter White, who was dismissed last October as chief executive of the Alliance & Leicester mortgage bank, has been handed £1.5m in compensation - and he is still claiming more.

Mr White, fired after 18 years at A&L when his boardroom colleagues said they were seeking a more "consensual style of leadership", is taking the bank to an industrial tribunal claim ing unfair dismissal. He also wants compensation for lost share options, unpaid bonuses and is believed to be demanding other ex-gratia payments which could total hundreds of thousands more.

The scale of the compensation payment handed to Mr White is disclosed in A&L's annual report, which has just been sent to shareholders.

It consists of £1.05m in lieu of two year's basic salary and a contribution to Mr White's pen sion of £533,500. Mr White had a two-year contract and a spokesman for the bank said yesterday: "We have given him only what he is contractually entitled to."

The bank has pledged to fight Mr White's claim for unfair dismissal, even if it ends in an embarrassing tribunal appearance.

In addition to the payoff, Mr White was also paid a salary of £438,000 for the months before he was fired and in that time also received a bonus of £110,000 and benefits in kind valued at £49,000.

Neither Mr White, who had a reputation for dictatorial leadership, nor the bank has revealed much detail of the events which led to his departure. But it has been claimed that Mr White was jettisoned after the A&L held merger talks with the Woolwich, without including him.

The company has so far failed to replace Mr White.

webTitle: IT and media lag behind on environment reports

fields.headline: IT and media lag behind on environment reports
fields.standfirst:
Psion
Eidos
fields.trailText: Computer and media companies of the "new economy" may have ousted some traditional industrial empires from the FTSE index this month, but they seem to be lagging behind on modern notions of environmental responsibility.
fields.body:
Computer and media companies of the "new economy" may have ousted some traditional industrial empires from the FTSE index this month, but they seem to be lagging behind on modern notions of environmental responsibility.

Research published yesterday covering almost 700 leading companies shows that IT has the worst record of reporting environmental performance, while media companies do little better. Utilities report comprehensively on energy use, waste and pollution as do companies in mining, oil, steel, paper, chemicals and construction.

The research, by Pensions and Investment Research Consultants (Pirc), excludes the dot.com stocks which have joined the stock market only recently.

Some high-profile IT companies are among those identified as lagging behind best practice in this field. They include Psion, Eidos, FI Group and Sema. Among media companies, none of the expected environmental information was published by BSKyB, the Daily Mail group, EMAP, United News and Media, Cordiant and Saatchi and Saatchi.

Companies which failed to report are likely to be in the firing line from environment minister Michael Meacher. But Pirc's research reveals that there were only 61 standalone environment reports in 1999. Just over half the 674 companies surveyed failed to mention environmental policy.

fields.headline: Trying time for risk takers
fields.standfirst: Brand values - Lloyd's of London
fields.trailText: Lloyd's, the best known insurance name in the world, is on trial. And it is the name, the brand, of Lloyd's that is in the dock. More than 200 disgruntled investors are alleging in the high court they were duped into joining Lloyd's, which the market denies.
fields.body:
Lloyd's, the best known insurance name in the world, is on trial. And it is the name, the brand, of Lloyd's that is in the dock. More than 200 disgruntled investors are alleging in the high court they were duped into joining Lloyd's, which the market denies.

Central to the case is the emblem, the logo, of Lloyd's. This, said the investors' QC, Simon Goldblatt, on the first day of the hearing, was blazoned across promotional literature distributed in Britain and America.

It was this emblem the investors trusted, that persuaded them to sign up for the syndicates that back Lloyd's.

Because the value of that brand is so important to Lloyd's, it is taking the case seriously. The £51m owed to Lloyd's by the investors may be a mere bagatelle; the name of Lloyd's is anything but.

Former chief executive Ian Hay Davison has written: "I describe Lloyd's as a place. That is what it is: a room where the business of insurance is carried on."

True enough, but he wrote that in 1987. In today's wired-up world it is possible to imagine the "room" evaporating but Lloyd's marching on in cyberspace. Lloyd's is not an insurance company, nor even a market place, in the sense of a stock exchange or auction room.

It is a name, above all.

And while it is on trial in London, the Lloyd's brand is being promoted worldwide in the first concerted advertising campaign in the market's 400-year history. Brokers and the business community are the target of advertisements in the British and American trade press along with publications such as the Financial Times and the Economist. Results will be assessed in the summer before any further campaigns are undertaken.

Various versions of the Lloyd's logo have done the rounds, but the blue lettering with a gold line beneath is being promoted as the "classic look". And Lloyd's of London is, the only name of a City institution to have become a Hollywood film title, in the 1936 Tyrone Power production.

Elsewhere in American popular culture, the satirist Tom Lehrer sang in the 1960s that, in the event of a nuclear war: "No one will have the endurance/to collect on his insurance/Lloyd's of London will be loaded when they go."

Not so much of "of London", nowadays, however. Since 1996, the Lloyd's logo has been just that, although the "of London" is still used in text. Should the court case go against the market, cynics might conclude that, as with the old circumcision joke, they threw away the wrong bit.

What has not changed is the apostrophe, a survivor from the market's origins in Edward Lloyd's coffee house in the City in the late 17th century. Its benefit in terms of distinguishing Lloyd's from the venerable banking house at the sign of the black horse far outweighs the inability ever to use the genitive correctly, short of horrors such as "Lloyd's's chairman".

In terms of brand values, Lloyd's has hitherto survived on the basis of an unmatched reputation. In contrast to the stock exchange, for example - whose leading lights will cheerfully acknowledge the roguery and backstabbing of centuries past - the Lloyd's name has rested above all else on centuries of trust.

Technically, the principle underlying all insurance - uberrima fides - means simply that all parties to the transaction (particularly the insured) must act in "utmost good faith" by bringing to the table all relevant information, in contrast to the "buyer beware" school of thought. But at Lloyd's it has tended to mean much more.

That is why this is a case Lloyd's cannot afford to lose.

fields.headline: Making tracks for internet value
fields.trailText: It is the twilight hour of a brisk spring day and the following conversation has been overheard on a Connex South Central train.
fields.body:
It is the twilight hour of a brisk spring day and the following conversation has been overheard on a Connex South Central train.

Mr IN Money, a private investor.

Mr NO Idea, a professional fund manager with Poor Performance Asset Management.

Ms B Spark, IT analyst at Dotcoms'R'Us Securities.

Idea: Nearly there - only Friday to go.

Spark: Couldn't agree more, it's been a long week. We've done five internet IPOs in just four days! I need a break.

Money: Glad I've bumped into you two. (Idea and Spark inwardly cringe, as they fold their Evening Standards and feign interest) Now can you two professionals explain what is going on with these internet stocks? Last week I more than doubled my money on fastbuck.com, and now everybody is telling me the internet bubble is bursting.

Idea: Ah - this is the end of the internet bubble. At long last the market has come to its senses and firms that actually make things are being treated with respect once again - the old economy is back in fashion.

Money: But surely the power of the internet hasn't disappeared overnight?

Spark: Far from it. The internet will continue to alter the way business is done forever. Actually, Mr Idea has got it wrong. There never was an internet bubble! The valuations applied to some of these stocks have run ahead of themselves as investors have become carried away with the concepts, but the fundamentals remain sound.

Idea: Ha - fundamentals and internet stocks - that's an oxymoron. These stocks are on incredible multiples without showing any sign of profits. I can remember the days when you needed a solid set of accounts, not just a concept, before you floated!

Spark: So what was the stone age like? This is the information age. Sure Amazon.com may need 84% compound annual revenue growth over the next five years to justify current valuations but is that really unreasonable for a young company in a dynamic environment?

Idea: Yes!

Spark: Well take a look at the growth rates in the early days of some of the "old" tech stocks. In the five years following their IPO, Microsoft achieved 53% annual revenue growth, Dell 66%, Sun 85%, Oracle 111% and Cisco 114%. Suddenly 84% doesn't seem so extreme!

Idea: Nothing like picking the winners to illustrate your case. What about all the losers? For every Cisco there were a dozen others that destroyed shareholder value.

Spark: True - but picking the winners is what you and I get paid for.

Money: But how can I pick the winners?

Spark: Don't ask Idea. His performance has been fourth quartile for the last five years!

Idea: All right then, how do we pick the winners?

Spark: The same factors that determine winners today will still be important for the new economy.

Money: But I thought that the internet age was going to cause deflation. I keep reading about the death of the high street, so how can the same things that mattered for the old economy still apply in the new?

Idea: Right. I remember reading that the CDs and books were between 9% and 16% cheaper online than in the high street. How are these internet firms going to make profits with discounting like that?

Spark: It is certainly true that prices are lower on the net. But there is wide price dispersion. For instance, books show an average difference of 33% between the highest and lowest cost online providers. For CDs, the range is about 25%.

Money: So what?

Spark: The interesting thing is that the lowest cost providers don't have the largest market share. That's because trust and brand name are even more important in the internet age. Firms that capture the public's hearts and minds will prosper - hence all the TV advertising dot.com stocks are doing.

Money: Must admit I can see your point. Watching TV last night, every break had at least one dot.com advert.

(Idea nods grudgingly.)

Spark: Given these significant sunk costs are a barrier to entry into the market, profit margin erosion for these internet stocks will not be as severe as the bears imagine. Great news for earnings.

Idea: Of course, you could just be talking your own book. I bet your corporate finance department has got masses of dot.com flotations in the pipeline - you would be bullish, wouldn't you.

Spark: You could try asking our head of corporate finance - he is up in first class! Sure we have a few more still to be done, but research is independent, you know.

Idea: Ummmmmm.

Spark: Did you know that in the US between 1975 and 1998 only 39 IPOs doubled on their first day. In 1999, 117 did so. So far this year 43 have! It takes a brave man not to be interested in this market.

Money: What and when is your next float (pen in hand, ready to scribble on the edge of his newspaper)?

Mercifully for the rest of us, the train pulls into a station. Idea and Spark depart.

 James Montier is global strategist at Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Another day, another rollercoaster ride. City traders must have been wondering when the world would stop spinning and let them off.
fields.body:
Another day, another rollercoaster ride. City traders must have been wondering when the world would stop spinning and let them off.

The Footsie closed a little under a point higher at 6,558, having shot up 155 points at one stage and a few hours later almost touching the 6,500 barrier.

And what is powering this white-knuckled journey into the unknown? Why, it's the "new economy", of course.

The FTSE - and the Dow - had been through an extraordinary few days as investors lurched out of high-flying tech, media and telecoms stocks into value sectors before jumping back on the growth bandwagon.

So today you saw the Techmark index whiz up 60.6 points higher at 4,843.9. E-investment bank Durlacher jumped 345p higher at £26.50, chip maker Arm Holdings effortlessly floated up 110p to £40.74.

Those who fancied a bit of action should have focused on Baltimore Technologies , which started at £107.50, leapt to £118.50 and then drifted down to £108.25.

Some events were more explicable. Britain's biggest company, Vodafone , rose 18p after it was announced that the mobile phone group had secured 94.7% of acceptances from Mannesmann's shareholders. Telewest Communications was one of the biggest percentage gainers across Europe, jumping 10% to £4.26 ahead of results due next Thursday.

Media stocks were also back in favour, led by Carlton Communications , 44p higher at 771, with Daily Mail & General Trust up 53p at £12.24, Reuters up 43 at £12.94 and BSkyB 60p firmer at £18.48.

So we know where the money flew into, but where did it depart from?

Well, there were the consumer stocks - Unilever gave up 3.7%. Then there was the oil sector - BP Amoco fell 2.3% to 554p. And of course those on drugs - AstraZeneca slipped more than 5% to end at £25.81.

The heavy hand of the banking review knocked the stuffing out of much of the retail financial sector. Barclays lost 124p to £15.03 while Lloyds TSB closed down 20p at 601p.

But for "bricks and mortar" businesses, it was not all bad news. Robust full-year figures saw heating and building products group Hepworth close 8p higher at 163p. Anybody fancy a ticket for next week's ride?

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Some less than essential fiction amongst the essays, plus The First Casualty
fields.body:
The Essential Gore Vidal
Little, Brown, £15
Buy it at BOL

Contains fiction - drear sections labelled as invented, anyway, but we commend it for the essays. Eleanor Roosevelt caught freshening the gladdies by standing them in the loo. A spookily prescient 1967 piece about who gets to govern America, predicting an era of "smiling, interchangeable gods". (Yep.) Best, the astute analyses that develop, almost against Vidal's will, into grave praise for two underread heroes, the sage Montaigne, who met himself and everyone else on the road to wisdom (Monsieur M is Vidal's bedside tome, and ours); and the late Georgian satirical novelist Thomas Love Peacock, a wicked stylist, like Vidal himself. Suave as suede writing throughout.

The First Casualty
Philip Knightley
Prion, £12
Buy it at BOL

The history of war reporting, updated to take in the Gulf war vidgames and the Nato spinning of the Kosovo air campaign (it wasn't a war). Problematic: we have always accepted implicitly Knightley's revelations about the sharp end press, from Russell of the Times, who never did get the hang of the newfangled telegraph, through to Don McCullin, bumped off the Falklands invasion fleet passenger list as the MoD feared his eye and lens. And yet - Knightley's account of Kosovo doesn't read any more like that place than did last year's Brit hack-pack stories. Which makes the book a lesson in scepticism to the very end, just as Knightley would wish it to be.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The polished tones of TV anchorman Barry Norman can't hide the danger behind the heroism of pararescue jumpers
fields.body:
That Others May Live
Jack Brehm and Pete Nelson
Random House, £12.99, 300 mn

It's the motto of the pararescue jumpers (PJs), a US air force unit. In wartime they rescue downed pilots. In peace, they are coastguard/mountain rescue corps. Veteran Jack Brehm survived as a PJ into his 40s, long after most call it a day, or die. He's written his story with a journalist, telling it in the third person.

It's usually better to hear such terrifying deeds from the subject who did them rather than, as here, via the polished, newscaster tones of Barry Nolan, a US telly anchorman. Brehm almost dies during his maiden mission when he is accidentally winched down into the funnel of a pitching cargo ship, and his career climaxes with the rescue of the downed pilot of the stealth bomber in Kosovo. Two shameful facts about these men stick in the memory: they are paid a pittance, and only one in a 1,000 rescued civilians contacts them afterwards to say thank you.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A soppy tale for those who have swapped nights out for nappies, plus The Island Of The Women And Other Stories, Other Stories And Other Stories and The Plato Papers
fields.body:
Man And Boy
Tony Parsons
Harper Collins, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

This book is so soppy that I thought I would need a six-pack of Kleenex to mop up the tears; New Man size, naturally. Parsons is from the generation that hugged babies as it shaved and his first novel will appeal to those who have swapped singletons' nights out for teething and toys at home. Everything is going well for Harry Silver; he has married his perfect girl and produced a blond angel, Pat, as well as a popular TV show. Then he does something very stupid with a television researcher and is left holding the baby. You can't fault Parsons for putting his heart into his narrative and the writing is zippy, but my tissue remained bone dry.

The Island Of The Women And Other Stories
George Mackay Brown
John Murray, £9.99

Six novellas which draw the reader towards Mackay Brown's Orkney, this collection is beautifully simple but never simplistic. The title story sets the tone with its uncluttered style and repetition reminiscent of oral storytelling. A young noble woman has to choose a husband from the rich suitors who make their way to her father's house, but she has given her heart to the prince of the seals. Maidens, voyages, shepherds, chiefs and poets are the stuff of these stories, in language which is truly magical. Fairytales and legends for grownups, but flights of fantasy firmly grounded in age-old realities.

Other Stories And Other Stories
Ali Smith
Granta, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

For once a truly apposite epigraph: "Everyone, real or invented, deserves the open destiny of life." Smith takes Grace Paley's words as the core of these snippets of life, suffused with alternating shafts of brightness and shadow. Built around duets, often of couples but also between strangers, each of these dozen stories deals with lives that touch and then pull apart. Smith writes delicately and she breathes life gently into her imagined worlds with a true understanding of the craft of the short-story writer. Too often short stories are crudely mechanical exercises for effect; Smith, however, dances surely and lightly over the form.

The Plato Papers
Peter Ackroyd
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

More Londoniana from Ackroyd, who for this time trip goes forward a couple of millennia and a half, but takes Plato as his guide. Like all exercises in futurology, the interpretation of the past is what makes it fun. The philosopher has taken the job of orator and attracts crowds of Londoners to his lectures on life in the age of Mouldwarp, c.AD1500-2300. He tells of a great comic masterpiece, The Origin Of The Species, written by Charles Dickens, and produces a dictionary of definitions for a lost civilisation until his soul takes him on a journey to the underworld of the past. Amusing, but Ackroyd marking time.

fields.headline: Ode to a nightingale
fields.trailText:
When one joked

she laughed

when the other
danced with her
she crooned in his ear...
fields.body:
When one joked
she laughed
when the other
danced with her
she crooned in his ear
songs about booze
and forest murmurs
and flowers-in-the-nose
unseen in the dark.

At her door
she kissed them both
first one
who laughed again
then the other
who experienced
a moment of blackout
kiss kiss
goodbye
to comrades in arms
veterans
of magic casements.

fields.headline: View from Aunt Augustine's porch
fields.standfirst: Nick Hasted goes hunting for ghosts with Ernest Gaines in altered Southern states
fields.trailText: Nick Hasted goes hunting for ghosts with Ernest Gaines in altered Southern states
fields.body:
In 1948, aged 14, Ernest Gaines left the Louisiana plantation where his family had lived since slavery, to follow his mother and stepfather to California. Family and friends, the only people he had ever known, waved him away from his Aunt Augustine's porch and the moment froze in his memory like a photograph, a picture of a vanished time.

His Aunt, a cripple who could only move by crawling like a baby, but who raised him without complaint, died before seeing him again. In his absence, the exhausting manual harvesting of the plantation by its black tenants, only subtly altered in a century, was squashed by mechanisation. The buildings, the life, even the people he had known were erased, as if they had never been. But Ernest Gaines held that last, lost moment close.

It was his fourth novel, The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman (1971), the "memoirs" of a tough-minded 110-year-old from slavery to civil rights, later filmed for American TV, that made him loved in the US. A Lesson Before Dying (1993), about bitter black school-teacher Grant Wiggins, longing to leave his Louisiana community in the 40s, held back by an aunt in order to save a Death Row man's soul, is his latest, million-selling book.

But it is a scene in his most recent UK publication, A Gathering of Old Men (US, 1983) that defines Gaines's work best. It is set, like all his novels, in Bayonne, his fictional version of his birthplace. A group of elderly black men and women are confronting an ageing white sheriff with old sins at the end of the 70s, refusing to go quietly. They repeat an incantation, "You don't see what we don't see"; they stare hard at the places where companions, shacks, lives once were, until they can see them in the empty space - raised, remembered ghosts.

Ernest Gaines, who now lives only 50 miles from his heartland, tends its cemetery and walks its grounds, can raise ghosts, too, writing books each summer away in San Francisco. Staring at a blank wall, he recalls the past. He once left for a better life as Grant Wiggins desired to do. But unlike his character, he feels no shame. "All my writing is about that place, and people like my aunt, so I didn't betray them," he says in a Louisiana twang. "Without them, I would be no writer, because I cannot imagine anything else. I've tried to write about California, but nothing has come of it. My body was there, but my soul was not. The old place is all I can write about."

It is in the cemetery of often unmarked graves that Gaines's bond to the past feels most sacred. "That's the thing that draws me, because my people's spirit is there, their dust and bones. When I was researching A Gathering of Old Men, I talked to people who had known my grandparents' grandparents, known slaves. And when I was a child, so much that I experienced was not too different from what my people had gone through then.

"One of the things I tell young African-American writers is that our lives did not begin in the ghettos. We were brought here to work on the plantations, in the rural South, and these things are worth writing about, too. But I had no intention of recording that past when I started writing. Because I did not know then that it would go away."

Much as he loved his home, Gaines knew that if he did not leave while young, it would destroy him. Though his own community felt safe, every contact with whites was a spirit-sapping ritual of averted eyes, absent rights, humiliation. Those who stayed bent to those rules, or broke. Almost all the men he knew have died, many violently. A Gathering of Old Men imagines that generation standing tall, for one day. Like all his work, it shows how they could have lived, not how they did.

The Californian town he went to was a disorienting dream, an integrated, migrant community. Most vital to him, though, coming from a place with no book but the Bible, was its library. "It changed my world," he remembers. "I was a lonely kid. I'd sit there for hours. At first I picked up books indiscriminately, then after a while I found I liked Russian novelists, because they wrote about peasant life, which felt akin to what I'd known. It stirred something in me. And after a while, I took the pencil and the paper, and started to write about my background."

Education at Stanford, especially in Wallace Stegner's legendary course for burgeoning novelists - where his classmates included Ken Kesey and Robert Stone - added to his self-belief. There, post-Beat, he was a bohemian. But he never wavered from his theme: the Southern past. It is an uncomfortable subject for many Americans. In period films and TV now, the young are shown black people more assertive, more central than they could really have been, racism reduced.

Gaines will not go that far. "Even back in the 60s, I was told they were tired of being reminded about the plantations," he says. "I know it can be hard for some people, black and white, they don't want to remember. Before, people had refused to discuss those times - in writing, even in their homes. I did not want to school anybody. I just felt there were stories I could tell."

fields.headline: A room full of emptiness
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  enters Rodinsky's Room and finds its secret
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard enters Rodinsky's Room and finds its secret
fields.body:
Rodinsky's Room
Rachel Lichtenstein and Iain Sinclair
Granta, £8.99
Buy it at BOL

A decrepit Jew lives in a single room in Spitalfields, above a synagogue. One day he leaves his room. He never comes back. The room stays locked for over a decade; when it is opened in 1980, it vibrates with absence. Notebooks and diaries indicate that their keeper knew over a dozen languages, most of them dead. Cabbalistic diagrams taunt the uninitiated. A copy of the A-Z is marked with routes. Of walks taken, or of walks that are yet to be taken? Everything, apart from the thick layer of dust that has settled over the years, is as it was, only waiting for interpretation, for explanation.

"The whole world," as we are reminded, is, according to the Talmud, a "mass of sealed words and hidden things". What is Rodinsky's secret? Was he one of the 36 just men, the unknown righteous whose good works alone keep the world from being destroyed? Had he achieved the cabbalistic secret of invisibility? Was he now a golem, "that which has been banished," as Sinclair puts it, "an atavistic cartoon... the ugly shape of something that has gone and cannot be recalled"? Or is he now something else: "Rodinsky, the idea of Rodinsky , had become a dybbuk. The soul of a dead person who enters the body of a living human and directs their conduct."

As you can see, there is plenty here for Iain Sinclair, psychogeographer and writer (not to mention a whole legion of trades, abilities, data, and confluences) to go "woo!" at us with. Too much, perhaps, too tempting for someone whose trademark style, or way of thinking, combines both apocalyptic mysticism and hard-boiled legwork. (There is a phonic similarity - which no-one picks up on, probably because it is, well, too phoney - between "shamus", Chandlerese for a detective, and shames, the caretaker of a synagogue.)

This is "material that operates like the shorthand summary of a Paul Auster novel," he says, and, in a sentence that can sum up the entire genre, "Projected mysteries that become actual."

So he doesn't really tell the story: he comments on it, frames it, but gradually drops out of it, in chapters he alternates with Rachel Lichtenstein, whose book this really is. An artist born shortly after Rodinsky died, she became obsessed by his story, the unspoken narrative. She was the living human whose soul had been taken over, if we allow for a certain metaphorical tweaking; and in discovering Rodinsky's identity and fate she learns about, and indeed influences, her own.

This is a biography whose subject is not there; it is the real-life counterpart to Perec's La Disparition, the novel written without the letter "e". Like that work, this one is really about Jewish disappearances, one of which will always be the exterminations and flight from Europe; and the other, from East London to - well, take your pick - Golders Green, Hendon, those places within the 'eruv' of the M25. Lichtenstein's journey takes her further: to Israel, to Poland, particularly Krakow (where, a decade ago, I had the most haunting moment of my life to date, catching the eye of what looked like the oldest, most ghostly human beings on earth, the last orthodox inhabitants of the Jewish ghetto, survivors against surely impossible odds), to her own tangled heritage.

As you can see, this is a rather special book, which at times seems to verge on its own disappearance. We are somewhere "between Welfare State poverty fable and Dostoevskian myth", the book's bathos part of its ambiguous message.

fields.headline: Role play
fields.standfirst: Doctors, royalty, gods, the opposite sex - Alex Clark  on being someone else
fields.trailText: Doctors, royalty, gods, the opposite sex - Alex Clark on being someone else
fields.body:
Impostors: Six Kinds of Liar - True Tales of Deception by Sarah Burton 246pp, Viking, £15.99

Have you ever, as the wine begins to take hold and your companions' faces blur into one another, invented a fragment of your past? A fantastic strand of personal history that, at the merest hint of investigation, would reveal itself to be an ego-massaging piece of invention? Do you, lying in your tepid bath, project yourself into the role of explorer, adventurer, doctor, soldier? Or have you simply wished for a different identity, anything that would relieve you of the intolerable burden of having to spend another day as yourself?

It would be an unusual - and, more to the point, unbearable - character who could truthfully answer no to any or all of these questions. Most of us have at one time or another yielded to the seductive charm of image manipulation, or have toyed with the possibility that we could, in fiction if not in fact, be someone else.

Just as, when the latest serial killer hits the headlines, we shudder as we recognise our own murderous impulses, tales of impostors chime with our suppressed attraction to shape-shifting. But most of us don't deliberately assume another identity, just as we don't take to interring people beneath our floorboards. Impostors, an account of those lost souls who instead of embroidering their lives have radically restitched them, attempts to work out what provokes such a manic display of wholesale reinvention.

The first stage in the process is to perform a kind of taxonomy. Thus, in these pages, we have various groups of impostors, ranging broadly from the fantasists, such as Louis de Rougemont, whose invented histories are so bizarre and incredible that they appear to invite unmasking, to those more pragmatically inclined pretenders - women, for example, passing themselves off as men in order to pursue lives as doctors, sailors and soldiers - who were simply trying to escape the constraints of the hand that life had dealt them.

Sarah Burton uses Louis de Rougemont to open her book, for the good reason that his deception makes highly entertaining reading. It also illustrates the point that often a mere cigarette paper separates the con artist from the lunatic. In the 1890s de Rougemont wowed the readers of Wide World magazine with his tales of three decades lived, after death-defying shipwreck and a brief Crusoe-style sojourn on a deserted island, among an Australian tribe. Its members believed him to be a god - with the exception of his wife, Yamba, who knew him to be mortal but loved him all the same.

One of de Rougemont's tactics was self-deprecation. He constantly drew attention to the strain caused by having to masquerade as a divine being, asking his readers to empathise with his frequent sleights of hand, such as furtively removing the poisonous fangs of snakes in order to "survive" their bites later. It appears to rely heavily on secondary sources, ending up as a superior cut-and-paste job; Demara's life, for example, has already been the subject of one biography and an extensive feature in Life. The book also tells us little of what really goes on in someone's head as they prepare, in that melodramatic phrase, "to live a lie"; nor, aside from the practical considerations, of what benefits such deception yields. It can't all be jam, after all.

My favourite character in the book is a hapless chap (British, naturally) who, along with a host of others, pretended to be the "lost Dauphin", son of Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette. Augustus Meves was busy spinning his tale when he was brought face to face with another Dauphin wannabe, Karl Naundorff. At which point he "became so confused by questions of identity that, on meeting Naundorff, he mistook him for himself, and was shortly afterwards certified as insane". Which just goes to show: you can't kid a kidder.

fields.headline: Cold comfort culture
fields.standfirst: Is Nobrow the end of elitism, or corporate exploitation?
fields.trailText: Is Nobrow the end of elitism, or corporate exploitation?
fields.body:
Nobrow by John Seabrook 215pp, Methuen, £9.99

John Seabrook is the sort of author who grates slightly. In his 30s, he is already contracted to the New Yorker, the revered and prosperous American magazine so envied - without being much read - by foreign journalists. He shops in Manhattan boutiques, he tells us here, and spends deliciously drawn-out afternoons looking for "good tomatoes". And he specialises in books of a certain elegance and shallowness.

Seabrook's method is to take a topical matter - in 1997 it was life on the internet, this time it is the triumph of the entertainment corporations - and subject it to refined and leisurely analysis. He quotes philosophers. He does a few interviews. He goes to a few symbolic places (which, quite often, happen to be in Manhattan). Most of all, in smooth, self-deprecating sentences, he writes about himself.

Some parts of this book concern the New Yorker and Seabrook's career there. Others are simply his New Yorker articles, slightly adapted. And the linking sections in between, often as not, concern how he felt during these assignments, or how he went about doing them. You could call this narcissism or highly professional recycling, but Seabrook has a grander purpose. His recent working life, he suggests, is the embodiment of a great change in the culture around him: the arrival of "nobrow".

Until the 90s, his argument goes, American culture was still firmly divided between "highbrow" and "lowbrow". Highbrow was paintings and theatre; lowbrow was movies and pop music. What kept them separate was social hierarchy: in the absence of an acknowledged class system, posh Americans defined themselves - and other Americans aspired to redefine themselves - by putting on their smartest clothes and going to Shakespeare festivals.

Then they stopped. Or at least, Seabrook did: "At the age of 31, the stream of culture as it flowed through me slowed, stopped, and started moving in the other direction... Pop music provided me with peaks of lyricism and transcendence that I long ago stopped feeling at the opera and the symphony." He began wearing Chemical Brothers T-shirts to lunch with his dad.

What caused Seabrook to abandon his family's traditions of tailored suits, "taste" and no television was the sparkly lure of showbusiness. Not the old sort, which had coexisted with "high" culture for decades and at times had sought to imitate it - rock bands attempting cod-classical works during the 70s and the like - but a new, all-consuming sort of showbiz called "nobrow" that drew no distinction between novelists and nodding bass players, and was simply interested in making money from both. Rupert Murdoch's enterprises, or one of the ever-swelling American cultural conglomerates, might be the best example of this; yet Seabrook, being Seabrook, picks his own employer.

His portrait of the New Yorker 's shift during the 90s from a fusty chronicler of provincial Americana to a trend-chasing tip sheet for urban consumers is alive with well-caught details. There is his first editor, donnishly accepting an idea for an immense article on gold mining: "'Oh, we don't have deadlines round here,' Gottlieb said, as if a faux pas had been committed." And there is Seabrook's next editor, Tina Brown, simultaneously commissioning articles while courting their celebrity subjects - once with Seabrook and his potential interviewee, an owner of casinos, both sitting in her office. The interweaving of analysis and autobiography is deft, as the magazine's better pieces always are.

But the actual arguments, after a while, begin to stall. Were American high and low culture ever as separate as he makes out? Tweedy American academics such as Greil Marcus have been enthusing about pop music for decades now, while poor black teenagers have long been borrowing bits of Ivy League style. Seabrook also makes much of the speed with which celebrities can be constructed nowadays. But is that really new? Or is it just that America, a vast spread-out country where reputations used to travel slowly, has finally caught up with more urbanised, gossipy societies? Before MTV and the internet, names could still be made in weeks or days with a few evenings' notoriety on a London stage.

The more academic chapters here, for all Seabrook's erudition and slickness, get a little coiled-up and laboured. This is often the downside of New Yorker writing, new and old: every logical leap is clarified in plain, almost folksy language. If you disagree or get impatient, it can feel like being locked in a classroom.

The last third of the book, thankfully, is more of a field trip. Seabrook leaves his own life and Manhattan behind, and explores the cold new territories where "nobrow" products are grown. At Skywalker Ranch, the Californian headquarters of the Star Wars industry, the saga's creator George Lucas works two days a week, looking out on vineyards and reproduction farm buildings - while his underlings stare at computers in a windowless basement. Seabrook meets an anonymous program-tester with Repetitive Strain Injury: one day into a two-month stretch of continuous typing, just enough of her fingers to reach the keyboard are left free of bandages.

She does not complain, though. And as Seabrook meets other such cultural labourers, their bosses in their hilltop mansions and the apologists and evangelists for "nobrow" at a creepy conference held at the Disney Institute, the lack of self-analysis in this new industry chills each encounter. To the entertainment corporations, relentless effort and commercial reward are all. Interventions by outsiders, such as critical reviews or uncontrolled interviews, are old-fashioned and unwelcome.

The author is one of those dissidents, it seems clear by the end. "It really is appalling, when you think of it," he blurts out on escaping Skywalker Ranch. On the last page Seabrook stands shivering at the foot of the New Yorker 's new steel-grey office tower, like the disillusioned narrator of an allegorical novel, and declares that "the last notions about editorial independence" are "entombed" above him. It makes a potent final scene. Until he thanks George Lucas and Tina Brown in his acknowledgments.

webTitle: How Grisha the fool ended an empire

fields.headline: How Grisha the fool ended an empire
fields.standfirst: With material from a newly discovered file, Edvard Radzinsky delivers the final word on Rasputin
fields.trailText: With material from a newly discovered file, Edvard Radzinsky delivers the final word on Rasputin
fields.body:
Rasputin: The Last Word
Edvard Radzinsky
Weidenfeld, £20, 524pp

Radzinsky's biography of the "mad monk" Rasputin begins with a cast list, a necessary point of reference in this detailed re-examination of the infamous anti-hero of the last days of the Russian tsars. The names are familiar - Nicholas and Alexandra, the last Romanovs, their haemophiliac son Alexei (or "Sunbeam", as his doting mother called him) and, of course, Grigory Rasputin, or Grisha to his friends.

As the much picked-over tale of the fall of the Romanovs has it, the licentious Rasputin used his uncanny powers to staunch young Alexei's bleeding to inveigle his way to the throne. Alexandra's belief in him and her domination of her weak-willed husband meant that she and her lover became the rulers of the Russian Empire in its last chaotic days. By the time his enemies had finally poisoned, shot and thrown this still struggling diabolic creature into the icy waters of Petrograd, it was too late. In the words of Kerensky, prime minister after the February Revolution: "Without Rasputin, there would have been no Lenin."

As in all legends, there is truth mixed in with melodrama, and even sober histories of the Russian revolutions cannot dismiss as fanciful gossip the fantastical stories of Rasputin's debauchery and drinking. The Siberian peasant with the hypnotic gaze attracted a gaggle of ladies who showed their devotion by sewing his nail clippings to their underwear. When Nicholas was away presiding over the Russian army's disastrous campaigns, he and the tsarina conspired to replace government ministers with people willing to share Alexandra's belief that her trusted "holy fool" was an envoy from God.

However, as Radzinsky demonstrates, Rasputin was more complex and more substantial than the myths that grew up around him. To understand how a semi-literate peasant came to be vilified as the satanic force respon sible for ending 300 years of Romanov rule, one must look beyond his relationship with the "Mama and Papa" of the Russian people and examine the complex loyalties and animosities of the grand dukes and duchesses, the role of secret policemen and clerics as well as the nature of Russian spirituality.

The "mad monk" of pop history was never a monk, nor was he in any medical sense mad. His was a peculiar, but not uncommon, religious fervour with deep historical roots in peasant distrust of official Russian Orthodoxy and a mystical belief in the ruler's bonds with the common people. Born into a peasant family less than a decade after Alexander II had abolished serfdom, he was known to fellow villagers as "Grisha the fool" until, at the age of 28, he left his home and began wandering from monastery to monastery in search of spiritual enlightenment.

Rasputin's quest was not unusual; nor was the fact that he was drawn to sectarianism, which had, by the end of the 19th century, become all-pervasive. He became involved with the Khlysti, a sect that believed they could become closer to God through group sex; in 1903 he was denounced, but had already attracted powerful devotees who protected him from persecution. Escaping official condemnation, this "man of God" made his way to St Petersburg and, by the end of the year, was being received in the houses of the tsar's relatives.

Before Rasputin, Alexandra had received "Mitya the nasal voiced" and "Matryona the barefoot"; Rasputin was merely the last and most favoured of a quartet of "holy fools" or "elders" who provided spiritual sustenance and a supposed link to the common people.

Radzinsky centres his biography on a newly discovered file, a record of an investigation into Rasputin which contains testimony gathered by a government commission in March 1917. Radzinsky believes it to be the missing piece of the historical jigsaw that allows him to write "the last word" on Rasputin. It contains reports from secret policemen, depositions by monks who met him during his wanderings and testimony from the coterie of high-born St Petersburg women who became Rasputin's apostles and probably his lovers.

One of Russia's best-known dramatists, Radzinsky recounts Rasputin's story with an unerring sense of the theatrical and an atmospheric evocation of the court. His conversational, occasionally florid style might irritate those seeking a scholarly tome (as does the lack of footnotes and the absence of attribution for quotes), but this is an immensely readable and gripping bedside history.

The author of hugely successful biographies of Nicholas and Alexandra and Stalin, Radzinsky knows the period well; he delves far deeper into the enigma of Rasputin than his predecessors, and provides new evidence on how Rasputin met his death. Holy man or sinner? A cause of the revolution or merely a symptom of the rot? For Radzinsky, Rasputin is all of these, as well as a uniquely Russian manifestation of religious belief.

Henry MacDonald must have chewed his fingernails over when to end this interim biography, opting finally for November 1999 and the gamble of setting up Ulster's devolved government in hopes that the IRA would decommission weapons by March.

David Trimble - as is now brutally clear - put himself on the line by offering his Unionist colleagues a postdated letter of resignation if that didn't happen. The result, of course, is that his position has been safeguarded only by the suspension of the executive: "The End" cannot be written yet. But the decommissioning issue was looming inexorably very early on: it was always the ghost at the unlikely love feast of Republicans and Unionists. Or, as opera-freak Trimble might prefer, the Commendatore's statue knocking at the door.

MacDonald's Trimble is not exactly Don Giovanni, but he emerges as an unpredictable and talented man. The author's stance is firmly pro-Trimble throughout; still, many of his judgments carry the impartial conviction of the experienced journalist he is (the IRA's attempts to claim parallels with South Africa are scathingly dismissed in favour of less welcome assonances with the situation in Israel or Serbia).

He is good on Trimble's rise from speccy nerd in Air Force Training Corps photos, encumbered by the class-ridden baggage of a petit-bourgeois Ulster Protestant background, through reactionary Unionist to trailblazing moderate. Personal touches are few, apart from a delectable interview with an ex-brother-in-law from Trimble's first, failed marriage to someone bearing the quintessential Irish-Protestant name of Heather.

The brother-in-law turns out to be "ex" in more than one sense; thanks to a sex-change he is now an ex-sister-in-law called Tina. Tina's description of that first wedding is vintage stuff, suggesting that Northern Ireland badly needs its Alan Bennett. Trimble is now happily married to an equally inevitable "Daphne". It is clear that much of his career has involved learning from early mistakes, and sharply changing direction.

Thus he shifted from civil service apprenticeship into academe, via the impressive feat of achieving a first-class degree by studying part time at Queen's. MacDonald convincingly portrays him as a classic academic in politics. But there are aspects of his past which always threaten to do a Commendatore, one of them being his membership of Vanguard - the extreme Unionist group set up by William Craig in the mid-1970s, which attacked modernising Unionists such as O'Neill and Faulkner as "quislings", and paraded in public with a sinister paramilitary back-up.

Trimble was also a vociferous know-nothing rejectionist of the 1973 Sunningdale agreement, the last attempt to set up a power-sharing devolved government for the province. MacDonald gives every excuse for Trimble, who was old enough, and certainly intelligent enough, to know better. It is one of several hostages to fortune given early in his career - making excuses for anti-constitutional action, describing negotiation with nationalists as "contamination" and, above all, his triumphalist Orange march hand in hand with Ian Paisley at Portadown in 1995.

Of course, if you believe that he was a closet moderniser all along, you will read this as Trimble cleverly manoeuvring himself into a position to wrest the leadership from the antediluvian lizard-figure of Wee Jim Molyneaux - which could only be done from the right of the party, rather than (as John Taylor seemed to promise) the moderate left. Once ensconced, Trimble could set about ridding Unionism of its prehensile tail.

MacDonald reveals that Trimble seized Paisley's hand on that fateful day simply to stop the Big Man invading his political turf and monopolising it. This may be so, but the overall portrait suggests something less calculating: a process of self-education on the hoof rather than a Machiavellian game plan. Trimble is always the autodidact, always the university lecturer: even in his Vanguard days he was still handing out texts (Hueston's essays on constitutional law) to his no doubt incredulous comrades.

The Machiavelli theme is provided, in this treatment, by his tutors: clever journalists and ingenious academics such as Ruth Dudley Edwards, Paul Bew, Eoghan Harris and Sean O'Callaghan - ex-Marxists, southerners, sophisticates from a very different world. Trimble himself learns to "spin", contributing anonymously to Fortnight magazine in its glory days as "Calvin McNee". Seamus Mallon's acid quip that the 1998 Good Friday agreement was "Sunningdale for slow learners" might have been coined specifically for Trimble.

But MacDonald also shows how far back Trimble's links with Blair go, and how early he spotted New Labour's impatience with the sentimental knee-jerk Republican assumptions of their predecessors. He also spotted an even more vital shift in attitudes: the new-look Irish Republic's devout wish to distance itself from anything like a United Ireland, which was subsequently proved by the near-unanimous referendum to change the constitutional articles claiming the territory of the North.

The Armani-suited Sinn Feiners may have been slower on the uptake than the distinctly un-soigné law lecturer. In MacDonald's reading, Sinn Fein went along with the negotiations on the assumption that the Unionists would wreck them - and found themselves finessed into underwriting a solidly Partitionist agreement.

This makes a certain sense, without necessarily implying that the Republicans then fell back on a hard line against decommissioning in order to extricate themselves. The interesting point is that Trimble, unlike many of his allies, is a realist who spotted both the illogic of integrationism Molyneaux-style and the irrelevance of United Irelandism to Dublin's Celtic Tiger cubs.

Moreover he is, by Ulster standards, a secularist: one of MacDonald's most unintentionally hilarious interviews is with a local clergyman determined to claim a deeply religious motivation for Trimble, against all the evidence. His Nobel speech, after all, not only admitted that Unionism had built "a cold house for Catholics" but also invoked Amos Oz, Edmund Burke and George Kennan rather than any of Unionism's traditional household gods.

He is still the academic with the shambolic desk, still handing out reading assignments - although nowadays that means giving the US President Malachi O'Doherty's The Trouble With Guns, a highly intelligent critique by a disaffected Republican. And he retains an academic propensity to see the other person's side of the question, both a strength and - when dealing with ambitious dissidents such as Jeffrey Donaldson - a weakness. Towards his conclusion, MacDonald quotes (rather too often) the dictum of another Italian prince, the hero of di Lampedusa's The Leopard: things must change in order to remain the same. This book is published at a time when it is not yet clear if both sides in Northern Ireland realise that it is also desirable for things to change in order to become different.

fields.headline: Artist of the floating world
fields.standfirst: Liz Jobey  discovers the life and work of a photographer of fleeting moments in What Was True
fields.trailText: Liz Jobey discovers the life and work of a photographer of fleeting moments in What Was True
fields.body:
What Was True: The Photographs and Notebooks of William Gedney
ed Margaret Sartor and Geoff Dyer
WW Norton, £23, 192pp
Buy it at BOL

Unlike the history of painting and sculpture, the history of photography has been only fitfully assembled, with many gaps and omissions, some only now being filled. Often the salvage work has been done by other photographers. After the death of Atget in 1927, the American photographer Berenice Abbott, then a pupil and girlfriend of Man Ray, bought thousands of his glass-plate negatives and prints. She later sold them to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, thus providing them with an archive of one of the greatest photographers.

Thirty years later, Lee Friedlander, who would himself become one of the great American photographers, discovered the glass-plate negatives of EJ Bellocq, whose 1912 pictures of prostitutes in Storyville, the red-light district of New Orleans, are some of the most mysterious and beautiful photographic portraits ever made. Friedlander bought the plates and printed a number of them (there were no existing Bellocq prints); they were exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art in 1970. Now another body of pictures, this time by a little-known American photographer, William Gedney, has found an audience with this book and an exhibition currently at the Museum of Modern Art in San Francisco.

It was not that Gedney was totally unknown or unexhibited before his death from Aids in 1989. In fact, he had what would generally be considered auspicious beginnings. He started taking photographs in the mid-50s after studying graphics at the Pratt Institute in New York. His early pictures - of his Brooklyn home and of Kentucky, where for 11 productive days in 1964 he stayed with a poor white family, the Cornetts - were praised by Szarkowski and helped him to a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1966-7.

His intention - to travel across the country making "Photographic Studies of American Life" - linked him not only to Walker Evans, whose American Photographs is one of the most influential photography books of the 20th century, but also to Robert Frank, who had set out a decade earlier funded by the same fellowship and returned with the photographs that made up The Americans.

Gedney could hardly fail to be influenced by both. His graceful black and white photographs come out of an earlier, more accepting era than today, when photography is dedicated to colour and the constructed ironies of conceptual art, but he was just as concerned with the question of art. He spent most of 1966-7 living with a group of hippies in Haight-Ashbury and planning a book of pictures tentatively called A Time of Youth.

"I am attempting a literary form in visual terms," he wrote. "I am telling a story with characters that reappear and scenes that are repeated." In this sense his project had similarities with Larry Clark's Tulsa and Danny Lyon's Bikeriders - the kind of stories in which the photographer has to be both emotionally involved with his subjects and detached at the same time.

Physical proximity wasn't a problem - the hippies were inert for a lot of the time, smoking dope, sleeping, tripping, making love - but he couldn't photograph inside their heads. "The book is weak in the nightmare area," he wrote in March 1969, "section number 5, the drug scene, the sexual escape, the freakout scene, the despair. It is understressed, but I don't have the pictures to do it properly... so much of the drug thing is interior, with very little exterior effects anyway. It is a mind thing, and hard to show visually (at least the psychedelic drugs). I think with hard drugs it is easier to show." And then, "But perhaps the dramatic structure of the book is close to life, the dramatic moments are brief and few in anyone's life."

A photographer who keeps notes offers a rare opportunity to understand more about his work on a literal as well as a visual level, and possibly allows a more intimate glimpse into his life. But Gedney's notebooks are not so much diaries as compilations of quotations which, presumably, he felt expressed his thoughts and feelings more eloquently than he could himself. There are only a few brief glimpses into his inner thoughts, but what comes across strongly is a delicate, tender, very private person who was perhaps obsessively perfectionist. You can feel the burden of sensory overload, of a man who thought and read too much and whose output was correspondingly reduced.

In the winter of 1968-9, Gedney had a one-man exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art; the reviews were good, but he seemed to care little for fame. In his essay, Geoff Dyer quotes Gedney's reaction to the New York Times art critic John Canaday, who found the photographs "so moving as human documents and so satisfying aesthetically (with no dividing line between those qualities) that I should think any painter who sees them must weep for his art's lost birthright." Gedney wrote: "Compliments even from someone you admire (most are from fools and not meant) warm you for about one minute and then mean nothing. The work in progress is the only thing that matters."

He never had another solo exhibition. In 1972 he went back to his Kentucky family, the Cornetts and their 12 children, and took some of his finest photographs. He was sensitive to the slight involuntary gestures that give away the emotional life. His photographs are often unresolved - they catch a fleeting moment, a chewing of the lip, a tentative touch, an embarrassed fingertip tracing the metal grille of a Chevrolet.

The life and art of his pictures is found in the everyday rhythms which play across the entire area of the frame. Sometimes the figures form a circle, with Gedney on the periphery. "Loneliness and the sensuality of the human figure, tied to the sublime, were his true subjects," wrote the photographer Ragliubir Singh, who became Gedney's friend when he travelled to India in 1969 and 1979, taking the photographs that he was printing and editing until his death.

Geoff Dyer, who spent months poring over Gedney's photographs and notebooks, has distilled the essence of Gedney's writings and photographs into a sympathetic essay which treats his inability to finish with a good deal of understanding. "He kept trying to refine his work down," Dyer writes, "selecting and rejecting, rejecting what he had selected - but could never edit it down quite enough. No finished form could do justice to what he had in mind. To complete was to compromise."

fields.headline: Homecoming dreams
fields.standfirst: Linda Grant's When I Lived In Modern Times follows a young hairdresser searching for her identity after the war in Palestine
fields.trailText: Linda Grant's When I Lived In Modern Times follows a young hairdresser searching for her identity after the war in Palestine
fields.body:
When I Lived In Modern Times
Linda Grant
Granta, £15.99, 272pp
Buy it at BOL

In the broadest sense, this novel succeeds. It has an overwhelming sense of rawness and is flawed but passionate, echoing its theme - the early, often violent struggle to establish a Jewish homeland. The action is set largely in Palestine in 1946, a country ruled by a weary British mandate and the place where displaced Jews have come together to create the new Zion.

Evelyn Sert is a 20-year-old hairdresser from Soho, "a girl without a past" who wants to be a new Jew and a new woman. Her introduction to the Mecca where all this is possible is a kibbutz where she is put to hosing down the lavatories, discovers the boredom of joyless sex and realises that this is no place for the liberation of the spirit. She makes for the gleaming white Bauhaus city of Tel Aviv - the city for which the Jews have been waiting for centuries.

Like everyone else there, she is a displaced person. Born in a home for Jewish wayward women (her immigrant mother Miriam had been seduced by dreams of Hollywood in the shape of an American who smartly left her), she has grown up in a higgledy-piggledy flat set up by Miriam's protector, "Uncle Joe". Mother and daughter are inseparable, sharing secrets and ABC Tea Room buns, while Miriam, adept in a mistress's wiles, is always alluringly dressed and perfumed, ready for her lover's visits.

When Miriam dies, Evelyn is kindly but firmly advised (and financed) by Uncle Joe to make a new life for herself in Palestine. She goes on her search for identity willingly enough, but finds no answers on the kibbutz: "I have no religion, just the same as you," says a fellow worker, Leah. "The British call us Jews to distinguish us from the Arabs but when the British have gone, who will we be?"

Tel Aviv is teeming with refugees from Poland and Russia, German Jewish intellectuals and Holocaust survivors, idealists from all over Europe. Evelyn, with an eye to the main chance, acquires a flat, a hairdressing job and a lover. She dyes her hair blonde and passes herself off to her clients as one Priscilla Jones from Lewisham whose husband has been inconveniently posted to Tiberias. Her disguise is useful to her terrorist lover, Johnny, and she finds herself drawn into the dangerous world of the tough Jews: a world of bombs, kidnapping and murder.

The novel is bursting with ideas: about idealism, the shattering of dreams and the struggle to belong. In Evelyn's search for identity it is hard not to read the quest of Grant herself to understand who she is - something she did so movingly in her book about her mother's descent into dementia, Remind Me Who I Am, Again.

Here it is the relationship between mother and daughter that is most sympathetically drawn, and the writing of it is tender and true: Evelyn, battered by events in Palestine and returning to England, remembers her childhood, "the slightly grubby chintz domesticity, where my mother had built one nest of seduction and allure for her lover and another of safety and love for me".

The other characters are less successful. In her eagerness to express her ideas Grant puts them into the mouths of people who simply would not talk like that: these are not conversations but polemic or prolix storytelling. Grant has important things to say about an important period of history; the energy and the love are there, but not the believable people.

fields.headline: London Book Fair gets wired
fields.trailText: Internet fever breaks out at the London Book fair, plus The Loafer's tips for the book of the fair
fields.body:
 Publishing folk are gearing up for the London Book Fair. The shindig, described by editors as Frankfurt in Toytown, always attempts to assume a worthy air by including seminars and discussion groups. This year, predictably, you're no one on the circuit unless you've got the words e-book, internet or digital revolution in the title of your talk. All of which dotcom distractions are simply a cover for the serious business of the fair: for European publishers, to smoke furiously in the aisles and watch the natives cough and splutter, and for the Brits to attend evening events such as The Book Fair Beer Bash or The Publishers' Rock Party. We'll report in more detail next week.

 So far, no real book of the fair has emerged. The Loafer's money is on Passing Time on the Loo, a collection of condensed classics aimed at the laziest people, and Mary's House, an illustrated account of the Turkish house where the Virgin Mary allegedly spent her last years. The latter is written and published by swinging 60s bookman Donald Carroll, and agented by Jonathan Clowes. The pair published Dick Clement and Ian LaFrenais some years ago, but renewed their acquaintance when they discovered an interest in common: Carroll had restored a Dominican convent in the Midi, and Clowes a Cistercian abbey in the Charente. How delightfully new Labour.

 Faber authors must be delighted to know that they are regarded as precious treasures by company chairman, Matthew Evans. In the New Statesman, Evans hits back at his critics - those who found his first foray into the world of museums and libraries a little too rich. "I am chairman of a major literary publishing house," he huffs. "If I were one of Margaret Thatcher's Essex businessmen, that would be one thing. But you could say Faber is the equivalent of the National Gallery." Quite right, too: we wouldn't want some ghastly nouveau with an estuary accent in charge, would we? What would Seamus think?

fields.headline: A good boke
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan  on John Kelly's striking debut, The Little Hammer
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on John Kelly's striking debut, The Little Hammer
fields.body:
The Little Hammer
John Kelly
Jonathan Cape, £10, 182pp

Buy it at BOL

These days, opening with the chatty enquiry "Would you believe me if I told you that I was only nine years of age when I killed him?" elicits a sigh of familiarity rather than a gasp of surprise. But this gloriously ragged first novel from John Kelly (recently voted, we are told - also rather inauspiciously - one of the "20 hippest people in Ireland") is less apprentice pop shocker, more the bastard progeny of Patrick McCabe and Flann O'Brien.

There's the dark vision of the rural North of the 70s, those "idyllic, murderous days" in a childhood of plaster saints and Action Man, married to the time-honoured tale of the outsider artist and peppered with a fair amount of blarney, visitations and saints ("like Marvel superheroes - each with special gifts and uniforms"). With mother vanished, father a "slayer of moo-moos" and domineering grandma constantly on religious pilgrimages, the precocious violence of this new butcher boy is no surprise. And though murder (especially the pre-teen seashore dispatching of a palaeontologist with the little hammer of the title) could be called the apotheosis of plot, here it's more of a variation on a pointillist theme than a literary event.

The narrator, a "painter of weirdy pictures", intersperses distant memories and present obsessions with old newspaper cuttings and encyclopaedic observations on wildlife and iconography. He is engaged in a confessional catharsis - "like a weekend on Lough Derg or a good boke" - and the book is full of burying and boking, as he struggles with the paranoid need to conceal the past and the exhibitionist desire to vomit it all out.

His tale begins in the crib ("I spent some years in this cot patiently waiting to be sprung") and proceeds along the Catholic stations: the first visit to the "hushing Tardis" of the confessional box, the traditional horrors of the priest-run grammar school framed in Portrait of the Artist and burlesqued in O'Brien's The Hard Life. Kelly turns in a fine version: the freezing corridors "with fearsome portraits of bishops constantly developing out of black nooks", the thick country priests, the schoolroom persecution ("How am I supposed to know how to spell abattoir - I'm not a fucking Frenchman! I'm only 12 years old for fuck's sake!"). Immediate, passionate and shot through with descriptive brilliance, the narrative voice is both charming and convincing; it is only gradually that the artist's rages and paranoias become something more chilling than eccentricity.

After the theft of a holy icon from Prague and the death of his beloved grandma, the novel - always impressionistic in its attitude to the real and the surreal - descends into delusion, with visits from Elvis (modest, deferential, very interested in Irish cuisine), the dead granny and St Peter himself, and fevered letter-writing campaigns to the Pope. The narrator's love/hate object has more of the nurse than the girlfriend about her; the reading of dead newspapers smacks of institutionalisation; his weirdy pictures are perhaps not an international success after all and his constant complaint that he's "talking to the wall" may be literally true. In his Psycho-esque finale Kelly overdoes what worked brilliantly as sinister suggestion, and we're back in the easier, shallower waters of shock-value twists and neat conclusions.

It is a disappointing end to a strange and frustrating book: ambitious yet slapdash, thematically dense but unstructured, an easy-reading novel that nods to all the Irish greats - sometimes boldly, sometimes in their thrall. Yet similar criticisms could be made of O'Brien, whose tone of callous whimsy Kelly so effortlessly updates. And while that's a backhanded compliment, it is also pretty high praise.

fields.headline: Sports books
fields.trailText: Don't accuse us of not having our finger on the pulse. A couple of weeks ago, we brought you news of the rise and rise of two wrestlers and their blood and guts autobiographies. Now Mick Foley - aka Mankind, Cactus Jack or Dude Love - and Dwayne Johnson, or The Rock, are kept from smashing against one another merely by the buffer of a biography of Muhammad Ali. Bet the greatest never performed the famous hangman manoeuvre, though, nor ever took part in Japanese death matches (in which the ropes are charmingly replaced by barbed wire).

fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: Stanley Fish in familiar sub-Nietzschean waters, plus The Devil's Party and The Therapeutic Garden
fields.body:
The Trouble With Principle
Stanley Fish
Harvard, £15.50
Buy it at BOL

What a falling off was there: Fish was once a stellar literary critic, inspiring countless students (including your reviewer) to love Paradise Lost. Now he's a sort of grizzled philosophical lapdog of Richard Rorty. The argument of his latest book is the same as ever: all belief systems are contingent and without foundation; sentimental liberal pluralism masks the fact that conflicts must have winners and losers; and (please note the non sequitur) because of these facts we can relax in a panglossian acceptance of free-market democracy and not worry too much about anything.

It's easy to kick this sort of sub-Nietzschean antifoundationalism (not least because if there's no reason to believe any claim of absolute truth, then why should we believe Fish's theory either?), but Fish is always entertaining in a pugnacious, baggy fashion. If you've read one political Fish screed you've read them all, however, and his earlier effort, There's No Such Thing as Free Speech: and It's a Good Thing Too, is better than this.

The Devil's Party: A History of Charlatan Messiahs
Colin Wilson
Virgin, £17.99
Buy it at BOL

One person's "charlatan messiah", of course, is another person's saviour. But this entertaining compendium of madmen through history concentrates on the clearly barking, with detailed accounts of the Aum cult in Japan, the Waco siege and the mass suicide of the Children of the Solar Temple.

Wilson means to construct an important psychological theory of the messianic complex; thus, Jung and Freud are repeatedly invoked - which is piquant for the sceptical reader (if not for the blandly faithful Wilson), given that Jung and Freud themselves were arguably the greatest charlatan messiahs of the 20th century. Eventually, we decide that folk like David Koresh are victims of powerful self-hypnosis. Wilson concludes, though, that such a process might be turned to the greater good, fantasising grandiosely that if we can all attain "non-leaking consciousness" then we will for the first time be "truly human". So, more loopy sub- Nietzscheanism. As far as I know, Nietzsche's books are still all in print; why be fobbed off with imitations?

The Therapeutic Garden
Donald Norfolk
Bantam Press, £15
Buy it at BOL

Disfigured by a nasty "handwriting" font for interludes of poetry and arboreal philosophising, this is nonetheless a lovely evocation of gardening hedonism. Don't exhaust yourself with constant Dimmockian sweating and digging: plant a few nice flowers and just lie in a hammock all day. It's not laziness, this book assures you; it's good for your health. A therapeutic garden, Norfolk argues, should be "irregular, wild and unrestrained". Hmmm. Let's see what Nietzsche offers up in the way of gardening tips. " 'According to nature' you want to live? O you noble Stoics, what deceptive words these are! Imagine a being like nature, wasteful beyond measure, indifferent beyond measure, without purposes and consideration, without mercy and justice, fertile and desolate and uncertain at the same time..." On second thoughts, I'll call in the landscape gardener.

fields.headline: Standing out from the crowd
fields.standfirst: Show employers how good you are on paper
fields.trailText: Show employers how good you are on paper
fields.body:
Covering letters are your first sales pitch to a potential employer. Employers receive hundreds of CVs and covering letters from people that are applying for the job you want. Your goal, therefore is to stand out from the other candidates. "Until the recruiter meets you, you are only as good as your paperwork. And the first piece of paper they see is your covering letter," says John Courtis, author of Getting a Better Job (IPD Books)

A good covering letter introduces you to the employer and explains why you are one of the best applicants. By avoiding the following common boo-boos, you can create a covering letter that separates you from the pack.

1 Forgetting to proofread your letter for errors and tone before you send it. Make sure your letter has no spelling, typing or grammatical errors. Job applicants are frequently deselected because of such mistakes.

2 Addressing the letter to the wrong person. Call the company and find out the name and title of the person to whom you should address the letter. It shows initiative and resourcefulness, and will impress your reader that you figured out a way to address them personally. Use their name and title - and don't try to guess their gender.

3 Using someone else's words. Make sure that your letter sounds like you, not like something out of a book. Your covering letter, as well as your CV, should be an accurate reflection of your personality. Employers are looking for knowledge, enthusiasm, and focus.

4 Betraying your ignorance about the company and the industry. This is where your research comes in. Don't go overboard - just make it clear that you didn't pick this company out of the phone book. You know who they are, what they do, and you have chosen them.

5 Being too informal. Promote yourself as a professional. Your letter should be as close to a business proposal as you can get - not a plea for an interview. What can you offer them that is of value? What objectives can you help them achieve?

6 Talking too much about yourself. Downplay 'I' and emphasise 'you'. Try to convert 'I haves' into 'you wants' for the employer. What can you do for the organisation that will create interest and arouse a desire for an interview with you?

7 Being too cocky. If you meet all the stated requirements for the job, spell this out in your letter - but don't lay it on too thick. Accentuate the good match between your skills and their needs.

8 Lacking focus. Structure your letter so that each part achieves a particular goal. State the purpose of your letter in your opening paragraph. Keep the letter organised. Decide on the focus of your letter and ensure that all the points you make reinforce the topic.

9 Boring presentation. Draw attention to your skills and attributes by underlining them, bolding them, or indenting them in lists with bullets. However, be careful with underlining because the line is often printed too close to the word, and can reduce its readability. Use these kinds of emphasis sparingly just to make the highlights stand out when the reader gives your letter a quick skim.

10 Droning on too long. Keep it simple and clean - not cluttered. Use no more than seven lines, and preferably five or fewer, per paragraph. Vary the sentence length. None of the sentences should be very long, but you don't want a staccato stream of very short sentences. One page should be the maximum for letters.

11 Sending photocopies. Send original letters. Don't send copies that look as though they are mass produced. Don't use typewriters or dot matrix printers and never, ever hand-write your letter.

12 Forgetting to include a copy of your CV. Remember that the one purpose for a covering letter is to get your CV into the hands of the employer and to obtain an interview. Thinking of enclosing a nice pic? Unless you are seeking employment in modelling, acting, or other performance industries, it's not appropriate to send a photograph with your covering letter. An employer will soon see what you look like, should you reach the interview stage. Until then, a photo won't help you get a foot in the door.

13 Forgetting to ask. If you don't ask... The primary goal of your covering letter is to get an interview. Be sure and ask for one at the end of your covering letter. Be prepared to initiate the follow-up communication and let your prospective employer know you will be doing this. This may be just enough to get them to hold on to your letter and give it a more thorough reading.
