webTitle: Help: My manager thinks he's infallible!

fields.headline: Help: My manager thinks he's infallible!
fields.trailText: Constantly covering up for your boss? Irene Krechowiecka suggests that you ask yourself what's in it for you.
fields.body:
My boss will never admit he's wrong. I end up covering for him, even apologising for his mistakes.
Dan S, planning officer, Surrey

That's why he's the boss and you're not. Those who are regularly seen to make errors of judgement don't have a long term future at the top of anything. To retain or improve on a senior position you need to cut down on detectable mistakes.

The powerful generally develop a self-image which makes it difficult for them to believe they could be at fault and that's reinforced by behaviour like yours. Honourably falling on one's sword has lost popularity when it's much easier to find a compliant scapegoat to help you appear infallible.

He can't compel you to cover up or apologise, so if you're going along with him you must see some advantage in it.

You're an invaluable ally. Where this leads depends on whether he's a rising or falling star. Before taking the shortcut of hitching your wagon to him determine the direction of his movement.

If you decide the situation is intolerable or unrewarding simply stop accepting his interpretation of events. He's shown you how easy it is to remain blame-free, so copy his technique. Avoid arguing the case - that can result in an undignified did/didn't exchange.

The most effective way to prevent blunders being associated with you is getting your interpretation in first or firmest. Convince yourself that disasters are caused by the incompetence or unreliability of others and you'll be well on the way to supplanting your boss.

Email Irene Krechowiecka with your comments and questions

Where this leads depends on whether he's a rising or falling star. Before taking the shortcut of hitching your wagon to him determine the direction of his movement. If you decide the situation is intolerable or unrewarding simply stop accepting his interpretation of events. He's shown you how easy it is to remain blame-free, so copy his technique. Avoid arguing the case - that can result in an undignified did/didn't exchange. The most effective way to prevent blunders being associated with you is getting your interpretation in first or firmest. Convince yourself that disasters are caused by the incompetence or unreliability of others and you'll be well on the way to supplanting your boss. Email Irene Krechowiecka with your comments and questions

webTitle: How to ... find your next job on company time

fields.headline: How to ... find your next job on company time
fields.standfirst: Watch out - your boss could be listening in
fields.trailText: Watch out - your boss could be listening in
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a man (or woman) possessed of a good job will find it easier to get another job. Employers are like A&R men - they don't like to sign you up unless someone else has already endorsed your talents.

"Employers like to see continuous employment on your CV," says Nick Isles, a spokesman for the Institute of Personnel and Development. "They get suspicious if you leave one job without having another one to go to."

The problem - as those of you who are gainfully employed will know - is that getting a new job can be a full-time job in itself. Students and the unemployed can afford to spend all day going through the papers, sitting in libraries, updating their CVs and writing applications. Full-time workers cannot.

And let's face it, the last thing anyone feels like doing after a stressful day in the office is trading Eastenders and a couple of pints in the local for an evening spent poring over job adverts. Only the truly dedicated job hunter will sacrifice their precious weekend leisure-time. What's more, few of us have the job-hunting resources - the internet, newspapers and trade journals - we need to find a new job, at home.

Which brings us to one conclusion: the best place to find a new job is in the office, where you'll have internet access, stationery, a phoneline you don't have to pay for and lots of reference materials. But how can you do it without incurring the wrath of your current employer?

The key, says writer, careers adviser and Rise agony aunt Irene Krechowiecka, is discretion: "If your boss finds out you're using your working hours and office equipment to find a new job, you could find yourself departing your current employment a little sooner than you'd anticipated. It's essential to use your common sense."

In other words: Don't leave the newspaper open at the jobs pages while you nip to the loo or into a meeting. Don't arrange interviews over the phone when your boss is sitting three feet away. And don't hand a report in late when it's patently obvious that you've spent all morning surfing the web, even if you claim it's for work purposes.

"Divide your working hours into working time and legitimate non-working time," advises Nick Isles. "No-one will mind if you make a couple of calls or read the papers at lunchtime. If your office operates a flexi-time system, use the time after clocking off to do your own thing for an hour or two.

"It's also a good idea to find out what rules and regulations your company has about pursuing private interests from the office. Some will be happy to let you use their facilities. Others will have strict rules about internet use and personal phone calls."

However discreet you are, beware the hidden pitfalls of job hunting from the office. Irene Krechowiecka says employers can - and will - monitor your use of the internet and email. They'll be able to tell that you've logged into Jobs Unlimited or sent your CV to a competitor: "It's also worth bearing in mind that the company you're applying to can tell where you're emailing or calling from and when," says Irene.

"It could suggest to them that you're not the most dedicated person and not above using work time to your own ends."

If you're not the risk-taking type, there are other - cleverer - ways to use your present job to secure a new one. For starters, why not take advantage of your company's in-house training facilities and improve your skills with a view to moving on elsewhere?

Irene suggests you use the contacts you've made through work: "Many jobs aren't advertised at all - people get them through word of mouth and recommendations. If a vacancy comes up at a client's company and the client likes and respects you, you might be top of the list. And keep in contact with colleagues who've moved to other companies. That way, you'll be the first to hear if an opportunity arises. If you don't want to be approached at work, leave a trail by which you can be found - by printing personal business cards with your home phone-number on, for example."

Of course, if people don't know you're looking for a new job, they won't approach you: "You need to send out subtle signals that you're open to offers, without appearing discontent in your current job," says Irene. "It's a fine balancing act."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this ...

According to Irene, it's not unknown for people to apply for jobs just so their employer notices them or gives them a promotion. If this is your motive, ignore the above advice - the subtle approach won't work. But be aware, it's a dangerous game and could backfire on you.

fields.headline: Tip of the Week
fields.standfirst: Put out the rubbish
fields.trailText: Put out the rubbish
fields.body: What do you do when you're at your wit's end at work? Quit? Throw a tantrum? Quietly start looking for a new job? According to author Matthew Gilbert, you still have one option left: You can change yourself. Or, more specifically, your attitude toward your work. His formula for job happiness is more about attitude than external factors, such as wage or status. "Stop identifying too strongly with society's standards of what constitutes valuable work," he says. "All work is valuable if it needs to be done, and a strong case could be made that it's more important to have our garbage picked up than to have 12 different kinds of detergent to choose from."

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No.29 IBM
fields.trailText: No.29 IBM
fields.body:
If you've been downloading music from the web it's quite possible that you owe a debt of thanks to IBM. You see, IBM is not only a leading producer of personal computers but also a provider of high performance web servers for every major platform from Unix to Linux.

And its technology know-how is making huge inroads into e-commerce. For example HMV, the world's largest music retailer, has been quick to seize e-business opportunities by enlisting IBM's help to develop its web sites.

IBM is also collaborating with major record companies -EMI, Sony Music, Universal Music and Warner Music - in the first ever market trial of a system that permits convenient and fast distribution of full-length albums to consumers over the internet.

Big Blue, as it later became known, began life in New York in 1911 as the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Co. (C-T-R). In 1924, C-T-R adopted the name International Business Machines and was given the nickname Big Blue after its blue-fronted headquarters building.

But in recent years IBM has distanced itself from the image it had earned as a computer industry dinosaur. Take three people and an IBM server and you've got a global e-business venture, says its current advertising.

The company has consolidated and re-engineered its business to become a "global solutions provider". It has, says IBM "torn down traditional barriers and streamlined core processes to implement its corporate vision of a truly networked world, where business between companies - and between customers and companies is conducted electronically and globally".

To pursue such ambitious strategic, operational and cultural development the company says it is committed to the career development of its intellectual capital, the employees. IBM says it is seeking recruits with the initiative and leadership potential to drive the company forward. However, staff roles are not confined to a fixed job description: the company says it builds on the flexibility, responsiveness and experience gained through each new project undertaken.

Some of its recruits come from an inside track. In the UK, IBM offers an integrated computer science honours degree scheme at the University of Portsmouth - the only sponsored full-time undergraduate computer science degree course in the UK. There are also industrial trainee placements lasting up to12 months aimed at students on four-year sandwich degree courses.

But like most in the sector, IBM has felt the pinch of the IT skills shortage and has a number of initiatives designed to draw, in particular, more young women into the industry.

For more details, you can contact the graduate hotline on 01705 564015 or write to the Recruitment Dept, IBM UK Ltd, FGC, PO Box 41, North Harbour, Portsmouth PO6 3AU.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to keeping your office email private

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to keeping your office email private
fields.trailText: Most people wouldn't dream of using company stationery for personal use, so why does common sense go out of the window when it comes to email?
fields.body:
A. Cyber sense

Your ordinary work mail is probably opened and scanned by a secretary every morning without you feeling intruded upon. You wouldn't dream of using your employer's letterheaded paper and franking machine to book holidays, send chatty notes to friends, apply for new jobs, pass on confidential or defamatory information. Who'd be brash enough to make a long personal phone call with their boss in hearing distance? When it comes to email use and abuse, common sense seems to disappear.

B. Eat your mail

The legalistic disclaimers which appear on emails denying responsibility for the content, but still urging you to delete and destroy the message once read, can make you feel part of some huge conspiracy. It's rather disappointing when the text they accompany is banal, but gives an insight into how jumpy employers feel about personal use of company email. Not only can they legitimately read mail you send using their computers, the government, in the interests of national security of course, is scanning cyberspace for early signs of trouble.

C. Safe text

Sackings for abuse of communication tools have increased; claiming ignorance of the rules is no defence. You can't assume your employer will respect your privacy if you don't respect the fact they're paying for your time and internet access.

Keep safe by regarding your emails as postcards that will be read by everyone.

webTitle: Which flavour of job will you choose?

fields.headline: Which flavour of job will you choose?
fields.standfirst: Graduate careers no longer fit the mould
fields.trailText: Graduate careers no longer fit the mould
fields.body:
There is no such thing as a typical graduate or even a typical graduate job anymore - so says a report published yesterday by the Institute of Employment Studies (IES), an independent consultancy.

An analysis of the research and trends of the last 12 months, the IES Annual Graduate Review 2000 - which is part-funded by employers such as BT, the BBC, Corus, the Home Office and Lloyds TSB - offers as good a snap shot of the current journey from degree ceremony to employment as you're likely to find.

The traditional 'hi-flier' training schemes, it seems now account for a relatively small proportion of graduate jobs. The 'milk round' and campus recruitment will, says the report, account for a decreasing minority of jobs. And while many university-leavers still covet these kinds of jobs, the majority will be unsuccessful and enter jobs with lower pay and limited initial prospects.

"Demand by the major recruiters is expected to recover from the surprise decline last year," says IES director and report author Richard Pearson. "However, many of the 200,000 graduate job hunters this year may struggle to get satisfactory employment in the increasingly fragmented and challenging labour market."

According to the IES, those graduating from engineering and computer science courses, along with those in medicine and education are likely to be best placed to enter high level managerial and professional 'graduate' jobs. But prospects aren't so good, says the report for those from the humanities, languages or biological sciences.

Yet to talk of a 'typical graduate', 'graduate job', 'graduate career' or even 'graduate scheme' no longer makes sense, claims the IES, since university leavers are now being recruited in so many different ways:

 Fast track management training schemes for small numbers in large organisations, where personal skills are critical and the supply is limited. Competition for the best graduates is intense, as is competition for entry.

 Professional and functional careers such as accountancy, engineering and teaching - a growth area where personal qualities are growing in importance and the supply of suitable candidates is limited for some functions.

 Graduate level administrative and management jobs with more limited initial career prospects. Personal qualities are more important than qualifications. Vacancies appear throughout the year and graduates may be recruited alongside non-graduates, internal and experienced candidates. Vacancies will increase but fluctuate with the economic cycle.

 Self-employment where the rewards may be uncertain, but lifestyle may be more important. A traditional area for arts and design students.

 Lower level jobs where graduates can 'add value', upgrading the contribution to the job. Vacancies will appear at many points in all types of organisations throughout the year but will fluctuate with the economic cycle. Again, graduates are likely to be in competition with, and working alongside non-graduates.

 The wider labour market where there may be little advantage in being a graduate.

While the quality of many of these initial jobs is not always what graduates want, most graduates say they see some career progression in terms of the quality of their jobs once they have been in employment for a few years. And four or five years after graduation, a much higher proportion are in professional and managerial occupations than at the two or three year stage. There is also a noticeable reduction in the proportion who admit to feeling 'under-employed'.

Yet being in an established or 'mainstream' job does not mean that graduates are settled. While retention rates are relatively good among the big recruiters, one in five graduates say they are looking for a different job.

All very interesting, but is there any advice for job-seeking graduates?

Even though the number of young people entering higher education has grown tenfold since the 1960s, the big graduate recruiters are still whingeing that they cannot get all the high-calibre graduates they need.

The IES study says that the rate of growth in demand for new graduates in managerial and professional occupations is likely to lag behind the overall supply. Many graduates will therefore have to adjust their expectations.

Some may have to take employment in associated professional or technical level jobs where job growth is expected to be strong and where graduates may have advantages over candidates who don't have a degree.

However the report says graduates also need to ensure they have developed their personal and employability skills. In particular they need:

1. Good assets - knowledge, skills and attitudes.

2. Career management skills - awareness of their strengths and weaknesses, adaptability, mobility and a realistic view of the opportunities open to them.

3. Presentation skills - an ability to present and sell themselves, their work experience and their qualifications through CVs, applications, tests and interviews.

 The IES Annual Graduate Review 2000: a diverse and fragmented market, by R Pearson, J Aston, P Bates and N Jagger. Priced £27.50 the report can be ordered by ringing 01476 541080.

fields.body:
 Buy! Buy! InterviewMe.co.uk, an on-line website that claims to cut out the recruitment agency middlemen to put your details instantly in front of company bosses, is offering free shares to students and graduates. The first 100,000 candidates who sign up will be registered to participate in InterviewMe's IPO (initial public offering) when it decides to float.

 Shattering news: Mentoring is helping women to shatter the glass ceiling. Management professors Jack Simonetti and Sonny Ariss at the University of Toledo surveyed 1,050 people at large and medium-sized companies and found that more than two-thirds of the women had mentors. Almost 40% said it had helped them to climb the corporate ladder.

 Book of the week: Most of us spend more time planning holidays than we spend planning a lifetime of work, but 'employability' guru Peter Hawkins offers an 80-page tool kit to help you start managing your career. Published by the Graduate Into Employment Unit, The Art of Building Windmills costs £12.99 plus £2.50 p&p. Ring 0151 709 1760 for info.

 Hide your lying eyes: So you think you can fool your boss with a sweet smile? Think again. The human brain may be hard-wired to detect whether a smile is sincere or not, according to a team of Australian and British psychologists. The researchers have found that we automatically look at the eye area, checking for the tell-tale crinkles of a genuine smile.

 I'm free! The growing number of mega-mergers and resulting redundancies is spawning a new pool of euphemisms for ruthlessly laying off or firing people. A reader reports: "One of our sales-people was on a call and noticed that Joe wasn't there and that his office looked empty. When he asked about his whereabouts he was told, 'Joe was made available to the industry'."

 What do you want... blood? Have you joined a full-blooded profession? Civil servants, army personnel and teachers are the workers most likely to give blood, while people working in advertising and marketing are the least likely says a survey by the National Blood Service.

And now there is a feeling that in some areas the two disciplines could even function as one
fields.body:
Management consultancy

There is a lot of overlap between management consultancy and PR, according to Will White deputy director of the Management Consultants' Association (MCA). "It depends on who you talk to but management consultancy is taking ground from public relations and advertising. And big public relations companies do offer management consultancy advice. So, there is on-going confusion in this area."

There was a trend in the early nineties for big boys in management consultancy like Coopers and Lybrand and Price Waterhouse to offer a one stop shop to their clients with public relations as part of the deal. Big management consultancies sometimes also offer legal services.

Other big management consultancy agencies have bought up public relations

agencies to acquire an extra string to their bow, but Will White's personal view is that there would never be a com plete tie up between the two because their services are still very different. "I don't see it as a perpetual trend," he explains.

Management consultants have, over the decades, gained an unjustified reputation for having more form than function, being more talk than action. John Birt was famously slated for spending £10m of licence payers' fees on management consultants at the BBC, although Will White, in defence of his industry, points out that this saved the corporation £500m, so there was a demonstrable effect, even if it wasn't to the programme makers' taste.

The MCA defines a management consultant as someone whose role is to give independent advice and assistance about management issues such as pinpointing problems and or opportunities, advising the client on what to do about them and helping the client see their recommendations through.

Sounds a bit vague? There are management consultants currently in the Ukraine advising on how to privatise the oil industry. Management consultants have advised the railway corporations in African countries on organisation, manpower, equipment replacement and future development.

Management consultants can have a vital role to play in a merger or acquisition, although it may not always be a pleasant one. Will White acknowledges the scapegoat role management consultants may unwillingly be forced to play if there is downsizing to be done.

"Sometimes the firm has made up its mind and pushes the consultant to a certain conclusion," he says.

Company politics have to be carefully negotiated and management consultancies need to work to a very clear brief.

But the rewards are good. Starting salaries for bright graduates are about £26,000 and it is said that some big players will shell out as much as £30,000 for a brisk young BA or BSc of the right calibre.

And that's just the beginning. The very nature of the job gives management consultants unrivalled access to the highest levels in a company.

This gives scope for cross-overs with consultants joining companies they have advised. And sometimes the traffic is the other way.

Contrary to popular belief, management consultancy is not about bright young things descending on a company with quick-fix solutions

"There is a very fine line between using bright young people and people with experience and management consultancy agencies do bring in people with a background in industry or commerce," says White. "And younger people go out with the more experienced to learn on the job."

White says there is more travel in management consultancy than public relations and the relationship with the client is different.

"Management consultants go in for a short period often to deal with one issue, like, for example, installing IT systems in banks so they are EMU compliant," says White. "Public relations firms have an on-going relationship with their clients perhaps on a monthly fixed contract."

The macho image of management consultancy is also changing with more and more consultancies offering their female staff flexible job packages which might include part-time or home working.

Public Relations

Public relations, of course, has always been seen as a female dominated business, a people business - but that is in flux. Anne Mealor, head of marketing at the Institute of Public Relations (IPR), says it is now fifty-fifty women and men at the recruitment stage of the business and racial equality has never been an issue.

"In local authority public relations, for example, there is a good racial mix which reflects the the local population. And local authorities are equal opportunities employers," she says, citing Tower Hamlets in London as a good example.

Mealor believes that public relations is gaining some ground from management consultancy. In an age where image can make or break a company, public relations can have a very direct effect on the bottom line. Linked with effective marketing it can turn a company around.

"Communications is being brought in more at the planning stage because communications is so vital to a company strategy," she says.

This trend has strength ened the hand of public relations since 20 years ago when it was seen as a bit of a bolt-on luxury. The public relations section of a company was often the first to go in hard times.

"Before it was a luxury, but now it's essential. Public relations is needed even more when a company is struggling," says Mealor. "Reputation and image are very important to turnover."

The IPR says that its own industry is arguably the most powerful and effective weapon in the marketing communications armoury of public and private organisations.

Getting your message across whether it is about a product, a service or a position people hold is vital in the multi-media communications age. It is an essential across the board - from lobby groups and residents associations through to the biggest commercial organisations and the heart of governments. Variety is obviously one of the attractions of a public relations career. It can offer work in the purely commercial sector or in local or national government, for charities, political parties, hospital trusts and any number of quangos.

One of the disadvantages of its popularity as a career is that starting salaries can be quite low with £16,000 being an average in local government.

"An account manager with an agency gets about £24,000 and an account director about £30,000. In house can be better and the highest starting salaries are in the financial sector," says Mealor.

Like management consultants, public relations people have access at the highest level. It was not always the case with hired-in agencies who might have dealt mostly with middle managers.

Yet again, the importance of a good communications strategy has upgraded public relations.

"A lot of public relations work is in crisis management and for that you need direct access to the top. That can create a lot of jealousy in a company," warns Mealor.

An in-house director of corporate affairs will report to the chief executive and someone in that position can earn big bucks, like the rumoured £150,000-plus for the new appointee at Railtrack.

The Institute of Public Relations is working hard on its own image and offers the full package you would expect from a professional body - a code of conduct, a diploma, career development and a raft of events.

Entrants to public relations need to be graduates and Mealor advises students to check that a PR degree is IPR endorsed. Those who do non-vocational degrees can do a post graduate course or take an IPR course.

Both management consultancy and public relations demand a high degree of commitment from their work force and people are expected to work long hours.

"In public relations you need to be creative and have a good business sense. You must also be level headed and calm and be able to take pressure," says Mealor.

What to do next

The IPR is holding a careers day in Manchester on April 13.

Websites to visit: www.ipr.org.uk and www.mca.org.uk

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees from either end of the career ladder share their experiences of working at the market research firm MORI.
fields.body:
Simon Atkinson
Aged 30
Partner MORI

Simon Atkinson joined pollsters MORI direct from Cambridge and after two years decided to quit to do a PhD. "But a few months into it, I realised I couldn't go back to academic life," he says.

Dropping his doctorate, he returned to MORI - Britain's largest independent market research firm and best known for its opinion polls during elections - and seven years later he has become a partner.

CV to date: Political science degree (Fitzwilliam) and at MORI he has mostly been involved in social research, specialising in local government and political research and becoming associate director.

Key project: "Being involved with local authorities carrying out the government's Best Value scheme for delivering services. This has meant research and consultation, focus groups and workshops."

The buzz? "In my current role I take an overview of social research (local government, political, housing, environment and health) and I guess it's the sense that it's vital we get it right for our clients."

Must-have qualities: Graduates must be generalists who, increasingly, can offer specific skills.

Final tip? "Don't specialise too soon."

Rebecca Klahr
Aged 26
Research executive MORI

Curiosity is the key to success in market research - according to ex-geography student Rebecca Klahr. "You have to be excited about what makes brands popular and why people do what they do," she says.

Rebecca joined pollsters MORI from doing her doctorate at Cambridge (preceded by a first degree at LSE). She was one of eight graduates recruited last year.

The call? "I wanted some challenging work. I was attracted by the idea of problem-solving, of working in a team in various business and industrial sectors and with the possibility of international opportunities. All this pointed me away from academia."

Work load: So far, Rebecca has worked in MORI's corporate division - projects have included new media, employee research, surveys in the car and water industries and "the image of the British abroad".

Rebecca's training - which has involved one month's intensive tuition plus regular seminars reinforced by assistance from team managers and a "buddy" scheme -is geared to a diploma from the Market Research Society.

Next call? "The possibilities are unlimited. I am looking towards some kind of managerial position."

For more career details visit the website www.mori.com

fields.headline: The fresh prince
fields.trailText: Name: Charlie Williams
fields.body:
Name: Charlie Williams

Status: Managing director of Premium Health Drinks (PhD)

Past: Graduated from Goldsmith's College with maths degree, and entered City as trainee equities trader at HSBC James Capel. A business trip to Hong Kong, where he sampled "fabulous fruit drinks I couldn't find in the UK" inspired him to launch PhD two years ago.

Present: Employs 13 people and oversees the production of 14-15,000 litres of smoothies and other fruit drinks at the company's base in Greenwich. Customers include Selfridges, Cafe de Paris and the Millennium Dome.

Future: Plans to team up with companies in the cosmetic industry and use PhD's waste products to create fruit scented gels, shampoos and zesty facial sprays.

Strengths: "I'm very determined and won't take no for an answer."

Weaknesses: "I'm a great ideas person, but I always move on to the next one before I've completed the first."

Wisdom: "If you have an idea, research it to make sure that it is financially viable and be prepared for lots and lots of hard work."

References: charlie@phdjuice.com

fields.headline: A right  gîte
fields.standfirst: If you're looking for self-catering accommodation in Europe this year, Ros Taylor helps you to track down the ideal holiday home
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor helps you to track down the ideal holiday home on the net
fields.body:
Don't be misled: tracking down a gîte or villa on the net takes time. Once you could order a few brochures, spend a pleasant evening flicking through them and then call to make a booking. It's not yet quite so simple on the net. Targeted searches are all very well for finding flights and hotel rooms, but choosing a villa - where the location, appearance and facilities are just as important as the price - is a different matter. You need photographs and maps, and these can take a long time to download on a slow connection.

French Connections
French Connections gracefully overcomes many of these obstacles. Lavishly illustrated, the site is a directory of properties from all over France. Each has its own webpage with photos, prices and the owners' contact details. Some are very good value, but others are out of the reach of most people, like the Chteau de la Tour near Bordeaux, available for £7,000 a fortnight in July.

Châteaux and Country
If nothing except a chateau will do, try the upmarket Châteaux and Country, too. Only eight of them can be rented in their entirety, but there are plenty of rooms available.

Villarama
The rather garish Villarama looks as though it might specialise in timeshares on the Costa Brava but in fact offers a good choice of villas all over Europe. The principle is the same as French Connections: you book with the owner directly. Some properties show an online availability chart so that you don't waste time chasing dates that are already reserved.

Abritel
The French themselves use Abritel, which started life on the primitive Minitel system and is beginning to adapt itself to the web. The chief weakness of this site is the lack of photos and details but, as long as you know exactly where you want to stay, it could prove useful.

Vintage Travel
For larger villas in Spain, Vintage Travel is well worth visiting; the site is richly-illustrated and fulsome in its descriptions.

Holiday-rentals
Holiday homes in Spain, Italy, France and even a few in Scandinavia are available at the long-established Holiday-rentals - a few oddities, such as the sauna chalets with beaver safaris in Norway, make it an excellent place to begin looking.

webTitle: Kennedy admits low impact as leader

fields.headline: Kennedy admits low impact as leader
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy was forced to admit yesterday that he has failed to make a strong impact since succeeding Paddy Ashdown as leader of the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy was forced to admit yesterday that he has failed to make a strong impact since succeeding Paddy Ashdown as leader of the Liberal Democrats.

Amid a growing whispering campaign about his lacklustre performance, Mr Kennedy said he had "definitely not" stamped his mark on the political landscape.

Asked on the Today programme whether he had made an impact, the Lib Dem leader said: "Oh no, definitely not. New leaders never make sufficient impact in their first six months."

Mr Kennedy, who has been criticised for his performance in the Commons and for sending confusing signals about his strategy, said that, at least, he avoided making the gaffes William Hague made in his first six months as leader.

"I would much prefer to move slowly but surely in the right direction rather than people having a very fixed opinion about Charles Kennedy going down a waterchute wearing a baseball cap," he said. Mr Hague was photographed doing that.

His remarks came on the eve of the Lib Dems' annual spring conference in which Mr Kennedy will attack the government for its planned tax cut and over its failure to address environmental issues.

In his interview, he said he believed that the Lib Dems could pick up votes from disenchanted Labour voters. "We will stake out a much more tolerant agenda than Labour is putting forward." He would argue against tax cuts and say that the stress should be on the health service, on pensioners and on education.

However, Mr Kennedy insisted that he was not attempting to position his party to the left of Labour. "I do not think that would be a strategy that would work for us ... I do think we want to be the most radical, the most reformist, and the most 'small l' liberal party in British politics."

His remarks will come as a relief to supporters of Mr Ashdown who believe Mr Kennedy has mistakenly tried to take his party to the left of Labour. Senior Lib Dems were alarmed when he launched a series of attacks on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for failing to live up to his commitments on social justice. They believe that there is little future for the Lib Dems in attacking the government from the left because the party's best hope at the next general election is in seats where it came second to the Tories.

Mr Kennedy's candid admission about his less than stunning performance as leader echoes the fears among some of his supporters. They believe that he is struggling to make an impression at his weekly confrontation with the prime minister which is doing little to establish his position as leader.

fields.headline: Odds on favourites
fields.standfirst:
Should you fancy a flutter on what the chancellor has to offer, Richard Colbey offers the City guide to the runners and riders

Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: City Index was among the first bookmakers to take bets on the Budget, committing itself to a range of prices last week, as an adjunct to its more serious - and profitable - stock and option markets .
fields.body:
City Index was among the first bookmakers to take bets on the Budget, committing itself to a range of prices last week, as an adjunct to its more serious - and profitable - stock and option markets .

In index or spread betting, a modern, rather upmarket form of betting, the punter "buys" the higher price of a spread or "sells" the lower one. Those who think Mr Brown will talk for more than 66 minutes can buy at so many pounds per minute - the minimum City will accept is £2. If the speech lasts a prolix 70 minutes, that £2 will be multiplied by four for winnings of £8. On the other hand, should he shut up after 50 minutes, buyers lose £32. Those who had sold at 63 would lose £14 on a seventy minute speech and gain £26 on a 50 minute one. The £6 difference in either case between the amount paid by losers and that paid to winners represents the one timeless feature of gambling, the bookie's profit.

Mr Brown's speeches have averaged around 61 minutes so far and there is no reason to think this one will be any longer. City's higher spread probably reflects no more than the fact that most punters prefer to be positive and to buy. There may be a modest profit in selling this market.

Those more interested in what the chancellor says than how long it takes, might consider the stamp duty market. While the consensus is that he is likely to raise this from 2.5% to 3.5%in for £250,000 to £500,000 homes, the rate for those over £500,000 is already 3.5%, and perhaps less likely to rise.

The City clearly does not agree, and its spread is set to take into account the possibility of an increase beyond 4%. Again a modest sale, at 3.8% on the rate for a £1m house, might be worthwhile.

An intriguing possibility is that of the chancellor introducing a different rate for London. The 3.5% rate bites hardest in the capital, where a relatively modest property can cost £500,000. While such homes are the preserve of the rich in most of Britain, in London it is no longer just the wealthy or even comfortably off who buy and sell them.

The political argument for a lower rate in the capital is still weak, but such is the government's desperation to block Mayor Ken, a bit of crude pre-election bribing can't be ruled out.

Heaven knows how City would settle bets if that did happen. Spread firms sometimes do the right thing when the untoward happens, and both buyers and sellers could be satisfied, if there is a dual rate.

Last year, though, the betting industry emerged with no such credit from the Budget. Sporting Index offered a market on how many times Speaker Betty Boothroyd would shout "Order".

As the Budget was in fact presided over by her deputy, the company declared all bets void, rather than paying out to sellers, as many argued it should, on the basis that the make up - should this be taken up was zero.

Laying a bet with fixed odds bookies on the Budget tends to be difficult.

Last year William Hill decided there could have been leaks and would lay odds only on the length of the speech. That did not stop it shamelessly circulating to the media prices for "information purposes", thus receiving a great deal of publicity at no risk.

The City will not guarantee the prices below will not change before Tuesday, but they will be keeping all markets open until just before the chancellor rises.

In index or spread betting, a modern, rather upmarket form of betting, the punter "buys" the higher price of a spread or "sells" the lower one. Those who think Mr Brown will talk for more than 66 minutes can buy at so many pounds per minute - the minimum City will accept is £2. Those who had sold at 63 would lose £14 on a seventy minute speech and gain £26 on a 50 minute one. webTitle: Capital sets  pace with a teaser

fields.headline: Capital sets  pace with a teaser
fields.trailText: A new front in the battle between the credit card providers opened this week with the launch of the lowest ever introductory rate of just 3.9%.
fields.body:
A new front in the battle between the credit card providers opened this week with the launch of the lowest ever introductory rate of just 3.9%.

However, the "teaser" rate of 3.9% lasts only until August. It is being offered by Capital One. The low introductory rate elbows out Tesco's visa card, whose 4.9% was until now sitting at the top of the plastic "best buy" league table.

After August the Capital One card moves to a standard rate of 11.9%, significantly better than Tesco's standard rate of 14.9%. Anyone shifting the balance of their previous card to Capital One also has a reduced transfer rate of 9.9%.

Both the Capital One and Tesco cards compare well with standard rates at the big issuers such as Barclaycard, which are in the region of 18-20%. But Tesco, which had 250,000 applications for its card in January alone, this week hit back at Capital One. Spokesman Mark Austin said: "There's a lot of confusion marketing going on in the credit card field, and the headline rates you see are not always what they seem."

He points to the longer introductory rate period on the Tesco card. Anyone taking out the Tesco card enjoys the 4.9% rate until January 1, 2001, five months longer than the low-rate period from Capital One. Tesco also offers the 4.9% rate on balance transfers from other cards compared to Capital One's 9.9% rate.

Both cards offer a similar interest-rate free period, with Tesco allowing you 56 days to repay while Capital One is on 54 days. The interest-rate-free period on credit cards ranges from 45 days at Egg to 59 days for cards at Bank One, Kent Reliance, MBNA International, Newcastle Building Society and West Bromwich Building Society.

One problem for someone considering switching is whether they will be accepted. All of the issuers use sophisticated credit scoring systems designed to weed out bad risks. This will go beyond a simple search of your credit reference. It will also score you on a number of criteria such as whether you are on the electoral register, how often you have moved in recent years and how frequently you have changed jobs. The rule of thumb is that if you are a job-hopper who moves home a lot, the credit card companies won't want you.

Or they may reject you for their best rate, but offer you a different rate instead. Capital One spokesman Richard Holmes says: "If we decide that you are not eligible for the 3.9% rate, we are more likely to be able to offer you another card, at a higher rate." But the rate may be significantly higher; Capital One says applicants rejected for the 3.9% deal may instead be offered cards with rates as high as 20%-plus.

Looking only at the "teaser" rates that dominate the best buy tables may also not work out as the best financial deal in the longer run. The list of best standard rates looks very different to the best introductory rates.

Here the Egg card dominates, with a rate of 9.9%, which beats the Capital One card by 2%. Other standard rates which match Capital One's 11.9% include Northern Rock and Hamilton Direct Bank. The Northern Rock card also has an introductory rate of 8.8% for 12 months after the date of issue.

None of the card issuers have yet been able to match the Egg rate, but they all warn that it is only available over the internet, and that Egg levies extra charges if users step outside of cyberspace and want to telephone a real human being or request hard copy statements.

fields.headline: A night with Ken (almost)
fields.standfirst:
Sista
Dingwalls, London
**
fields.trailText: Those of us who remember Ken Livingstone's Greater London Council with affection usually come back to two things. First, those lovely low transport fares. Second, their subsidising of live music, with particular emphasis on sounds from London's ethnic communities. There are many moments during this Women in Reggae event when you feel you're part of some collective, Ken-inspired flashback. Except that in 1984 this would have been full, it wouldn't have cost a tenner and there would have been a collection for the miners before the main act.
fields.body:
Those of us who remember Ken Livingstone's Greater London Council with affection usually come back to two things. First, those lovely low transport fares. Second, their subsidising of live music, with particular emphasis on sounds from London's ethnic communities. There are many moments during this Women in Reggae event when you feel you're part of some collective, Ken-inspired flashback. Except that in 1984 this would have been full, it wouldn't have cost a tenner and there would have been a collection for the miners before the main act.

After the Ranking Miss P has played a truly "follow that!" DJ selection of reggae tunes old and not-so-old, a strangely familiar group of women fill the tiny stage, adorned in sumptuous Afrocentric garb. As the MC mentions groups like Abacush and Akabu, you realise it's not so strange. These are exactly the same women who were playing this kind of show back in the early 80s. And, although they seem to have aged well, the music, sadly, is a bit turkey-necked and saggy. It is, frankly, as if ragga had never existed. As a version of Rivers of Babylon segues into a lyric that insists "you can't go into Zion with a carnal mind" (and they thought filling Dingwalls was tough), we know we are in for that ol' time roots and culture.

This is a place where someone on stage can holler "Jah!" and receive the response "Rastafari!!!" with no attendant irony. And that's just the white blokes. The effect, as a poet lectures us between songs about how Africa should just sort itself out, is less like a gig, and more like a revue for inner city schools, as each song reminds us that black children are beautiful, African and must learn their history, not - hurrah! - his story.

With it's anti-star collectivism, impeccable musicianship and unshowy singing, it is a mini-triumph, because the enthusiastic audience of young rastas and nice social worker types know what they like, and like what Jah know, and all very cosy it is too. Indeed, anyone who wouldn't like it is probably the kind of crazy baldhead who feels that both black music and the race debate have moved on in the last 20 years. Let's just say that, if Ken wins, one hopes he's picked up a liking for speed garage.

webTitle: To every share there is a season

fields.headline: To every share there is a season
fields.standfirst: Patrick Collinson consults the calendar and counsels against careering into a frenzy of investment to beat the taxman
fields.trailText: Patrick Collinson consults the calendar and counsels against careering into a frenzy of investment to beat the taxman
fields.body:
Over the next three weeks investors will pour up to £4bn into Isas to take advantage of the tax-free plans before the April 5 end of tax-year deadline, but City experts are warning that now may be about the worst time to buy.

The tidal wave of cash from small investors is likely to push up the stockmarket as the money is invested in shares, but once the tap is turned off in mid-April, the process will go into reverse, with share prices dipping because of the lack of demand.

The warning comes from Salomon Smith Barney, a major London investment bank. Its analysis shows that the old stockmarket maxim, "Sell in May and go away" (which goes back to the days when City stockbrokers left their desks for the "season" of Ascot, Henley and Wimbledon) has more than a ring of truth about it.

Figures for the FTSE All share index going back to 1965 show that the market is remarkably seasonal. April tends to be a very good month, with returns averaging 3.6%. But May is the worst, with typical returns of -0.6%. Neither do markets improve much after May. As the graphic shows, the best months for investment tend to be in autumn and winter rather than summer.

A spokesman for Saloman Smith Barney says: "Last year we suggested a trading strategy of 'sell in April, stay away until October.' This strategy may be applicable again this year."

It also suggests that most investors should not leave their annual Isa buying until the last minute. Mark Dampier of investment advisers Hargreaves Lansdown says: "I've been saying for the last couple of years that the best time to buy is November 1. But the trouble is that people love a deadline. In the long run it probably doesn't matter too much. If you look back at the October 1987 crash it doesn't look like more than a blip on the charts."

He cites Invesco's European fund: "A lot of people bought it last February and March, only to see it down by 10-15% a few months later. But since September it has rocketed, so investors didn't do too badly after all."

This year's rush to buy Isas which invest in technology will have an even more pronounced effect on sections of the stockmarket than ever before, says Salomon. As recently as June last year, technology funds made up just 1% of total unit trust sales. In the next few weeks they could hit 50%.

"US data suggest that as much as 25% of retail equity flows are currently being directed to tech funds. Given the current euphoria surrounding tech stocks, it would not be surprising to see up to 50% of Isa inflows in the next few weeks finding a home in the tech world. This could, yet again, provide a further squeeze to UK tech stocks and specifically to those low free-float stocks such as BSkyB, Telewest, CMG, Kingston Communications and Energis," says Salomon.

Jason Hollands of Best Investments has grave concerns about the rush into technology funds: "We had an 85 year old ring us recently to ask if she could switch out of her corporate bond fund and into technology funds. She also asked us if we knew what the internet was."

He says that around nine out of 10 requests for Isa investment brochures are for technology funds. "I think the world has gone mad. People are pouring into these things like lemmings. No doubt there are some good high-technology shares out there, but most of them have prices that are just a mixture of hope and greed.

"There is going to be all-out carnage when the crash comes."

Mr Hollands believes that investors should avoid technology funds in favour of more broadly-based UK equity funds, although many are now heavily weighted towards high-tech stocks. "Most of the funds are now loading up with technology, so a lot of existing investors may already have more technology investments than they realise."

He says that funds such as Gartmore UK Smaller Companies, Gartmore European Selected Opportunities and ABN Amro UK Growth as trusts have so much invested in high-tech stocks that they are effectively technology funds.

At investment brokers Chase de Vere, the financial advisers are more sanguine about the outlook for technology funds. "We still believe it can make a good investment if you are going to hold it over the longer term," says Janine Starks.

"It's common sense that if you already have a portfolio of Peps, then adding a technology fund is fine. But for first time investors it's probably best to stick to your knitting and buy a straightforward UK growth fund."

Mr Dampier says that a 25% correction on technology shares could well happen over the next few months - but that it shouldn't necessarily scare off investors. "Companies such as ARM and Psion are world class companies that are not going to go away. They may fall 25% or so but they are likely to come back. The market is definitely overheated, but you don't want to miss out on the long term story. The internet is not going to stop growing tomorrow."

For the cautious investor who still wants a piece of the technology action, Mr Dampier recommends looking at opening a technology fund savings scheme. Savings schemes for technology funds begin at around £50 per month and can be placed in an Isa.

webTitle: Egg has a basket to put your funds into

fields.headline: Egg has a basket to put your funds into
fields.standfirst:
As Prudential launches its online investment operation Patrick Sherwen looks at the prospects of yet another idea from the US

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: As Prudential launches its online investment operation Patrick Sherwen looks at the prospects of yet another idea from the US
fields.body:
No ribbon was cut and no minor member of the royal family attended but when Egg, the net-banking arm of Prudential, opened its online investment supermarket this week the effect was as dramatic as any gala event, particularly for its competitors.

The investment supermarket was originally an American idea.The biggest players over there are Fidelity and Charles Schwab, with first and second largest market share respectively and control of over 90% of the market. This side of the business alone is worth $176.8bn (£110bn) to Fidelity, which has just overtaken Schwab as market leader.

The principle of the investment supermarket is simple. Investors access a website which offers a broad range of mutual funds. These are available at a discount to the price the investor would pay if buying from an adviser or direct from the fund manager, which will usually charge the full initial charge - up to 5.25% - despite not providing advice. So far, it is hard to tell the difference between an investment or fund supermarket and a discount broker, and indeed, the two are very similar. But there are, in theory, two key points of contrast.

The first is that where a discount broker offers no advice at all, the supermarket does offer the investor limited guidance. Egg's version has a facility called the "investor profiler" which asks questions about the customer's financial circumstances to build a picture of their attitude to risk and the purpose of the investment. A basket of funds is then suggested on the basis of this picture. It is important that this should not be construed as advice - since that would require more severe regulation - so the recommendations are based on quite loose criteria.

Egg suggests a handful of funds based on fund sectors that appear to suit the investor's purposes. There is a fine line, however, between this type of service and the fund analysis service offered by many discount brokers. The only difference is that the brokers do not claim to make any recommendations, only to offer a view.

The other differentiator is that the supermarket allows investors to buy and sell within a single account to make it easier to track the value of all the holdings. Egg also provides something it calls the personal balance sheet, into which customers can enter all their financial details, including those held outside Egg. Elements of the customer's finances that Egg can get information on are updated automatically to create a consolidated record of all the customer's financial affairs.

Egg says the supermarket is designed to appeal to a broad church of relatively unsophisticated investors who are not comfortable with choosing investments from scratch but do not want to pay for advice. With a starting line-up of only 169 funds out of a universe of over 1,500 unit trusts and open ended-investment companies they certainly will not be bamboozled. Mike Harris, chief executive of Egg, says this is deliberate: "To have 169 funds covering all sectors is enough for most investors," he says.

Despite that, Egg does plan to add more to the range as time goes by, but there is a long way to go before it reaches the breadth of service offered by Fidelity in the US, which sells 4,100 funds. Of these 900 have no initial charge; these are known as "no load" funds which have not really taken off in the UK.

Another limitation on Egg's market is that until the new tax year, which starts on April 6, only Egg's 1m customers will be able to use it. After that date, it will be open to anyone who opens an Egg savings account.

Egg was not the only outfit to open a supermarket this week. Torquil Clark (TC), a Wolverhampton-based advisory broker, also joined the fray. TC's service offers access to 600 funds from 39 managers. TC's 35,000 personal equity plan (Pep) and Isa customers already use the site to track the £350m that is invested in their portfolios but is unlikely to be able to compete against Egg, which has a stronger brand and can draw on the deep pockets of the Pru to maintain a competitive edge.

The introductory offers are an illustration of this. Until April 27, visitors to the Egg supermarket will be able to claim a 1% cashback on any Isa investment. Where the Isa carries no initial charge - most do not - the investor stands to make an instant profit. There are also discounts that bring the initial charges down to a maximum of 1.5% and minimum of 0% - rather than a typical 3.5% to 5.25% - on other funds sold through the market. TC's offers comprise an ongoing £25 flat fee for Isa investments and discounts of up to 5.25%. These are good value, but do not have the instant appeal of the cashback offer.

In fact, the cashback offer has forced at least one other discount broker to revise its marketing strategy - an early indication of the sort of pressure Egg is likely to exert on the current players in the market. Allenbridge, the third largest discount broker in the UK, has traditionally offered a guarantee that its discounts are the lowest to be found. This was backed up by an offer to double the difference if anyone can find a better discount elsewhere.

Anthony Yadgaroff, managing director of Allenbridge, says since Egg made its cashback offer Allenbridge can no longer afford to maintain this guarantee. fields.headline: Blair anger at BMW tactics
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government last night traded blows with the German car giant BMW over the Rover sell-off as it emerged that up to 6,000 workers at Britain's biggest car plant could lose their jobs after its new owners unveiled drastic proposals to slash output.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire  and  Mark Milner in Munich
fields.body:
The government last night traded blows with the German car giant BMW over the Rover sell-off as it emerged that up to 6,000 workers at Britain's biggest car plant could lose their jobs after its new owners unveiled drastic proposals to slash output.

The scale of the losses prompted Tony Blair to telephone BMW's chief executive, Joachim Milberg, to express a "great deal of disappointment and anger" at the shock sale of the factory at Longbridge, Birmingham.

The plant will begin running down production from Monday, with shifts being reduced at a cost to workers of about £80 per month. Dozens of BMW managers have already been pulled out.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, who yesterday visited Longbridge, announced £152m state aid to regenerate the West Midlands, suggesting the government fears the worst. A task force, which will have its first meeting today, would advise workers and businesses affected by the sale, he added, and would report to him about the impact on the local economy within six weeks.

Dismayed union leaders last night predicted nearly three-quarters of the 8,500-strong Rover workforce would be axed.

BMW yesterday continued its surprise reverse out of UK motor manufacturing when it confirmed the sale of its successful Land Rover complex in Solihull to Ford for £1.85bn.

Downing Street made it clear that the prime minister was furious that Britain had been kept in the dark about BMW's sell-off plans.

Ministers are angry that German officials were discussing the sell-off of Rover while they were negotiating with the European Commission in Brussels for a £152m aid package for Longbridge.

"That is not the way the prime minister believes people should do business," a Downing Street spokesman said.

The German company blamed the strong pound for its decision to shed Longbridge and refused to accept the blame for loss-making Rover's problems. "We reached the limit that we could tolerate," a spokesman said.

Prof Milberg said the high value of sterling made "an already very difficult situation even worse", as he reopened the row over Britain's membership of the euro.

Government claims that it was unaware the high pound was fuelling a BMW rethink were undermined by Michael Heseltine, who disclosed that a director had warned him over dinner last month.

"The government cannot begin to suggest that BMW weren't concerned about this," said the Tory former deputy prime minister and industry secretary. "The guy I spoke to made no secret of it."

John Moulton, the head of Alchemy Partners, which set up the MG Car Company to take over Longbridge, made clear it will concentrate on sports cars in the future, with new Lotus-style models, including a sporty saloon.

Production will be around 40,000 in five years and peak on the most optimistic forecasts at under 100,000, compared to the current 180,000 vehicles-a-year output.

Longbridge is carrying five months stock of the Rover 25 and 45 cars and the models will not be replaced. Mr Moulton accepted selling them would be difficult.

"There are two groups of workers at Longbridge. There are people who will lose their jobs, which we bitterly regret but that it is inevitable," he said. "There is another group of workers who will have greater opportunities and they will not be staring over their shoulders fearing redundancy."

Mr Byers said Alchemy was not a "done deal" and suggested a new buyer could be found. "I think people would be more confident if someone with an established reputation took over Longbridge. We will find out more in the next few weeks," he said.

After his plant visit, Mr Byers said: "I walked on the track at Longbridge and spoke to a number of men who've worked there for decades ... We mustn't turn our backs on those people. They deserve the full backing at this time and they will get it. I understand the anger that they feel."

Ford, the new owner of the Land Rover range, is unlikely to reduce radically the 10,000-strong Solihull workforce.

fields.headline: Bank review 'explosive'
fields.standfirst: Cruickshank to attack profiteering and break monopolies that stifle entrepreneurs
fields.trailText: The man heading the government's banking review is expected to unleash a harsh attack on the industry next week and recommend that some practices be referred to the competition commission for anti-competitive behaviour.
fields.body:
The man heading the government's banking review is expected to unleash a harsh attack on the industry next week and recommend that some practices be referred to the competition commission for anti-competitive behaviour.

Don Cruickshank, appointed in November 1998, is expected to accuse high street banks of making excessive profits and to propose a series of measures to break the monopolies operating in the smaller business banking market and the clearing system for cheques.

Government sources say the report - to be published on Monday - will be "explosive". Sixteen months in the making, the report could have a dramatic impact on the banks' share prices, which have taken a pounding in recent months.

Mr Cruickshank is also expected to announce moves to make it easier for customers to move their bank accounts, and is set to fuel the already highly charged row over cash machine fees by giving some degree of support to the concept of surcharges for people who use the machines at banks where they are not customers.

Members of the Link cash machine network prompted an outcry last month when they backed moves to introduce surcharges for non-customers who use their machines. They later agreed to ban double charging, whereby people using other banks' machines face both a "disloyalty charge" from their own bank and a surcharge from the one that owns the machine.

Mr Cruickshank has already said customers should have to pay no more than 30p. His report is expected to say there is a definite cost to providing cash via an automatic teller machine (ATM), and it is unreasonable to expect this to be free all the time. Crucially, it is likely to say that if it is a choice between a surcharge and a disloyalty fee, a surcharge would be better. This would put him at loggerheads with several leading high street institutions which are opposed to any charges whatsoever, and also the office of fair trading, which believes surcharging is inherently wrong.

The review was set up by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to look into competition and innovation in the industry. Some banking sources say it is possible the chancellor could take immediate action on some of the recommendations in the budget on Tuesday.

There have been mixed messages about the report. Some bankers claimed to have been told that rather than attacking the sector it would present a picture of a competitive and innovative industry.

One source said: "I would not put it past him to surprise us. I think he would like to surprise people if he can."

An area where Mr Cruickshank might say further investigation is needed into potentially uncompetitive behaviour is in the provision of services to smaller firms, a market dominated by the big clearing banks, particularly NatWest.

Another is the system for transmitting money around the system. Mr Cruickshank believes the Association for Payment Clearing Services, which runs Bacs, the body responsible for transferring payments in and out of bank accounts, operates as a monopoly.

One industry source said he suspected Mr Cruickshank "would have something to say about competition. He has already tried one attack and that seems to have not quite hit the mark." Mr Cruickshank last year proposed that the FSA, the City watchdog, should be given a separate competition objective, a suggestion Mr Brown has not yet embraced.

webTitle: How is he going to spend our money?

fields.headline: How is he going to spend our money?
fields.standfirst: What rabbits will chancellor Gordon Brown produce from his hat on Tuesday afternoon? Patrick Collinson consults his fiscal crystal ball
fields.trailText: The Daily Mirror's Budget headline was "Flash Gordon", while the Daily Express shouted "Everyone a winner", and even the usually hostile Daily Mail hailed the chancellor as "Moneybags". Will the headlines this year greet an "e-conomy" Budget, or slam a steep rise in property taxes?
fields.body:
The Daily Mirror's Budget headline was "Flash Gordon", while the Daily Express shouted "Everyone a winner", and even the usually hostile Daily Mail hailed the chancellor as "Moneybags". Will the headlines this year greet an "e-conomy" Budget, or slam a steep rise in property taxes?

Swingeing increases in stamp duty on property is the favourite prediction for this Tuesday. The government is in the middle of its first term, its coffers are full, but no-one expects a giveaway Budget. Gordon Brown will win plaudits from the City for not loosening the purse strings when economic growth is, if anything, too vigorous, and will win support from his party for keeping his powder dry ahead of a probable pre-election Budget next year.

"I don't see Gordon Brown spraying the money around. Tax revenues are healthy, there's a lot in the pipeline already, and I don't expect a further raft of major changes," says PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC) partner John Whiting, one of the leading tax experts in the UK.

Nonetheless, pulling a rabbit out of the hat at the end of his speech is now a Budget day tradition, and as our guide below shows, the pundits are speculating about significant reforms to property and personal taxes. What's more, staged changes announced in last year's Budget, such as removing the married couple's allowance and Miras, will hit taxpayers hard over the next tax year.

Inside the chancellor's Red Box?

Stamp duty on houses

A hike in stamp duty on expensive houses is seen as a neat way to take the froth out of the property market without having to increase interest rates, which hurts manufacturing. But the increase could be painful for anyone with a house in London and the south-east. Someone buying a home for £250,000 already faces a stamp duty bill of £6,250 (up from £5,000 last year), and if the rate rises from 2.5% to 3.5% the bill would be £8,750.

It's worse for houses worth £500,000 or more. The rate went up last year from 3% to 3.5%, taking the bill from a minimum of £15,000 to £17,500. This year it could hit 5%, giving the rich home buyer a bill of £25,000.

Last year the standard 1% on houses valued between £60,000 and £250,000 did not move, nor was the zero rate on houses below £60,000 changed. Few expect the chancellor to hit the struggling first-time buyer, but an increase in the other bands will be widely regarded as a "tax on the south".

Property consultants argue that a rise could have an impact the reverse of that intended. CKD Kennedy Macpherson, a consultancy that specialises in country houses and estates, says: "The chancellor may increase stamp duty in an attempt to cool the market in the south east. But by putting up the cost of selling, it will reduce the number of these properties for sale, and as a result, prices will rise."

But the argument may fall on deaf ears. Even if the chancellor raised stamp duty to 7%, it would still be the lowest in any EU country.

Betting duty reform

The £1.5bn the government picks up from the 9% levy on betting is leaking away badly with the exodus of punters to offshore (but on-line) bookies operating from Alderney to Australia. The Inland Revenue is not happy. "A certain amount of tightening up is almost inevitable," says PWC's Mr Whiting.

The flow overseas could be staunched by a cut in the levy, but noises from the Treasury are not encouraging.

What the government does will be a test of how it handles the huge threat to its tax base from the shift of commerce into cyberspace. Already thousands of people are importing CDs from abroad via internet sites, and evading Customs & Excise in the process.

When new MP3 technology becomes widespread, allowing net users to download music and videos directly from the web, the loss to the Revenue could become substantial.

Lower tax burden on internet start-ups

A peculiarity of the phenomenal leap in dot.com share prices is that the balance sheets of these young start-ups are creaking under the cost of reserving for share option schemes. Mr Whiting says: "It's becoming a major issue; some net companies are already technically insolvent because of it."

At issue is the 12.2% national insurance levied on the gain on options. When a share option of £1 doubles from its issue price to £2, the employer has to put aside 12.2p to pay NI. But if it goes from £1 to £20, in the style of many dot.coms, the reserve has to be £2.32. Even for small companies the bill can be enormous. Expectations are that the chancellor will don an e-commerce hat and either cap employers' NI liability or allow companies to pass the cost on to employees.

Separately, new rules on all-employee share schemes will be included in the finance bill, effectively replacing approved profit sharing schemes. It will allow companies to give small amounts of free shares to individuals and give other shares as part of a targeted bonus scheme. A spokesman for Arthur Andersen says: "We expect a huge great rush as companies try to implement it and we understand that the shares schemes unit does not have enough people to cope with the expected deluge in August."

Insurance premium tax

This tax on car, home and medical insurance went up from 4% to 5% in the last Budget and earned the chancellor a relatively painless £290m last year. The tax adds around £15 to the annual cost of a car insurance policy, but is still low in comparison with rates levied on the continent. "IPT is a soft target. In Europe it is around 10%, so we could see another rise here," says Mr Whiting.

Taxes on petrol will almost certainly increase, but with the price of unleaded petrol already up to around 80p a litre compared to 68p at last year's Budget, the chancellor's room for manoeuvre will be limited. The increase in duty last year was 3.79p a litre.

Changes to company car taxation were unveiled in the last Budget and will be phased in after April 2002.

Capital gains tax

The rate of capital gains tax for individuals selling business assets is going to come down to 10% after five years - originally it was 10 years. More details on "taper relief" will come out in the Budget, and some experts are predicting that the taper will be extended to include any shares held through an employer's scheme. Tax accountants also want a simplification of the rules.

There is some talk of applying CGT to gains made on house sales, but this is widely regarded as political suicide. The current exemption on CGT for individuals is £7,100 and this is likely to be raised by a small amount. More important to the wave of new amateur stock market investors is the 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases. The City wants the duty to be abolished, but the doubling in share dealing volumes since November last year has netted the Treasury a bumper dividend running to almost £3bn. Abolition would also pave the way for a sharp increase in "day trading" at a time when the authorities are increasingly nervous about the bubble in net stocks.

Inheritance tax

Widespread (and legal) avoidance of this tax by the rich has made this a levy on middle-class homeowners rather than on big estates. "There is a realisation that it is hitting the wrong people and we are expecting a revamp. But we don't expect fundamental change." The current rate is 40% on everything over £231,000. Changes could come in the gifts regime which allows assets to escape death duty if they are transferred seven years before death.

Income tax

There is already a 1p reduction in income tax in hand to 22p from 23p starting on April 5. Almost no one expects a further cut, although personal allowances, currently a basic £4,335 plus extra for married couples, are likely to be uprated in line with inflation or average earnings. And he may widen the 10p tax band by more than inflation.

However, Mr Whiting says here lies the potential for the rabbit in the hat. "It's not inconceiveable that the chancellor will reverse the 1p tax cut and say that the money saved will be spent on the health service instead." Even more daring will be if the Chancellor ditches the National Insurance contributions scheme altogether and merges it with income tax. But that would result in a basic rate of income tax of around 32p.

Pensions

The Chancellor could axe the 40% higher-rate tax relief on pension contributions, reducing it to the new 22% basic rate, but with the government keen to launch stakeholder pensions from April 2001 it is unlikely to want to upset the pension tax regime too much. Instead he may use the opportunity to announce measures to ease the strict annuity rules, or play with the 25% tax-free lump sum on personal pensions.

ISAs

The chancellor will hail individual savings accounts, initially derided as impossibly complex, as an unalloyed success. As a "thank you" to its supporters, he may well extend the £7,000 first-year investment limit, due to come down to £5,000 in 2000/01, for a further year.
