The Inland Revenue is not happy. "A certain amount of tightening up is almost inevitable," says PWC's Mr Whiting. The flow overseas could be staunched by a cut in the levy, but noises from the Treasury are not encouraging. What the government does will be a test of how it handles the huge threat to its tax base from the shift of commerce into cyberspace. Already thousands of people are importing CDs from abroad via internet sites, and evading Customs & Excise in the process. When new MP3 technology becomes widespread, allowing net users to download music and videos directly from the web, the loss to the Revenue could become substantial. Lower tax burden on internet start-ups A peculiarity of the phenomenal leap in dot.com share prices is that the balance sheets of these young start-ups are creaking under the cost of reserving for share option schemes. Mr Whiting says: "It's becoming a major issue; some net companies are already technically insolvent because of it." At issue is the 12.2% national insurance levied on the gain on options. When a share option of £1 doubles from its issue price to £2, the employer has to put aside 12.2p to pay NI. But if it goes from £1 to £20, in the style of many dot.coms, the reserve has to be £2.32. Even for small companies the bill can be enormous. Expectations are that the chancellor will don an e-commerce hat and either cap employers' NI liability or allow companies to pass the cost on to employees. Separately, new rules on all-employee share schemes will be included in the finance bill, effectively replacing approved profit sharing schemes. It will allow companies to give small amounts of free shares to individuals and give other shares as part of a targeted bonus scheme. A spokesman for Arthur Andersen says: "We expect a huge great rush as companies try to implement it and we understand that the shares schemes unit does not have enough people to cope with the expected deluge in August." Insurance premium tax This tax on car, home and medical insurance went up from 4% to 5% in the last Budget and earned the chancellor a relatively painless £290m last year. The tax adds around £15 to the annual cost of a car insurance policy, but is still low in comparison with rates levied on the continent. "IPT is a soft target. In Europe it is around 10%, so we could see another rise here," says Mr Whiting. Taxes on petrol will almost certainly increase, but with the price of unleaded petrol already up to around 80p a litre compared to 68p at last year's Budget, the chancellor's room for manoeuvre will be limited. The increase in duty last year was 3.79p a litre. Changes to company car taxation were unveiled in the last Budget and will be phased in after April 2002. Capital gains tax The rate of capital gains tax for individuals selling business assets is going to come down to 10% after five years - originally it was 10 years. More details on "taper relief" will come out in the Budget, and some experts are predicting that the taper will be extended to include any shares held through an employer's scheme. Tax accountants also want a simplification of the rules. There is some talk of applying CGT to gains made on house sales, but this is widely regarded as political suicide. The current exemption on CGT for individuals is £7,100 and this is likely to be raised by a small amount. More important to the wave of new amateur stock market investors is the 0.5% stamp duty on share purchases. The City wants the duty to be abolished, but the doubling in share dealing volumes since November last year has netted the Treasury a bumper dividend running to almost £3bn. Abolition would also pave the way for a sharp increase in "day trading" at a time when the authorities are increasingly nervous about the bubble in net stocks. Inheritance tax Widespread (and legal) avoidance of this tax by the rich has made this a levy on middle-class homeowners rather than on big estates. "There is a realisation that it is hitting the wrong people and we are expecting a revamp. But we don't expect fundamental change." The current rate is 40% on everything over £231,000. Changes could come in the gifts regime which allows assets to escape death duty if they are transferred seven years before death. Income tax There is already a 1p reduction in income tax in hand to 22p from 23p starting on April 5. Almost no one expects a further cut, although personal allowances, currently a basic £4,335 plus extra for married couples, are likely to be uprated in line with inflation or average earnings. And he may widen the 10p tax band by more than inflation. However, Mr Whiting says here lies the potential for the rabbit in the hat. "It's not inconceiveable that the chancellor will reverse the 1p tax cut and say that the money saved will be spent on the health service instead." Even more daring will be if the Chancellor ditches the National Insurance contributions scheme altogether and merges it with income tax. But that would result in a basic rate of income tax of around 32p. Pensions The Chancellor could axe the 40% higher-rate tax relief on pension contributions, reducing it to the new 22% basic rate, but with the government keen to launch stakeholder pensions from April 2001 it is unlikely to want to upset the pension tax regime too much. Instead he may use the opportunity to announce measures to ease the strict annuity rules, or play with the 25% tax-free lump sum on personal pensions. ISAs The chancellor will hail individual savings accounts, initially derided as impossibly complex, as an unalloyed success. As a "thank you" to its supporters, he may well extend the £7,000 first-year investment limit, due to come down to £5,000 in 2000/01, for a further year.

fields.headline: Amnesty ahead?
fields.standfirst:
Patrick Sherwen offers a ray of hope for those daunted by the Revenue's dense documents

Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: People do not want to pay tax: not exactly a revelation. The tax system is hard to understand: again not really shock news. The Inland Revenue is sympathetic to tax payers' problems and plans to make life easier for them: now that is a surprise. The government admits it has raised taxes: that really is stretching the imagination. Or perhaps not.
fields.body:
People do not want to pay tax: not exactly a revelation. The tax system is hard to understand: again not really shock news. The Inland Revenue is sympathetic to tax payers' problems and plans to make life easier for them: now that is a surprise. The government admits it has raised taxes: that really is stretching the imagination. Or perhaps not.

March is always a frenetic period in the financial calendar as the tax year comes to a close and the week before the budget is particularly fraught, but the week just passed was an extraordinary one for tax, even by those standards. Accountants and financiers of every colour rush about worrying about what the chancellor is going to instruct the Inland Revenue to do to them or their clients.

This year things are slightly different. The government has admitted that is has been increasing our tax bills and it is the Revenue staff who seem to be in a panic as they fumble about under a truck-load of late self-assessment forms that have jammed the system.

The good news for tax payers is that the tax faculty of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW), the largest professional accountancy body in Europe with more than 116,000 members, says it is all the Revenue's fault. Roughly 730,000 people failed to get their forms back in on time this year - one extra failure for everyone who missed the deadline last year and 350,000 of those still have not handed in a return for 1997-98.

All those whose forms arrived after January 31 are liable for £100 fines for their transgression, but the ICAEW says they should not be blamed since they are simply reacting in a natural way to an over complicated tax system that gets worse by the year. In an open letter to members of parliament published this week, the institute says: "When it's no longer possible for reasonably intelligent people to understand the basis of their tax liabilities, it's only a short step to their questioning their moral responsibility to comply. The nation cannot afford a rising spiral of tax avoidance, but we fear it's on the way unless urgent action is taken to prevent it."

What is the Revenue going to do about this impending disaster? One possibility is an amnesty for late tax payers to be announced in the Budget on Tuesday. Such an uncharacteristically generous gesture would actually be in the Revenue's best interests since it does not have enough staff or time to pursue all those who have not paid. There are 300 tax officers responsible for recovering the debt which works out at just over 2,433 cases each, some of which may go to the county courts. The idea of the amnesty is to offer an incentive to people to turn themselves in voluntarily in exchange for waiving the late return penalty.

For those who do not volunteer themselves, the late return penalty may be raised to £250, backed up by the introduction of other finable offences.

David Brodie, a tax consultant at TaxAid, says dropping the late return penalty is less generous than it seems. The Revenue will gain far more from the proportion of the 1.2m people who pay their late tax - on average £4,000 a person - than it loses from letting them off £100.

In spite of that, for those who could not get their forms to the Revenue in time, Tuesday might hold some good news.

fields.headline: How to break the bankers
fields.standfirst: Richard Colbey finds a penny-pinching plot to punish the men who are closing their branches while pushing up the charge for cash machines
fields.trailText: It really isn't the sort of thing a respectable newspaper (the Guardian, anyway) should be encouraging, but some might think "Penny Pincher day" a good wheeze.
fields.body:
It really isn't the sort of thing a respectable newspaper (the Guardian, anyway) should be encouraging, but some might think "Penny Pincher day" a good wheeze.

On 3 April Steve Syder, a computer consultant who dislikes banks even more than the rest of us, urges everybody to write five cheques for 1p each. At the very least the cost of processing these cheques, about 40 pence a time, will make a tiny dent in bank profits. Syder's claim "we can make a massive difference to banking in Britain", is an overstatement, but if enough people do it, banks will be subject to a satisfying degree of chaos.

Syder's venom is largely inspired by the banks' efforts to raise cash machine charges. This attempt to add a few more millions to their profits could seem particularly inopportune, as the growth of these machines was their favourite excuse for closing the branches, which they now want to penalise customers for not being able to use.

Penny Pinchers has the attraction of simplicity, but there are more effective ways of annoying banks. Like most large organisations, banks have streamlined procedures to keep down administration costs. These rely on customers' willingness to do their work for them.

Every time, for instance, a customer writes their account number, the bank saves a few pennies. Customers are asked to do that when posting credit card payments. Although the counterfoil identifies the account, banks like the number to be written on the back of the cheque in case the two come adrift when the envelope is opened. Stapling them is not approved of as someone then has to spend time separating them. Change of address forms on the back of card statements even ask the customer to copy out the account number - the same number that appears on the other side of that form, to save a bank clerk the trouble.

Don't do it. If the bank ends up crediting the cheque to the wrong account, that is the bank's problem not the customer's. The payment has been made and the bank is not entitled to interest.

A few pennies can also be pinched by not putting a stamp on credit card payments. The banks all provide freepost services when trying to persuade customers to apply for overpriced loans and other profitable "financial services", and they may not distinguish responses to these from mere payments when post arrives. In any case, turning away cheques would cause massive correspondence, which would reduce profits by even more than paying the 26p excess postage.

Such matters, unlike Penny Pincher day, do have slight advantages for the customers, but those twisted types who want to be gratuitously annoying should remember the one thing banks hate is small amounts of cash through the post.

Forms have to be filled in and countersigned, complex security procedures involving several members of staff have to be gone through. If everybody were to put a single coin in with every credit card payment they made that would have a serious impact.

Worse still, if the payment is sent to a head office rather than a processing centre, then someone will have to spend ages looking for the security forms. Marking the envelope "private and confidential for the attention of the chief executive only", is likely to mean someone in the CE's office has to do that. Addressing it by name in a pink envelope with cute pictures or hearts drawn on the outside and a slight whiff of perfume may mean the CE gets to open it personally.

This could then result in someone who thinks they are worth £500,000 per year spending 15 minutes scratching around on the floor trying to gather up a pile of two pence coins. After all, if any of the coins are lost, a whole day's form filling in will be necessary.

Other action, which the net-based Penny Pinchers is lining up, include a Call the Head Office Day, when customers will be encouraged to ring their bank's head office to give their views on the proposed cash machine charges, and a Bank Managers Day which it hopes will encourage disillusioned bosses to leave messages on its website in support of the campaign.

Of course, doing any of those things, like Penny Pincher day itself, is terribly immature. What we should be doing is believing the banks when they tell us that their charges are entirely fair, indeed are levied for our benefit, and that only the most unreasonable customers could think there is anything to protest about.

Penny Pinchers: www.smos.net

webTitle: What to look for if you go ethical

fields.headline: What to look for if you go ethical
fields.standfirst: Clare Short's call for pension funds to place more money in developing countries is part of the growing clamour for investment based on beliefs. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Clare Short's call for pension funds to place more money in developing countries is part of the growing clamour for investment based on beliefs. Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
Government minister Clare Short this week flew the flag for ethical investment when she called on pension funds to invest more of their money in developing countries. The international development secretary said UK pension funds, which look after billions of pounds of people's retirement cash, could make a real difference in helping to reduce poverty in the world's poorest countries.

Speaking at a pensions industry conference in Eastbourne, she highlighted the fact that growing numbers of people are looking for their money to be invested in a more socially responsible way.

Hardly a month seems to go by without the launch of another new investment product aimed at people who want to put their money where their beliefs are. There are now well over 40 ethical unit and investment trusts, the majority of which are available as individual savings accounts (ISAs). Recent entrants to the market include Legal & General and Norwich Union.

There is now more than £2bn invested in ethical unit trusts alone - up 35% on a year ago, according to Co-operative Insurance Society (CIS), which runs the £165m Environ unit trust.

Broadly speaking, there are two types of ethical fund. There are those that take a very strict line on a range of issues such as animal testing, pollution and pornography, and won't invest in companies that have anything to do with such activities. And then there are the "light green" funds, which tend to adopt a "best of sector" approach - they will invest in companies in the more controversial sectors such as banking, oil and pharmaceuticals, but will seek out those that are doing some thing positive to improve the environment or that have a good record on workplace practices or community involvement.

Most of the newer funds that have come along have tended to fall into the latter category, says Amanda Davidson at Holden Meehan, an independent financial adviser specialising in ethical investment (www.holden-meehan.co.uk). This probably reflects the fact that most people like the idea of a light green approach.

So which ethical funds are delivering the best returns? The latest monthly figures for ethical unit trusts issued by CIS put Framlington Health firmly ahead of the pack over both one and five years. A sum of £1,000 invested in this fund in March 1995 would have grown to £4,959 today. But, Framlington Health isn't really an ethical fund and has never des- cribed itself as one - it appears in the lists of ethical funds because it invests in the healthcare sector, which includes hospitals and nursing home companies.

But it makes no secret of the fact that many of the drug companies it invests in carry out testing on animals.

If all that sounds confusing, welcome to the wonderful world of ethical investment. The example above illustrates that you really need to do your homework so you know exactly where your money will and won't be going.

After Framlington Health, the next best performing unit trust over five years is Lloyds TSB Environmental Investor, which has turned £1,000 into £3,410 over five years.

The Ethical Investment Research Service (www.eiris.org) will send you a free information pack or a free list of IFAs who advise on ethical investment - call 0845 606 0324.

webTitle: Why you should go back to basics

fields.headline: Why you should go back to basics
fields.standfirst: New technology is driving the new share boom, but there should be a place in any portfolio for the old industries, argues Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: New technology is driving the new share boom, but there should be a place in any portfolio for the old industries, argues Robin Stoddart
fields.body:
Established companies, earning profits and paying dividends, must be the main vehicle for investors who do not expect to live forever.

The inflation and deflation of communications companies this week accompanied more news of the dire straits of some of the oldest manufacturers and the likelihood of heavy job cuts.

Although the economy has grown on the back of the mobile phone boom and sharply higher oil price, product development and invention in both manufacturing and services must play the leading role.

More mergers in nearly all high technology and services sectors are highly probable and most will be dominated by the Americans, Japanese, and Scandinavians.

The future for British components subcontractors is distinctly mixed, particularly at anywhere near the current exchange value of sterling, relative to the euro. It should certainly be brighter in mobile phones than in motor components. As Italy's giant, Fiat, moves under the wing of General Motors, the world's biggest company not long ago, the position of smaller UK manufacturers making vehicles for the wrong side of the road is unpromising.

It may just be that national economies no longer follow the trend set by their motor industries as communications, health and financial services leave older industries like farming and seafaring, as well as private transport, way behind. But balance is still important and a good spread is the main safeguard in investment.

The sacrifice of growth in seeking a high income has been particularly marked over the past year, though over three years or more strong growth has been achieved thanks to the progress of BP, BT and Glaxo, whose shares offered good returns until they embarked on acquisitions that relied on upgradings and cost savings rather than dividend increases. Yields of more than 3% on equity income funds now reflect a low growth performance.

Also most of the better-performing funds, including Dresdner and Henderson are medium sized, while Gartmore UK Growth & Income units, although managing more than £200m do not, as the name indicates, concentrate on income to the exclusion of growth, so the yield is under 3%. Perpetual, with more than 10 times as much under management, returns 4%, but, as with Jupiter's large fund, performance has tailed off over the last couple of years. Over three years, the total return from the top UK income funds is around 50% and over five well over 100%.

Although some companies that should be capable of renewed growth as the recovery in the industrialised world extends to all continents offer high yields, for example ICI and others in the chemicals section, fears of competition, expensive takeovers and never-ending special charges keep most of them at a discount. Burmah Castrol, with its strong brand and specialities is now being swallowed by BP, removing another share with a fairly high yield.

Similar returns have accrued from the better performers in investment trusts concentrating on the UK and higher yielding shares. Deutsche Equity Income, formerly under Morgan Grenfell's name, remains a top performer, despite a few poor months, thanks to oil and other blue-chip holdings. GT Income Growth has just overtaken it.

Its appreciation of 14% over a year exceeds all except the new ABN Amro Income unit trust fund which had a flying start in some high-yielding smaller company shares.

Lowland, once a top performer, thanks largely to its stake in Henderson, the management company subsequently bought by AMP of Australia, is now pedestrian with negligible growth over the last year.

But the shares yield nearly 4%, helped by a 17% discount on asset value. Holdings in general industrials and utili ties became poor performers after producing a high income.

By switching categories to UK General trusts investors would have achieved a much better performance in 1999. Govett Strategic has achieved outstanding growth most years, thanks to the selection of software companies at an early stage and large stakes in outsourcing service companies, notably Capita and Serco.

JD Wetherspoon, the no-music pubs group, was another sparkling winner. The fund has passed the £0.5bn mark, up 40% in a year.

But Finsbury Trust's strength in special situations, has enabled it to take the lead with similar growth in six months under the ownership of Close Bros, the sole remaining independent investment bank.

Burmah Castrol, with its strong brand and specialities is now being swallowed by BP, removing another share with a fairly high yield. Similar returns have accrued from the better performers in investment trusts concentrating on the UK and higher yielding shares. Deutsche Equity Income, formerly under Morgan Grenfell's name, remains a top performer, despite a few poor months, thanks to oil and other blue-chip holdings. GT Income Growth has just overtaken it. Its appreciation of 14% over a year exceeds all except the new ABN Amro Income unit trust fund which had a flying start in some high-yielding smaller company shares. Lowland, once a top performer, thanks largely to its stake in Henderson, the management company subsequently bought by AMP of Australia, is now pedestrian with negligible growth over the last year. But the shares yield nearly 4%, helped by a 17% discount on asset value. Holdings in general industrials and utili ties became poor performers after producing a high income. By switching categories to UK General trusts investors would have achieved a much better performance in 1999. Govett Strategic has achieved outstanding growth most years, thanks to the selection of software companies at an early stage and large stakes in outsourcing service companies, notably Capita and Serco. JD Wetherspoon, the no-music pubs group, was another sparkling winner. The fund has passed the £0.5bn mark, up 40% in a year. But Finsbury Trust's strength in special situations, has enabled it to take the lead with similar growth in six months under the ownership of Close Bros, the sole remaining independent investment bank.

webTitle: Too little, too late on Serps

fields.headline: Too little, too late on Serps
fields.standfirst: For decades the DSS gave out misleading information on Serps which could halve the amount bereaved relatives receive. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: For decades the DSS gave out misleading information on Serps which could halve the amount bereaved relatives receive. Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
Many thousands of elderly people face an anxious wait to see if they are eligible for compensation after the government this week announced measures to tackle what's been dubbed "the Serps mis-selling scandal".

Ministers said they would be taking action to protect people who faced losing out as a result of being given poor advice about the state earnings-related pension scheme by the department of social security.

For more than a decade the DSS gave out incorrect information about a rule change that will halve the amount of Serps pension that widows and widowers can inherit when their spouse dies. Thousands of people have made the wrong decisions as a result of relying on this.

However, the solution proposed by the government was condemned as "disgraceful" by Help the Aged because it appears that to stand a chance of getting compensation people will have not only prove they were misinformed, they will also have to demonstrate they acted on this wrong information.

The government has declined to spell out exactly how the compensation scheme will work. It says that more details will be given next year., In the meantime it has set up a helpline on 0845-600-6116.

So how did this scandal come about? A widow or widower is able to claim his/her spouse's entire Serps pension entitlement if they die after reaching pensionable age. But 14 years ago the rules were amended so that from April 6 2000, widows and widowers would only be entitled to 50% of Serps.

For 10 years until 1996, leaflets were issued that made no mention of the change. And as late as April 1999, people contacting the DSS about their pension enti tlement were still being given wrong information. Some of these people would undoubtedly have made additional arrangements had they known that their surviving spouses would not be receiving the full amount of Serps.

In an attempt to put right this colossal blunder, social security secretary Alistair Darling said the cut in Serps planned for next month was now being put back to October 2002.

He added that a scheme is to be introduced that will ensure some people keep the right to pass on to the husband or wife all their Serps pension in the event of their death after this date. But to be eligible you will have to show that you were given wrong information and that you made financial decisions based on this.

Help the Aged describes this as "clear as mud," adding: "It seems that only those who have written to the DSS and received inadequate information will have grounds to complain." It's not clear what happens if you didn't keep the letters or you dealt with the DSS over the phone and therefore have nothing in writing.

Age Concern's advice is:

 Ring the helpline. The DSS is already taking names and addresses of those who may be affected.

 Start gathering your "evidence" - if you have any letters that were sent to you, keep hold of them. Did you speak to someone on the phone? Have you kept a record of the conversation? It's still not too late to write down that conversation now, says the charity.

 If you've got paperwork that shows you made financial decisions based on your understanding of the rules, all the better. Have you changed the terms of your occupational pension? If so, have you got any letters from the scheme to back up your claim that you'd have acted differently had you known about the rule change?

The charity gives the real-life example of "Mr W," 75, who opted for a lower level of widow's benefit on his company pension because he assumed his wife would receive the full Serps entitlement. However, the amount she gets could be halved from £3,150 to £1,575 a year if he dies after October 2002 unless he can prove he was misadvised.

Mr W never phoned or wrote to the DSS, or consulted a leaflet to check on his rights - he simply trusted in the system to deliver what it has originally promised him, and never received anything saying the rules were changing.

fields.headline: Moil and madness
fields.standfirst:
Speed-the-Plow
New Ambassadors, London WC2
***
fields.trailText: Speed the "plow" is an ancient English expression, a blessing upon those setting out to do an honest day's toil and harvesting the wheat necessary to sustain life. In David Mamet's 1988 satire, Bob Gould, newly promoted head of production at a big Hollywood studio, cheerfully admits that in 11 years in the film business he has never done a day's work. He and his wannabe producer friend, Charlie, know that it is the deal that counts. And if that's the case, then it doesn't matter if you turn out garbage.
fields.body:
Speed the "plow" is an ancient English expression, a blessing upon those setting out to do an honest day's toil and harvesting the wheat necessary to sustain life. In David Mamet's 1988 satire, Bob Gould, newly promoted head of production at a big Hollywood studio, cheerfully admits that in 11 years in the film business he has never done a day's work. He and his wannabe producer friend, Charlie, know that it is the deal that counts. And if that's the case, then it doesn't matter if you turn out garbage.

Then Karen, the temporary secretary assigned to Bob, comes up with a novel suggestion. Why don't they make a film that isn't complete drivel? Bob and Charlie are astonished. Business, they argue, just doesn't work like that. You give people what they want and what you gave them last year, and you don't try to give them what they need. But when a bet is laid between the two men that Bob can bed Karen, and as a ploy he gets her to report on a potential project, a change of heart might be in the air.

Mamet's great early plays such as Glengarry Glen Ross and American Buffalo cast a jaundiced eye over the American dream and charted its disintegration with the sourest of wisecracks. So who better to dissect the institution that peddles dreams to us all? But Mamet is the great illusionist himself, as much in love with the scam as Bob and Charlie, and the sassiness of the play disguises the fact that this is another empty Mamet fable in which the dice are all loaded. When it comes down to it, Mamet is never on the side of the angels; he's with the cynics.

For all their swagger, Bob and Charlie are as much innocents as Karen, and Mamet depicts all three as if they have been gripped by a kind of insanity. It is a pity that Peter Gill's production doesn't quite capture the intense, wired madness of the world they inhabit.

I'd rather see a play by Patrick Marber than one in which he stars, but as the desperate Charlie he has the rumpled, careworn look of a deranged teddy bear. Mark Strong as Bob offers all the confusion you'd expect of a man who has undergone two Pauline conversions in a day, and Kimberly Williams excels as Karen, brilliantly evoking the daisy-like persona of a woman who is like one of those religious pedlars who tries to sell you your own soul.

 Until April 22. Box office: 0171 836 6111

fields.headline: Expanding miniatures
fields.standfirst:
Nash Ensemble/ Martyn Brabbins
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.trailText: To mark Elliott Carter's 90th birthday in December 1998, the modern music journal Tempo asked a group of com posers to write brief celebrations, which were published as a supplement to the magazine. There were responses from Franco Donatoni, György Kurtág, Heinz Holliger, Pierre Boulez, Oliver Knussen, Steven Mackey and from Harrison Birtwistle, who offered a trio of settings for soprano and cello of poems by the American Lorine Niedecker. The work of this elusive poet, who died in 1970, clearly struck a chord with Birtwistle, who has gone on to expand the set; the Nine Settings of Lorine Niedecker was given a superbly accomplished premiere in the Nash Ensemble's concert on Thursday by the soprano Valdine Anderson and the cellist Paul Watkins.
fields.body:
To mark Elliott Carter's 90th birthday in December 1998, the modern music journal Tempo asked a group of com posers to write brief celebrations, which were published as a supplement to the magazine. There were responses from Franco Donatoni, György Kurtág, Heinz Holliger, Pierre Boulez, Oliver Knussen, Steven Mackey and from Harrison Birtwistle, who offered a trio of settings for soprano and cello of poems by the American Lorine Niedecker. The work of this elusive poet, who died in 1970, clearly struck a chord with Birtwistle, who has gone on to expand the set; the Nine Settings of Lorine Niedecker was given a superbly accomplished premiere in the Nash Ensemble's concert on Thursday by the soprano Valdine Anderson and the cellist Paul Watkins.

Introducing the performance, Birtwistle likened the little pieces to drawings, compared with the large canvases of his major works. The crystalline observations of the haiku-like poems inhabit tightly circumscribed worlds, and Birtwistle preserves the fragility of the images in spare, unadorned lines. The voice and the cello float around each other, often in different tempi, so that the two lines are independent of each other yet curiously symbiotic. There are no big gestures: the text is unfolded, the cello perhaps comments elliptically, perhaps supports subliminally, and the poem is over. The whole set lasts less than 10 minutes.

The Nash also performed a group of the Carter birthday tributes in their original miniaturised forms. They included the tiniest of musical paragraphs from Donatoni; a rhapsodic cello solo from Knussen containing enough musical ideas to spawn a much more substantial work; a noble, eloquent cor anglais solo from Kurtág; and an elegant tracery for oboe and harp from Holliger. There was also a piece by the recipient himself, the Enchanted Preludes for flute and cello, in which the two instruments take hair-raisingly demanding journeys across ever-changing musical terrain, superbly negotiated by Watkins and Philippa Davies.

Knussen's enchanted Songs Without Voices, four lyric impulses in which every note and colour glows, began the programme. Simon Holt's Sparrow Night, an evocation of a fearsome nocturnal vision taken from a Chekhov short story, ended it. The Purcell Room is a bit small for the acerbic collisions that Holt's writing generates, but the power of the music and the excellence of the performance under Martyn Brabbins came through powerfully enough.
